text: UPDATED: JUN 18, 2017 I really like this beer. Its aroma and overall taste lack a bit for me, but its palate of caramel malts blending into hop bitterness is impeccable. Its a great beer. Definitely a beer I hope to be sipping this coming winter.

Pours deep amber brown with cream head. Scent is caramel, coco, and bread. Taste is stone fruit, caramel, and nibs. A bit boozy. Overall a complex beer. I wouldn't choose to drink it often, but it would be good occasionally.

Bottle @ malt o humle. Pours dark amber with an off white head. Aroma is sweet and fruity with prunes, dates, deep caramel, toffee, vanilla hints, milk chocolate. Body is big. Carbonation is balanced to provide freshness. Taste of prunes, raisins, caramel, milk chocolate. Finish is quite dry with earthy notes, grape, chocolate and assertive bitterness.

Prunes and molasses in the aroma. Almost non-existent tan head and a murky orange/amber body. More prunes and molasses in the taste with butterscotch and caramel. All that sweetness is balanced by a nice earthy, mushroomy bitterness and a strong alcohol bite. Finishes warm, sweet and slightly spicy. I didnt especially like the first few sips, but this grew on me as I got further in.

Backlog. Bottle at home, bought at Mikkeller webshop. Dark red color, tanned head that disappears quickly. Sweet fruit, oak, sherry, plums in aroma and taste. Solid balance. Just a hint of booze in the finish to show character.

Piwo klarowne w kolorze ciemny bursztyn z niezbyt obfita drobnopecherzykowa piana. W aromacie karmel, toffee, miod, czerwone owoce i kwiaty. W smaku polslodkie z lekka goryczka i wysyceniem na srednim poziomie. W smaku rownie bogato jak w zapachu, alkohol lekko grzeje w gardlo. Podbudowa slodowa, geste i oleiste, bardzo fajne!

Packaged 08/31/16.
This was poured into a tulip.
The appearance was a ruddy burnt dark amber color with a two finger white foamy head that dissipated at a fair pace. Sticky speckled lace.
The aroma glistens with caramel and toffee malt, some ash and vanilla. Dark fruits. Grassiness. Sweet side of licorice. Earthiness.
The flavor definitely leans towards the sweet side touching the earthiness nicely. Dark fruits again. Some grassiness in the taste. Tobacco/earthy to vanilla and malty aftertaste. Wet vanilla sort of lenient tobacco dry finish.
On the palate, this one sat roughly at a a medium on the body keeping some sipping quality sliding over my tongue with a nice becoming smoothness. Barely any carbonation felt right now. ABV seems just a touch under than projected by the brewer.
Overall, cellared beer review for this one and it came out on top. Guess I pulled it out at the right time for a nice snowy cold New England night.

A little lighter in flavor and feel than many barleywines, but I like it. Deep red brown and cloudy. High head. Aroma of cherry, light hops, malts, sweet yeasts, and musty sugars. Taste is sweet and slight hops. Coats the whole tongue and sugars just sit in the mouth. Tap

This is a well done barley wine (old ale). Fresh bottle has aroma of dark carmel and strong flavors. Head fades but leaves a ring. Taste has a hop bite but not over powering. Carmel notes. Carmel hue. Basically a perfect style beer. Clean High abv, crisp thick nice!

Poured from a 12oz. bottle.

Paired with cheese fondue and oka & brie cheese.

Appearance: Dark brown, almost black body with a nice light brown head & cascade of bubbles heading down. Very nice.

Smell: Slightly bitter, dried fruit aroma.

Taste: Rich & full-bodied, smooth & creamy, more fruit (berries?) & slight bitterness

Mouthfeel: Alcohol is felt but very pleasant. Feels a bit like a Barleywine & as it warms, becomes sweet & malty at the end.

Reviewed on: 02-11-2008
What a wonderful.example of the brewing arts. Light cola color. Wish it had more head and lacing, but the flavor and balance are excellent. This beer is on tap at whole foods in wexford.
Bottle thanks to BenH! Pours deep burgundy red with no a modest white head which soon recedes. Aroma is dusty, caramel and earthy. Taste is caramel sweet, slight pine bitter, raisins.
355ml bottle. Pours hazy dark orange with a large head. Aroma is rich toffee, molasses and raisin. Taste has toffee and caramel. Raisin on the finish. Warming alcohol.

12oz bottle. Clear copper kettle color with tan head. Pit fruit, toast, caramel, cardboard, sherry aromas. Medium bodied. Toasted, sharp spicy caramel flavors with pit fruits, herbals---nicely bitter warming finish___good
user_location: Same Trailer, Different Park, Louisiana, USA

text: Aug 2016 bottled, reviewed in Dec 2016. Dark amber, somewhat cloudy, with a 1/2 inch tan head. Dark fruit and caramel somewhat weak aroma. Very smooth taste and feel. Taste follows the aroma, but is much more assertive, with dark fruit and caramel in the initial taste with a somewhat bitter finish that lingers for a short while. At 10.2%, the alcohol is noticeable, especially in the finish, but it is well controlled. This barleywine has a wonderful taste, but a somewhat subdued aroma. On balance, quite good.

Pours a dark amber color with a small off-white head. Malty caramel aroma with hints of dark fruit. Sweet malty hoppy bitter caramel flavor with some hints of dark fruit. Sweet malty warming finish with some hints of dark fruit.

Pours a light caramel color with tan foamy head and lots of lacing. Semi-sweet aroma with some earthy wood tones. Light syrupy body. Some sweet caramel toffee and woody flavors with a warm alcohol finish. Decent lingering aftertaste. OK but not great.

Bottle. Pours brown mahogny in color with an off-white head. Sweetness, dark ripe fruits, fudge and nice malty tones in aroma. Raisins and 

vinous notes later on, quite nice vibes here. Smooth moutfeel. Raisins and brandy in taste, some bitter notes too. Great, sweet but enough with 

bitters are present. Toffee, some late spicyness, vinous and malty notes in the warming finish. Really good.

12oz bottle to tulip. Pours deep mahogany, shirt beige head. Aroma of plum, brown sugar, raisin, black cherry, fresh cut hardwood, fresh bread. Taste of brown sugar, dark fruit, oak. The boozy finish is somewhat cough drop medicinal. Wish I wouldnt have tasted that...now its all I can think about. And I really like everything else about this ale.
mohogany color; sweet caramel malt aroma; rich, sweet, caramel malt flavor; sweetness is tempered by lots of piney hops; some dark fruit notes and warm alcohol notes; bitter finish
Its a good one. Definately will buy again. Nice cool pour. Clean taste and finish. Caramel and smoke vanilla woody soy sauce.

330ml bottle (Alus Celle, Riga)
Sweet malty aroma. Scary soapy taste. Harsh palate because of that soapy hopping. Alcohol not hidden at all, this is sweet and boozy. Palate is heavy and sweet, sticky and slick, and the hops are aggressive. Finish has a woody dry bitterness. Harsh, bitter and boozy.

330ml bottle (Alus Celle, Riga). Very dark brown color. Huge size, yellow head, stays. Looks nice. Malty, raisins, fruity, sweet, prunes in aroma. Sweet, hop tea, fruity, raisins, spicy in taste. Hop tea and sweet and prunes in aftertaste. Soft carbonation. Quite nice brew.
Bottle. Deep amber, moderate off-white head. Aroma of water melon, nectar, berries. Full bodied. Bittersweet taste. Nectary. Fruity. Vinous. Brandy. Nice.
Bottle. Amber color. Aroma: port wine, malt, nectar, floral, fine. Taste: malty, white port wine, brandy, candy and caramel, a little hop bitterness. Very good.
Bottle. Dark red color, tanned head. Nice aroma has malts, sweet fruits, sherry, oak notes. Nice sweet balanced body, sherry, oak, plums.
Dull light brown body, dried fruit on the aroma as well as hints of caramel, medium to full body with good length in the taste whilst not being overpowering, great drinking.

Bottle, bottled 10/10/2015 . Pours rather uncleardeep brownred. Ok White head smell is full, Rich barley wine maltyness. Taste is full, caramelly, Rich barley Wine maltyness. Bit clinical boozyness in the back. Not bad, but nothing amongst the top onesbin the style. Perhaps more time Will mellow it out ?

Bottled 2014 vintage. Pours sort of copper, amber color, white head. Aroma is toffee, fig, booze, dark fruit, vanilla, sort of plum-like, despite being called "old ale", very much a barleywine. Flavor is plum, fig, pine, some toffee, nice and pretty pronounced hop bitterness in the finish, not too boozy in the nose. Really nice mix of sweet dark fruits, and hop bitterness. Will def. be revisiting this one, for sure.

Bottle from Beer Gonzo shop, Earlsdon, Coventry consumed at Polderflora camp, Nr Alphen aan Den Rijn Saturday 24th September 2016.   This beer would win nothing in a beer beauty contest, grubby, dirty brown in colour with lots of stuff in suspension. This is a big beer, its strong with burnt sugar (molasses) and booziness and a smokiness the standout flavours. I have to say its doing very little for me, its ok but Im not that fussed. A6 A2 T6 P4 Ov12 3.0
Bottle at Home. Pours hazy brown with a white head. Aroma of hazelnuts, toffee, caramel, dried fruits, sidste skoledag flødekarameller. Taste is Extreme sweet with Nuts and toffee, slight grainy.

Bottled 2/15. Deep brown with a dense beige head that never gives up an laces well. Aroma of sweet fresh and dried fruit - greengages, golden raisins - butterscotch, Sherry, sweetshop spices, a curious bark note. Silky, lowish carbonation. Very sweet indeed, but plenty of bitterness with spices and woody notes at the end that make you think that 18 months is on the young side. Perhaps the fruity things will shine a little more then but I do quite like the firm bitterness as it is (some burnt notes at the end dont obviously fit). Boozy but not hot. Id probably like it more in a year or two.

Copper brown, with tracings of head. Aroma has dried fruit, overripe bananas, plums. Body is medium to full. Bit of booze burn. Flavour has maple syrup, burnt brown sugar, nuts, soy sauce, whisky and wood. Dark and moody.

Bottle from World Market. Very rich and sweet with a bit of a candy flavor to it. Very loaded with dark fruits. Lots of fig and some prune. Some toffee flavors as well. Alcohol is well hidden. A bit of a burnt roastiness in the finish. Low on the hops. Pretty nice sipper. Good for the winter.

From the bottle, it pours hazy and dark amber in color, the head is cream colored amd dissipates but leaves a this head remaining on the beer. The aroma is malts, carmel and a hint of alcohol in the back of the nose. The taste is cream, caramel and malts. There is an alcohol bite but not overpowering but none the less present. The finish is malty with a little alcohol warmth. The mouthfeel is medium to thick, but not as thick as a heavy stout. Overall a great strong ale with a few flavors making this a great slow sipping beer.

33cl bottle via Beer Gonzo. It pours a clean caramel color with a large khaki pillowy head. Aroma is sweet and musty with notes of raisins, caramel, toffee, vanilla. Taste is balanced between the sweet caramel notes and the burnt sugar bitter finish. More vanilla, raisins, eggnogg, custard cream, milk chocolate notes. Full bodied with good carbonation. Overall, intense
Amber colour, white head. Aroma of toffee, milk chocolate, vanilla. Taste is medium sweet. Medium body, oily to creamy texture, soft carbonation.
Dark caramel color with a small beige head that quickly faded. Aroma of maple syrup, fig jam, and booze. Sweet flavor with light bitterness and a bit of am alcoholic finish.

Copper-light brown (20-25EBC), fine poring small beige head offering lovely viscousity. Aromas of ripe dark fruits, figs, plums, butterscotch, caramel, honey glazed toast with a light floral blossom note. Fine perlage, smoot-slick, full bodied. Caramel-toast fig sweetness, with dark fruit bitterness with a whaff of sugared lemon peel on the lasting finish.

Bottle @ Mikkeller Web Shop. Pours deep ruby copper with a small head and lacings. Deep and rich toffee-ish vinous nose with notes of dark dried fruit and caramel. Slick, soft and vinous. Warming dryish ending. Enjoyable ..

Bottle from the ever pricey Oak Barrel. Really good Barley wine. Pours clear ruby/brown with a tremendous long-lasting creamy beige head - looks the part. Big caramel and heavily malty nose with a bit of yeastiness and booze as you might expect. Soft carbonation and a medium to full body. Taste is surprisingly hoppy and bitter with some grapefruit. Also some caramel sweetness and booze, but all very well balanced.
Bottle. Dark brown with a small head. Powerful, full bodied and in your face.Some maltiness and a strong presence of alcohol. Very interesting.

Hazy rustic plummy Amber with a thin ivory head. Big amazing fruity nose of plummy raisin and a little rummy brown sugar, but not in a Belgian Quad kind of way. Hard to explain. Boozy malty depth without being overly fruity or purple. Delightful boozy warmth with loads of dark raisin and Woody undertones. Semisweet and stone fruity and a light sharp heat. Smooth and big and very complex. So hard to explain but its a really amazing textbook Barleywine.

Bottle from Cotteridge Wines; hazy dark brown pour with a thin beige head, aroma has earthy fruits and toffee, taste has dark fruits, sweet caramel, bready malts, very sweet, quite boozy, stewed fruits, some wood.

Third Coast Barleywine is the kind of thing youd want to cap off the evening after a fine long meal. Or, in my case, after youve eaten a bunch of greasy tacos... heated up in the microwave. We all do classy in different ways, alright? Third Coast pours cherry mahogany with a thick, cream-colored foam layer. Caramel, butterscotch, molasses, vanilla, and fruit aromas. All of that shows up in the taste profile, too. Some notes of cherry, date, fig, plum, prune, light cocoa, and booze. Like a port or a brandy, Third Coast is a rich, voluptuous way to end an exceptional day. Or, you know, taco night. That works too.

Molasses, lightly resinous, pine, sweet, dried, dark fruits, alcohol. Hazy, dark brown, medium, frothy, beige head. Medium sweet. Sticky texture, molasses, caramel, pine, turns bitter, heavy bodied, dark fruits, raisins, prunes, warming alcohol. Beautiful Barley Wine, heavy, complex and very intense throughout. Bottle from Beer Gonzo, Coventry.
Caoba limpio y espuma beis. Aromas se melosos de fruta confitada, anís, caramelo. Cuerpo denso y sabor como en aroma con final seco y regusto ligero de tabaco.

Third Coast Old Ale has a rather thin, cream-colored head, a semi-clear, red appearance, with powdery sediment, throughout, and minimal lacing left behind. The aroma is of rich nougat, dates, light fudge, and plum, and the flavor is of those elements, riding alongside tea notes, brown bread crust, plum skins, golden raisin, some golden sherry, and a noticeable, balancing bitterness. Mouthfeel is fairly heavy, and Third Coast Old Ale finishes in the dry realm, but not as a particularly dry item. RJT

A: malty, bready and slight dark fruit. Ap: wonderful deep maroon pour with a fluffy white head. Probably should have been scored a 5, but I couldnt pull the trigger. T: dark fruit, grain and booze make up a mix that cant be beat in a barleywine. P: full bodied, slick mouthfeel. O: very good beer, very drinkable for how big of a beer this one is. Will get again.

Deep ruby pour with short lived tan foam. Loads of toffee, caramel, sweet malts on the nose, followed by flavours of caramel, sugar, alcohol... medium heavy body, sweet, but with a pleasant bitterness to keep it fresh. Really good.
pour read brown with a fine off white head. dark fruit, nutty, port wine aromas hints of yeast., taste light sweet medium bitter. medium to full bodied. light bitter finish.
Bottle from Biercab Shop. Copper colour with off white head. MAlt and caramel aroma. Sweet, malt, caramel, dark fruits taste. Medium to full body.

Very solid and enjoyable brew, but nothing too exciting. Huge malty mix, vinous maltiness, caramel, some bit off dried fruits, but works well in overall character. Moderate to intense sweetness with moderate to intense bitterness
Lovely

Bottle from Mikkeller Bottle Shop. Its a ruby amber beer with a beige head. It has a fruity sweet character with a vinous hint. Deep malty. High malty flavor with notes of dates and sweet fruit. A bit cloying. Some alcohol notes.

Robe brune aux reflets ambrés. Nez puissant sur le malt, les épices douces, le café au lait, les fruits secs. Bouche à lattaque à la fois ample et tendue, une belle tension, de la puissance, des notes épicées et une finale longue et acidulée. Une bière de méditation ou de fin de voyage....
Amber hazy with small to medium yellow head. Sweet malty aroma with bitter notes. Strong bitter taste on sweet malty background, but bitterness preveals. Strong lasting bitter aftertaste.

(355ml bottle shared @ VilleValla Pub, Linköping, Apr 21 2016) Pours clear deep brownish red with a small fine off white head and lace. Aroma is honeyed grains, marzipan, slight oxidation, torrified sugar. Palate has a sweet toffee and marzipan core, dark honey, layers of malt complexity, raisins and other light dried fruits, maybe apricots? A bit of lightly toasted grain. Bittering hops are slightly leafy but well in balance. Tannic feel to the dry down with alcohol moderate and complementary. Medium-full and smooth, mostly in the English style, very nice sipper that is substantial without being overbearing as some barley wines are.

Bottle from VilleValla Pub. Pours amber with no head. Low carbonation. Aroma of malts, hay, rye, fruits. Taste of malts, regular base and caramell. Some rye. Fruity hops (not IPA fruity). Great barley wine/old ale

Bottle at Bishops Folkis.
Clear redish copper with a medium off white head.
Glue and almonds with some red fruits and caramel. Malty, complex alcohol and no hops.
Sweet and slight warming, leather, some spice, caramel, vanilla, dried fruits.
Big oily body, soft carbonation, oily.
Nice old school brittish old ale with a slight belgo almond aroma and low hop profile. Something to age.
Pours a hazy orangish amber color. Aromas of strong malts, citrus, fruit, and alcohol. Flavor big malt taste with fruity finish. Long malt aftertaste. Can really taste the alcohol in this one

Bring it on! Foggy caramel colored pour, nice beige head with terrific lacing. Aroma is molasses and dark fruit. Flavors match quite well. Texture is a bit thin but smooth. This one confuses me. Is it a Barleywine or an English Old Ale. Whatever.....its solid!

Appearance: Packaged 5/9-2014. Dark redish brown, clear. Small light tan head.
Aroma: Dark fruit, molasses.
Taste: Dark fruits, molasses, some maltiness, vinous, warming. Hides alcohol well, I think.
Bought: Trade with Benzai - thanks!, 355 ml
Info: 23/3-2016

Refrigerated 12 oz. brown bottle, bottled on April 4, 2012.  poured into a snifter. Dark Translucent Crimson with small beige head. Aroma is caramel malt, medium body, low carbonation, and a little lacing. Taste is oxidized caramel malt and tobacco. Not a fan.

Alcohol and fruits come through on the nose after an autumn dark brown color.

Light effervescence yields to rich mouthfeel. Strong whiskey-like liquor finish is pretty pleasant especially for a non-barley wine guy

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours hazy chestnut brown with a tan white head that gradually fades to a rim. Mild lacing. Aroma is molasses and malt and sweet wine. Taste is rich and flavorful and quite dry on the palate. Very much like wine or brandy in taste and character. Still, there is a sweet toffee and malty roastiness - even burnt sugar here. Despite the wine-like character and ABV, not overly boozy. This is a very flavorful beer and a fantastic example of the style. If you like old ales/barleywines and are willing to lean into the malty side, this is a winner. Just great.

2013 vintage 12oz bottle, poured into a snifter. The aroma is caramel, wood, light molasses turns to a bright rum raisin with mild leather. It pours a murky, dark wood brown color with a tan, foam head that has very light retention and just a mild, runny lace. The taste is highly bitter, with a medium high sweet. The texture is thick with a mild, fizzy carbonation and a full body. The flavor profile starts with a muted rum or brandy warmth and raisin notes and finishes with a brighter rum raisin that turns to sweet tobacco and coffee with smokey molasses and bitter herbs. It leaves an aftertaste thats lightly astringent with notes of smoke, ash, tobacco, and herb.
Malty aroma. Deep Amber color. Thin white head. Bitter with a tad of sweetness. Grain fruit notes.

Medium brown pour with thin head. Musty malty aroma. Pleasantly malty and boozy, some syrupy feel and some alcohol get in the finish. Label doesn't provide much information, glad the ratebeer app clued me in that this was a barelywine or I may have been very confused by this one.

Bottle courtesy of Jake65. Without any research, I was thinking this was an old ale. Bottled August 2013. Muddy brown with small skin of beige head. Sweet malt and molasses on the aroma, hints of vanilla and oak in the taste, very gentle warmth. Slick, oily body. I would have kept this longer had I known. Thanks Jake.
This beer was fantastic glad i was able to share with Brian and dusty...hopeing to get a bottle for myself soon...tons of caramel ages very nicely...would drink again and again...better as it warms.

Bottle 0,33l from The Beer Cartel, Sydney. Pours a red brown colour and leaves a small Head and a ring of lacing. Aroma of malts, wine, caramel and toffee. Taste of malts, alcohol, hops, caramel, toffee and syrup.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

12oz bottle. 10/3/15 package date. Appearance: Slightly cloudy Amber brown, with a thick khaki head that dissipates quickly. 
Aroma: Bread crust, dark fruit (cherry), and sherry notes. Alcohol apparent. 
Taste: Deep, rich malt sweetness, with toast and bread crusts standing out. Also some rich caramel and sherry notes. Strong bitterness in the swallow to balance the malt base. 
Mouthfeel: Medium to heavy body with some viscosity, and a low carbonation. Alcohol well hidden. 
Finish: Leaves a rich malty, bread crust flavor long after the swallow. 
Overall: A very rich, but smooth barley wine. Loads of dark fruit flavors for complexity, while the alcohol is well hidden for a beer this strong and young. Interested to see how the flavors develop over time.

reddish brown, slightly cloudy with a thin off white head. Sweet, toffee, dried fruits and nuts. Starts off with toffee, not overly sweet, burnt sugar, a little dried fruit. Has a bit of bitterness underneath, booze, and more burnt toffee. A bit out of my element with barleywines, but its pretty damn good
Bottle to a pint. Mahogany pour with thin tan head. Toasty malt with spice and tiger notes. Smooth and balanced... Excellent!!!

Draft. pours a deep reddish-brown color with a thin off-white head. Aroma of sweet malt and dried fruit. Medium-full body, taste echoes the aroma - more of the dried fruit and malt theme. Somewhat sticky mouthfeel. Finish is sweet at first then a little bitterness comes out. Great!

Cloudy brown with rimming Lacy tan head; grainy hoppy fruity notes; flava is incredible balance of malt hop grain fruit alcohol notes of wood ; feels medium to thick decent fizz; finishes malty yet dry and full of hop flava bitters
Plenty of caramel in the taste along with ripe dark fruit like figs. Appearance is orange brown with spotty lacing. Sticky mouthfeel a bit sweet but not too sweet.

This is a solid, aggressive barley wine. It pours deep copper color with a thin head but a lot of lace. The aroma is candied fruit and nuts and dark liquor; raisins, figs, something like bourbon. The taste packs a lot of kick on the back end. Rich flavor, dense mouth feel.

355 mL bottle. Nice dark bronze colour with a small, tan head. Booze, fruit, caramel, and maybe even some nut. Or toast. Something. Still pretty hot. Booze dominates, but there is some caramel sweetness to provide a little balance. This one needs a little age.

Slightly hazy dark copper beer, small off-white head. Nose is caramel, malt, hop notes, sugar. Flavor is malty, sweet, sugary, caramel, fruity notes. Finishes with sugary notes and resiny-herbal hops. Sweet, caramelly and hoppy. Simple and straightforward.

Bottle (from firma bier). Pours amber with beige head. The head doesnt stay. Aroma is sweet, malt, caramel candy. Flavor is sweet and bitter, caramel candy, toffee, malt. Finish is dry-piney bitter. Overall: very nice.

Bottle: Hazelnut brown color, brown head. Malty aroma, light roastiness, hints oft nuts, some fruitiness, molasses. Flavor ia full bodied, dense and round, intensive maltiness and notes of nuts, toffee, catamel, grainy, sugar. Ends roasty with cacao powder, chocolate and dry dark chocolate notes. Round intensive brew, would love to try a longer aged one.
Bottled. Poured a deep brown with very little head. Wood, booze and malts. Probably maltier than most b wines. Very good.

12 ounce bottle purchased 13 months ago at Bine & Vine ($3.49). "Packaged 09/05/2014". Pours a reddish muddy brown hue with one finger of yellow-tan foam. AROMA of dried figs, raisins, candied dark fruit, holiday fruitcake, port wine, and brown sugar. Great FLAVOR of rich toffee, dark fruit (raisins, semi-sweet cherry), cinnamon and other holiday spice, a bit of chocolate, and almost a roasty-bitterness with some lightly burnt molasses. Moderately sweet but still far from cloying. The big ABV is pretty well concealed here. San Diego / Escondido really doesnt get that cold, but this is a nice beer for a cooler day with an early dusk. (1540, 989)

Bottle. Pours a deep amber color with off white head. Caramel, malty, slight wood aromas. Caramel, boozy, cherry, slight soapy, wood flavors. I cant believe I hadnt tried this Bells beer before. Decent barley wine.

Bottle. Pours a murky brown beer with a thin off white head on top. Aroma has massive barley, some chocolate and slightly red fruits. The malts are dominating the nose in a sweet and sugary way. No booze detected. Flavor is sweet and malty again, bigger hints of dark chocolate and also a slight bitter aftertaste. The booze comes out in the very back of the palate, giving it some nice kickback. Very warming, great balance and soft carbonation. Great stuff.
On tap pours an amber color with an off white head. Aromas of cherries, sweet booze similar to brandy. Flavored of burnt toffee, toasted malts, boozy cordial finish. Leaves the palate dry.
Tap. Hazy dark copper hue with a pale tan head. Smelled of strawberries and malt. Lightly fruity taste with a big malt and alcohol bill! Full bodied with moderate carbonation.

A juggernaut of goodness, Third Coast is a mouthfilling malt bomb that, despite its high alcohol content, remains very drinkable. Big caramel, cocoa, and dark fruit intermingle with piney hop notes that play in the aroma and flavor, but dont add much bitterness, serving merely to keep the sweet malts from completely stealing the show. Thick bodied, but never cloying, this is a Barley Wine done the right way, showcasing the grain elegantly. Ends cleanly with a slow malty fade, leaving wads of viscous tan head behind.

Deep maroon body, off white head soapy lacing. Sweet dried fruit, vanilla, grains, white chocolate aroma. Taste Is a strong dried fruit, raisins, some roasty bitterness, booze, cocoa, sharp finish on back of the throat. Smooth rich coating palate. Very nice.

Mahogany color with beige head. Aroma has a lot of sweet, dark fruits like raisins, plums, dates and also some molasses. Taste is really well balanced. Starts a bit sweet with caramel and dark sugar but gets really roasty and bitter in the finish. Alcohol gives some warmth but doesnt burn your palate. Overall its a really well made beer, perfect for the colder seasons.

It pours a cloudy amber color. It has a full head that produces lacing. it has aromas of molasses, bread, some nuts, and some dark fruits with cherries being the most evident. It has flavors of molasses, bread, cereal, nuts, dark fruits, with cherries being the dominant dark fruit although there are hints of plums. It has a quality bitter hit on the palate.

12 oz aged bottle served in a snifter. 
Pours a hazy, nearly opaque, reddish-brown. Would be murkier but I left the last bit of sediment in the bottle. 

This is a rich and robust ale with moderate spiciness and a load of dark fruit flavors. Somewhat boozy but not bad for > 10% ABV.

Pours a deep mahogany brown from the bottle with a thin cap of tan head that leaves good lacing. Aroma of musty wood and dark fruits with just a hint of oxidized caramel malt. Taste is more toward the dark fruit and caramel malt with a slight bitter finish. Mild carbonation, boozy burn, decent barley wine.

Type: 12-oz. bottle
Glass: AleSmith Barrel-Aged Reserve snifter glass 
From: Barons Market in Alpine, Calif.
Price: $3.19 
Purchased: Aug. 28, 2015
Consumed: Sept. 3, 2015
Misc.: Packaged on Sept. 5, 2014

Poured a brownish, auburn color with 1-to-2 fingers of grayish, khaki, rocky head. A few foamy spots on the sides of the glass. Below average-to-average retention. (Sight - 3.88)

Smelled a healthy dose of hoppy dark malts. Specifically got toffee, caramel, booziness, tobacco, leather, faint butterscotch, fig, dates and some slightly spoiled red apple. (Smell - 4.13)

Taste pretty much followed the nose. Got sweet caramel, toffee, booziness, scotch, tobacco, dried fruit - dates, figs, prunes and earthy raisins - some roasty malts and light herbal hops. (Taste - 3.63)

Full-to-medium body. Creamy-to-sticky texture. Average-to-lively carbonation. Long, boozy finish. (Feel - 4.00)

I had high hopes with this one, but overall it wasnt that great. (Overall - 3.75)

3.80 86 B+

355 ml bottle. Enjoyed at Los Angeles, CA. Pours a dark amber brown colour with a small white head. Aroma of toasted malts, syrup and resin. Flavour of strong bready maltiness, resin, grassy bitterness, wood and syrup. Medium bodied. Mouthdrying wooden finish.

355ml bottle

Pours dark reddish brown with a smooth white head. Aroma of berries, caramely malts, chewy toffee, hints of syrup and spices. Taste is malty, caramely, chewy and heavy with syrup, toffee and sugary notes. Finish is sweet, malty and heavy. Quite heavy but complex and surprisingly good still.

355 ml bottle @ hotel room, Los Angeles.
Pours mahogany color with a small head. Sweet ripe fruits on the nose, caramel malts and toffee, mild alcohol notes. Sweet caramel malt flavor with toffee and raisins, syrupy and some alcohol warmth at the end. Nice, though a bit sweet.
6424

35,5 cl bottle (10.2%) @ hotel room, Los Angeles. Bottled 05.09.2014. Aroma has raisins, harsh malt and sweet ripe fruits. flavour has woody tones, some menhol notes, grapefruity hops, raisins and harsh malt. Alcohol warms here nicely. Quite typical aged BW - pleasantly balanced though.

UPDATED: MAR 1, 2017 re-ate 3/17.  same 9/14 bottling date.  increased score from 3.2  better taste than I remember but the end of barleywines are a negative to me  the piney syrup alcohol finish is too much like medicine.......................................... high marks for aroma, app, and palate. Just didnt really like the taste/beer; not a fan of the style. bottle dated 9/5/14. too syrupy sweet and too much hops (even after a year) for me. yadda
2014 bottle. Pours a reddish brown. Aroma and taste are dark fruits and caramel.

12 oz. bottle from Liquor Barn (Jefferson Commons); not quite a year old. Aroma: Moderate raisin liqueur; moderate molasses; light dog vitamin; very light Pinot Noir with hints of plum and leather. Appearance: Dark ruby brown pour with a bubbly tan head that settles into a bubbly, wispy ring. Flavor: Raisin and molasses notes feature heavily here, but not to the detriment of the rest; the finish has a leathery quality, and dries out about as well as a beer this strength can. Palate: Full body, very sticky texture, very soft carbonation, long finish. Overall: Very good, especially for being under three bucks a bottle. An inexpensive beer that allows you to see the effects of cellaring on a budget.

At cellar temperature and into a brandy snifter. It is radiant when held to the lights but is misted by a lot of fine sediment caught in suspension. Like a good Barleywine the head is short lived replaced instead by oily, viscous legs. The body a deep, burnished copper. Thick and rich, melanoidens and savoury fruit mince nose hinting at fresh baked fruit cake dowsed in sherry. There is a hint of vanillin and milk chocolate, earth and oak underneath that gives complexity. A little rough on the palate. Twiggy bark atop earthy, spicy hops in the very back broaden the chewy, meaty malts. Nice, sweet, toffee and burnt caramel front with the generous, savoury minced fruit of nose playing on the mid-palate. Rolling it around it cedes up the alcohol in a hugely peppery effort. Bitter and lasting finish that holds a lot of warmth and ashen, earthy, musty notes. More English than U.S in style - which I love - so hoping the bitterness dulls after a few years of cellaring. The body is good and the carbonation low to medium with an oily finish stripped short only by the alcohol. Well rounded with a lot going on. I love it so a few bottles away for a few years is a must! (12fl.Oz, bottled 30/10/14, The Liquor Shed, Jandakot)

330mL bottle from Beer Cartel. PKGD 10/30/14
Dark copper body, moderate clarity, small dense off-white head.
Aroma not overly pungent, but plenty to enjoy - brown toffee, vinous red fruits, raisins, earthy (hop?) undertones.
Thick rich body, booze thins things out a bit, low carbonation, syrupy somewhat.
Lots of rich toffee & dried fruit on the palate. Subtle undertones of red fruits, licorice, toast, smoke, oak, spice, and port-like characters. Lingering earthy bitterness.
Big beer, might actually do with more age.

Draft from Whole Foods. Here is a big barley wine with lots of everything: hoppy bite, caramel sweetness, and abv. A bit of sweaty funk mixed with flowers in the nose. A nice amber glow in the pour. Lots of hop bitterness in the finish and a strong impression on the palate. BW is not my top style, but this is another very good release from Bells.
Very good old ale. Aroma of malt fruits. Taste follows nose. Moderate carbonation medium mouthfeel.

Bells makes some pretty incredible beers, the third coast ale is no exception. For such high gravity (10.2%) it is one of the tastiest beers full or malty hints and caramel overtones. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Bottle shared at a tasting at Maxs place. Pours orange to brown with a beige head, aroma of marmalade, orange and alcohol, flavor of marmalade, orange, tangerine, alcohol, medium bodied.

Old rating. Pours a very hazy dark orange with a small off-white head. Sweet aroma of hops, caramel malt, brown sugar, lots of fruit and alcohol. Taste starts with caramel malt, brown sugar, fruit and alcohol and finishes with a nice hoppy bitterness. Medium bodied. Complex and well balanced.
Bottle. Dark brown with little head. Aroma is cinnamon raisin toast, dark fruit and toffee. Taste follows. Rich, sticky and boozy. Very good.
Mooie roodbruine kleur met een aardige kraag. Ruikt vanille, crème, kers. Smaakt zoetig, vanille, crème, iets bitter. Dikke structuur.
Thanks to Benzai! Donker rood bier met een getinte schuim kraag. Ruikt gedroogd fruit, kruiden, rogge. Smaakt gedroogd fruit, koffie, kruidig. Medium tot dikke body en plakkerig.

Old rating. Dark Amber. Giant sweet malts, caramel, dark fruits, spices, boozy heat. Full
Bodied. Nice.

Pours a dark amber, with a tan head. Aroma is caramel malts, with a sweet smell. Big heavy malty body with lots of caramel and a dark fruity sweetness. Has a touch of piney hop bitterness also. Thick and rich yet very well rounded. I enjoyed it.

Bottle @ home. Lightly hazy dark red to almost purple color, medium sized off-white to beige head that lasts for a long time. Aroma is malts, overripe fruits, dark fruits, sweet. Taste malts, sweetish initially, dark fruits, slightly alcohol, a slight bitter touch in the finish. Medium to full body, suitable carbonation.

Old rating. Bottle from Old Town. Pours a brownish amber with a medium eggshell head that dissipates fairly quickly. FIg, prune, star anise, sorghum and toasted malt on the nose. Full body with a rich and sticky mouthfeel. As it warms up more of the fruit comes out along with some vanilla and oakiness. Slighly sweet on the palate. Smooth and rich boozy finish.

12 oz bottle dated 9/5/14 poured into a tulip glass..amber/ruby pour with a thin white head..aroma of booze,caramel,molasses, dark fruits..unique taste..dry,boozy but with fruit and spices..very good.

Bottle, pours an amber/copper color, hues of ruby. A thin off-white cap. Aromas of sweet berries, molasses, roast and a subtle hint of earth. Taste comes in layers. A nice sweet molasses coats the palate and allows the dark fruits to leave their impressions. Nothing is dominating this profile...nice balance here. Some slight spice, along with an earthy dryness make an appearance in the middle ground. This finishes with hints of alcohol, dark fruit and a nice light spice. Solid stuff!

2011 vintage (11/07/11). Pours a very, very dark red with little wisps of foam that cling to the glass. Super mellow aroma. Not faint, just, you know, mellow. Herbal... savory/sweet... something and then Bang! Ginger snaps. Thats the aroma. Also dried fruits: currants, cranberries. Cinnamon. Aromas are very reminiscent of Thanksgiving or Christmas. Warming, calming, comforting. I could smell this all night. But lets move on to the flavor. Sherry/oxidation, but very much in balance and not at all outside of a desirable level or expectation. Sweet, dark fruits like fig and dates. Chocolate. Quite a restrained bitterness. Balance is sweet. The finish lingers with slightly burnt oatmeal raisin cookie notes. This has aged superbly.

Aromas of dark fruits, plums, apricots, molasses, tangerine, burnt sugar, burnt caramel and liquid malt extract. Appears a dark amber color with a thin white foam. Taste is incredibly forward to the style with dark fruits, plums, apricots, molasses, brown sugar, maple, toffee and burnt sugar. Finishes with no booze and a large sugary sweet date, molasses, and caramelize sugar. Overall, really nice barley wine to the style, big sweetness and sugar to the style. A rating.

Bottle at home while in Jacksonville. Pours dark Amber brown with a thin white head. Sweet candy figgy cakey toffee aroma. Medium to full body, medium carbonation. Lots of figgy, pruney fruitiness, booze, cake, caramel, light lemon... Sweet and tasty. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle from GreatDane1632 as part of Local world wide swap, many thanks. Deep ruby red brown with medium off-white head. Sweet berries in aroma with caramel, alcohol. red fruits, honey, malt, earthy hops, alcoholic bitterness in finish. Tasty sipper.

Deep amber/garnet with a tight tan head and viscous lacing. Rich dark fruit aromas accompanied by alcohol - sherry - and brown bread and baked apple. Big caramel sweetness up front, with ripe fruit and a touch of chocolate syrup. Full body, syrupy mouthfeel, gentle carbonation, warming alcohol throughout and a lingering fruit sweetness in the end.

Draft sample at Cincinnati Beerfest 2015 pour dark copper with thin tan head. Nose sweet malt, licorice, dank and earthy. Taste moderate bitter up front, then toffee and dank. Light bitter finish. A bit overpowered by the other beers I sampled this day.

Pours an dark orangish brown with creamy 1 finger white head. Head dissipates pretty quickly. Aroma - toffee, caramel, dried fruits, a little bit of an almost bourbon barrel note with vanilla and mild spices. Taste - malt, dark malts, med roast coffee. Moderately thick on the palate with a nice warming across the back of the throat. Bottle is from Sept. 2013. Its aged very nicely.

Smells great, tons of caramel, soy sauce, sticky toffee. Hazy brown color with a foamy brown head. Tastes great, upfront sweet and sour characteristics, finishes with candi sugar and intense earthy bitterness. Long finish with a hint of molasses at the end. Not super to my taste but very good beer nonetheless. Thick bodied, average carbonation.
Draft at Bricks. Pours clear brown with some off white head. Nose is caramel and whiskey. Taste is same. Some bitterness in the aftertaste. Good.

Bottle to glass. Pours a medium nut brown color with a light tan head. Aroma is molasses, dark fruits, port. Flavor is boozy, dark fruits, raisin. Thick oily creamy body with a lingering alcohol burn. Decent barley wine, but I think Im starting to get spoiled with all that barrel aged stuff out there.

Tap at Ginger Man, New York. Colour is reddish brown with small white head. Aromas and flavours: Dark fruits, dry fruits, raisins, spices, ginger? and malts.
Quite dry barley wine.

Tap. Pours cola brown with creamy beige head. Aroma is rich bready and cookie malts, plums, raisins, caramel, black licorice, and molasses. Flavor is rich malt profile with medium floral hop bitterness, dark fruit esters, caramel, and faint woodiness. Medium/full body and medium carbonation.

Draft. Pours hazy nut brown with a bubby off white head. Tastes like raisin, dried fruits, booze, toasted malt, and dry grapefruit hops. Light body and low carbonation. Smells like raisin, nutty malt, toast, and caramel.
Aroma of plums, bourbon and malt, pours a dark amber without much head. Taste of malt, and bourbon. Medium body with a sweet malt finish.

Pours a deep brown with a short tan head and lacing. It has a rich aroma of vanilla, dark malt, plum, and dark cherry. The flavor is well balanced, with slightly toasty malt up front with a sweet, dark fruit finish over a smooth, medium-heavy body.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Up, up, and away. This brew is amazing. Fruity and I can only guess about how it ages overtime. Enjoy.
Bottle not aged. Nose is sugary and sweet. Very smooth and sweet. Good color and mouthfeel. 10% hides in there. Looking forward to aging this one. I'd buy again although it's a bit $$$.
Nose is burnt sugar, caramel, booze, light raisin. Flavor is same plus an underlying bitterness. Okay but unremarkable

Bottle on 2/3/15. Pours a dark brown with a thin light tan head that mostly dissipates pretty quickly. Nose is great, booze, bourbon, chocolate, brown sugar, dark fruit, caramel. Taste is the same, really good. A bit more fruit coming through, sweet, some hop bitterness, and alcohol burn. Delightful.

12oz bottle into a pint glass.

Pours a very dark brown with a tiny light tan head. Some splotchy lacing on top but good foam around the edge of the glass.

Aroma is dark fruit and burnt sugar. A touch of pine and oak notes but it is all very weak. I was really hoping the aroma would pop a little more than it does. 

The flavor has a huge shot of hop bitterness right off the bat. The hops really overwhelm whatever subtle flavors might be present. As the beer warms, some more dark fruit and oak comes through but it is still hampered by the bitterness. Sweet and pretty thick mouthfeel with some alcohol warmth on the finish.

Overall, I had very high hopes for this beer and feel a bit let down. Maybe a couple years on this will ease the bitterness but I feel like there are some really good flavors buried in there.

I have had a few barley wines before and have not liked any. I got nervous after I bought a six pack of this and saw that it is considered a barley wine and not an old ale like Curmudgeon.

I get a raisin type smell from it. Pours a light cola color with no head. I am getting flavors of fruit like raisins and dates. It has a dry finish too. There is another taste that I honestly cannot pick out. Part of it reminds me a bit of pine needles - but not like some types of hops. I do enjoy this beer.

I now have to look to see if barley wine and old ale are closely related, what the differences are...and is it that I like barley wine, but only the top tier ones.

Pours dark amber, with tan head. Looks pretty thick. Aroma is heavy caramel malts, smells sweet. Big heavy malty body. Lots of caramel and a little bit of fruity sweetness. Has a bit of piney hop bitterness also. Really good sipper.
Pours dark amber with a thin tan head. Complex aroma but taste is a bit too syrupy sweet for my taste.
Draft - Sweet caramel malts. Deep cloudy Amber with a decent beige head. Boozy caramel and a orange fruity nice long sweetness. Nice and would be good to cellar and mellow a bit.

UPDATED: MAY 15, 2015 Golden caramel pour. Aroma is honey, hops, caramel chews. Taste goes with aroma but with more hop bitterness coming through. Also some resin and mild pine cutting through. Some stewed fruits on the finish. Not overly complex but certainly tasty. Nice sticky sweet finish. A very approachable American style barleywine - could do with more x factor but just solid stuff.

4 Jan 2015, bottle. dark amber/light brown. nose is strong, pungent bread dough, moderate alcohol, raisins, some nuts, yeast, slight rancid fruit. full body and moderately fizzy. Faint nail polish alcohol up front and more just before the finish, nutty, wheat bread, alcohol, raisins. taste in my mouth after a while is meaty and charred wood, almost like eating burnt tips. this is a good (but not hoppy) barley wine.
12oz bottle pours a dark brown color without any head. Huge malty aroma and flavor. Like a home brew kit extract.

Extra from Harrison_gord, thanks Gordon! Pours a clear mahogany with a thin white head that quickly fades and doesnt leave much lacing. Nose is of caramel, toffee and raisins. Taste is of fruity caramel, brown sugar, alcohol. Not really hot or fusel-y alcohol, just slightly boozy. Maple syrup. Body is medium-full, carbonation medium and mouthfeel slightly syrupy but surely sticky. Overall a good barleywine but not really that distinctive, needs to be a little richer or something like that.

Bottle at home, thanks to GT2 for the trade, 28/12/14.
Extremely dark mahogany brown meets light black with a well appointed khaki covering that stays for the show.
Nose is toffee, dark fruit rinds, tobacco, earthy, light spice, dates, cake mix.
Taste comprises much the same, fruit cake, dates, raisens, prunes, caramelised brown sugars, almonds, woody licks.
Medium + body, fine carbonation, semi drying close with lightly warming alcohol.
Decent barley wine, well balanced, some well tempered bitterness so it doesnt get too sweet .
user_location: Hazlemere, the lower Xhitlerns, Buckinghamshire, ENGLAND

text: Bottle. This is a big bitter viscous BW with lots of malt sweetness and good full flavor.

Bottled 9/5/14 into tulip glass, dirty dark amber color with minimal tan head. Aroma of heavy malt, dried fruits (raisins, apricots, plums), caramel, booze and light fruity citrus hops. Taste adds notes of grain, bread, sugar, fruit (cherry, strawberry, apple), cocoa, vanilla, light spices and some yeast. Heavy body, low carbonation, rich, creamy with thick fruity malt finish. Quite excellent this fresh, almost perfect hop balance. Curious what some age will bring out.
Poured from a bottle it is a light brown with a slight head. The aroma is boozey and the taste is coffee and bitter overtones laced with boozey ness

Poured from a 12 oz bottle into a snifter. Dark amber beer with a thin white head and low carbonation. Aroma is of plums, figs, prunes with alcohol behind it. Taste is much the same: starts off with sweet dark dried fruit notes: raising, plums, figs--ends with a warming alcohol kick and a lingering bitterness. Exceptionally well balanced--despite the sweetness it finishes dry enough to not be overwhelming and it is easy to drink a bottle of this. Mouhfeel is exceptional as well--full bodied but silky smooth due in part to restrained carbonation. Hops are present, but not overwhelming.

Overall very much on the lighter, more easily drinkable side for barleywine, but exceptionally rich in flavor.

12 oz. bottle from Marketplace Liquor in Minot. Appearance: finger khaki tan head, dark copper-deep red color, clear, gook oily lacing. Aroma: heavy malt, raisin, caramel, floral, notes of citrus. Palate: medium-full body, soft carbonation, oily texture, light alcohol bite, bitter finish. Taste: sweet caramel and raisin, with some citrus and floral bitter bite on the backside of the sweetness. Decent booziness. Overall, very very smooth barleywine, lovely fruit aroma and taste, balance is good, and booze is present but not overly. Very very nice.

12 onces. Embouteillée le 09/05/14. Robe brune/ambrée avec un anneau de mousse. Nez richement fruité, entre la Old Ale et le vin dorge anglais, avec du toffee et de la liqueur de noisettes. Bouche pleine de prunes, de raisins et de petites baies avec une amertume forte, un alcool coloré et une poignée de noix diverses. En bouche, un corps parfait, rond et liquoreux avec un pétillement adapté. Une finale houblonnée, fruitée et chaude sans être brûlante. Superbement balancé. Il est si facile à boire mais si dangereux. De classe mondiale. Centième vin dorge pour moi sur RateBeer.

Poured from bottle into snifter. Thick, opaque caramel/ brown color, with almost non-existent white head (just a few bubbles around the edge and in the center). Malty, brown sugar smell. Taste has some more sweet-ish malt, and some boozy bitterness. Feel is kind of thick and slick, really coats the mouth. This isnt a style that Im accostomed to, but I really like it. You can definitely taste/ feel the 10%+ abv, but its not overwhelming or unpleasent. Good beer.
Bottle. Pours a thick medium brown with a creamy head. Aromas of malt, pine, and brown sugar. Very sweet with noticeable bitterness. Coats the mouth nicely. A good slow sipping beer.
Tap. Pours a murky amber brown with a ring of beige head. Aroma and taste of caramel, malts, some sugar, and some boozy notes.

Bells Third Coast Old Ale is an old ale in name only, as it doesnt have any of the barrel character often found in traditional brews of the style. This is more of an English-style barleywine, and its quite good. A complex palette thats also perfectly balanced and highly drinkable. Impressive.

I poured a 12oz bottle into a tulip glass. It was bottled on 9/5/14 and cost $4.35 ($0.36 per ounce).

Appearance: Beautiful cherry wood hue, slightly translucent. Pours to a large, dirty white, frothy head which laces and retains very well.

Smell: Surprisingly mild nose with a general sweetness of red fruit, sangria, and a hint of alcohol.

Taste: In the glass, Bells Third Coast Old Ale looks a lot like a cabernet Sauvignon wine, which is interesting because it has a lot in common with that style as far as flavor notes go. Right away theres a sweet taste of dark cherry, strawberry and pomegranate  if all were covered in milk chocolate. On the second half theres a noticeable dry bitterness, slightly sharp, followed by a rich sweetness of toffee and butterscotch. And while all these flavors taste good, I am a little surprised that their intensity is not through the roof (especially in a fresh bottle). 

Drinkability: Big heavy beers in this style that weigh in at 10.2% ABV tend to be difficult to drink, but Bells Third Coast Old Ale is remarkably approachable. The mouthfeel is not sticky or thick, but closer to a medium body with low carbonation. The texture is silky smooth, which makes it easy to gulp down, especially considering theres no alcohol warmth, either. An ideal liquid dessert.
Thought it was a good beer. Very brown and good. Appearance is brown and last was a bit malty. Overall a pretty good beer.

Really old bottle to snifter. pours a murky brown with red tint and a small off white head that is mostly medium to large bubbles. aroma is sugar and a light bit of oxidation. some grape notes and fruit roll ups. taste is very chewy malt, but kind of flat in terms of complexity. just a sweet sugary mess at this point. likely my fault for drinking it 6 years after bottling.

i thought it was a prototype old ale, which made for a very good beer that fell just a little short of the "wow" factor. rich aroma, body, and flavor. caramel, lactic qualities, rum, raisins...maybe a touch of hops in the finish, but not bitter at all. pretty stinkin smooth. not a top 100 beer for me, and Expedition is far and away my favorite Bells beer, but this adds yet another tasty brew to their line-up. Im starting to doubt that they make anything average."

Transfer from BA review on 7-24-13-

 Poured from bottle into a snifter

 Appearance  Pours a deep mahogany color with some ruby highlights shining through when held up to the light. Upon pouring there is a small tan colored head. The head fades rather fast leaving only a trace of lace on the sides of the glass. While there is little lacing a thickness can be seen when swirling in the glass as the brew clings to the side leaving a fast dissipating foam on the glass once the liquid recedes.

 Smell  The aroma is malty and fruity with a big malty bread smell mixed with lots of darker fruits. The darker fruits are mainly of a plum, prune, raisin and fig aroma bringing a rather sweeter smell to the brew. While the fruit brings a sweetness some hop of an earthy and herbal nature along with a boozy rum smell help balance the aroma creating a warming smell overall.

 Taste  The taste begins with a smoother bready and slightly fruit flavors taste. The fruit is of the darker fruits that were detected in the nose. While the nose was rather heavy overall in the sweeter fruit, the taste was not but instead was heavier on the bready tastes upfront. As the taste advances the breadiness remains the same in intensity, but the fruity flavors dwindle some. As this occurs some spice flavors of nutmeg and clove come to the tongue along with some earthy bitter hop and a moderately strong rum flavor. The rum and hop get stronger more toward the end and when combined with the now lighter fruit and bready flavor create a moderately bitter and rummy taste to linger on the tongue.

 Mouthfeel  The body of the beer is super thick and creamy with a carbonation level that is on quite low. Both work in concert to create a mouth coating feel bringing all the drier, slightly earthy, malty and boozier flavor to linger on the tongue creating a very warming feel.

 Overall  A barley that is a bit on the drier and more bitter side with a big warming and slow drinking style. This one is nice to sit down with for a long haul.

Poured from a 2014 bottle into a pint glass darkest of amber with a beige head.
Aroma is burnt caramel some booze.
Flavor is straight up fresh hop sweet caramel.
Prefer this brew with age. Have had 3 years back & its more subtle in the hops department and smooth as freshly mowed grass. Looking to lay this baby down. Still quite exceptional in its newness.

Pours as a dark brown beer with minimal head. The aroma is of strong chocolate and some caramel. As I sip, I also notice the barley and hops; the latter are quite herbal. The taste is mildly sweet. The palate is perfectly smooth. A great, complex beer that I want to try more of!
Nice caramel front, toffee, nuts, apricot and cider. Notes of orange, licorice and sweet grains. Smooth creamy feel and good carbonation.

2009 vintage at Akkurat. Poura deep caramel with reddish hues and a minimal white head. Swirling it in the glass leaves some nice oily lacings. Nose is incredible:a deep caramel and raisin upfront with some toffee, figs and dates mixed in. Behind those some apple, prunes and slight musky tones that vye for attention. Mouthfeel is increedible as well: smooth as hell with almost no carbonation. Taste is caramel sweet with figs, dates, honey, raisins, plum and roasted nuts. Towards the end deeper musky earthy notes come forward along with the caramel, apple and raisin notes. Just fantastic!
Sweet, malty. Raisins, especially on the finish. Alcohol is quite apparent. Some yeast perhaps?

Bottle as shown. Pours a cloudy brown with small beige head that lasts. The aroma is strong oak, vanilla, and candy sugar. Medium mouthfeel with sweet vanilla, light roast, oak, wood, and light boozy finish, very good.
Sweet fruity, caramels and toffees, hints of cocoa, very much an English BW or Old Ale. Delicious and hella drinkable.

12oz bottle into a snifter. Pours very dark w thin head. Lots of yeasty bread aroma. Very drinkable. Alcohol is concealed well for 10.2 abv. Bells just has it figured out. Havent had a bad beer from them.
Imported from untappd iphone. comes as close to my memory as possible. This is aged a little more than two years and im not sure how much it helped but its still good.
Bottle. Opaque medium brown with a small head. Sweet aromas of dark fruits, raisins, bread, with a touch of hops. Flavour is rich dark fruits balanced with a bit of citrus hops. Fabulous barley wine.

UPDATED: SEP 26, 2015 Has a sweet, spicy, complex aroma. More hops in the scent than most barleywines/old ales I have had. Caramel and some booze in the aroma. Im getting some citrus as well. Pours a great dark ruby color with a thin white head; moderate lacing on the glass - just beautiful. Taste is caramel/butterscotch at first, malt sweetness second, slight booze third and piney hop bitterness fourth. Palate is slick with more carbonation than I was expecting (a great surprise for me). Aftertaste is intense at first but fades wonderfully, faintly present at the time of your next sip, no matter when that is. Says Old Ale on the bottle, RB classifies it as a barleywine - personally, I think its an Old Ale, either way, its great. Adding to its appeal is that you can buy a 6-pack of this 10% ABV beer. I dont know of any other beers that offer that except Expedition Stout - maybe its a Bells thing. This lets you drink 4 and cellar 2 for later. Go buy this right now. 
Currently drinking a 2 year old bottle.  Much less hops in the aroma, more butterscotch/caramel.  Taste is also less hoppy, still boozy with a good amount of sweetness.  Palate is still slick and full, carbonation is significant.  I cant say the aged bottle is any better, but it is just as good.

12oz bottle. Bottle dated 10/12/12. Pours a clear rich mahogany color, with a medium bubbly head, seems to have held up well over the last 1.5 years. Aroma is just superb, quite balanced, and appetizing, lots of bread and rich malts. Taste matches aroma, light at first, then builds into a symphony of taste. Palate doesnt let you off easy, but its not too bitter, either. This is an example of why I love barley wine.

Yum. Murky dark amber in color, smell and taste is caramel, dark fruit and raisins. The 10+% ABV is barely noticeable, really good

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

UPDATED: MAY 25, 2014 Pretty new bottle, I think. Smells great. Definitely the aroma of a barley wine. Kind of fruity smelling. Taste is sweet, rich, decadent. A little bitterness. Im wishing for slightly more depth of flavor and thicker body, but thats nitpicking. Great beer! Edit: Just found out you can look up the batch # on the Bells website from Ray, who traded this to me. The bottle is a 2009.

2010 Vintage, huge aroma of wine and jam, dark brown with some sediment. Massive flavour, brandy, notes of chocolate, full bodied and coats your mouth. Complex sugars leave a rich sweetness that builds each sip, with a mellow hop background. Warms you slightly, but there is no burn, this is a piece of fine art in the beer world. Leaves your lips a bit a sticky, world class. Tingles your tongue the whole time, even after you swallow it lingers.

2012 bottle. This has lightened up and mellowed out over time. Raisins, must, brandy, sweet malt aromas. Light mouthfeel and still has good carbonation for a Barleywine. Taste is sweet prunes, tawny port, burnt sugars, toasted cinnamon. Very good and the age is nice.

12 ounce bottle. Packaged on 08/07/13. Paid $3.25. 
Cloudy brown color with lots of floating stuff inside. Small beige head disappeared quickly. Rich dark toffee malt aroma with notes of stewed plums. Bittersweet treacle-like roasted malt flavor has an intense bitter hop backdrop. Lots of bold flavors here, including dried figs, burnt raisins, bourbon and resiny hops. Alcohol presence is well hidden. This is a wonderful barley wine that should only improve with age.

12oz bottle - 2013 vintage Pours a deep brownish/amber . Sweet dark fruit aromas . Fig , raisin faint cherry and licorice . Very smooth . 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle pour.  Thanks Frankie.  Dark brown pour with a sweet, boozy aroma. This beer doesnt taste nearly as strong as it smells or looks. Very smooth. Amazing roasted flavor. Has the aged beer feel, without the boozy side. Awesome beer.

Single bottle from August 2013. Very sweet and malty aroma - figs, gapes, caramel. Pours a dark mahogany with a small tan head. Very sweet at first, then a big hit of brandy-style alcohol and a slightly hoppy finish. Slick mouthfeel. Would be interested in seeing the difference after another year or so of cellaring.

12 oz bottled 2 years ago, purchased at Johns Grocery ($3.49) and poured into a snifter at home.  Dark brown appearance with a small, light brown head, minimal lacing.  Aroma of caramel, chocolate, dark malts, earthy hops, vanilla, fruity esters, toffee and light alcohol.  Similar flavor, rich, complex, bittersweet, lingering finish.  Full body, creamy and smooth, nice texture.  One of the best barley wines I have ever had.
Wow. Brown with ruby tones and a tan head. Aroma of roast malt and caramel. Flavor follws nose but ends with an astringent bite. Great beer.
12oz bottle pours a hazy ruby brown with an tan head. Aromas of raisin, fig, malt, and caramel. Flavors of caramel and booze with a slight bitterness.
Sweet smell, has a dirty pond water look, light head. Im not a huge barley wine fan, but this is a good one.
2012 vintage opened today. Typical dark fruit nose with booze, good low carbonation mouthfeel. Aging provided nice mellow rounded edges. Sweet, touch of bitter, just a hint of alcohol.
bottle. amber mahogany with minimal head. sweet malty base with dark fruit. complex flavor. well done.
Draft at Blue monk. Beautiful mahogany dark or with an off white head. Nose is dark fruit and booze. Taste is sweet dark malt, raisin, Fig, booze, some yeast.

Pours deep ruby minimal head

Smell sweet juicy fig and caramel, bit of coco, toffee, raisin

Taste bread, caramel, booze, big classic barleywine flavors

Mid to fuller body

Smell great, everything else was only ok
I havent had very many old Ales but this is pretty good. Malty and sweet with a taste of alcohol.
Bottle from West Lakeview Liquor s, Chicago. Pours dark brown with sediment. Aroma of vanilla, toffee, and raisins. Taste of dark fruits, toffee, and booze. Crisp aftertaste. Thick body.

Deep brownish pour cloudy with a thin off white almost khaki head .... aroma of dark fruits, roasted light chocolate and chewy burnt caramel malts .... taste is of dark fruits, roasted malts, light chocolate malts, chewy burnt caramel malts with a light hoppy bite on the back end .... mouthfeel is very smooth and the abv is hidden well medium to full bodied ... bottle aged almost 7 months ..... finish is bitter and malty with a nice lingering bite on the tongue .... a very complete beer

Pours a murky red-ish brown with light brown head. Has a sweet caramel aroma, with other unique characteristics including some coffee, chocolate, malt and light hops. An excellent smoothy and creamy taste with caramel, dark alcohol, spices and some grains.
Poured from the tap. Murky dark reddish brown with tan head. Light caramel aroma with decent degree of hops. Same flavour, alcohol hidden. Medium body.

Draft sample. Pours a darker copper with a thin beige head of foam. The aroma is very malty with notes of bread and nuts, but also dark fruits and toffee. Definitely on the sweet side. The beer was listed as 2010 Bells Old Ale. It definitely tasted like it was that old, but it was taken care of nicely while it was cellared. It aged very nicely. Big body with low carbonation. Earlier Rating: 11/30/2012 Total Score: 4Poured from a 12 ounce bottle. 2012 vintage. Pours a translucent brown with a thinner beige head of foam. The aroma is bready, nutty, malty bitter, leather, earthy. Theres a lot going on here. The taste is very earthily sweet. Its got a nutty bitterness and bready note that sits on the back of the tongue developing. Nearly chewy, thick mouthfeel. Very nice beer. Im looking forward to seeing what a little age does to this beer. It doesnt need any help, really, Im just wondering how it will grow and develop over time.
Poured dark brown. Sweet barely flavor. Syrupy in the palate. Can taste the alcohol on the finish.

Dark brown ale with an off-white head. Has a pleasant, sweet aroma characteristic of barley wines. Taste is caramel, and towards the end of the beer theres a stronger hint of sweet fig and syrup. Theres a touch of bitterness to further add to the complexity. I enjoy this, and I wonder how it will be after aging.

Pours dark brown with a thin beige head. Aromas are sweet malt and chocolate. Upfront flavor of dark chocolate, coffee, and dried fruit with bready notes. Finishes with chocolate, licorice, nutty notes, and a lingering hop bite. Very complex flavors. Creamy, but peppery mouthfeel. Big and boozy. This is a delicious beer. It would likely get even better if allowed to age.
Bottle sample at a tasting at avrashis. Thanks troubles. Murky dark brown with white wave. A little alcoholic, fruity and vinous aroma, sweet, vinous taste. Full-bodied, sweet finish.

Really deep purple-y brown pour thats a step away from black, no head to speak of, some white lacing. Fresh pungent but light aroma of brisk dark fruits, grain, balsamic and nuts. Carbonation is a bit low, slick mouthfeel and smokey almost warm finish. Robust complex flavor of dark fruit raisins, bourbon, woodsy smokey malts, pine, the graininess is certainly in the forefront. I feel like a fancy boy drinking this beer, probably would be better, richer, and smoother with some age.
Bottle. Deep ruby with off white head. Nice full body smooth caramel/butterscotch taste. A hint if bitterness. Solid stuff.-- rated with beerbasher
Had it on tap. Looked like an amber in the glass and it smelled good. I didnt taste much flavor and the beer was very bitter to me. So bitter that I did not like it very much.

12 oz bottle for 3 bucks. Pours a hazy dark brown with a slight amber hue to it and a light tan head. Aroma is caramel, dark fruit, a little biscuit and chocolate as well. Taste has some caramel, a little piney hops, a little sweet, bready, fruity as well. Body is average with a slick mouthfeel and a lasting sweetness. This is a pretty good barley wine.

12 oz bottle into proper bells tulip. Minneapolis.

Appearance: Deep brown with rudy tint. Completely opaque. Small tan head.

Aroma: Earthy notes: Wood, Leather. Roasted malts, spices, warming alcohol. 

Taste: Very rich. Dry sweetness upfront that transfers into a slightly bitter finishes. Mellows out in the end with a warming alcoholic finish. 

Palate: Full body, smooth texture. Long finish. 

Overall: A really nice barley wine. Rich and earthy, not overly sweet or fruity, which is refreshingly different. Strong roasted profile. A nice beer. will be interesting to try with some age on it.
Fresh 2013 tap pour @Thirsty Monk in Asheville, NC. Cloying bitter. Aroma hints at barley wine nature, but body just isnt there yet. Will age and reassess.

A one inch, mostly tight, somewhat creamy light khaki head momentarily floats on a clear mahogany body flashing ruby highlights, a few extended peninsulas of lace form

Sweet, yet lively aromas of caramel, dark cherries, and vinous tones, a soft piney citrusy hop character works its way into the aromas with warmth, initially appearing on the creamy silky medium body, nutty biscuit and wood nuances are introduced along with chocolatey notes building into the finish and complimenting the lightly piney, citrus hop influence in the residual, light fruit cake, solid complexity with well restrained, nicely balanced components, mildly warming, pleasant

12oz bottle code 12260 PKGD 08/07/13 C at 55º into 16oz Spiegelau Soiree Brandy snifter
Yep, I want to drink this beer on the regular. Not overly hoppy like I want my barely wines to be, but its flavor is so deep and traditional that I love it nonetheless.

Deep, murky, rich auburn pour. A sliver of white head. Laced. Aroma of red fruit, caramel, sugar, and faint timber. Taste is doughy. Sweet. Caramel and stone fruit notes on a rich malt backbone. Boozy, but not obtrusive. Long dry finish. Lively carbonation. Proper.
A deep red color. Dark fruits and a woody taste. Big alcohol flavor in this one. A big sipper. Good tasting stuff.

I had this at Global Brew. Pours reddish-brown with a tan head. Taste sweet, boozy, dark fruit. I thought this was so so. I would skip this down the road.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle from Save On, six months old. Dark brown with garnet hue ring head and some lace. Cherry liqueur woody earthy hop caramel. Rich fruity caramel earthy boozy sweetness with woody piney earthy hoppy bitterness and balancing dryness. Full body. Excellent.

Dark like rosewood. Feels like syrup in the mouth. What a great malt character this one has. Not very hoppy compared to some of the other barleywines Ive had that go that route. Caramel, licorice, and molasses on the nose. Sweet caramel maltiness from the very beginning. The abv on this beer is not hidden, but isnt completely in your face. The hops that are present lend a very minor bitterness and a VERY small amount of dank taste, but I suspect the rest of the moldiness (in a good way) comes from the other parts.

Bottle, dated 1/13. Pour is dark amber, big off-white head, little retention/some lace. Aroma of toffee, brown sugar, prune, raisins, grape drank. Taste is sweet but not cloying, toffee, caramel, prune, more grape drank. Palate is soft, slick, sweet finish.

Pours a dark amber-red color with a two-finger, long retaining, tan head. Competing sweetness and tartness on the nose. Caramel aromas. A somewhat oily mouthfeel, with mild carbonation and slight astringency at the finish. A little palate confusing with the flavor. Definitely some thick sweetness, but theres an overarching tartness that doesnt quite blend for balance. Theres some alcohol bitterness at the finish that further complicates the profile. Definitely dominated by caramel with some ripe apple.

Bottle purchased online awhile ago. Batch 9970.

A: Dark mahogany with a creme colored head. Nice lacing.

N: Huge toffee and caramel in the nose. Bread and salted caramel. Oxidation.

T: Huge bitterness with only a touch of malt. Some of the oxidation shows through. Astringent.

M: Medium body. Sticky.

O: Bleh. This is harsh and not wonderful. Too much bitterness, not enough balance.

Pours with a slightly cloudy deep amber/brown body topped by a thin off white head with a good amount of lacing. Slightly sweet malty aroma with good fruity hop notes and a touch of caramel. Slightly sweet caramel malt flavor to start, turning piney from hops with a touch of alcohol. The finish is slightly sweet yet bitter and hoppy. Full bodied and smooth yet slightly tingly and warming
Excellent barley wine style ale. Malty, sweet, full-bodied and very flavorful. Brownish-red in color. Great addition to the cellar.

Third review: batch 9958 (25AUG10)

Pours a dr.pepper cola with a loose bubble sheet of light tan foam. Smells from afar of caramel, as I draw in: gobs of sugar, caramel, tea, turbinado, malt, a hint of nougat. Taste is sweet with alcohol, caramel, bits of almond rocha, metal, still sharp alcohol here. Medium on thick body for the style with moderated assertive carb and a semi dry finish. This is a decent beer. If I lived in the distro, Id throw a few in the cellar annually. So far, Ive only had em back two years, I think I will hold my last bottle for the five year mark and see where that lands me.

Review 1: Batch 9958: 08/25/10
Review 2: Followed by Batch 8943: 1/28/09 - reviewed 03MAR11 4/4.5/4.5/4/4.5-4.43
A: Ale pours a nice cherry orange amber. No head formation. Thin sheet of fine bubbles that sticks around. Spotty laces.
A2: Again pours cherry ale. This time forms a single finger, creamy tan head with just a few moments of retention. This dissolves to leave a solid sheet of the same. Initially, full drapes for laces, when stirred, lacing disappears for good.
S: Caramel, toffee, burnt sugar. Great malt body in the nose. Hints of oaky drieness, somewhat woody. Alcohol boozy, but very well enveloped. Not much hops here. Hints of vanilla on the back.
S2: Two years into maturation, this beer develops even more caramel, toffee tones. Beautifully matured malts, burnt sugar, brown sugar and now: hints of molasses.
T: Lovely caramel malt. Alcohol still a little hot at this age (six months). Very drinkable. Sweet, but has nice earthly hop addition and mellow mallow tones. Good.
T2: Uh oh, this is sooo good! Man, the toffee turns to salted caramel. Man, so good. Still backing of bitter hops. Alcohol a little more evident in this one, but sweet and good.
M: Smooth, low carb, medium-heavy body. Silk screen in the mouth, leaves the mouth slick. Nice.
M2: Continues to be smooth, a little more carbonation. Leaves the mouth more or less dry at this point. 
D: I would drink this on a very regular basis if it was available in the area. So nice.
D2: This has convinced me that I need to come up with a good vertical of this beer. I am stoked because this beer is relatively inexpensive and easily available.

Serving type: bottle

11-08-2012

12 oz bottle, Bridge Street Kroger in Dublin, $15.99/6. Pours a darker brown, with creamy one-finger white head that dissipates into nothing; medium lacing. Aroma is indescribably just "old"--like an old wooden library full of dusty leather-bound books; dirt, tobacco, malt, some dark vinous fruit (maybe raisin). Flavor is similarly "old"; tobacco, dark malt, some bitterness in the finish offsets the sweet dark malt. Palate is fantastic; dark and full bodied, oily, yet not overly sticky. Not particularly sweet as barley wines go, which is fine. The other 5 bottles are already on the shelf and I may pick up another sixer for a longer-term aging venture. Very nice.

Dried fruits on the nose. Tastes like a caramel covered amaretto cherry. With alcohol for bite. I like the color, a dark cloudy, musty mahogany type with dark pale brown notes. Good taste, not stellar but good. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
6/13/2010. From bottle. Amber color with a short white head. Aromas of dried fruit, malt and caramel. Sweet caramel flavors that shows the alcohol on the finish. Pretty good.
Bells fails to disappoint once again. Very good all around beer. I recommend trying.

Oh, yes. Pours from the bottle a deep coppery brown with just the slightest yellowish head that dissipates quickly. Aroma is caramel and figs and dark fruits and maybe some cherries. Taste is caramel and rich complex malts, sweet but with a significant but not overpowering bitterness. Mouthfeel is medium heavy, nicely carbonated. Leaves a bitter aftertaste. This is slightly more bitter than I would like in this style. A very nice beer. I love Bells.

On tap at Barcade philly. Aroma of nuts, dates, figs, and toffee. Pours brown with a frosty well sized head. Taste is lovely with dark fruits, caramelized sugar, more sugar, and a slight brandy alcohol finish. Not the most complex but darn tasty. Would love to try an old bottle.

UPDATED: DEC 5, 2015 Sometimes, I wonder why it is that I like Bells so much. OhI recallHopslam. And this. And its an interesting parallel: while the Hopslam sports an enviable hop profile, this one stands out on account of its spectacular malt bill. The aroma is dark, sumptuous, and sexy, with dried fruits (figs, raisins, prunes) fighting with overripe ones (cherries, plums) for attention, all on a background of wood, vanilla, brown sugar, molasses, and toffee. The taste is strong, with a a woody, boozy bitter and sweet, fruity undertones. Bitter malts and piney hops linger in the aftertaste. The alcohol is very much perceivable, but it isnt intrusive. The mouthfeel is absolutely fantastic: viscous, creamy, fulfilling. Dangerously close to perfection, although a tad too filling. God, its such a mess. A filthy, sexy mess.

On tap at Whole Foods in Market Square in Fairfax, VA. 

Clear, dark copper brown with off-white head and excellent lacing. 

Aroma of caramel, malt, figs, bourbon and peach. 

Taste of caramel, malt, booze, figs and peach. 

Medium/full body and medium carbonation.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

12 oz bottle. Pours a dark red with small off white head, minimal to no lacing. Aroma is moderate to heavy malts, caramel, dried fruit, moderate hops and wood. Taste is moderate to heavy bitter, moderate sweet, hops. Long finish. Body is medium to heavy. Texture is oily. Alcohol is present throughout.

On tap at the abbey. Pours dark brown with no head. Aroma is caramel and booze. Flavor is sweet and roasty, earthy and nutty with a big boozy burn. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Aroma is great. Malt, caramel, molasses and rasins. Taste is big malt, caramel and rasin. Actually tastes like rasin bread on the finish. Amazing!

Bottle poured into a snifter. From notes. Dont remember the batch number, but it is a newer batch. Dark fermented fruits, caramel and toffee, slight hop bitterness. Still on the hot side. Good, but needs some age on it.

aroma: hot caramel, mission figs, and maraschino cherries are balanced by floral hops. appearance: dark, ruby-brown. off-white head. amazing lacing: foam makes a delicate arch on the glass and breaks down into a uniform line of alcohol beads. taste; this is where its a little upsetting. almost too sweet, with the caramel giving way easily to the sweet fig taste. but ends with a harsh bitterness that stays and stays. palate: sticky with average carbonation. bitter finish.

UPDATED: AUG 19, 2014 Bottle: Deep, muddy copper & brown-ish; solid, opaque body with a small, creamy, tan film that has very good retention. Aroma is full of booze-soaked raisins, brunt brown sugar, rum, bitter black cherries, and some finishing floral & hoppy notes, a little obscure and lost in the malty mix. Taste includes a warming alcohol presence thats tamed by sweet raisins, plums, dark figs, caramelized & almost burnt sugar. Hops are more vibrant on the palate, nearly citric at times with a tight, bitter bite on the very back end. Thick, syrupy body, chewy mouth feel. Totally delicious beer, and one of the best barley wines you can still get in a six pack.

Listed as "Bells Old Ale" on their brewery taplist. I understand that this is a different Old Ale than Third Coast, even though RateBeer has deemed it an alias recently. Tap @ Bells: Deep rustic copper and cloudy, ruby-red; thin eggshell head. Aroma of raisins, figs, and booze-soaked dates. Strong brandy and wine-like alcohol presence in both aroma and flavor. Very potent, sherry and brandy heat in the throat. Sweetness helps to cut the burn a bit; grapes, raisins, plums. Sweet malt in the form of caramel, sticky toffee, and butter.
