Astringency in the finish with a bitter bite. Heavy, sticky, oily mouth feel with low carbonation. Great beer, just a little too immature and perhaps too hot to love. Even sipping can be a tough exercise. Tasty though, and would be grand if mellowed out a bit.

2009 batch. Dark brown pour with some sediment. Aromas of toffee, caramel, roasted malts, and coffee. Big roasted flavor with coffee notes and lots of dark fruit. It almost tastes like a cross between a stout and a barleywine. Very complex. Slightly dry finish at first but sweetens as it warms. Little warmth from the abv comes through in the finish as well. Great beer!
On tap at bells ec,Great carmel and maple aroma... similar malt flavor, really good!!!
Delicous barleywine. Very fruity with a wonderful aroma and leaves a nice sticky taste in your mouth.

Bottle. Poured a dark, somewhat hazy brown color with a small off-white head. Aroma is caramel notes, malts, lots of sweet dried fruits in this one. Brown sugars, maple and malts round this one out. A but heavy on the booze, this one would probably age quite well but is a little sweet and hot for me.
Draft at Reno's east. Deep burgundy with a big, beige head. Dark fruit and candy. Sweet, sticky and resiny.

Deep prune color with one finger creamy white head. Aroma is pure dark fruit with a bit of yeast. Flavor is just a bit lacking, opens with dark fruit but finishes with some woody acidity and generic sweetness. Not a bad beer, but perhaps needs age to be great.

Hazy copper/cider color; Medium slightly creamy body; Aroma of toasted sweet malt, caramel/toffee, spicy hops, & fruit; Flavor of sweet malt, caramel/toffee, molasses, dark fruit, and spicy hops; Warm finish; Nicely balanced; Very good.

Bottle received by my summer secret santa. Thank you jsquire! Pours hazy wooden brown with a rather small frothy brownish beige head that quickly dissipates while leaving a small trace on the glass. Smell is sweet and malty with caramel, biscuits, toffee, golden syrup, brandy-like alcohol, wood and grapefruit rinds. Taste is sweet, heavy bitter, malty and herbal with biscuits, caramel, toffee, lemon balm, heavy peppermint, freshly cut grass, pine needles, grapefruit rinds and alcohol. Mouthfeel is tiny round, astringent, boozy and medium to full bodied. Finish is slightly sweet and slightly bitter with caramel, biscuits, alcohol, lemon balm, peppermint and grapefruit rinds. Nice smell supported by a taste that is way too astringent bitter. It mellows out a little as it gets warmer but still too bitter.

So damn good. Pours a rich murky brown color with a thick tan head and aroma of caramel and brown sugar. Taste is amazing, big body of caramel malts, brown sugar, hints of brandy, and dark fruit with a hint of hop bitterness in the end. Vanilla tones included. Stock up on this one.

Batch 9458 from 2009. Thanks Bells batch finder!
Aroma is fairly malty with some dark caramel, toffee, and hints of scholars and roast. Some fruitiness with cherries, raisins, fig and plum. A light sherry note is also present. Pours a fairly dark brown with light amber highlights and a small, medium thickness tan head that recedes fairly quickly to the edges. No lacing but moderately big legs. Flavor is big on malt and fruit. Initially it's caramel and toffee but that turns into chocolate and roast but then becomes toasted bread. The fruit is more prevalent upfront with cherries and plums while the finish has more raisin and prune. Moderately strong bitterness in finish but no hop flavor. Light alcohol spice in the finish works with the toasted bread and raisins. Mouthfeel is medium full bodied with medium low carbonation. Low astringency and moderate alcohol warmth. A slight stickiness in the finish. Overall a fairly nice old ale with some nice malt character and complimentary fruit notes. I like the way the beers character changes so much throughout a single sip. This one is showing oxidation as I found it in a box that's been sitting in my cellar for at least two years, but the oxidation is light and sherry-like. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours amber, murky, finger tan thick creamy head. Aroma bready malt, lots of sweet caramel and toffee, slight roast, no hop. Taste surprising slight hop bitterness up front, then huge bready, sweet caramel and toffee, sweet and bitter linger, with a slight alcohol presence. Mouth feel is medium full, creamy, low carbonation, slight hop spice, bit of alcohol heat and astringency, sweet finish. Overall very interesting beer, lots of flavors, combine well, the nice hop presence balanced out the sweet malt, very well crafted big beer.
Pours deep amber with tan head. Sweet caramel, candy. Taste is thick in body but sweet boozy caramel, candy and malty. Very smooth. Excellent.
Bit of sweetness, bit of hard candy, solid barleywine flavors. Noting crazy or unique but a solid BW.

Vintage 2012

Pours a brownish-red with plenty of yeasty particulates visible. Thin white head that leaves a decent amount of lace. 

The aroma is very malty on the top with a pretty hoppy finish, with sweet undertones. 

The taste is a little bitter on the front, and pretty much what you'd expect to get of you had mixed an old ale and a barleywine together. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Draft @ Bells. Pours a murky brownish amber. Strong taste of sweet malt, dark fruit, pine and booze.

Deep brown tinged with amber, thin beige lacing. Pleasant grape and apple juice aroma, with hints of vanilla, caramel, and wet bread dough. Complex blend of fruit sweetness, tannin-like bitterness, and a hint of tartness. Smooth, a little spiciness, and fairly full-bodied. Long residual bitterness in the finish. 2007 vintage.

Dark brown pour. Not much of a head, at all. No lacing. Looks flat. Roasted barley and raisin aroma. Sweet raisin taste. Some molasses and malt. Some vanilla as well. Alcohol is hidden well. Nice warming beer.

Pour is hazy brown/amber with a very thin head. Nose is slight caramel and malt. Taste has nice malt backbone with light hop notes. Over all not a very overfly flavorful barley wine. More boozy burn notes than flavor. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours a dark mahogany. The beer is not clear. Slight red tinges around the edge of the glass. Hardly any head, and what is there is an off white ring. Huge alcohol legs on the glass. The aroma is big notes of caramel, raisinsm, toffee, dates and figs. Slight alcohol hint. The taste starts very sweet, very nice. Rolls through caramel, toffee, dark fruits. Finishes with a hop bitterness. This was bottled in October of 2012. The hops could mellow a bit more. The alcohol warms the entire body. Excellent beer. The second barley wine Ive ever had. Its also the best!

Bottle. Pours a dark clear mahogany with creamy beige head. Aroma of tootsie roll, butterscotch, dark fruit. Flavor has some great butterscotch notes complemented by booze and dark fruit. Slight alcohol bite with lingering butterscotch flavor. Balanced, rich, slightly boozy, and really good.

Pours reddish brown with a small, quick dissipating tan head.  Aroma is caramel, toffee, earthy and woody.  Taste is sweet.  Medium bodied with a smooth mouth feel, almost creamy at times.  Excellent.

Reddish-amber with an off-white head. Aroma is dark fruit, toffee, alcohol and bread. Flavor is dark fruit, caramel, toffee and grapes. The alcohol is noticeable. Medium mouthfeel and medium carbonation.

Bottle. Pours a deep ambery-brown with fluffy off white head, mad crazy lacing. Nose is heavy on the dates, figs, brown sugar, caramel, malty goodness. Mouth is full bodied and slightly creamy, heavy caramel up front, some candied orangey notes, vanilla, maple syrup, malty, malty, malty, with some bitterness towards the middle and long into the afterglow I like this a lot, so its going to be hard to sit on the rest of this six pack and let it cellar at least until the leaves fall and its time for a new hockey season to begin.
Dark brown pour...wow that 10%pops out at ya. In a good way.. Super strong but yet i could drink this all day.. One of the best barley wines ive had

Cream foam head, dark pour out of a bottle. Been drinking all night but this was a creamy smokey good impression!!! Good stuff 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

12oz bottle. Pours a dark reddish brown color with almost no head. Aroma of bready malts, caramel, spices, and some light fruits. Taste is bready/biscuity malts, caramel, apples, some other fruity flavors.

Pours very hazy and dark with almost no head.  Had strong aromas of plumb, raisins, cherry, alcohol, and bubblegum.  Very malty and yeasty on the tongue, with a noticeable alcohol burn and had a decent bitterness to it.  Pretty big bodied beer.  While it could have benefited from more age, it was great at 6 months anyways.

I found this guy at some random liquor store an hour away from my house when i was bored one day looking to buy some beer. It was aged 6 months in the bottle. It pours a very dark amber color. It looks completely black and opaque at some angles, but at others you can see it is SLIGHTLY translucent and amber. There is very little head that completely went away quickly. This beer has my absolute favor aroma Ive smelled in any beer. Its smell is evenly split up between caramel, chocolate, fruityness, and brown sugar. The taste is also phenomenal and extremely complex. Its very similar to the aroma but it has a nice alcoholic warmth to it. It also has a little dark chocolate and burnt caramelly which makes for one of my favorite beers. Ive always been a fan of barely wines since Ive first had one and this one tops the cake. At almost $4 for a 12oz bottle its a little expensive, but still definitely affordable. If Im ever in the area where I found this at, or see it anywhere else, Ill most likely be getting it.

Drank this bottle just after its 6 month birthday. Poured a deep dark brown amber with a foamy white beige head and a little lacing. This beer has THE BEST aroma I have ever encountered. Fruity molasses and brown sugar, a hint of chocolate and some hops. Flavor is marvelous, sweet fruity flavor, subtle hints of dark chocolate, a lot of molasses here and brown sugar with a mostly dark chocolate and brown sugar aftertaste that lingers for a while after you drink it. It has just enough hop presence to make it refreshing. This beers mouthfeel is the only place I could ever complain about this spectacular brew. With a body this molassassy youd think it would be a tad bit thicker but its not. Its a fair bit thin. Bells has done it again and brewed up another phenomenal beer. This is one of my favorite barley wines and is definitely worth a try if you get a chance.

Light amber color, cloudy, unfiltered with some slight sediment. Long lasting head. Flavor hops but also fruity, manot toffee, not a lot of bitterness. Mouthfeel is pleasant, complex with a touch of alcohol warmth. This is excellent. Great beer to cellar.

Bottle from Bells Brewery. POUR: Barely any head. APPEARANCE: A beautifulggolden amber color with mild carbonation. SCENT: A faint warm smell that is not too bousy as some barley wines contain. TASTE: Smooth and robust in flavor. The initial taste is pleasing; however, an alcoholic taste lingers in the aftertaste which definitely affects the palate-not very pleasing.  Overall its a pretty good beer and it tastes better in warmer temperatures (45 F-50F). I would recommend buying this brew again-especially for one of those horrible mid-week days when the stress begins piling on and you need a break.

11 vintage pours a merky red brown no head alot of sed nose is slight boozy still for the 11 dark cherries plum and raisin leather dark fruit skins toasty taste is dates and kinda flat sugary a little like copper still very good

UPDATED: JUN 17, 2014 Drank from a snifter. Pours a very dark and almost opaque ruby/amber with a nice ring of head that builds as the beer sits in a glass. Good amount of carbonation and lacing. Nose has a lot of yeast and dark fruit up front. Alcohol and bread, mixed with plum, cherry, and caramel. Mouth is very bitter and malty with a strong presence of alcohol. More dark fruits mixed with a subtle roastiness. Somewhat dry finish.
Bottle. Dark mahogony beer with a dark cream head. Caramel aroma. Caramel and toffee flavor with light dark fruit. Medium-plus bodied. Caramel and toffee lingers with light dark fruit.

UPDATED: JUN 20, 2014 Bottled 4/6/12. Rated 4/10/13. Clear Ruby reddish brown. Medium creamy beige head, lasting soapy topping. Inviting, almost dessert-like, aroma. Sweet, lightly fruity, rich caramel - I want to bite into it. Full body but smooth and soft, some booze, lasting hop finish balanced out by rich maltiness. Most drinkable barley wine Ive had to date. --------    Update:     6/20/14  ----- Aged more than 2 years now. Malty aroma, lots of bread crust, caramel, dried dark fruit, port, perhaps still a hint of old pine. Flavor follows as well. Body has lightened up to a lighter medium. Less carbonated. Fairly dry finish. Interesting development since last time.

Initially drying, then mositioning, then warm alcohol-like burning upon first couple of sips.  Strong aroma of caramel, wine, malts.  Roasty.  
Becomes much smoother the more I drink.

10/12/12 bottle date, so this one is 6 months old. Pours deep brown with a reddish hue. Tannish yellow one finger head. Aroma of caramel malts, some sweet dark fruit, and a bit of booze. Thick viscous mouthfeel. Almost have to chew this, which I was not expecting. All malt flavor with sweet figs and prunes up front that meld into an interesting ever so slightly bitter finish. A lingering caramel covered fruit left on the palate. Low carbonation. A real winter warmer.

Smells like oxidizing metal. Taste is mouthcoating medicine. Alarming to the back of the throat once the session commences. Funny the descrip on this site says its the brandy of beers, it is not. Its not even the sherry. Way too fresh. I know Bells has a big following and, I havent recovered from the time I rated expedition as a loser for a lager lover. That time I got lots of not so nice bmail. Regardless, this has me on the same streak. Im not sure if these american BW are trying to be old world, but their not. How could these american wannah beez ever be in the same category as Lees or Thomas Hardys. Better create a new category - American Barley wine, must be a new category. Otherwise, overall just a big medicinal alky mouth coating thing which is way over the tops and makes me dizzy near the end of the session.  Although Im not an expert, I dont think any amount of aging could make me think this stuff would ever be good enough for anything but a 2. Difficult seething negative nasty nellie, as with most big ass american wannah beez barley wines.
user_location: Beaver Valley, Beaver County, Pennsylvania, USA

text:
Tried a 2011 and a 2012 side by side.  The newer version had much more of a bite, old version had definitely mellowed out and has more of a smoothness.  Older version is sweeter and I prefer the more aged version.  Noticeable color difference between the two as well.  

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle from trade with umich03jm. Interested in this since its rated high in the style, this bottle looks to be about a year old. Pours medium brown with a low, weak head. Aroma is malt with big carmel notes, and a hint of alcohol. Flavor is pretty well balanced between malt and hop bitterness, sort of along Bigfoot type barley wine. Significant alcohol burn, but doesnt detract. Not very complex, but more here than just sweet malt and bitterness. Flavor is fairly intense, almost overdone for my tastes. Looks like this brew would hold to to aging very well. Good sipper, but probably would benefit from my cellar time, and more complexity. Thanks for sending, JM.

Poured a dark muddy color from a bottle dated 10/12/12. There was no head whatsoever and lots of sediments floating around. Aroma was sweet, toffee caramel. It smelled sweeter than it tasted. I was surprised how hoppy and dry this beer finished. It is full bodied and the alcohol really comes through once it warms up some. Ill put a few bottles aside to age for a while and taste the difference.

Bottled 4/6/12. Consumed 3/24/13. Pours a deep red-amber with a soft, dense off-white head. Aroma is caramel, grass, fruit, wood, some bitter hops, sweetness. Taste is sweet, spicy, alcohol, dark fruit, floral, caramel; long but mild bitter chocolate finish. Chewy mouth feel. Medium carbonation. Dense, coating lacing. Extremely well-hidden alcohol. Very drinkable. At 10.2% abv, this could really sneak up on you. Impressive.

Bottle thanks to my little brother.  Line at Hard Liver was too long to stomach, so decided to enjoy my own barley wine night at home.  Big beautiful caramel and toffee aroma.  Dark amber/red color, thin white ring of head.  Almost like candy in aroma.  Mild oxidation.  Surprisingly potent citrus/pine hop bitterness, with great underlying caramel sweetness.  Slick texture, medium body, moderate carb. Overall:  above average barley wine.

12 oz. bottle a gift from Zach. Bottled 9/14/11. Pours a thick beige head, with Belgian lacing, over a reddish brown (SRM 20), particle laden body.....nose is plum, treacle, raisin, brown sugar,.....taste is plum, toffee/caramel, very heavy sherry tones, finishing with with a harsh bitter bite....mouth feel thick, sticky, lightly astringent, alcohol heat present, carbonation low. This is quite harsh and alcoholic given its age. Particle laden as it is, it is most probably mishandled and is obviously over the hill, which is a shame, given the remnants of a huge complex malt backbone. Rating is of this bottle. BJCP 7/2/13/4/7
Definitely not a favorite.  The beer was a bit cloudy and almost reddish.  Seemed very hoppy, but did have a bit of kick to it.

12oz bottle from TW&B. Bottled 10/12/12. Pours a rich mahogany, slightly opaque, with no head. Nice boozy aroma, with nice notes of sherry and bread esters. Taste is complex with a great hoppy bite. Notes of gingerbread, booze, and sherry. Delicious!!

UPDATED: APR 21, 2013 Draft at Farmers Cabinet and later Khyber Pass. Red brown pour with a small foamy head that leaves some nice lace. Rich vanilla caramel. Raisin pie. Spicy sugared figs. High ABV is felt but the finish is mostly smooth. Full body. Syrupy, but lots of nice wood notes. Red and dark brown fruit.

Ive been sitting on this one for about 3 months now.

Very Dark Brown. Sweet Caramelized Malts and mild Citrus notes are prevalent in the nose. Flavor is a mixture of Caramel, Malts, Hops, Toffee and Resin. The flavor is offset a bit by the rather strong booziness. Thick bodied with mild carbonation.

Its a decent Barleywine, but it just needs a little less booziness to the flavor

Bottle. Dark clear, rubby/ copper color with a thin creamy beige head. Aroma is toffee with caramel and some nuts, slight alcohol. Flavor is nutty, caramel malts, sherry and some slight chocolate notes, bitter aftertaste. Full palate, warming but not (overly) alcoholic, coates the mouth with flavor. Nice nightcapper.

UPDATED: AUG 31, 2014 Bottle->Snifter.  Dark brown with lite tan head.  Aroma has malt, toffee, dark fruit, booze.  Flavor: malt, dark fruit, spices.  Finish is somewhat dry with lingering sweetness.  Complex and well done.

Bottle poured into tulip. Appearance is very dark brown, almost black, with a lasting medium tan head. Aroma is rich malt, caramel, toffee, and dark fruits. The taste mostly follows the nose, with some alcohol taste apparent, too. Very rich, complex flavor. Mouth is light carbonation and smooth, almost oily feel. Overall, its pretty tasty, though the alcohol taste doesnt completely suit me.

Muddy iced tea color with minimal off white head. Almost a smell of sweet tea as well with brown sugar, brandy. A sweet spicy kick to the mouth at first with noticeable booziness. A distinct bitter lingers afterwards. Not as complex as I hoped but not bad overall. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours a clear mahogany color with small tan head and decent lacing.  Caramel and malt aroma pervasively with some brandy soaked fig and raisin.  Taste follows aroma with the caramel and roasted malt.  Dark fruits and grassy, lingering bitterness from hops that was a surprise.  Alcohol is apparent in flavor and has a slight warming effect.  Mouthfeel is medium/full with moderate carbonation and leans toward being dry with a bit of residual sweetness.  A good barleywine that was more bitter than I like and more than expected.  Curious to see how this ages.  I expect I will like it more when the hops have dropped off a bit. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
hazzy brown/ruby color, aroma of toffee, caramel, dark fruits, same flavors, nice bitterness, boozy warm finish, med body, smooth and rich, very enjoyable

Oct 2012 bottle to tulip glass.  Pours a slightly hazy reddish brown color with a decent off-white head.  Strong malt aroma with a little toffee and just a hint of alcohol.  Taste is malt with a sweetness that gives way to an unexpected, biting bitterness.  A bit of dark fruit and some toffee also.  A full, thick mouthfeel that is slightly oily and then dry at the end.  I found the sweetness to be a little cloying for my tastes and I did not enjoy the bitterness, however, this is just a matter of personal preference.  

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

12 ounce bottle.  Pours a cloudy reddish brown with a small off-white head.  Aroma of fruit, malt, molasses, and caramel.  Taste is malt, dark fruit, molasses, caramel, spices, and wood.  Very warming.  Very good.

Pours a dark prune juice colour. Aromas are intense dark rye bread dough. Lots of sweet raisin and prune aromas too. More of the same malty rye driven flavours. Nice dark fruit sweetness with just enough bitterness on the finish to keep it honest. Really good ale.

Very nice, easily my favorite barley wine, a style I'm not usually fond of. There's an unusual toffee flavor coming through that is just fabulous. This is on top of a solid malty base that has caramel notes as well. ABV is perfect at a few ticks over ten. Would love to see a chocolate version of this. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Slighty bitter . Hint of chocolate. Small foamy head that doesnt hold long.
Medium thickness in taste.
Dark carmel color. Good beer.

Bottle. Thanks to mike12da. Big buttery malt aroma, wit some fumes. Thick copper-brown.  Heavy concentrated sugar and caramel malt; mid gains legs with the hopping; final moves into very nice balance. Medium body. Great stuff. Smooth and rich.
This bottle had about a year of age on it. When fresh I found this to be fairly harsh, but with a year on it, it has turned into a really excellent example of the style.
Dark red pour with a small off white head.  Aroma of candied fruit and some caramel malts.  Taste is toffee along with the aroma flavors and a solid finish.  Good stuff!

Pours a deep brownish red color. Completely opaque with a very small head and sticky lacing. Aroma is malted barley, cherries, bread, and caramel. Taste is slightly bitter from the hops although there isnt much hop taste here. Its a malt bomb with cherries and bitter hops. Decent but not really my cup of tea. A little too rich/sweet for me but a good winter beer.
Bottle. Pours dark brown with no head. Aroma is malts and booze with a matching taste. Some sweet fruits like plum and brown sugar in there as well.

UPDATED: JAN 27, 2013 Thick and weighty on palate. Well crafted, full-body, smooth malty taste. Great aroma and aftertaste. A slight hint of heat on the back-end to remind you this bottle contains 10.2% alc.

[4744-20120818] 355mL bottle. Spiced whiskey toasted malt wood aroma. Hazy, brown body with no lasting head. Caramelly sweet toasted malt flavour. Full body. Roasty and interesting, might be a little old. (7/3/7/3/14) 3.4
(@ Campground Brewdown 2012, Millmont, PA)
Overheard: "This is not the cheese you are looking for."

Fresh bottle.  Dark chestnut brown body, large off-white head, solid lacing.  Nose is caramel, dark fruits (figs and raisins), molasses, and some toffee.  Flavor is similar with a sweet and earthy malt profile dominating.  Full bodied, appropriate carbonation, well-masked heat, sweet (but not cloying) finish.

Poured from a tap into a tullip glass.  Pours a nice dark amber color with minimal off white head that doesnt last too long.  Aroma is nice and sweet of dark fruit, malt and caramel. Flavor is sweet malt with still some fruity notes along with the malt and alcohol.  It has  bitter finish that lasts a decent while.  Mouthfeel is full and average carbonation.  Overall this is a delicious beer.

12oz bottle - pours dark amber with khaki head and great lacing. Nose is dark fruit, rye/barley, and caramel. Flavor adds alcohol and something akin to chocolate. Moderately sweet. Cant wait until this warms up. Definitely a sipper. Dry, granted I played in the snow this afternoon in a place similar to the label. Grapefruit aftertaste for some more obvious bitterness.
This has a strong malty wood flavor with a moderately bitter and warm aftertaste. You dont really notice the abv in the flavor.
Pours a dark reddish color with a large light brown foamy head. Notes of port, cookies, figs, and plastic. I would re-categorize this beer to old ale.

Poured from a 12 oz onto a brandy snifter. Pours a beautiful brownish red hue. Only about a half inch of off white head that quickly dissipates into a whisp of lacing on the surface. Fantastic aroma of mold fruit, cherries, brandy, cinnamon and candy. Real, real nice. Mouthfeel is slightly syrupy and a bit too much carbonation. Taste is a little disappointing. Cinnamon, fruit, brandy and earth predominate. But there's an underlying bitterness that's there always. Kinda off-putting. Oh well, coulda been great. Lets see if a year or so in the cellar will fix the bitter taste. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Draft to taster. Looks solid; a semi-transparent amber with foamy off-white head. Smells and tastes sweet and malty with a good mouthfeel. A good example of the style.

UPDATED: DEC 19, 2016 Been aging a bottle for a couple of years... overall still very vibrant, pours a nice frothy head, taste and palate have been stable... only real difference, is that the flavors may have melded into a more cohesive flavor. Still excellent.
12/21/12 - On tap @ Silver Creek. Pours a hazy dark, nut brown, no head.  Aroma slight hint of licorice and overall roastyness. Flavors of molasses, spice, vanilla, shortbread. Medium body and nice mouth feel with sustained flavor over time. Overall, a beautiful melding of flavors to create  its own profile. Very nice.

Bottle thanks to Jstax. Pours a deep copper color with a finger of sticky foam. On the nose this beer is big and complex... rich toffee, earthy autumn woods,  fig and raisin... the complexity continues on the palate. Big chewy mouthfeel with a journey of flavors; molasses, leather, walnuts, licorice and some bitter booze on the finish that lingers into some earthy woodsy caramel notes.

12oz bottle. Poured a murked out amber color with small off white head, lacing wasnt worth noting. Aromas of mollases, figs, cherry. Taste was sweet sugars, caramel malts, dark fruit, and light hops. Nice light bitterness from hops towards the finish. Medium to heavy bodied but in a good way. Nice barley.

2010 12oz bottle thanks to nimbleprob. Murky brown with a nice biege head that completely disappears. Somewhat musty fruit and sweetish malt, brown sugar, some molasses, vanilla, banana, alcohol. Full body, mild carbonation, balanced sweetness with a hint of bitterness, alcohol is present but not overwhelming, becomes dry with a lipsmacking layer on the palate. Delicious.

Bottle shared at the Christmas party 
Appearance: Cloudy amber with a small white head, no lacing 
Aroma: Toasted malts, figs and woody 
Taste: Dark fruit, figs, vanilla and woody 
Very nice.

Pours a murky, deep amber/brown color.  Aroma is of malts, brown sugar, figs, licorice, and molasses.  Medium bodied.  Flavor is of sweeter malts, oak, fig, vanilla, brandy, and dark fruit.  Leaves an oak, brandy and fig finish.  A nice and pleasant surprise.  Well done.
Excellent!  Rating/drinking this one fresh, but some will go into the cellar for sure.  Clean flavors from the malt and a distinct but not overpowering hoppiness from the finish.  Warming and earthy.

Poured vigorously into the Spiegelau tulip glass.

Aroma - lovely notes of caramel, spice, citrus, and cooking stock.

Appearance - dark amber color with a white head that subsides quickly.

Taste - nice caramel notes with a hint of bitter on the finish that lingers and lends another taste.

Palate - full bodied with an oily mouthfeel that coats the tongue with a virtually no carbonation present after pouring and finishes like a fine vintage port. A great effort here.
36cl, American brew, from De Bierkoning Amsterdam, complex brew, malty/bitter and slightly spicy/woody, balanced, hazy, small head, good Winter brew, yet expensive!

Clear deep mahogany pour with a tight bubbly tan head and bits of lace. Aroma of brown sugar, toffee and caramel malts, dark fruits light bread with some earthy hops in the background. Sweet entry with roasted nuts, sweet brown sugar, dried dark fruits, leather leading into a nice earthy bitterness. Medium full bodied with lower carbonation. Not bad.
Bottle. Dark brown amber with cream head. Aroma is dark fruit, leather and molasses. Flavor is the same with a dry somewhat boozy finish. Nice barleywine.
Interesting, but not my style. Boozy, but fairly attenuated and dry. Its also a little bit harsh.

Pours cloudy amber-brown with a thin, light tan head.  Aroma of sweet, sweet malty candy, dried fruit, figs, dates.  Flavor follows, with dried fruit and especially figs...sweet but not cloying.  While not especially complex, this is deeply flavorful and very enjoyable.

Roasted sweet malts, light coffee bitterness, toffee and dried dark fruits. Aftertaste is lasting dry, bitter hops and some bakers chocolate. Not very complex, but smooth and warming. The hops are pleasantly earthy. Alcohol is well hidden.
Bottle. Pours a dark murky brown with a moderate off-white head. Very malty nose with some red wine notes to it. Taste is fairly strong with some alcohol notes in here.

S: Molasses, toasted caramel, slight hops. Very welcoming, complex and intense
A: Deep dark ruby brown. Slight light brown head, great lacing 
T: Malt bomb! Compatible to Curmudgeon but more aggressive. Has a lot of sweetness from the molasses and Carmel, but there is a wonderful addition of hop notes
P: yes
O: Great beer - awesome compromise to the hop monsters 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottled on 04/2012. Dark murky brown in color with little too no head. Not much lacing left on glass. Overwhelming barley malt smell with some dried dark fruits on the background. Taste is of roasted malts, carmel, toffee up front with some sweet fruit flavor and dry finish on the back end. Creamy mouthful, definitely a sipper. Not bad....I plan on keeping the rest of my six pack in the basement for a couple of years.

UPDATED: FEB 24, 2013 From a 12 oz bottle shared at home.  Pours a cloudy dark brown with ana tan head.  Aroma of  dark cherries.  Flavors of roasted malts, toffee and booze.  Light bitter finish.

Update Feb 2013.  On draft at the Mad Fox Barley Wine Festival, Falls Church VA.  Pours a cloudy amber with an off white head.  Stronger hop character than the bottled version.  Bitter finish.

Pours a very small head. This beer has an amazing aroma with caramel and dark fruity notes.The taste is similar to the aroma, and it has a somewhat syrupy mouth feel with a slight booziness. Overall it is an excellent beer, I will definitely buy it again.
Nice beer great aroma to it for a barely wine you wont go wrong with this beer better on draft at the bells pub

Aroma is sweet fruit, a mix of apple and cherry. Appearance is a deep amber, thin, light brown head. The first taste you get is overwhelming booze. You get some flavor at the back end which resemble the aroma, but its hard to decipher between the boozy bitterness. I am drinking this fresh, though, maybe I should have aged it. But I shouldnt have to. The mouthfeel is ok, but its hard to keep in there because of the booziness. Overall, I probably should have expected this, as the last barley wine I had was hard to drink as well, but I expected better from Bells on this. Oh well.

UPDATED: JUL 28, 2014 Fresh 2012 bottle poured in snifter.  Pours a dark murky mahogany color with nearly no head.  Aroma is maple syrup, toffee, raisins, tobacco, booze, and some light fruitiness.  Taste is moderately sweet and very boozy.  Taste is not nearly as complex as the aroma.  Only getting a slight raisin and syrup taste because the brandy alcohol flavor takes over.  Maybe its too fresh and needs to age a bit still.  Finish has a slight bitterness and moderate alcohol burn.  Slightly disappointed by this beer.  Hopefully it tastes better with some age.

I smell sweet caramel malts, barley, figs, and slight fruit notes. The appearance is nothing out of this world even though I did dig the dark hazy brown color. As for the taste, it is great. The third coast is sweet maybe too sweet but it tends to balance out with a kick in the end. I tasted minor hops & bitterness during the end. That is why I enjoyed this brew. It is just right not too sweet & not too bitter. The hops and alcohol content seem to put this drink into check. I will enjoy this brew again for sure.

Bottle: Poured a deep mahogany brown with hints of orange embers at the bottom. The head was thin and beige in color. Aroma is sweet with malts and barley. Taste is strong with alcohol and hops, but mellows to a sweet caramel malt finish.

AGED FOR TWO YEARS AND NINE MONTHS.  Aroma is of maple syrup and alcohol.  Poures dark brown with a cream colored head.  Complex sweet and nutty flavor whith a bite at the finish and a nice full body.

Pours a deep burnt rust color, with a very minimal, and quickly receding white head. Aroma is minimal as well, mostly caramel and floral hop notes. Taste follows the nose, and is less than amazing. Too much gritty hop presence makes this score lower than most people seem to grade it out. Im hoping that the 4 bottles I have left age graciously, in the cellar they go for a few years.

Tap. Pours deep brown with a medium tan head and nice lacing. Strong aroma of caramel, toffee, rye bread, notes of pine. Flavor is medium sweet caramel, toffee, prune, molasses with a medium bitter finish. Warming alcohol far finish. Rich and creamy in the mouth. Very nice enjoyable beer.

Pours dark ruby/brown with a creamy head and soapy lacing. Smells of figs, licorice, cabernet, and brown sugar. Tastes a tad sour with brown sugar, oak, tobacco, and toasted malt with a touch of hot alcohol. Pretty solid barleywine.

Bottle. Pours a medium hazy brown with a very slight light brown head that quickly disappears. Aroma is of burnt caramel with some sweetness and roasted coffee. Taste is a slight bit of oxidation, harsh toffee and a lingering sweetness. Some bitterness finishes this one out. Overall, a middle of the road barley wine that might not have been cellared in optimal conditions or was just off. Lots going on here that isnt bad just that the oxidation was up front and off putting.
user_location: Morro Bay via Orange County, California, USA

text:
I split a bottle of this with Matt the other night.

Batch 7800
Vintage 31 Jan 2007

A: Dark sunburst hued with a small head. Even though the head isnt that big, it lasts a long time. Staying power baby. Also, Im noticing an abundance of particulates meandering about the beer like space cadets. Whatever. Im not afraid of sediment.

S: Sweet malts, dark fruits, alcohol.

T: This beer has really smoothed out nicely in the nearly four years it has spent in my cellar. Its considerably less hot then a fresh bottle. Dark fruits and caramels soaked in alcohol flavors. Pretty good.

M: Good carbonation level, which is always nice on an aged bottle. Alcohol definitely still present, though subdued. Decent feel.

D: Overall, a good brew. I definitely recommend aging this beer, as it noticeably improves with time. Best in small quantities.

Had a nice balance between the bready malts and caramel/slight fruity flavors. Alcohol very well hidden for a 10.2% barely wine, also not syrupy. The problem I have with most barleywines is that they are too syrupy and too boozey. This definitely doesnt encounter either of those problems. Definitely recommend trying it.

Bottle from trade and drank at Penner with DTM.  Im pretty confused about the "old ale" in the name, but it is indeed a barley wine. I found this one to be quite bitter with regards to the hop character. Aroma gave me the rope-a-dope. Not nearly as enjoyable as the DFH Olde School, although I absolutely love Bells offerings on the whole. We did drink it at a temperature above 55 degrees, so that couldve been it. Very good beer.
Bottle: Solid barley wine. Tasty, smooth and special. there was some floaties as expected. cant wait to get my hands on more of this

A - Pours a dark amber-brown color with a half-finger of frothy off-white head. The head fades down fairly quickly leaving behind some lacing.

S - Aroma is full of rich sweet caramelized malts, with some dark fruits, molasses, other dark malts, a bit of light fruit, and some booze.

T - Starts off with a mix of sweet caramelized sugars and caramel malts with some molasses and some raisin and other dark fruits. Through the middle, some more dark caramel malt flavor comes through with some light fruits and some citrus hops. The finish is a mix of caramelized malts and residual sugars with some dark fruit, a bit of citrus hop, and some booze.

M - Full bodied with moderate carbonation. Feels smooth and a bit thick with a sweet and warming finish.

D - Very drinkable. Really nice American Barleywine with a really great malt profile and enough body to balance things out.
Pours a thick dark amber with sweet malt notes.  Very sticky sweet with layered nuances.  The finish gets a bit medicinal but finishes very long.

As good as it gets. Advertised as an old ale, I give it a barley wine. Pours amber with a thin head. The aroma is malt and malt with just a bit of hops. The flavor is hops with just a bit of malt. Perfect together.
UPDATED: JUN 1, 2012 Aroma of dried fruits.  Deepest darkest of amber colors.  Bit of a white head.  Very smooth on the mouthfeel.  Boozy, malty and fruity.

I usually enjoy most offerings from Bells Brewery, but not this one. First of all, dont call a barley wine an old ale! Theyre two vastly different styles. Aroma was bread, licorice, and fermented raisins. Appearance was dark brown, minimal head and lacing. Taste was not my thing, overbearing flavor of burnt raisins, followed by licorice, and bitter hops. Would not recommend, didnt sit well with my taste buds and was dumped down the drain half way through.

Pours murky brown with a very small white head that recedes very quickly to a few bubbles around the edge of the glass.  Nose is dusty oak bookshelves that have been sitting in an attic for a long time.  Sweet caramel notes, banana, cloves and grass.  Taste is bittersweet up front, but mostly sweet but then gives way to all bitter toward the finish which then takes over to the end.  Mouthfeel is soft and creamy, heavy body with a long aftertaste.

Bottle at home, from my Minneapolis Town Hall glass. Pretty sure this from 2009 or 2010.. Pours deep russet brown, almost murky chocolate brown, very attractive looking beer... Thin tan head, great lacing. A Sharp Looking Brew! Nose is raisin, tobacco, plum, prune, fig, spice, leather. Flavours of molasses, tar, leather, cedar, spice, clove, anise, and more dried fruits, especially prunes and dates. Outstanding mouthfeel, really glad I cellared this one. Fantastic beer!

on tap @ Bennos in beautiful West Allis, WI.deep red pour with a thin tan  head. aroma of toffee, sweet malt, earthy hops and fruit. sweet flavor of dark fruit, caramel and molasses. slick mouthfeel with a lingering sweet toffee finish.i generally prefer a more hop forward barley wine but this one is very good!

Bottle purchased at West Lakeview Liquors in Chicago. Pours a reddish light brown colour, with a light tan head that recedes to a ring rather quickly. Smells sweet caramel, vanilla, a little malt and some banana. Tastes quite sweet and some dark fruits with vanilla and banana. A little bitter bite on the tongue. Super soft and boozy. Awesome.
UPDATED: NOV 24, 2012 Has some big malty caramel and cherry sweet scents. Taste is rather similar with a decent sweetness, finishes pretty smooth
This is very well done.  Sweet, aromatic, and hides the alcohol quite well.

Originally reviewed: 1/14/09. Pours a deep mahogany, with just a bit of light coming through along the edges. 1/4 inch head, that dissipates to a thin sheet. No lacing present. 

Smells of raisins, caramel, wine, with some obvious sweetness. Nice crisp mouthfeel. This leaves a pleasant warming feeling in the stomach. Great for the cold months (even in NC). 

Taste of raisins, plums, caramel, and some grape-like wine characteristics. This is a good beer for sure. Im not an expert in Old Ales by any means, but this is a good one.

This beer was worth the wait. Pouring a crisp, golden body and thin white head, this beer merely looked average. One sniff reveals tropical fruits, grassy notes and hints of fresh honeysuckle. The taste was fruity as well, mainly dried citrus, but the cherry character is what caught the senses. Only with a mild malty finish and slight warmth could you guess the generous ABV.

Bottle.  Pours dark red and a small, off-white head.  Dark malt aroma with caramel, dried fruit and earthy hops.  Flavor is slightly sweet with dark malt, dried fruit, wood and moderate hop notes.  Smooth finish with some hop and alcohol notes.  A great barleywine.

Pours a wonderful brown.  Per Kristina, appearance is a caramel apple.  Taste is a bit acidic, with toffee, quite sour, yet very smooth, with a very a icidic aftertaste with the toffee lingering.  Pleasant and potent.

Beautiful appearance but unexpected aroma and strong alcohol tones overpowers most flavors.  Could be a great beer for some but not me.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

From notes.
Pours a nice ruby red with a thin light khaki head. There is a little Bit of sediment floating around with a small amount of visible carbonation.
Aroma has lots of dark fruit, cherry, plumb, sweet roasted malt, caramel, finished with a bit of booze. 
First sip you get a lot of sweetness on the front of the tongue and the bitterness follows at the back. The taste really stays true to the nose. Lots of dark fruit, sweet malt, caramelized sugar, and a nice hop finish accompanied by booze. 
Mouthfeel is super smooth, leaves a silky feel over the entire mouth. The bitterness of the finish really sticks around on the palate while the alcohol warms on the way down.

12 ounce bottle into snifter, bottled 11/03/2010.  Pours slightly cloudy red orange color with a nice 1 finger dense khaki head with good retention that reduces to a thin cap that lasts.  Some nice spotty lacing on the glass.  Aromas of big caramel, biscuit, herbal, raisin, grape, molasses, pine, and a touch of alcohol.  Nice and well balanced aromas with good strength.  Taste of big caramel, biscuit, herbal, grape, raisin, molasses, brown sugar, pine, wood, and earth.  Fair amount of herbal bitterness on the finish; with lingering notes of caramel, pine, herbal, dark fruit, and molasses for a while.  Fantastic flavor balance and complexity.  Light-medium carbonation and medium-full bodied; with a nice creamy, sticky, and slick mouthfeel.  Nice amount of smoothness, but is definitely a sipper.  Alcohol is well hidden with only a warming after the finish present.  Overall this is a fantastic and complex barleywine.  Very smooth and enjoyable to sip on.

Pours amber-brown in color with a minimal off white head. Its a November 2011 bottle and Im noticing some sediment. Aroma is a very strong vanilla, oddly enough, with some malt fragrances in the background. Full malt flavor with maple syrup up front. Some hop bitterness slides in at the finish. Interesting. Ive had this beer before, but I dont remember it this way. Maybe its 5 months worth of aging. Still good, however.

Pours a cloudy medium amber with a good head and lace.  Taste begins with solid caramel malt which is overcome by a well-balanced dose of hops, and finishes with a nice warm coating of alcohol on top of the caramel.  Well designed, very drinkable (in spite of the abv), and a great beer for any occasion.

Location/Date:Bottle split with Bryan on March 9, 2012.
Appearance: Pours a dark maroon.
Aroma: Aroma is sweet, malty.
Taste: Malt forward with a nice amount of bitterness..
Palate:Medium body, light aftertaste.
Summary: Solid barley wine, really enjoyed the hops.

12 ounce bottle.  Some beers make the others look bad.  This one has all the big flavor, high but hidden abv, foggy orange color, big floral smell, and a complex, deep veggie yet hoppy citrus flavor.  It has it all and its nice about it too, meaning it wont make you wince.  Very good, but hard to find, so grab a bottle of it when you see it.  I look forward to trying it on tap sometime soon.

2010 Bottle (9458). Poured into a Portsmouth tulip.  Dark maroon-brown body with a thin white head that quickly dissipates into light ring around the edges of the glass.  Figs, raisins, plums and cherries fill the nose.  Caramel vanilla notes and some maltiness.  Reminds me a bit of JW Lees Harvest Ale.  Lots of cherry and fig.  The flavor is also very fruity.  Same fruits as the nose.  A bit boozy, but not too in your face.  Sweet maltiness throughout.  Light sherry oxidation.  Light carbonation and fairly smooth body.  However, the body seems a bit thin.  Overall, this is a pretty tasty barleywine.  Reminds me quite a bit of the regular JW Lees Harvest Ale, but not executed quite as well.  Still worth picking up a bottle though if you like the style.

Pours a reddish-brown amber with a thin off white head that dissipates quickly.  The aroma is rich malts, caramels, dark fruit, figs.  The taste is rich malts, medium caramel sweetness, medium hop bitterness, and a boozy finish.  Id be interested to try a bottle thats been aged for a few years, but its pretty good now.

Bottle 12fl.oz. @ home.[ Courtesy of polomagnifico ]. Clear medium to dark red amber colour with a small small, frothy, virtually none lacing, fully diminishing, off-white head. Aroma is moderate to heavy malty, dried fruit, caramel, moderate hoppy, wood notes. Flavour is heavy sweet and bitter with a long duration, alcohol, dried fruit. Body is medium to full, texture is oily, carbonation is flat to soft, finish feel is light alcoholic. [20120103]

Dark reddish-brown color with almost no head. The aroma is a nice balance of malt and hop with neither taking control, but both working in harmony with each other. The taste is just as balanced as the aroma, but stronger in all facets.

UPDATED: SEP 19, 2012 Great tasting barley wine here. Alcohol nicely tucked behind great flavors of raisins and oak. Sweet and strong. Cannot go wrong. Aroma is inviting and a great hint of whats to come. Drinks easily with a nice kick.

Batch 9525.  January 10.  Dark murky mahogany with big, quickly dissipating, off-white head.  Some sediment visible.  Sweet nose of caramel, bright sour cherry,  toffee.  Medium body, decent carbonation, a bit gritty.  Mellow, dark dried fruit flavors with lots of caramel, and a bit of bitterness on the finish.  Too hot when fresh, too gritty now.  My guess is about a year would be perfect.  Still, very good.

From notes.  First reviewed 7/14/2009.  Served on tap at the Eccentric Cafe.

Third Coast Old Ale has a caramel copper color with a thick creamy head. Leaves some lacing down the side of the glass.

Dark fruits, cherries, caramel, and molasses flow into my nose. A very strong, sweet smelling ale, although I would expect this from a barley wine.

Strong raisin and fig flavor throughout. Firm molasses malt taste carries most of the sip. A light bitterness lingers in the mouth, but not much of a hop presence. My only criticism of this one would be how sweet it is.

Even more noticeable than the taste is how creamy of a feel this has. Very smooth, to which the self-replenishing head will testify.

Of course this is a sipper. The sweetness lends it to be a beer best served with dessert or after dinner. A nice, strong flavor masks the ABV, but I will definitely still not be putting too many of these down in one sitting.

Date: February 21, 2012 Mode: Bottle Source: Crown Description: Semi-opaque light brown with nice amount of head.  Aroma was malty, caramel, and dark fruit.  Taste is similar to aroma with an alcohol finish.  Fairly smooth and medium bodied.  As I was holding this beer and looking at others in Crown, two customers started to get in a fight.  Gotta love downtown Indy!

A - pours hazy amber garnet color with 1 finger head, that dissapates quickly. Floating bits of yeast. S - aromas of bready malts up front. Hints of caramel malts and dark dried fruit.  Notes of grassy and floral hops. M - Smooth and rich, slightly sticky body. Lingering dark dried fruit malty ending with light alcohol warming. T - dark dried fruit on the nose, bitter grassy and floral hops and caramel malts on the palate. O - nice drinkable, though simplistic barleywine. Nothing that really stands out. 6/6+

Bottle. Dark. Creamy. Small, slightly off-white head. Not much of an aroma. Sweet. Aftertaste like cotton candy! Never gonna be my favorite, but not bad for a change of pace.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Batch 9958. Ive been sitting on this for a while. Pours amber to garnet with a quickly settling head. Its pretty still in the glass, just a few bubbles here and there, and plenty of floating sediment. Nose is sweet fruit, like plums, apricots, cherries. Still traces of piney, earthy, and herbal notes. Taste is mostly sweet with some bitterness still present. Palate is smooth, rich but not heavy, some stickiness, and a nice finish with plenty of bitterness. When fresh, I remember this stuff to be pretty aggressive, but it has aged nicely and has rounded out well. Very good barley wine.
Completely baffled how I havent rated one of the best barley wines out there that is basically my go to BW...but anyway, what more is there to say than that?

Bottle.  Clear dark brown pour, good carbonation/lasting lacing and a nice rich warm caramel, booze and slightly sweet aroma.  Flavor is nice warm boozy raisins, pepper and sweet sugar on the aftertaste.  Very nice.

UPDATED: FEB 2, 2012 My first barley wine!  Pours a dark brownish red. Very sweet aroma and taste but ends with a fairly strong alcohol burn. Bought a six pack but only put two in the fridge. Think I?ll make the other four the initial brews of my cellaring effort! :)

Bottle. Pours a ruddy brown with orange highlights under light. Smells of alcohol, caramel malt, and dried fruit. It also smells kind of old and earthy. Unbelievably smooth for a 10.2% ABV beer. Flavor is of dried fruits, caramel, woodiness, and hoppy spiciness. Alcohol flavor is present, too, but masked very well.

Unfortunately this beer lacks a lot of the complexity I would expect from a beer this big; but it gets major points for being unbelievably drinkable. Im not sure if I have ever had a beer this big that was this drinkable. Recommended.

Pours a dark and mysterious shade of tawny garnet with hints of tightly wrapped tan bubbles that melt like an April snow. Aromas of dark fruit salad dredged in caramel and dark sugar then soaked in vodka. Hits of floral and earthy hops vainly try to cut through the malty sweetness. Flavors explode with sweet sugary dark fruits, caramel, cherries, plums, and a hint of alcohol and earthy hop flavor. Medium to dry finish in an otherwise full body. Light level of carbonation with a sweet almost sticky mouthfeel. This is a really nice barleywine, I wish I had picked up more than one because I think a bit of age would have only made this better.

Bought a single for $2 Ive been on a barleywine kick lately. 

A  Slightly opaque deep copper-colored body with a ¼ yellow- white head which remained until the last drop. Theres a good amount of lacing sticking to the edge of the glass.

S  Sweet malt, caramelized sugar, raisons, and maybe green grapes.

T  A bit boozy Big caramel flavor, the alcohol brings some spicy notes. It finishes nicely with big sweet malt and plump fruit.

M  Velvety smooth body with an alcohol burn. Slightly syrupy.

O  Id like to revisit this brew with a bit of age on it. Its good, but I beat it is much better after a year or two. A nice brew for cold winters day.

Serving type: bottle

Bottle; syrupy brown color; heavy, persisent lace; heavy, but pleasant mouthfeel; this barleywine has great, mature taste, avoiding the sweetness of lesser barleywines.  Look forward to the bottles I put away for next year.

12 oz bottle: Thanks Casey! Pours a chestnut brown with a tan head. Lots of CO2 and yeast sediment. Bready malt dominates the aroma. Rich malty flavor, sweeet on the front and bitter finish. Bubbly. Very good Old Ale.

Bottle to snifter. pours hazy (cloudy) dark red (mahogany) with a soapy off white head that settles to a soapy foamy collar. Aroma is sweet caramel malt and nutty with some vanilla. Taste is bitter hops caramel and burnt sugar with hints of nuts dark fruit and some vanilla. Palate is full and creamy with a chalky dry finish and some warming alcohol. Solid Barley Wine with a nice drying finish that bring you back for more.

Interesting beer. $14 for a 6 pack at Gomers in KC, MO. Pour a dark hazy brown with a half inch tan head that diminished after a few minutes to a think  lace. Appearance was almost like a belgian quad - appearance and aroma reminded me a lot of Boulevard Sixth Glass Quad. Great aroma. Aroma of dark fruit - fig, raisin and alcohol. With the appearance and aroma, flavor was much different than I expected. Mouthfeel was immediately noticeable as a subtle gritty feel but overall creamy texture. Flavor was upfront with brown sugar, wood/earthy flavors, toast flavor finish. Not getting a huge dose of alcohol warmth on this. Its there, but not over the top. Perfect. I havent had a lot of barley wines, but I would suspect this this is one of the best. This is a rare occasion beer and I will be stashing a couple away in my cellar out of the 6 pack to see how they age. Definitely will be a 6 pack I buy once per year. Good stuff !

9/27/11 bottle served at 50 degrees in a snifter.  Glowing brown pour with a khaki colored head that thins to a film after about two minutes.  Aroma of hop leaves, booze and cedar planks.  Sweet and syrupy in the mouth.  Honey, brown sugar, and burnt wood overwhelm the palate.  Very full in the mouth.  The slight booziness only serves to enhance the elegance of this beer.  I actually feel the alcohol warmth down my chest and into my stomach up to a minute after taking a sip.  This beer is great.

Batch 9592

The full aroma with a lot of citrus.  The taste is good, but not great.  Leaves a little more of an after taste than I typically like.  The color is fine.  A decent barley wine that I would have again, but not the greatest.

Thanks Pepsi-santaBatch 10672  10.2% abv.

Appearance:  Pours a dark amber with a thin white film.

Aroma: Brown sugar, strawberries, herbal hops.

Taste:  Dark sugar, bitter hops, alcohol and toast.

Mouthfeel: Full bodied, creamy with modest carbonation.

Overall: A pretty solid, tasty strong ale. This was a pretty fresh bottle, and I honest have no idea what time will do with this beer. I stashed a few away, so Im hoping for the best. It just seems so balanced now, I dont see what time would buy it.  Ive read reviews that indicate some older batches started off hotter, so I can see wanting to mellow that a bit.

12oz bottle poured dark amber color with minimal head. the aroma of brandy and sweet malts and alcohol are amazing .the flavor hits the aroma dead on. the sweet malt flavor the alcohol burn are insane. the flavor jumps out everywhere. this bottle has been sitting around a couple of years now so i am guessing its just hitting its prime. love the flavor.

Bottle.  Pours a hazy brown with a medium tan head.  Aroma of sweet caramel malts.  The flavor is a nice blend of alcohol, hops, and malt, giving the beer both balance and complexity.  Caramel and dark fruits are prominent.  Very nice - one of my favorite barleywines.

Good, but not great barleywine.  I had it aged about a year, so I think it was at the in between phase: still had some hops up front, but not enough so it sort of tasted funny at the beginning the moved in to smooth sweet caramelly slow sipper.  I want to try one thats about 3 years old....

UPDATED: MAR 29, 2012 WInter 2010 bottle from my cellar..  Poured deep copper/brown into a snifter.  1/2 a finger of head.  Dried dark fruit in the nose, leather, sweet, a slight hint of alcohol.  Almost no hint of alcohol when I drink this - Dark fruit, plum, red grape, hard candy, toffee and caramel, Fig, Raisin.  Warming and sweet - medium bodied.  webs of lacing all the way down.  i enjoyed it last year when I first bought it but a year in the cellar really brought out this beers strengths.  Now do I age the other 2 a while longer or drink them now??

pours deep hazy red with a creamy off white head and some spotty lacing.  aroma is complex with notes of baked goods, cranberry, chocolate, licorice and red wine.  taste is rich with notes of cranberries, cherries, currants, licorice, vanilla and maple.  finish begins sweet but then turns hoppy.  very complex and a perfect winter beer.

12 oz bottle - a big gigantic thank you to rayl101 (Kevin) for hooking me up with this gem. This brew pours a dark brown with a thin head and has some lacing to it. Nice taste of toffee and caramel and the alcohol is definitely there. Has a heavy mouthfeel and slightly bitter on the aftertaste.

Pours hazy burnt amber/brown.  Toasted malt, caramel brown sugar, molasses, light cherry and plum, and a bit of booze.  Light initial sweetness followed by dry roasted/toasted malt, a bit of dark fruit, mild grapefruit-like hops, and burnt biscuit.  Finishes moderately dry and roasty.  Reminds me a little of an amped-up dubbel a bit.  Well-attenuated, with only mild to moderate malt sweetness.

Cheers to Hopscotch who benefited me with this bonus  beer that has been in my cellar after a trade!  Yeasty bread dough aroma along with dried dates.  Upfront some citrusy hops followed by a sweet, warming linger.  After awhile the hops return.  Good beers are complex and leave you wanting more.  This is one of those.

being from michigan sometimes i feel as if i may be partial to michigan beers.will say that this is not the case for this bells product.this is a wonderful barley wine ale.the alchohol really shows through and would suggest this sitting by the fireplace on a cold michigan winter night.
Very very good. One of my favorite from Bells and I ran across it by accident. Nice lil surprise

UPDATED: NOV 20, 2014 Bottle pours amber brown with tall tan head and a  lightly roasted aroma of barley and some sugary fruits. The taste is full but smooth cold with some slightly burnt caramel, as it warms the grain puts out a good bit of fruity, semi wine like alcohol and a dry grainy palate, but this is still the standard barley wine to go by thru and thru. Good til the last drop, particularly on a cold night. --	aged notes, a smell of amaretto and a slightly almond buttery complexion that was not noticeable in a young batch. The beer is still dry but the hop flavors are deeply blended--

Pours an opaque reddish copper with just a thin diaphanous layer of tan head. Aroma is lovely - a mix of raisin, almond, vanilla and oak. Flavor is lovely. It has a lot of raisin character, caramel and bread and a tinge of butterscotch. Body is creamy but not thick. Just the right amount of carbonation to lighten it up.

Bottle. Pours dark amber/copper color. Aroma of dark fruit, licorice, caramel. Taste is mild sweetness. Finish has some bite, medium bitterness. Long finish youd expect from a barley wine. Medium-full body, thick texture. This is a barley wine done right, Im just not a fan of this category.

0.355l bottle @ Oliver Twist, Stockholm. This one pours a clouded deep bronze body with a big-bubbled and sidesticking just off-white head. The aroma is lightly sweet, some deep caramel, forest. Yes, forest. Hints of toast and something lightly burned. Full-bodied with a nice creamy mouthfeel and a average carbonation level. Flavors are not to sweet, but still light sweet. Malty and dry, lots of wet leafs, light grassy as well, some raisins and figs and its somewhat vinious and woody before it ends really dry-mouthing and light fruity with a warming aftertaste. Good stuff!

Bottle courtesy of Strykzone. Wow. Another great beer from a great trading partner. Poured a rich mahogany color with a billowing off-white head and lacing rings like glue. Beautiful.  Rich nose of ripe fruit.  Rich body and creamy mouthfeel. The flavor is intense, with lots of roasted malts with ripe fruit including raisins and figs.  The finish goes on and on with just the right amount of sweetness and bitterness you expect from a barley wine.  Superb ale and good to the last drop.

Aroma - Light Fruity, subtle malt aroma
Appearance - Medium Brown, cloudy, thick small head
Taste - Medium malt flavor, light hops
Palate - very smooth finish, no bitterness
Overall - A solid barleywine ale; not too hoppy-American, but not nearly as malty as the English-style I prefer.  Really a pretty good hybrid of the two styles.  Probably my favorite Bells beer.
Carmel, malt, and bitter sweet.  Very good to drink today, but probably even better a year from now.  Six months in a cask and six in a bottle would be nice.

Ive had it in my cellar for about 10 months, pours a dark amber, clear, with moderate/ low carbonation, aroma is sweet caramel toffee  with alcohol up front with a dark fruit in the background . Drink this at 55-60 degrees, the aroma is outstanding. Smooth malty alcohol flavor with lingering alcohol and sweetness. Great beer, when it comes out this year I think I buy a case with 6 pack  for years 1-4.

G. Gordon Liddy once wrote, "Drink this beer, it shall give you imeasurable strength." I dont know if thats true. Infact I know its not. It might be. 

Im not the least bit curious what beer he was citing- maybe this one. Probably. One can hope. I will say with absolution this is a crown of the style. 
Brilliant bright nose; as she sits today=young as heck- its malt forward and full of nutmeg-y malt, yet still swirled and cloaked with alcohol warmths, even in its adolesence. Superising how spicy (cinnamon and the likes) it is- would be shocked if these dont take a back seat in the future. Hops are a snapshot in history- great noble oily tartness that balances the strong viscous malt nicely, and then finishes the flavor off for this young old ale, but will bow out as it cellars. Only reason this beer recieved a 17/20 on overall is because I know its going to continue to evolve into greatness. 
Look, if you have the opportunity, be patient. G. Gordon Liddy would.

Bottle, Batch 8211, bottle November 9th, 2007.  Four years does this beer wonders. Pours hazy amber, slightly reddish. Small yellowish beige head. Nose of sweet caramel, toffee, bread, and candied sugars. Notes of brandy and sweet fine sherry. Taste is a bit less complex, but still great. Lovely beer.

Botlled 9-14-2011.  Pours rich hazy ruby with dense head, great lacing, and great retention.  Aroma is burnt sugar, molasses, herbal spice, and a wierd medicinal note that penetrates through everything.  Taste is a bit of a mess; mild caramel notes give way to bitter herbal hops and dried red fruits, medicinal alcohol, finishes very bitter with just a hint of sweetness.  Body is full, below average carbonation, big creamy/oily mouthfeel, boozy sweet finish.  Overall, this is definetly a beer you want to cellar.  The unbalanced aroma and flavor now will certainly give way to a bold and potent profile after at least a year, but judging by the utter undrinkability of this brew right now, this one could age successfully for 4 years or more.

Chef Pauls, draft. Snifter. Bottle is from 2010.  Thick light brown pour.  Aroma is cherry, sweet malt.  Tasting strawberry jam, more cherry, rich sweet malt, then long long finish of orange hop bitterness.  Heavy alcohol.  This is thick, syrupy.  A lot of work to get through, even for an aged barleywine.

Bottle.  Brown sugar malt, cherry, and light alcohol aroma.  Cloudy brown color with giant tan head.  Sweet raisin, orange, brown sugar malt and strong bitter alcohol flavor.   Excellent - one to keep on hand.

Bottle from batch 9525.  Pours a dark leathery brown color.  Sweet dried fruit and toasty malt aroma.  More toasty malt in the flavor as well as molasses, toffee & some creamy coffee.  Overall, its really delicious and drinkable in spite of the 10.2% abv.

Im big on higher alcohol content brews because of the added flavor & structure, so this is the second time Ive gone back to this one.  This time Im getting so much jammy fig in the aroma, almost a super sweet scent.  I remember growing up we had real molasses on the table- that my family made, and sometimes it was really dark and sometimes a little lighter, but always sugary.  And thats what I taste in Third Coast Ale- a lot of molasses with that slightly bitter back of the palate burn, and a few over ripe fruits on top.  For me this is a starter (or finisher) but not more than 2 in one sitting.

Fresh this BW is a bit of a mess, but I think the brewer is confirming that in the blurb. I have only had 1 with 8 months, and I can see where its going. I think this beer is going to be one I really enjoy at age 2-3.

Purchased at Hyde Park Wine & Spirits in Cincinnati, OH; enjoyed on a cool Labor Day watching baseball and just relaxing.  Appearance a slightly clear, dark muddy reddish brown hue with practically no head, just a thin white strip rimming around the snifter.  Aroma of caramel malt, sweet, a definite alcohol presence, licorice/molasses, plums, pretty complex and nice.  Taste does hit you with alcohol, a little more boozey than what I anticipated, but its still rather smooth.  The molasses comes out more in the taste, definite full body with decent carbonation.  Its really good stuff, not really something Id drink often but for the weather outside right now (low 60s) its fitting and great.

Very minimal carbonation in this barleywine.  Aroma is apple, caramel, cinnamon.  Taste is lightly fruity with a good amount of sweetness.  Minimal hop presence if any.  Sweet but not offensively so.  A very nice barleywine from bells.

Pours a mahogany with very little head and carbonation.  Smell is sugar dates, caramel malts, booze and some toffee.  Taste is very  mature, almost like a cognac with notes of caramel malt, fig and some hops.  The alcohol is very, very well hidden.  Now that I know what this is I think age would do this wonders.  Cant wait to get my hands on some more and forget about it for several years.

No head or lacing. A beer with no lacing? Really? I dont care about lacing and I dont know what the deal is. Big heavy scotch ale flavors then they set you down easy with a light hoppiness. Love it.

12oz bottle from Discount Liquor Milwaukee, Batch 9970, bottled 10/15/2010. Pours a deep, reddish-brown color with a tan head and some lacing. Aroma is malty, dark fruit, maybe a little booze.  Heavy on the palate with soft carbonation. Flavor is sweet, malty, dark fruit, toffee. Delicious.

Tasted on 8/3/11 from a 12oz bottle purchased at Lush West Town, batch 9358.  Pours an opaque prune juice purple/brown color with a thick beige head with a purple tint that slowly recedes to a nice collar of lace with a thick bubble of lace settling in the center of the glass.  The nose is very malty with tons of brown sugar, caramel, and molasses malt, and dried fig and prune fruitiness, along with a burnt bitter component.  The flavor is pretty much the same with the sweeter malt and fruit notes up front, moving to roasted, toasted, and burnt bitterness.  The body is full with just lighter than average carbonation, and a long malty and burnt bitter finish.

Notes from the 2011 BarleyBlind tasting.  Pours an unclear orange tan.  Aroma is chocolate with cherries, overripe fruit.  Taste is chocolate with cherry, alcohol somewhat present.  Finishes syrupy.  This offering finished a ways back in the pack at the tasting, trailing the top tier of Hog Heaven, Behemoth and Old Numbskull by a ways, but also behind the tier of Old Stock, Old Guardian, Duck Rabbit and Jack & Kens.

12oz bottle.  Dark iced tea pour with no head.  Nose of sweet toffee, malt, caramel, and alcohol.  Taste was not as sweet as the nose.  Certainly loads of toffee, caramel, and toasted malt.  Unexpected piney hoppy finish which is ok but doesnt quite work for me.  As an Old Ale, just okay.  As a Barleywine, maybe a bit better.

Pours a drab, opaque mahogany color with a modest, creamy, sand-colored head. The fragrant aroma is rich with characteristics of cherries, prunes, and some brown sugar. The flavor is not quite so sweet, with caramel and raisins being contrasted by a woodsy hop bitterness that I can best compare to pine bark. Both the bitter and sweets sides are presented in big doses along with an alcohol warmth that is noticeable without being overpowering. The fine, tingling carbonation keep neither adds nor detracts from the experience.

Served from a 12 oz bottle thanks to Andy. The appearance is a clear boded red caramel hue with a smaller white head. The aromas pour out with sweet malts, loads of cherry, vanilla, butterscotch, caramel, very enticing nose. The flavors have similar characters but the initial sips are heavy with booze, bourbon, almost a Manhattan flavor profile. A spiced almost oak edge to it. The mouth is warm with a good carbonation to fill the mouth. Very well done beer. Should be excellent out of the cellar too.

Bottle/12oz - Pours a hazy very dark amber in color with almost no head... low carbonation.  Aroma is slightly sweet and quite malty with some pine resin hops.  Flavor is slughtly sweet to start, then hoppy... pine resins... and bitter in the finish.  Some alcohol warming at the end.  An excellent American-style barleywine...

12 oz.  Pours a cloudy red-brown, minimal head.  Aroma is rich of malt, cinnamon, and booze. Taste is HOT.  Smooth, for sure, but strong od cinnamon, bananas, and butterscotch.  Nice strong burn going down, but a little more heavy-handed than I would have hoped for.  Especially this late in the night;).  Oh well, still a fine Bells offering.

Süffig malziger Antrunk, sehr aromatisch. Wenig hopfig, sehr süß malzig, dunkler werdend. Später karamellig, etwas alkoholisch, was die anderen Aromen bestärkt. Kräuterartiger, stark malzig-voluminöser Abgang. Vielen Dank an kappldav123 für das Bier! /12/12/13/10/13
Pour is a deerp amber color with little to no head. Nose is of dark fruits dominately grapes dates and plums. Taste is dominately the same, and for 10% not al too boozy.

16 oz draft served in a tulip.  Pour is orange highlighted tea with three fingers of kaki head on top; lacing and retention are both above average.  Nose is an immediate blast of oranges & citrus, which is followed by velvety layers of caramel, malt, and resinous hops.  Taste is caramel and orange right off the bat, which is then joined by hops, citrus bitterness, malt, and a touch of booze.  This is a very nice barely wine that changes as it warms with the complexity of a chameleon.  The whole palate becomes more rich and velvety with about 10 to 15 degrees of an increase in temperature; the sweet aspects (caramel and orange) also take on a more decadent approach.  This is a top notch barley wine, which is especially well balanced, however it is not my favorite take on the style.
somewhat drunk already when i popped this bottle open. malty with a backend bitterness. very good but not amazing.

UPDATED: MAY 18, 2011 12 oz Bottle.  Appearance is nice mahogany with light head.  Aroma is sweet with plums, caramel, some cereal, and alcohol.  Taste is complex with huge malt bill consisting of dried fruits, caramel, some cereal notes, and a subtle hop bitterness and a slight booziness.  Palate is full-bodied, a little alcohol astringent, mild bitter finishing.

Bottle. Pours a mahogany with a very small head that dissipates into the slightest wisp. Smell is quite charming with lots of dried figs, maple and red vines. The taste is sweet with burn toast at the beginning, with even more toast and some caramel coming through as you swallow. The chewiness of dried fruits linger with lots more toast coming through after you swallow. Finishes quite boozy.

Bottle into brand new tulip. The nose on this beer was extremely pleasing and confusing at the same time. Complexity to no end and such a delectable scent. Plum, crystalline sugar, butterscotch, raisin, and wine notes were everywhere. I took about ten minutes just to savor the aroma and really think hard about what I could pull out of it. The pour was also quite nice. Fluffy, lasting head with solid lacing and champagne like bubbles. Murky brown color. The taste was definitely top notch but left me wanting more due to the aroma. The taste had a sweet front with caramel and roasted malt with some hop bitters on the finish. Complex and satisfying. Great.

On tap served in pint pour was a deep amber with two inches of off white head with a nice showing of lacing nose was malts and dark fruits taste was   loads of caramel,dark fruits,light brandy and alight hop Finnish. Hides the abv well not a bad brew and would.enjoy it again.

UPDATED: SEP 7, 2011 Bottle @ home, courtesy of LeopoldStoch. Dark red orange appearance with a two finger tan head. Sweet berry jam, slightly boozy, quite caramel malty nose. Sweet, red fruity, caramel malty, slightly boozy flavor. Red fruits, some bitter hops, and light to medium booze on the finish. Somewhat bitter, earthy hoppy aftertaste. One of my new favorite Barley Wines!

Awesome 12oz bottle, I love the artwork. Nutty brown appearance, minimal head with a tan color. At first, tastes kind of like a strong juice, but after a few seconds is when I really first begin to appreciate it. Nutty, wine-ish taste, like a grape champagne. Definitely tastes "vintage". Aftertaste seems to come and go in waves, which is fun. (Friends: "Interesting.")

Apr 23, tap @ Excentric Café. Pours cloudy dark brownish amber with a small off white head. Aroma is molassis, malty, sweet, hooppy and fruity. Tart, very malty, fullbodied, sweet, bready, raisins, alcoholic flavor. Tart sweet fullbodied palate. Finishes mallty and tart hoppy with a touch of raisins. Really excellent.

Bottle.  Light brown to deep caramel color.  Suspend solids -- very still.  Thin tan head that stays.  Rich aroma - caramel malt.  Full body, very smooth and relatively thick.  A great beer to enjoy.  The high alcohol does not overpower, good balance.

(12 ounce bottle - Shaker glass)  Pours a very dark ruby red color and has a half finger size head with sketchy lacing.  Aroma is of citrus hops and dark malts.  Piney hop taste and caramel, toffee, chocolate malt taste too.  Also has a relativley heavy sweetness and a medium bitterness.  Full body, creamy sticky texture, soft cabonation and bitter finish.  Overall alot of flavor in this beer.

Slightly sweet notes of carmel and fruit blend was so complex I had to swish and smell 4 times and still can not really say what all the aromas are. Nicely blended. The color poured a medium dark brown and was cloudy with a light tan head that stayed for 3 to 4 minutes . Slightly sweet flavor followed by a grapefruit taste, that lasted quite awhile.  It has a full body, creamy texture, that was soft on  carbonation, and finished bitter, long finish.

Chevy Chase Wines and Liquors bottle ($2.79): Pours a cloudy amber color with a white head. Really sugary and fruity aroma. Taste is a mixture of nigh cloying sweetness and slightly subdued hop bitterness. I think the sweetness makes its appearance at the front and then the bitterness kind of follows, but in the world of Venn diagrams, there is an overlap.  Plenty of astringency. (I really dont get the raisin taste, except perhaps a little at the finish, but its a faint echo and not so much a charecteristic.) Some somewhat burnt malts are present in there as well. Pretty full-bodied, which makes it a little hard to drink. Minimal aftertaste considering the powerful flavors present in this here beer. Well-balanced.

12 oz. bottle, sent by FuckSociety (thanks Sebastian), pours a gorgeous rich dark ruby red with pretty much no head. Great aroma of raisins, plum, toffee and brown sugar - suggesting considerable sweetness. Very rich flavours of dried fruits (raisins, figs, dates), plum, grapes, toffee, caramel - heavy on the malts, with little hops detectable. Viscous, sticky body that leaves toffee and boozy notes, with considerable sweetness on the palate. Absolutely wonderful.

Biscuit and malt aroma.  Very dark pour with off white head that disappears quickly.  Malt and alcohol flavor.  Alcohol heat at the end.  Very warming.  No hop character at all, raisins and dried fruit.  An excelent beer.

2008 bottle into an orval glass...Pours a watery medium brown, very light highlights, not much head...The aroma is pretty dead, lots of alcohol, light figs and caramel...Taste is light alcohol and chalky, not a ton going on, a little tough to drink..

Dark cloudy amber pour. Complex smell; dark cherries, subtle alcohol, maple. Relatively complex taste; each sip bring out different flavors. Slightly bitter aftertaste, very little alcohol. 
12oz bottle sm pub glass

Tap at Bells. Hazy deep amber thin white head. Aroma dark fruit, caramel, bread, a bit roasty. Taste dark fruit, mild hops, caramel, hints of booze, orange peel, slight earthiness. Mf full body mild carb. Pretty tasty.

12 oz. pours reddish brown with just thin white ring around the top of my snifter. Not a whole lot on the nose some dark fruits maybe some bread and some caramel. A very nice balance of hoppy bitterness and smooth malty sweetness. I also get some raisins, licorice, and alcohol that is well balanced. Mouthfeel is rather thick and the finsh is a long bitter one with some definite warmth from the alcohol.  A very good barley wine but not my favorite.
Smells of grapes plums, and malt. Smooth sipper with a nice sweet, yet tart taste. Flavors of grapes, caramel, and crab apple. Ages nicely (bottled: April 2010, consumed March 2011).

Pours a real cloudy turd color lacking any aesthetic appeal with about a one inch head. Faint sugary notes on the nose which disappear quickly. Taste is sour and slightly bitter and one note. Didnt mellow much as it warmed. My least favorite bells beer so far.

12 oz bottle, bottled in August 2010.
