It pours a murky brown with tons of sediment. The head is small and fizzy, not the greatest looking beer.

The smell is nice though. It has lots of dark fruits, caramel, and some very noticeable yeast notes. It has a certian hint of spice to it that is very nice

The taste is awesome. Just a mouthful of flavor. It has a lot o the aforementioned dark fruits, some very nice yeast notes, a surprising bitterness, and a ton of sweetness. It is initially a bit overpowering (I am also drinking it a bit cold (30 minutes removed form fridge) and cloying the the sweetness department but then it mellows down.

It is a yeasty barleywine that is quite unique and well worth a try.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 11-01-2010 01:41:49

Aroma is sweet caramel, alcohol and a touch of hops.  Its aroma and taste is very clean. Taste is very thick almost too cloying, but with the dark fruits there are just enough earthy hops to keep it from becoming too sweet.   I can almost taste the hard top of a creme brulee in there.

A dark brown beer with a small head that quickly becomes a ring and leaves some lacing.  An aroma that is full of rich complex fruit along with yeast and bready malt.  This looks and smells very inviting.  The flavor begins with hop bitterness and then some coffee which is unexpected.  There is some powdery chocolate and that complex fruit.  The finish is chocolate.  Alcohol is not tasted but it provides plenty of warming.  This is everything I hope a barley wine would be.

Bottle poured into snifter.  Aroma is a sweet caramel nose.  Has a dark reddish amber color with off white head.  Flavor out of the fridge was sweet alcohol and fruity.  As it warmed up the harshness mellowed out to a nice liquid caramel infused with dark fruit.  It has a soft carbonation and borderline syrupy, but not thick.  I would love to try another one of these aged.  All in all this is a nice old ale example.

Bottle shared thx to gnoff, cons 2011-02-26 Göteborg
AP: hazy amber, wee frothy head
AR: fruity, grape fruite, raspberry fruit compote, creamy
F: alcohol, almonds, plums

Pours deep reddish brown out of bottle, thin yellowish white head.  Aroma has notes of dark fruit, caramel, toffee, some slight aged hops, and even a touch of roast.  Taste is warm and slick, no sign of alcohol.  Malt and hops interplay well, wish the flavors were a bit cleaner but has nice notes of sweet caramel and toffee, along with the dark fruit and hops.

Great color.. great fruit taste.  I have to say.. The back of the bottle told me to cellar and test my patients.. not going to happen.  Long taste, apricotes and something else i cant put my finger on.  I will be coming back for this one.

UPDATED: MAR 3, 2012 Bottle.  Pours a dark mahogany with a medium sized, off white head.  Aroma and flavor are delightful:  loads of caramel and toffee, very malty, brown sugar, dates and raisins.  Thick but not slippery or syrupy.  Keeps improving as it warms.  Delicious.

pours a brown/ruby color with a thin tan head...ligth sediment throughout.  aroma has vanilla, red licorice, and fig...a bit of alcohol.  flavor has hints of chocolate with dark fruit...earthy...subdued sprucey and spicey hops.  mouthfeel is lively...robust...finish is warming and very dry, fruity,  and earthy.

2009 on draft at Teresas in Wayne. Pours a slightly opaque brown with little lacing and head. Nose is sweet and plesant not too strong.  The first sip is like silk with flavors of vanilla, caramel & hard candy (like my grandmother made on the stove top). Finish is malty and slight hops permenate. Glad I tried this.

Pours an opaque deep copper to ruby with a three-finger, thickly creamy and frothy, off-white head.  

Not much to report on the smell.  Caramel and some dry malt, load of sugar, and definite alcohol.

Taste is nice and rich.  Loads of caramel and french toast.  Super sweet.  Subtle hop presence on the finish.  And theres a nice layer of sticky aftertaste from the hops too.  The thick malts and tangy hop accent go together well.  

Rich and hearty.  Highly enjoyable drink.  10% abv completely hidden other than its somewhat filling.

Tap. Pours a deep amber with a nice foamy head. Smell is prunes, raisins, grapes and sweet caramel. Taste is sweet and malty finished up with a nice balancing hop presence. Citrusy hops in the finish. Sweet raisins on the front. Lingering bitter, tastes develop as you sip. Booze is noticeable.

Pours amber with barely any head. Nose is a light sweet caramel with a hint of alcohol. Taste is dry and warm with alcohol. Hint of sweet fruit like strawberry and raisin. Alcohol is nicely carried.  Mouth feel is medium to heavy. Very good sipper!

Nice BW. Aroma has that sweet dried fruit going on,  like tart grape and apple. Love the big brown hazy dark amber color, not much in the way of a head.  Taste is heavy and malty, the dried fruit comes through in the finish like a syrupy cider closing with a final bitter note. Its hard for me to go overboard when rating BWs so this is perdy dang gooood.

Bottle. Little to no head on a murky dark brown with copper tones.  Brandy, caramel, toffee, dark grapes, and slight citrus hops in the aroma.  Flavor is quite sweet up front, but dries out with toffee and has a light bitterness from both hops and the malt...but caramel and dark fruit continue.  Thicker body with very warming alcohol (that doesnt show in the taste).  Nice sipper.

Bottle. Pours a mahogany with pretty much no head. The aroma is dark fruits, malts, caramel sweetness,  apples, and a bit of alcohol. The taste is sweet with the flavors mirroring the nose pretty well. There is is a nice hoppiness on the finish that adds just the right amount of bitterness. Very respectable beer.

Reviewed from notes.

Pours mahogany win a slight off white head and not much of any lacing. Nose brings sweet bread and caramel along with dates, brown sugar, and some generic sweetness. Taste is quite boozy with brown sugar and rum-soaked dark fruits. Medium body with low carbonation and booze. Drinks well, but is definitely a sipper.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 10-13-2010

12 oz. bottle. The pour is a dark reddish-brown with a thin beige head. The aroma is caramel, honeysuckle, figs and coffee. The flavor is very sweet and a little bitter. The finish is bitter but fades quickly. The palate is thick and sticky. Overall, a strong and flavorful beer.
12 oz bottle, pours a dark brown color, with a tan head.  Aromas of caramel, malt and molasses.  Sweet , thick taste.  Like to see what it tastes like in a year

10 bottle from Joe - thanks!  Medium caramel brown in the glass with a healthy, long lasting tan head.  Very carbonated.  Aroma is smoke, roasted malt, toffee. caramel, and sweet raisin.  Taste is chunky raisin and sweet malt up front with some bitter hops in the middle and smooth toffee/caramel notes into a prickly alcohol finish.  Smooth and light feel in the mouth.  Great beer and Id love to track down a more bottles to see how the beer does with a few years time.

Thanks to Santa for this.  Pours a dark ruby with a thin beige foam.  Aroma is plums, raisins, malts and a little candy sugar.  Taste is a great blend of plum, raisins and sweet barley and malts.  Great sipping beer.
Absolutely must not have this beer anything other than slightly chilled, otherwise it will not taste right.  Great complex flavor, no other way to phrase it.
Pours a light brown.  Aroma of molasses, sweet honey.  Pretty sweet taste, smooth taste with hops, molasses and light malt.
Both malty and bitter. Lots of spice notes. Almost reminiscent of wine or spirits. Pours a dark reddish brown with a very small head.
Pours a nice dark brown. With a thin and bubbly head. Scents of malt complex malt with overtones of oak. Almost tastes like a nice burbon or whiskey. Alcohol content is warming. Definitley a sipper.
A deep coppery color with a whitish head. Malty aroma. Flavor is standard barley wine -- malt, dry aged fruit, alcohol content very present.

Pours a dark amber color with a medium tan head. aroma is sweet malty caramel, sugary spice and everything nice! taste is boozy caramel, ginger and cinnamon. palate is good with nice warming ability. overall a very good beer!

copper pour minimal but lasting head.  Earthy attic funk aromas with a bittering dusty waft and slight soured apple touch.  A preview of juicy notes to follow.  A slightly rugged body with a good depth in flavor but perhaps lacking a nuanced subtlety in its transition.  Potent.  a good brew to finish a night and it proves to be quite a stomped when appropriately applied.  A good brew for sure and a great example of the style.

Bottle.

A - Dark tawny orange color with a healthy sized, creamy, foamy, fairly thick and dense, white head. Plenty of sediment. Great retention leaving a nice layer of lace.

S - Strong caramel smell along with rum soaked golden fruit and orange aroma. Some toffee and other citrus (grapefruit). Faint alcohol presence.

T - Like the nose, there is a large caramel presence with citrus flavor, some rum soaked golden fruit, and hints of alcohol. Some toffee. Hops are there, but not strong, slight herbal and floral flavor. A bit of spice and some spice.

M - Medium body with average carbonation. Warming and slick.

D - Definitely wanted to sip this. A little to sweet, coating and warming for me to drink too much of this.

Notes: 9525 bottled in Jan. 05, 2010. Not bad. Hops and alcohol had a slight presence even after a year. Not my favorite beer but not bad. Fruity and caramel with some flavors resembling some spirits. Worth a try and if the price were good, I would get it again.

Ruby with brown notes, excellent retention, viscous, this is what an old ale or barleywine that has a head should look like... Pungent aroma, bg malts with notes of fruits... Loads of dark fruits and malts with some chocolate mixed in... Lively, dry finish, full bodied.. Great Flavor...

12oz bottle. Dark amber color, brownish hue. Very thin head with an oily lacing. Tons of malt in the aroma. Flavor is malty with a slightly sweet after taste. Heavy on the palate with a somewhat bitter after taste.
Picked up at the brewpub. Pours beep brown with low head. Nose is port and spice. Thick body, taste of caramel malt, pine resin, figs and raisin. Nice smooth finish with mild caramel bitterness.
growler 09 keg.  Murky brown, floaties. Taste is heavy malts backed solidly w/ malts. Less hops than i remember fresh.
A bit overrated. Mostly sweet prune taste with a lasting sweet and alcoholic finish. Sweet aroma. Light carbonation and full bodied. Too sweet overall but may be better after a few years of aging.

UPDATED: MAR 21, 2011 Pourd s muddy dark red. Not a whole ton on the aroma, some mild malt.  Taste is a nice blend of full bodied malt (never too sweet) and some hop edge. Very good beer. Among the elite of the barley wine style, which is not a personal favorite of mine. Definitely have this one fresh, so as to still get the hops.

Pours a deep reddish brown with a small light brown head.  Brown sugar and hops are present in the aroma.  Taste is a bit sweeter than other barley wines I have had.  Has a burst of brown sugar goodness mixed in with a jet of bitterness from the hops.  Has a nice pine needle/resin taste in the finish.  Another tasty beer made by bells!

12 oz bottle. Pours deep copper/ruby brown. Complex aromas of raisins and  toffee. Equally complex flavors on the palate. Fruit up front with nice hops on the finish. Best wide distribution old ale from USA producer.

Bottle.  Pours a clear dark brownish amber color with a thin beige head.  Contains some suspended yeast sediments.  Little lacing.  Aroma has a fair amount of alcohol along with dried pitted fruit and sweet toffee malt.  Toffee/caramel malt sweetness in the initial flavor with some hop bitterness on the back end followed by warming from the alcohol.  A good winter warmer.
12oz bottle. Aroma strong of malts with some hops.  Flavor roasted malts, a little chocolate, and some sweet malts.  Nice tecture.  A pretty good beer.

Thanks bro.  Pours ruby brown with a frothy cream colored head.  Rich fruity aroma (fig, raisin, etc...) with carmelized brown sugar and molasses.  Warm and roasty flavors with a hint of bitterness.  Very full-bodied, and luscious with some well-hidden heat from the alcohol.  Not as sweet as the aroma leads you to believe, but a very complex and well put together beer.

pours deep brown, initial maltiness on the palate and nose, 2nd sip leads to sprucy hops  As the maltiness disipates and leads to a little drier hop flavor.  Turns into a very strong drinking ale.  I like it, just couldnt drink it everyday.

Bouteille (été 2010)10-12-10: Ambrée brun avec reflets rougeatre, trouble, avec de la lie au fond du verre et plusieurs particules en suspension. Asser vive effervescence et petite mousse légèrement beige persistante. Premiers arômes de caramel, de cassonade, de beurre chaud, de brandy, suit des notes de fruits rouge. Plus que moyennement sucrée, mais sans lêtre exagéremment, elle a également une bonne amertume, mais le tout est très bien balancée et ce complète très bien. Complexe et doux en bouche et en saveurs, tel que caramel, cassonade, fruits rouges, alcool, elle a une texture ronde et riche. Petite note de métalique a peine perceptible. Finale asser astringente, avec une touche damertume, mais surtout de la richesse en bouche et une chaleur dalcool. Très plaisante a déguster.

Poured from a 12oz bottle, a dark amber/brown.  Lots of nice lacing.  Smells of peat and band-aids.  Loads of bitterness on this one.   Some tastes of plums and figs with some sweetness that is overpowered by the hoppiness.

Batch # 9958

Poured from a 12oz. bottle into a over-sized wine glass.

The color is dark and very cloudy maroon with some reddish highlights and a small wisp of head that cleared out pretty fast and left a small bit of lacing.

The smell is a bit an orange flavor at first. To my surprise there is a light, airy fruit flavor that is a bit like oranges or orange peel in the nose. Some juicy malts are in behind, holding up the set work before leaving a trail of sweetness in your nose for a minuet of two.

The taste is malty at first with a airy malt flavor that seems to pop a bit. There is a nice juicy flavor that continues from the nose, the orange seems to be gone but there is a slight tomato flavor that is mixed with some pears and a bit of a malty finish.

The feel of this beer is pretty big. It has some drinkable, juicy feel to it but also has some complex flavors that add up to a beer with legs. It goes down well but seems to register itself as a beer with a punch.

Bottle poured a clear dark orange asmber with a small lingering amber head. Aromas of plum, raisin, dates, sherry, toffee and carmel. Palate was medium bodied and smooth with a warming finish. Flavors of toffee, carmel, fig, dates, brown sugar and sherry with a smooth warming lingering toffee finish.

This has got to be a classic for this time of year.  Dark cherries in abundance on the pour with a strong tea colour.  Malty sweet up front with roasty burnt sugar and hints of nutmeg.  Wham, the astringent hop bitterness hits with a force that could change the spin of our planet.  Bells should proudly proclaim this brew as their own.  Absolutely one of the finest barleywines that Ive tried.

2 bouteilles de 12 oz partagées lors dune dégustation Ratebeer Montréal. Arôme: Odeur de mélasse avec une pointe dhoublons et de petits fruits. Apparence: La couleur est brune. Présence dune fine dentelle sur le verre. Saveur: Goût de mélasse légèrement fruité avec une pointe dhoublons et dépices. Durée moyenne de larrière goût. Palette: Le corps est moyen avec une texture légèrement huileuse. Moyenne effervescence en bouche. Légère présence de caramel en arrière goût. (Rating #3361)

Bottle pour gives light cola color with decent off-white head.  Very nice lacing.  Aroma sweet  malts with fruits.  Taste complex with sweet malts, spices, fruits and hops.  Finish of strong hops which normally I dont like in a barley wine, but it works in this case.  Alcohol well disguised.  Palate thick but not syrupy.

Really a very nice beer.  I am not much of a hop lover but enjoyed this one.

Bottle shared at a recent BA/RB tasting...  Had a 2009 and 2008 vintage side by side.  The 08 was a bit oxidized, but the 09 was tasting very nice.  Poured an amber-dark orange.  Fruity, sweet, almondy even.  Notes of marzipan, tea leaves, and sweet malts.  Not much going on hear with malt.  I plan on keeping my 2009 bottle for quite some time.

12oz KC 2010 bottle. Pours a dark brown with a medium khaki head and light sediment. No lacing but its got some legs. Pretty big aroma of cherry meat, sweeter malt, molasses and a fair amount of hops in the finish. Pretty heavy flavor thats full of roasted malt, spicy and bitter hops plus a little coffee. Warming alcohol in the finish. Pretty big beer across the board.

Dark fruits (cherries?), spice, some yeast, alcohol and caramel.  Taste is EPIC.  Tons of flavor. Nice mix of various dark fruit flavors. yeast notes and sweetness comes through as it warms. Alcohol is covered well.  Delicious astringent finish.  A perfect beer.
Bottle - Dark brown low beige head, complex aroma, smooth and easy to drink, hides 10% abv very well, recommended.

12oz btl. Pours a deep mahogany with a thin white head. A candied fruit aroma with some sugared nuttiness. Sweet maltiness but some nice juicy fruit notes. Maybe some cherry with a nice bit of spice in the finish. 10.2% abv and you can taste it in the finish. I like the fruit characteristic for sure. A little boozy but nice overall.

Cherries, Honey, All the way into Citrus this beer is aromatically a gift.  Dark brown, low carbonation, whats to be expected from the style.  This beer has an incredible palate, everything from hops, to mega fruit, to some alcohol taste and plenty of honey, theres not a note that is thin in the taste.  Make that high alcohol taste.  This beer is something else.  Theres so much going on in the flavor its hard to take it all in at once.  Nice full bodied mouth feel, taste that lingers of dry hops but also a slight sweetness.  All I can say is wow, dont drink this too fast.

Notes from September 2010.
12 oz. bottle from Steves Liquor Madison.

Ar: Light smoke, burnt sugar, pit-fruit, brandy.
Ap: Deep brown read pour with a 1" light cinnamon head.
T: Light chocolate, roast malt, brandy burn on the finish.
P: Medium to thick body, medium carbonation.

O: Great offering from Bells.

Pours an amber brown with a thin tan head typical of the barley wine genre.  Taste oaky with an alcohol flavor that hits you all at once.  A great beer of this sometimes under-appreciated style.

12 oz. bottle

I bought a single bottle of this from a local beer store. It pours dark with little head. Aroma caramel and toffee. Taste is sweet and malty. Palate is full body with a decent amount of carbonation and a slight bitter finish. Very nice!

Jan. 2009 bottle.  Poured a dark and hazy amber reddish color.  Nice fluffy white head, excellent retention.  Lots of lace.  Aroma was tons of caramel, toffee, some fruity sweetness, maybe some raisins.  Flavors were sweet malts, caramel, some earthy flavors and a subtle bitterness in the finish.  Just a hint of booze too, pretty tasty stuff.  Big mouthfeel, decent carbonation.  Some great unique things going on here, not just a sweet barley wine.  Solid.
an older batch shared at RBSG - sweet toffee and molasses, with earthy brine. A touch of oxidation. Not bad.

Color looks like a cloudy quad.  Aroma is musk, dew, and mulch.  Flavor is incredibly salty, seawater, brine, brie, sap, malt, and resin.  Also reminds me of break-away erasers.  Would have given it a better overall, but Im still not sure if I like it or hate it.  Each sip alternates between joy and despair.  Bottle from Illinismitty. (Thanks, Smitty!)
Color is maroon, translucent, with a bit of lacing.  Taste is like licking a salty log, malty, smells earthy.  Subtle long-lasting palate.  Bottle from Illinismitty. (Thanks, Smitty!)

Bottle (Batch 8727) - Ruby pour with a big fluffy off-white head. Aroma is big--black licorice, toffee, molasses, and just a touch of warming heat. Smoothed out nicely. Taste has lots of bitter roast with sweet molasses undertones, charcoal, butterscotch, leather, tobacco, oak, and some alcohol warmth on the finish. Smooth and slick, with a decent amount of heft. Really sweet and complex and a nice sipper. This was a two-year-old bottle, and it confirms for me that Im going to have to put some of these away for awhile.
Alot of flavor and complexity going on here.  Had on draft tonight and out of bottle last week.  A sipping beer.  Would definitely get again and again.

This whole Micro-brewing has really gotten out of hand here in the states. But, that makes me a hypocrite because I was the first one to complain about not having options. Now Ive too many. Seriously. Its good though to know I can fall back onto some of my favourites before the micro-boom. Bells is one. I havent had all of their brew and may never do so, but damn do I love when I get to try a new one. It really makes me wonder if these other micro-brews sprouting up over night are really that good. Consistency and quality should become key. Its where America went wrong. We cant compete with quantity, and why should we? This brew reads like an American classic. A F. Scott Fitzgerald just makes age more easy, and so age makes this brew much better. But dont be fooled. This was good from the start, much like that Fitzgerald classic. The label does a good job of minimally reaching the point. Lots of sediment in this one so the pour was careful, into the recommend Snifter. Pours a dark brown-burgandy, much like a dark belgian ale. Nice head, good amount of low in fizz to keep it fresh. Nose is lots of vinted malts, oak like vanilla, worn leather. Landscapes of herbal qualities comes to mind. The great and once vast forest of colonial North America, cedar, eucalyptus, oak, maple. Taste is pure class and quality. Well sipped. Oak, worn leather, smooth vanilla ends with herbal and earth tones of fresh dug roots. Buffalo grass,  dark fruits such as plums and a slight apricot. Some slight tanin offers a nice bitterness to round out a slightly sweet, piece of perfection. Most other brewers would ruin this by leaning heavily on brown sugar, a Wal-mart like imitation. But not this brew, and certainly Bells would never sink to such levels. Massive <3s on this one. Next week Ill buy a 6er and see how far 10.2 % can age.
Bottle at monks. Deep brown pour with little head. Thin nose. Tastes slightly creamy with a thin, faint trace of alcohol. Woody flavor finishes well off the tongue. Would love to age this.
On tap at The Eccentric Cafe, pours a dark amber color with a frothy white head, aroma is has a great kick of hops and malt, very thick finish with a nice hoppy overall finish, very very good.

Bottle pours deep copper with a khaki head.  Aroma is brown sugar, raisins, toffee, figs, and apricot.  Flavor shows the same with additional notes of milk chocolate, plum, and cherry.  Overall body is full and soft, with a nice reinforcing alcohol warmth.  Good stuff, cant wait to see how well this develops.

Serving: 12 oz. bottle from Total Wine Sterling. 
Aroma: The nose is big and malty with notes of boozy fruit, raisins, dates, and figs. 
Appearance: It pours a deep amber color but it couldnt even form a head.  Just a small pool of foam sitting in the middle. 
Taste: Sweet but not very boozy considering the high alcohol content.  Lots of dried fruit, ripe plums, dates, raisins, and a surprisingly hoppy content given its age (from 2009).  The bitterness provides nice contrast to the malt sweetness. 
Palate: Medium to rich body with prickly carbonation and a sweet, then bitter finish.  You realize the alcohol content as it warms its way down your throat. 
Overall: Definitely one you could put up and save for awhile.  But when it tastes this good, its hard to keep your hands off it.  Definitely recommended.

UPDATED: DEC 5, 2013 Re-rated to reflect an aged version. 2006 bottle, shared. Pours ruddy brown with ruby highlights, decent carbonation, which is surprising. Nose is almost all caramel and toffee, a little winter fruit and raisin. Slick mouthfeel, with big plum, caramel, a little chocolate finish. Slight oxidation shows itself in mid-palate dryness, but still a nice lingering heat on the back palate. Graceful beer.

UPDATED: NOV 11, 2012 Rerate courtesy Johnsense, Aug 2010 bottle. Big figgy and raisin notes. Alcohol is completely integrated now. Lots of molasses still with a smoke edge. Two years really does it good.

Bottle purchased Oct 09 at the Brewery. Opened after 10 months is too soon, to my chagrin. Black Molasses, birch smoke and raw alcohol aromas from this deep burgundy ale, pours with a strong head that quickly recedes to a 1/8" light tan cap. Taste is again Molasses, some soya sauce and strong black tea flavours perking through, a light oily mouthfeel with faint carbonation. Probably needs 2 years in the bottle to fully integrate into the complex beast it could be.

$15.99 for a six pack at Total Wine in Jacksonville Florida.   Thats about the high end of what I would pay for any regular top end beer.  Bells makes it almost worth the money.   Served in a snifter.  Clear dark amber pour with a small beige head and some lacing.  Aroma of dark fruit, sweet dark malt, spice and booze, very pleasing.  Flavor is rich with sweet dark malt, caramel and toffee, roasty and boozy, with hop flavor and some bitterness at the end.  Very smooth and balanced all the way.  None of the abrasiveness of cheaply made barleywines.   Hides the alcohol well, so you dont really notice its 10.5% abv, just a mild alcohol warmth at the end.  Medium-full body but not overly chewy. Very drinkable and enjoyable.    Makes me wish I had a decent cigar to go with it.  Excellent!

8/13/10.  12oz bottle with big thanks to cbfobes!  Sweet bready aroma with dark sugars and dark fruits.  The flavor is sweet, but far from cloying, and filled with raisins, dark fruits, brown sugar, and even even some roast.  This is very flavorful without being too thick or viscous.  Very nice!

A: snifter. nice tawny colored brew, slightly opaque. nice khaki colored head. decent retention. mild lacing and some sediment.

S: nice warming malts. solid fruit aroma. some figs and pears.

T: great flavor out of this old ale. pears, figs, some apples. awesome citrus hop flavors. light spices from the yeast.

M: very warming. solid carbonation. wonderful palate for a "barleywine/old ale". medium bodied. great bite.

Bottle: Pours an amber color, with a modest head. Smells of molasses and raisins. Flavors of the same and a malty feel - frankly I didnt get anything else out of it. Slightly sweet flavors, overall. Slightly carbonated, perhaps slightly bitter as well. A decent brew - frankly my first barley wine.

Bottle from Cavie.  Brownish red pour with a tan head.  Aroma is alcohol, chocolate, dark fruit, spice, and more alcohol.  Taste is very roasted, cocoa, alcohol, vanilla, and almost woody.  Strong finish.

12 oz bottle courtesy of Summer Secret Santa.  Pours a muddy amber/brown color with a 1/2" off white head. Not a very attractive beer at all and that is the only negative thing Ill say about this marvelous brew. Aroma is heavy with sweet malt and the smell of dark fruits. Full, warming palate without being slick or oily.  Flavor is rich with plums, dates figs, cherries. Think alcohol soaked chocolate covered cherries. Then balanced with a muted hop flavor. God I love Barleywines.

2007 vintage on draft at Hopcat. Pours a deep amber/orange. Nose is robust with sweet tangerine and toffee, caramel and some nice hop notes. Round and full nose that keeps you sniffing. On taste, more great clean caramel notes, minimal oxidation and a full body. more of the citrusy honey comes through with a strong bitterness that compliments. Very well balanced. Fantastic.

Batch 7695. 2006 version. Bottle via trade. I wish I could remember who cause Ive been looking forward to it. Im pretty sure it was Sprinkle, cause hes the man.  Clear dark ruby color. Little amounts of head. Aroma is fairly heavy wood, raisin, mossy wood and clay. Very aged in nature. Taste is much of the same; wood, dark fruit, and heavy earth tones. Has a bit of vinegaresque flavor which I suppose developed over time. Has the beginnings of a soy flavor. Cool.

Draft. Stopped in the brewery and had a little sampler of several beers. Darker reddish amber color with a tan head. Sweet dark fruit aroma. Taste transitions nicely to a hoppy finish after the sweetness. Medium mouthfeel. Lingering taste. Very tasty.

2007 version, draught at HopCat, RBSG. Lovely brownish-orange with lace. Huge caramel, dried fruit aroma. Orange, dried oranges, a little spice. Sweet, somewhat oxidized flavor. Slightly sherry-like. Vinous and very smooth. Nice.

A: The pour is a slightly cloudy mahogany color with very little off-white head. It ends up being a thin ring around my snifter.

S: Plenty of brown sugar, caramel, and toffee right off the bat. A little bit deeper there are plenty of dark fruits such as plums, cherries, and maybe some figs.

T: A toasty malt and sugar flavor with a moderate bitterness. A good bit of brown sugar and toffee along with a mixed bowl of dark fruit flavors. Really well balanced between, overall.

M: The body is medium to full with a slight warmth to it. The carbonation is low to medium.

D: Though this definitely packs a punch, this is a dangerously easy to drink old ale. Im happy to have another bottle of this to stash away.

A very cloudy brown/deep amber with a small off white head that quickly diminishes into a ring around the edge of the glass. Aroma of caramel, plum, apricot, vanilla, grapefruit and a hint of clove. Medium thick syrupy creamy palate that briefly coats the mouth and has a nice alcohol warmth. Huge flavour of caramel, plum, some citrus, pine, raisin and spice. An excellent beer.

Lovely beer. Dark ruby color, thin tan head. Lots of malt in the nose. Flavor is sweet and bready to start, followed by a strong dose of hops. A good bit of burnt caramel followed by a strong alcohol warmth in the finish.

batch9385 into a standard pint.
Pours dark brown with ruby edges and a one-finger nearly white head which dissapears to just an island of foam.  Lacing is pretty scarce as well.  Odd since bubbles hang all over the place within. Nose is lots of malt, raisins, banana, and rum.  Taste starts very sweet - brown sugar, raisins, grapes, caramel, then some breadiness with some bitterness, dryness, and warming in the finish.  Mouthfeel is heavy with lots of carbonation. This is a sipper but a nicely complex (interesting) brew that I have had before and will seek out again.

Pours a beautiful deep burnt red with a light tan head which fades quickly.  The aroma is extremely complex with red wine, brandy, figs, dried prunes, raisins, and rich sugars.  No hop aroma.  Its one of those you can keep your nose in forever.  Taste is super heavy with esters and caramelized sugars.  Just enough bitterness to keep the sweetness from being cloying.  Full body with just enough carbonation to keep it lively.  A very fine example of a barley wine. One to enjoy with friends and fine cigars.

Probably the best-drinking Ive had from Bells. Pours a orange-brown emberish color, noticeable white ring of froth,with an overridden plethora of sweet and sticky syrupy smells; chocolate cotton candy can best describe it. It tastes burnt and sugary - truculently caramelized and lighthearted   I like this one, it has appeal and has more than one dimension of flavor.
Sunken among us to the Coast of another, does this wonderment of style come from the middle of where is nowhere, has this taken shape in our mouths as it tastes of merry!
Thick, rich, and tasty. A warm ale with caramel and vanilla flavors that run wild with a hint of molasses. DEFINATELY a keeper!

Bottle. 12 oz. Split with James. Pours a sick, deep amber with a creamy, rich tan head. Awesome lacing. Aroma of pepper, honey, slight copper, vanilla, barley, roasted malts, and toffee. Full bodied with a chewy, moderately spicy palate. Finishes with a great warming burn. Really good barley wine.
Bottle. Poured a ruby red color.  big aroma of caramel, little smokiness.  you taste some fruity sweetness, then caramel. you get a little booziness and tastes better as it warms up.  damn good beer.

12oz bottle, 2004 vintage, compliments of dukefan.  Poured a hazy, dark amber body with just a hint of tannish head.  Very appealing aroma of raisins, candied fruits and alcohol.  Flavor mirrors the aroma and was lightly sweet and just a touch bitter.  Great nose and a smooth, warming finish.

(12 oz bottle).  Pours dark amber color with off-white head.  Aroma of molasses, shortbread cookies, brandy.  Taste is bitter with sweet and sour for balance. Full bodied and creamy, this beer has quite a bit of fizziness on the tongue to it.  Finish is a long and lingering bitterness that is quite pleasant.  This is a fine beer.

Bottle. Dark ruby caramel color with lasting white head. Aroma is dark dried fruit of raisin plum, molasses sweet, toffee. Taste is boozy molasses raisin syrupy, goes big bitter at back end. Finish is long bitter and dry. Prevalent alcohol, bitter lasts on tongue. Sticky.
I love Old Ales and this is no exception. Put one of my favorite breweries and one of my favorite styles together and you get a winner. Very nice!

Im not a huge fan of barleywines, but this one - like almost everything that Bells does - is pretty doggone good. A rich, creamy texture with almost no carbonation hints at the plummy goodness and mild alcohol burn to come. This is from batch 8900-something, and so has been aging for about 6-9 months. Im eager to stash a few more away for the long haul to see how they improve with time.

Pours brown with a thick off-white head, pretty good lacing and carbonation is evident. Aroma is of brandy, light fruits, hops, fairly well balanced. Taste is a lot heavier on the hops then the aroma would give away with a slight alcohol burn in the end.
Perfect ale. Thats all their is to say about this beer. Nice brown color. Its taste is like heaven.
Tap. Pours a deep clear mahogany with minimal head. Aroma of raisins, caramel, and malt. Creamy texture with a bit of carbonation. Taste is toffee, caramel, and dark fruit. Nice beer.

12 oz. bottle batch 8211.  This is a beer I have had many times and just realized that I hadnt rated since Ive been on the site.  Pours a deep reddish amber color with a small, creamy beige head.  The aroma is a nice blend of dark fruits, creamy caramel, citrusy hops and some alcohol.  The flavor has ample dark fruitiness, more creamy caramel, a still noticeable amount of citrus and earthy hops that bring a solid bitterness well into the finish, and signs of the 10.2%. The alcohol is more warming than anything.   With warming, I also get more brown sugar flavors working their way in.  Medium-full bodied.  This is as solid a barley wine as you can find in many places in the US.

Vintage 2008 bottle pours a deep mahogeny with a thin white head that quickly dissapates.  Poured bottle carefully, yet ended up with yeast particulate in the glass.  Aroma of grapes, raisins, dates, plums, caramel, and toast.  Tastes of caramel, toffee, dates, grapes, and figs.  Alcohol present in finish.  Medium heavy body and carbonation.  Highly complex beer, well balanced and flavor rich.

Pour: Cloudy dark brown, slightly reddish hues.  Small head. Aroma: Resinous, caramel apple, hops, ripe fruits. Flavor: Intense, initially sweet, hints of piney hops, caramel malts. Dense, lively palate.  Finishes with with strong hops tones and a lite sweetness.  Excellent barleywine, very balanced and complex.

Bottle at Monks. Pours a ruby amber body with some lacing, no head. The aroma is very faint - some sweet malty notes detectable along with a touch of alcohol. The mouthfeel is thin to medium, silky and syrupy some what.  The flavor is somewhat subdued - and not knowing this was a barley wine, I would have never guessed the 10.2% alcohol content. Decent brew.

12 oz bottle poured into my snifter.

A- Body is a beautiful translucent medium mahogany hue that pours with a minuscule off-white head that dissipates so fast that I cant recall the exact color. Small white particles can be seen floating throughout as well as some yeast.

S- Molasses and caramel malt come through first in this brew with a hint of phenols. Im picking up something else but I cant tell quite what it is as I am not too familiar with this style of beer.

T- The flavor upfront is mild and I notice a hint of barley as well as caramel malt initially. A hint of molasses and sweetness is there as well. A sharp phenolic bitterness comes through at the end then the sweetness quickly soothes this and a nice balance of heat and sweetness come through much like a bourbon.

P- Medium to high carbonation. Body has a moderate phenolic acidity to it that is the highlight but not cloying.

O- This is a complex and interesting brew that I cant quite get my palate around. Im pretty inexperienced with the Strong Ales (Barleywines, Old Ales, other Strong Ales) and I tend to shy away from them- because they arent really my thing. The character to this one is phenolic for sure as it is a relatively fresh bottle, but it also has a distinctive sweetness to it and good complexity. I would like to try it once it has some age behind it. Its fun to venture to a style I am less familiar with none the less.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 01-06-2010 07:14:10

Another one that I tried at a tasting at Tims. 2006 batch. Aroma is sweet molasses and raisins with a touch of alcohol. Carmel colored & slightly cloudy with minimal head. Strong alcohol with a touch of raisins and molasses. Great to sip after a meal like a cordial. Very smooth on the tongue.

12oz bottle.  Nice amber color with no head.  taste was thick and hearty.  Very sweet caramel with vanilla.  of course a sippin beer.  Sweetness left my lips like a cany lolli pop.  Ver nice beer indeed

Reviewing this fresh.  Pours a deep mahogany with almost no head.  Nose is dark fruit and brown sugar.  Flavor is figs, raisons, molasses, and a bit of alcohol, though not too much given the 10+% ABV and the freshness.  In fact, while this is a big, bold beer, it isnt overly boozy.  If I didnt know this was a barley wine, I would swear it was a Belgian Quad.  Cant wait to see what age does to it when the malt really comes out.

Pours a beautiful amber color with a short-lived cream colored head.  Nose full of malts, hops, and vinous complexities.  Notes of vinous fruit, crisp hops, and warm malts that really open up as it warms.  Delicious beer!

First thing I notice is the ambiguous label of a rather uninteresting tree. I can only hope the beer has more personality. Pours cloudy amber brown, with yeast particles floating around the bottom of the glass. Only a small head sits atop, but quickly fades, leaving no lacing. The aroma is multi dimensional featuring elements of maple, oak, caramel, candy, and raisons. The taste contains much of the same. Caramel malts lead the way mixed with maple syrup, raisons and a touch of nut. Taste like it was wood aged as it has hints of bourbon. There is a significant alcohol presence in every sip making this a very warming beer. I imagine sitting by a fire on a cold winter night.
Pours brown with hint of red with thick tan head.  Aroma of caramel and dark fruits.  Taste of caramel malt, raisins, and has nice alcohol burn.  Full body.  Definitely a sipper brew.
This is a perfect nightcap ale; medium head, sweet and port-like up front, solid hops in the finish, plenty of alcohol.  I will put some up to age.

12oz bottle, 2002 vintage, thanks to ryan!  Rated 3/28/2010.  Pours a deep brown, red in the light, with a thin white head.  Smells incredible, with sweet raisins, a bit of alcohol, and dark fruit.  Tastes amazing, incredibly smooth, very malty, lots of chocolate, a bit sweet, and a finish raisins and only the slightest hint of bitterness.  Awesome!

Appearance: Very dark for a barleywine; dark brown, with hint of ruby; medium-lasting thick, light-tan head

Aroma: Very complex; rich malt with moderate hop character; sweet carmel, even a coffee note

Flavor: strong malt, bitterness builds mid-palate to finish; good balance towards bitter and strong alcohol flavors, perhaps a bit too much

Palate: Pretty textbook; full-bodied and chewy; with great, lush texture; long finish

UPDATED: MAY 11, 2010 Poured a beautiful hazy copper with a small beige head. Aroma: malt, fruits, caramel, grain. Taste: strong alcohol, mild grain, with a hint of caramel. Long finish of alcohol burning my throat. This beer has a ABV of 10.2% and it was not hidden at all... not really a bad thing, just not what I was expecting. Overall: a strong brew that tastes more like bourbon. Not much balance in my bottle. However, I would like to cellar a bottle for a few years and give it another try.

12 oz bottle thanks to Vince. Pours a hazy copper with a small dense beige head. Big aroma of toffee, caramel, citrus, dates and alcohol. Flavor is sweet and malty with an almost roasted bitterness, also a very light alcohol presence. Medium to full body with mild carbonation and a soft thick mouth feel. This is a really nice Barley Wine, the bitterness cuts the sweetness back and balances it out.
From a bottle poured a brown color with a good amout of head.  Syrupy pour sweet with a bit of alcohol in the finish.

Bells does it yet again. Strong, but not overly thick mouthfeel, especially for a barleywine. Surprisingly drinkable for such a high ABV. Excellent choice if you get a few extra bucks to spend on a 6er!

The beer poured hazy brown with no head and the aroma was sweet malty and fruity with citrus notes.  The flavor was grainy, malty with fruity notes, slightly sweet, OK.  The palate was thick with light carbonation, very pleasing.   This was an OK big beer, wasnt all that impressed with it, but it was drinkable.

The burnt umber colored body was topped with a small, one finger thick head.  There was a lot of yeast chunks floating around, so next time Ill have to pour more carefully.  The smell was bready, raisiny, and very malty, with just a hint of hops.  The taste was rich without being neither overly sweet nor brazenly bitter.  Very well balanced for such a high strength beer, with the alcohol not very evident either.  A lot of raisin and apricot notes in the flavors, which were accentuated by a hint of sourness in the finish.  A very satisfying heft to this beer as it traveled down the tongue.  Not a coating nature, but not slippery either.  Just a textured caress all the way through, somewhat similar to an orange juice with pulp in this matter.  The finish is where the hops shined the most in their spicy herbal bitterness.  Finish was pretty dry and warming.  Quite easy to drink, considering what it is.  Just got better and better, the more I took in.

Pours a deep red color, grainy, with a cream-colored head that gathers around the side. Aromas of vanilla, caramel, alcohol, and shoe polish. The palate is thick, softly carbonated, with a long-lasting finish. The taste is rich and malty upfront with a strong bitterness, tree-bark-like yeastiness, and alcoholic warmth at the end. This beer is almost overwhelming. I imagine it will mellow quite a bit with age. Definitely a sipper.

Bottle, 2009 vintage. Pours a dark hazy brown with a low almond head. Aroma is of sweet dark toffee with equal elements of grain, fruity yeast, and a vaguely swampy quality. Palate is quite carbonated, with flavours of dark toffee and hints of yeasty fruit. The finish is hot, bordering on harsh, with an astringent bitterness in the back of the throat. This seems like it needs a little time to mellow out. It just didnt come together for me. Upon reflection, this played more like an amped-up dubbel than a barley wine.
user_location: the land of bitumen, beef & beer, Alberta, CANADA

text: Beaytiful aroma of dark fruit, bread, booze, citrus.  The appearance is a nice hay red/brown, off-white head.  The flavor is a nice fruity, bread dough flavor, some booze.  The finish is light piney hops, sweet.  The mouthfeel is syrupy, very full bodied.  Excellent.

Sampled at Binnys Glen Ellyn, IL. After Dinner Tasting. Poured a clear, deep, orangy amber, with modest, off white foam to the head, and spotty lacing. The aroma was candi sweetness, hints of caramel, dark fruit and maybe a little citrus, alcohol, and a light vinous character. The flavor followed these notes closely, along with a moderate hop bitterness, and alcohol turned warming. Current, and not a cellared version, so the color was probably lighter, and the little citrus was noticeable. A tasty winter warmer!

Is a dark brown-red when poured.  Head was thin and dissipated rather quickly.  Aroma was a mix of semi-sweet malts and fruits, but not of the citrus variety.  Taste was initially fruity, with some malts and alcohol.  The alcohol started to become more apparent as the beer warmed.  Good amount of thickness, warms the body on a cold day.  Overall pretty damn good taste and drinkability, especially considering that it has a 10% ABV.

Pours brownish-amber with offwhite head that laces well, but isnt very thick.  Nose has some caramel, citrus and a slight herbal quality. Palate gives up plenty of caramel and holiday nuts, with a caramel sweetness that carries into the sweet finish.  Alcohol bites at the end.

[Bottle] How the hell have I not rated this yet? This beer is absolutely fantastic and if it were a rare release, would be rated much higher in general. Pours a clear caramel color with a smallish tan head. Aroma is sweet malts, caramel, figs, prune, raisin, alcohol, and light sherry. Flavor matches the aroma to a T, with a silky mouthfeel, moderate sweetness, perfect carbonation, and nice warming alcohol burn. Such a great beer. I look forward to its release every year along with Expedition and Hopslam.

12 oz bottle.  Pours a deep, murky brown, unpenetrated by light.  Head is thin and light tan.  Woody, chocolatey, malty aroma with a lighter twinge, maybe some citrus and alcohol.  Smoky, woody, flavor.  Quite earthy with some citrus and hoppy notes and a strong alcohol finish.  A strong beer with a lot of flavor.

Generally speaking, I tend to enjoy beers from Bells Brewery...Not so much with this brew.  It had nice color - a sort of dark ruby brown, and thats pretty much all that was good about it.  It had little to no aroma at all, it had flavor - mostly on the hoppy side but not a nice citrus, more the bitter...it wasnt malty enough, it had too much of an alcohol flavor to it, and well, I just wasnt a fan.  Maybe its better on tap?

Bottle. Batch 8269 so a little over two years old. Reddish brown body with a medium sized light tan head. Some oxidation in the aroma that interferes with everything else.  Some rich raisin, plum and alcohol.  Lots of toffee sweetness and a bit of bitterness along with oxidized cardboard notes. Improved as it warmed. Not bad, just a little too much oxidation for me to enjoy. My beer closet must be worse than I thought for cellaring.

Pours murky murky brown, tons of yeast swimming around in the glass, the whole bottom was covered with yeast. This beer is delicious, so thick and chewy. If you find this at least pick up one bottle, well worth whatever price, great all around and very potent.
Deep murky reddish brown. Little head disappears quickly. Aroma of dark fruit and fruity esters. Much of the same on the flavor. Decent but not my favorite barletwine.
Bottle from Tops.  Pours garnet with a trim beige head.  Smells of plums and booze.  Tastes of further plum, green strawberries, and vanilla.  Bitter hops become apparent as this warms.  Nice.

Bottle.  Over-rated barley-wine, overly sweet maltiness and some fruityness.  The hopping isnt very obvious, not at all aggressive.  Reminded me a bit about Anchor Old Foghorn, which is not such of a compliment.  But with Dieu Du Ciel Solstice dHiver as a personnal reference, most barleywines seems so annoying...

Poured into snifter, pours an extremely dark ruby/black/brown with a very thin film of soapy head.  Sweetness in the aroma, with some nice nutty caramel notes.  Really nice building sweetness, with a little burnt toast bitterness in the aftertaste.  Caramel and dark fruit combine slowly to build into a really nice soft sweetness to go along with the aftertaste.  Really good, and not heavy handed.

12 oz bottle from batch #9358 (I think).  At least thats the number on the bottle.  Poured a dark dark dark brown/red color with light head forming bubbles around the edge.  Good aroma of nuts.  Def an interesting taste.  This is my first ever barley wine and its certainly unique.  Lots of different flavors and ends fruity as the last goes down.   I was expecting a little more out of this but still a fantastic beer.  Maybe this style will grow on me down the road.

batch 7421 from the cellar in 12 oz bottle - a little over 4 years old. Pours a dark, viscous brown with a thin head. Aroma is malt and caramel sweetness with a clear alcohol presence. Sweetness is big and mellow with a serious alcohol warmth that pushes a creamy sip past the lips and over the gums. Secondary flavors are sweet date/raisin with hints of candy/licorice and vanilla. A great beer for a cold winters night, pushing out billing, and sending payroll reports to the accountant.

12 oz. bottle.  Fantastic barleywine!  Pours a dark brown with a tan head that fades to a nice ring of bubbles around the edge of the glass.  Aroma of bread, nuts, some caramel, dough, a touch of alchohol.  Taste is soooo good.  More caremel, toffee, dough, a little dark fruit and a litle bit of floral notes.  Texture is creamy with nice carbonation followed by a small bitter finish.  Great beer to drink on a sub-freezing evening, as I am right now.

My goodness batman. This may be the perfect barleywine. While the aromamanship is lacking a bit Id say the followup isnt. Pours a darkish brownish amber color with a semi spritzy head or pancake that lingers a bit. Full nectar with excellent carbonationmanship. A uniform malt density shielded by a "thorny jacket" Ill call the hop element. Not unlike a porcupine. This brew professes its love for gluttony and indulgence at first sip and carries me through to the light at the end of the tunnel. Its all brown cakebread, caramel, bit-o-honey, coffee cake, and pine sap. The finish is seared by the thorns of a thousand roses. NIce brew!

A nice caramel color on the initial pour.  Full bodied.  Half an inch of head dropping off a touch but the rest staying around for the duration.  Fruit, malts, caramel, along with hints of hops on the nose.  I taste caramel, malts, slight hops, toffee and some candied sugar also.  Great beer.

Bottle. Its a clear, reddish copper beer with an off-white head. West-coast sweetish maltyness on the nose, with some mint and a hint of cellar. Raisins, sweetness, alcohol, caramel and a cellar touch in the flavor. Full-bodied and warming, finishing malty sweet with some roasted malts, raisins and alcohol. A pleasant by-the-fire beer. 091016
it should be noted that this is one of my favorite beers! Great old ale that brings a kick.
pours a brown with a tan head aroma is caramel malt hops spices. flavor is bitter hops caramel spices earthy and grassy with some bitterness in the finish.

Bottle. Murky brown colour with a beige head. Aroma is sweet, resin, alcohol, malt, caramel. Flavour is sweet, resin, alcohol, herbs, malt, hop, apple, caramel. Full body. Nice slowtime drinking beer.

Pours dark brown with particles and a thick creamy tan head. Aroma of mild caramel, honey, caramel, dark fruit. Taste is sweet at first with a slightly bitter finish and some alcohol noticeable. Medium thin body, low carbonation. Roasty
Caramel / alcohol aroma with little head. Flavor is a sweet caramel and brandy flavor that lingers on the tongue.

12 oz. bottle from The Party Source.  Pours hazy reddish plum-brown color with almost no head, but a thin beige ring around the inside edge of the glass.  The aroma doesnt pop as much as Id expect, but has notes of raisins, caramel malt, blackberry jam, bread, cherry, alcohol, and earthy notes.  The flavor is boozy, with notes of raisins, cherries, caramel malts, brown sugar, fruit syrup, and alcohol.  Gets nicer as it warms.  Medium-bodied, with low carbonation.  Smooth.  Not bad, but definitely overrated and there are far better barley wines out there.

Bottle. Poured a darker brown color with a white head. Aroma was malts, bread, and spices. Flavor was caramel, bread, alcohol, and some bitters. Finish was dry and had some alcohol. As the beer warms the alcohol can be felt. A very full bodied beer. Had a long sticky finish. A great beer.

Bottle.  And an old ale it is.  Batch number 8135, so over two years of age in the bottle.  Pours a murky brown with a medium sized dirty beige head that deflates quickly.  Loads and loads of plum and caramel malt, coffee and a bit of chocolate.  Flavors follow the nose mostly, big creamy malt and caramel.  Huge booze on this, with a sort of packing peanut taste on the finish initially, moving towards coffee grounds as it warms.  The booze is so glaring its really hard to drink.  Not for me, but few barley wines are.

Bottle. Opaque - visually like a stout. Aroma of metal, chewable vitamins, cherries, burned sugar, whiskey, vanilla. Truth is I dont like the scents. Viscous, chalky on the tongue. At first not tasting much - malty sweet, but flavors indistinct cold. Tastier as it warms - for a barleywine, I just dont detect as much going on as Im used to.

UPDATED: OCT 25, 2010 Batch 8863.  Very dark toffee, creamy head, very light tan.  Little heat, lots of toasted brown sugar aroma.  Comes off young, little erratic.  Strong caramel, dried raspberry and blackberry.  Boozy, syrupy, sticky.  Awesome.  With such a muscular foundation I expect this to be a patient developer.  102510 Batch 8211.  Strong toasty toffee, seems to be peaking.  Toasty caramel, little peach, more warm toasty notes in the finish.

12oz bottle, batch 8943, bottled on Jan 28, 2009.  Pours reddish copper brown with almost no head, just a light whispy covering.  Couple of spots of lacing and a lot of floaties.  Aroma is pretty subdued, some caramel malt and a little cherry cola.  Flavor is sweet and malty, caramel, some citrus and bitterness on the finish.  Mouthfeel is sticky but not too thick, low carbonation.  Pretty good but a bit underwhelming.

12 oz bottle - pours deep, deep red, with a brownish thick rocky head that basically lasts forevah.  Aromas of booze, dried dark fruits, musty hops, plum.  Flavours subtle but complex, lots of dark fruit again, honey, incredibly dry bitterness.  At four years old, it seems more like a port than a barley wine, which I suppose is the point.  Absolutely wonderful sipper.
Barley wines have been hit and miss with me so far. This one was a hit. Nice balance, smooth drinking.

Pours out a dark reddish brown with a little bit of head that goes away quickly. Leaves a bit of lacing. Aroma is fruity with some hops present. Taste is the same as aroma and this one goes down smooth. Large amounts of sediments present.

UPDATED: DEC 9, 2012 First ratingInitial Rating Date: 12/21/2009355 ml bottle, thanks to Schroppfy!Marked 9358Shady dark brown color, dense tasn to light brown head. Caramleized sugar, "knäck", alcohol, milky scent. Also malty and bready like "knäckebröd". Some cinnamon. Sweet, bitter, sugar, fudge, alcohol taste. Bitter aftertaste. Rather dry still. Smooth mouthfeel, though very dry mouthfeel after a while, especially for a Barley Wice. Rather low bitterness, though still there. Nice, not as overly bitter or overly sweet as many commercial BW can be. Scent is very nice, taste not as good as the scent.8/4/7/4/16=3.9RerateBottle purchased from Kingdom Liquors, Brandon, FLSampled on February 26, 2011Clear copper color, yellow head. Sweet, grainy, bitter scent. Sweet, bitter, dry taste. Medium mouthfeel, medium high bitterness.6/4/6/3/13=3.2RerateBottle thanks to (non-ratebeer) Matt/Nekrobarr! Sampled on December 2, 2012.Clear red color, big tan head. Sweet, malty, alcohol taste. Warming alcohol. Smooth mouthfeel. Sweet, malty scent. Medium bitterness.7/4/7/4/15=3.7

12oz bottle.  Pours a thick, opaque darkest shade of red-brown, approaching blackness.  Minimal head, some bubbles in the middle and coating the edges.  The aroma is quite rugged, lots of liqueur notes.  Relatively soft on the palate, this is quite a nice beer.  Lots of raisin and dark fruit notes, but they are balanced out nicely alcohol and very light hops. Big and rich, but still maintains a smooth creaminess.  Really one of the best examples of the style I can think of offhand.  Rich caramel tones, some chocolate toffee in the finish.  Awesome beer.

12 oz bottle. A lot of anticipation here and for the most part, not a lot of disappointment. Definitely a rich and malty barely wine that goes down smooth. On the aroma, a good amount of nutty toffee, cake mix, cocoa powder, dark sweet fruits, and  cola. Not off balanced there, but also no real hop presence. On the pour, a light layer of cream head, a medium thick body, and dark cola brown in color. As far as the taste goes, this is a great feeling beer, especially on a cold winter night. Sweet, full bodied, creamy, and yet has the right amount of pop. The aroma and flavor notes also play off each other very well, each with a similar profile. Nutty toffee cake, dates, cherries, and other sweet fruits. More a bitter nutty chocolate through the malty finish. The overall package here is very nice, though not terribly exciting. Just very solid.

12 oz bottle no head but who cares. A barley wine that taste much like Bells thick porters or stouts. This is one of my favorite styles so hard for me not to give this a high grade. Served in a sniffer just the brew to have on a winter evening. taste of molasses with a slight hint of hops with a strong chocolate malt finish. I shall take one and put in the "beer cellar"

12oz bottle poured into a tulip glass produced a light frothy tan head with dark amber body.  Aroma of citrus and caramel.  Flavors of nutmeg, cinnamon, and the sweetness of cotton candy.  Lots of sediment and floater were present.  Nice warming ale.

A 12 oz. bottle courtesy of "hannont". Colour... garnet-amber with no head. Nose... sweet with hints of dried stone fruits and muscovado sugar. Palate... sweet, sirup-like, hoppy, with loads of candied fruit, raisins, dark currants and ..."bring us some figgy pudding, yes bring us some figgy pudding" and a helluva long finish!

Batch #9358 Bottled Sept 23rd, 2009. It poured a dark mahogeny brown with an orange tinge and orange highlights around the edges of the glass. The head was a light tan and about 1", but it went down to just a film rather quickly. There were bits of sediment suspended in the glass. There was a good earthy roasted malt aroma, with some alcohol, a faint bit of chocolate and some dark dried fruit scents as well, The texture of the beer was thick, creamy and smooth. The flavors were many, molasses, chocolate, raisins, plums and a good warming alcohol flavor. The beer mellowed on the finish with a good lasting flavor and a touch of a hops bite and the warmth of the alcohol. Excellent beer for a winter night.

Pours a glowing amber if you hold it against the light, with fairly large yeast sediment swirling around my pint glass from the 12oz. bottle: Nose is of caramel and bitter, dark chocolate, brown sugar, dark fruits, and a hint of hops. Flavors are similar. Thick mouthfeel, but incredibly smooth. The sweet malts, rather than overwhelm, complement a mildly bitter finish. Characteristically spicy after the swallow. Drinkability: Complex, balanced and thoroughly enjoyable. Best barleywine Ive had to date. #237 on 04122009, DG.

Pours very thick and brownish orange. The aroma is pretty complex with notes of chocolate, orange, caramel, molasses, and maple syrup. The flavor is very sweet with orange, prunes, caramel, maple syrup and a touch of cocoa in the finish. Not really all that bitter to me. The sweetness overpowers everything else, but it is complex and chewy. Really a classic example of the style.
Bottle approx. 5 years or older. pours a rich brown amber, Aroma of molasses and burnt sugar cotton candy sweet. Too malty sweet for me but the beer is what its supposed to be.

UPDATED: NOV 26, 2009 12 oz bottle, 5-6 years old, no batch number or date on bottle. Beautiful deep reddish brown, tan head. Aroma of molasses, caramel, raisins, and burnt sugar. this beer is huge. Big caramel sweetness, deep flavor. This is a special occasion beer.

BATCH #8727 (September 25, 2008)

Man, I love Bells Brewery, and Im glad to finally get the chance to try this one. Super thanks go out to VandenBossche for hooking me up with this.

Pours a hazy, medium/dark brown color. A lightbulb will get the edges to show a golden glow, but little else. One-finger head od truly tan colored foam. Retention is okay. Lacing is spotty, but fairly decent.

Nice level of maltiness comes through, surrounded by a big presence of breadiness. Raisins and dark fruit jamminess. Slight earthiness mingles with a nice hint of maraschino cherries (!). Loads of sugarey sweet caramel notes. Definite brown sugar notes.
Smells like a decadent dessert brew.

Butterey french toast, covered in cherry syrup. 
Big yeasty bread notes, nice sweet caramel presence, slight hints of warming spices and a top-off of sweet cherry flavor. 
A different taste than Im used to expecting from an Olde Ale, but I certainly like it.

Smooth and creamy, which is nice, but I expected it to be a bit more lush. Especially after the nose. (Yum!) So, it could have done better, here.

The ABV is undetectable, by me, so Id say, drink em if it suits ya. It suits me quite nicely, thankee sai. 
I just wish I had regular access to Bells and didnt have to rely on trades, or out-of-town trips, to aquire them.

draft @ redlight redlight.  Caramelly molasses notes on the nose with hints of toasted malts as well.  Pours a rich caramel colored amber with a thin white head.  Rich malts, caramelized figs, candied raisons, rich caramel flavors with dark dried fruits, very smooth, with spicy hoppy finish.
8th June 2008. Strong ale. Slightly sour caramel and matl that has a hint of saltiness. Goes down easy enough but I could not have drunk a second bottle.

Poured from bottle into Snifter.

Cloudy reddish-brown that glows ruby in the light. White thin head with minimal lacing.

Aroma of butterscotch, dark fruit, brown sugar and a big whiff of alcohol.

Sweet and alcoholic malt body, with strong notes of butterscotch, plum and molasses. Ends with a very peppery hop note, but not bitter at all.

Low carbonation, thick chewy body, a little smooth but also a little chalky.

Solid Barleywine overall, but there are others I would rather seek out again, as this has a little more booze than depth.
Wow! Pours brown/amber. Small head not very thick body, lighter barley wine .  Alchohol and yeast flavor, u know its a barley wine.

Bottle. Glad I finally got my hands on this brew.  Aroma is caramel and fruit.  Poured a nice dark burgandy.   Flavor is all dark fruit a good touch of brown sugars and nice grapefruity hop.  Palate is mouthfilling. Overall, what can I say about Bells, its hard to find a bad one.

bottle - cloudy/hazy brown beer, pours a bit thicker than water with a smallish head that doesnt leave much for lacing. It seems like it doesnt have much for carbonation but a good swirl of the mug brings out more bubbles. Complex aroma with strong caramel, brown sugar, dark fruits and a hint of hops. Goes thick over the tongue, smooth and a bit hot. Mildly bitter but it balances well with the malt. I like this BW and plan to age a few.
Smells of fruit and yeast. Taste of prunes and dark sugars with some hints of possible figs. Has a slight alcohol finish but overall good. A very well balanced barley wine beer.
(bottle) hazy brown, small beige head, aroma of intense longan, hops, bit of alcohol; flavour of hops, fruit; long bitter finish

Reddish brown in color, med/low carbonation, with aromas of plums, figs, and dark sugars.  Flavor is medium bodied, toffee, light roast, med alcoholic, cherries, nutty, creamy, and has a long, sweet finish.  This should develop nicely for many years.

Bottle, thanks to TheCheeseMan. Pours a dark, hazy copper brown, with a finger of creamy beige head that dissipates slowly to a ring. Aroma is of soft, sweet butterscotch, nuts, vanilla, some spices, perhaps cinnamon or cardamom, raisin and dried apricot. These notes return in the flavour, along with fresh tasting bready malts and brown sugar with a solid earthy and slightly citric semi dry hop finish that makes it surprisingly drinkable. A noticable alcohol sting as well. This bitterness in the finish is actually a bit harsh, would have liked it toned down just a little bit. Guess that will improve with age, but for now, I only have this one bottle. Full bodied, carbonation is smooth, loads of tiny tiny bubbles. Overall a complex and enjoyable brew which probably improves with age.

(Bottle, Monks Café, Wallingatan, Stockholm) Reddish brown colour with frothy, beige head. Malty, fruity nose with dried fruit, red berries and caramel. Malty, fruity taste with notes of caramel, orange peel, red berries, black-currant and a slightly vinous finish with generous amounts of earthy hops. Full body, fairly sweet. Lots of taste and brilliant balance between the solid malt and generous hop character. Lovely beer!

12 oz bottle from a long while back, single bottle frm somewhere. Pours a nice copper hue, darker, decent haze, a nice red body underneath almost, with a moderate tannish head, stays at a decent layer with decent lacing. Aromas are a rich caramel and toffee malt base, bringing floral and grapefruit hops underneath, a rich sweetness with a touch of toast, vanilla, and a faint nuttiness. Good fruitiness, almost candied fruit is the theme. Initial is a richer sweet body, still only moderate bodied, with a decent dosing of hoppy bitterness behind. Toffee, caramel, a touch of vanilla, with some candied fruits, or sweeter ones at that, with a decent booziness, dusting of cinnamon. The hoppy elements are pretty good and help balance this malty brew, in fact the hops are really the most prominent part of the finish with some decent trailing malty sweetness. A solid brew.

12oz bottle, batch 8211, poured into a tulip.

Pours a murky caramel brown with hints of orange through the edges with a big creamy off-white head that shows fairly good retention and leaves very little lacing.

The aroma is dominated by caramel malts, toffee and dark fruits.  There are lots of sugar coated raisins in the nose and there is a bit of citrus hops left in the nose up front, but theyre not nearly as noticeable as they likely were fresh.

The taste is slightly more bitter with a sharp hop bitterness up front which gives way to the toasted caramel malts, but its definitely less sweet than the aroma would suggest.  As it warms, the toffee and dark fruits start to show, but the finish is boozy and bitter with less lingering sweetness than I was expecting.

The mouthfeel is slick with soft carbonation and a sugary dessert-like body overall.  Definitely coats the palate completely.

This is a solid brew from Bells, a drinkable barleywine thats not overly complex but is certainly tasty.  Its not one of my favorites from Bells, but thats a pretty high hurdle (see Oracle).

Dark copper pour, Lemon zest and lots of citrus and grapefruit aroma, some caramel sweetness to the malt as well a little toasty. Flavor has a lot more orange or red grapefruit to it then expected, sweet finish.but still dry. Very nice

Dark Copper Pour.  Aroma is caramel malt with a touch of light bread.  Hops are grapefruit and lemon zest.  Flavor is sweet and fruity - blood orange and grapefruit.  Some sweet cedar woodiness coaxes the malt along until the finish which is nice and dry.  Really Enjoyable

12oz bottle.  Copper color.  Aroma of sweet bready malt.  Nice caramel, some alcohol.  Some leather, dark fruit, molasses, hint of citrus hops.  Flavor has a lot of alcohol.  Sweet wort, biscuits, caramel, earthy, raisins.  Nice toasted malt in the finish along with Alcohol.  Very, very good.  This beer makes up for some of the other Bells Ive recently had that have been below quality.

thanks to jblauvs for this one. Dark amber pour with a small bubbly head and lots of yeast sediment. Aroma holds citrus at the start with lemon and grapefruit, then moves to bready malt, caramel, and a more pronounced malt character. Hop presence is great on the tongue, with similar traits to the aroma. Palate is really nice; immensely smooth for 10.2 % ABV, great finish. Really tasty American style barleywine.

Thanks jblauvs. Dark copper pour with a smallish white head. Aroma is citrus hop and a delectable caramel sweetness. A biscuity toasty malt rounds out the aroma with a slightly alcoholic nature. Flavor is quite hop oriented with grapefruit, orange and lemon coming through. Caramel and toffee complement and balance out the hoppy nature nicely. Palate is full and bubbly with a lingering dry hoppy finish. Quite nice.

Pours a cloudy dark brown color with slight amber edges when held to a light source and a thin beige head that very quickly fades into a lasting ring.

Earthy and leathery aroma with some chocolate malt, subtle hops, sweet alcohol, grape and dark fruit.

Hoppy up front with a peppery spiciness followed by a dark roasted malt presence and a lot of sweet alcohol flavor. Hints of dark fruit and licorice with a decent amount of alcohol warmth in the finish.

Bottle at the Brick Store Pub. Murky copper in color, lots of floating particles in my glass. Really lovely, complex nose--dark fruits, particularly black cherry and raisin, berries, some malts, molasses, and even some honey. Flavor follows with all those, plus some spice and alcohol. Pretty thick brew, really demands you take your time and enjoy it. Very nice.

12oz bottle from City Beverage in Winston-Salem, enjoyed out of a Duck-Rabbit pint glass in a mall parking lot as a "pre-party" beer (dont worry, I wasnt driving).  Pours a clear dark reddish-brown with a foamy beige head.  Aroma is caramel, molasses, dark fruits, mild roast, and brown sugar.  Flavor is malty and fairly sweet with caramel, raisin, cherry, wood, brown sugar, and maple syrup.  Palate smooth, full, and creamy with some alcohol warmth.  Another great one from Bells.

Two year old Third Coast Ale. Aroma is of fruit, maple sugar, oak, syrup, and roast. Flavor is of maple syrup, dried fruit, oak, and roasted grains. Finish is a little alcoholic with a hint of brown sugar. Coats the mouth. Ages like the remainder of the human race in a mineshaft over 100 years (Dr. Strangelove), sweetly -- complex like a sample of the human race. But really, a great beer. Deserving of the humor of Stanley Kubrick.

From coyotehunter via trade.  Poured an attractive dark copper/light ruby color with very little head.  The beer was almost viscous, thick and clingy.  Lots of malts, dark fruits and light citrus with a nice whiff of alcohol.  The flavor is malts, dark fruits, light spice and citrus with some pleasant warming alcohol.  Nice coating mouthfeel.  Enjoyable and well made.

33 cl bottle, Fargo, ND, USA via Kalamazoo. Thick and syrupy looking pour, hazy orange autumn leave colour. Earthy aroma, mild raisin. Mildly syrupy in the mouth, sweet, with a creeping alcohol finish that is balanced by the sweetness.

Bottle at Akkurat.

Pours clear red brown with a beige head.

Smells of citrus hops, red berries and a bit vinous.

Tastes sweet and a bit burnt like gluwine.
Bottle. Very good brew! The body is incredible soft and smooth. Tastes and smells dried fruits, spices and bitterness in the aftertaste. One of the best american barley wines ive had.

Nose of caramel apples, dark fruit, light hop presence is somewhat noticeable too. Nice reddish amber, hazy, thin foam ring. Caramel apples, earth, some darker fruit notes, decent spicy hop bitterness, and some alcoholic notes. Nice bitter hops balance out the caramel apple sweetness. Soft carbonation and big bodied.

UPDATED: MAR 27, 2010 (12oz bottle) Pours a cloudy brown with oily bubbles and low head. Nose is alcoholic, raisins, caramel and spices. Taste is spicy hops, alcohol kick, and more cinnamon. Finishes with the spicy hops and has a nice sweet malty backbone to compliment the whole thing. The body is thick and oily as it should be. A really nice barley wine.

My chalice glows with the dark rusty haze of old ale delights. She is burnished mahogany and old wood given a new breath of life. A soft khaki head laps at the edges of my glass, splashing back to the center in confused globules of fragile foam. Lace carefully decorates while I cup my glass, waiting a few minutes for my body warmth to coax her closer to proper quaffing temperature. As I wait, her nose grows ever impatient; deciding to take action in her own hands, an irresistible aura of sweet boozy delights strut their stuff under my nose. Seduction is her wily ploy, and I am a willing victim. Nose-deep into my glass, wanting to be as close as possible to heaven, my nose drips a precious drop or two of Old Ale when I emerge for air. Sweet and boozy with spiced rum, brown sugar, maple, dry wood, burnt sugars, earthy licorice root, red apples, pears, dried cherries, dried prunes, and a warm wisp of chili powder and dried chili peppers. Did you get all that? Take notes. I know I did, and I lay with her nose for a good many minutes. Beautiful. As I wet eager lips, the skies open, light shines down, and angels sing. Another beautiful beer moment has descended even as my soul ascends. Rich, sweet, dry, and mouth-coating all at the same time. Whether an Old Ale or Barleywine, it is easy to understand why these robustly complex beers were prized during the 19th century; and even more mind-boggling why they almost disappeared from the pages of brewing all together. But I digress. She immediately leaves my mouth awash with dry wood, dry spices, and pervading warmth that soothes. Her alcohol hits the back of my throat while my lips smack with brown sugars and warm maple syrup. In the middle, red apples and yellow pears picked fresh from the orchard explode with flavor as I bite into their juicy bounty. A wisp of tart prune juice flitters on and off again as rum, spice, wood, plums, apples, pears, and warmth make sweet love to my palate. Exquisite. Delicious. An instant classic. I cant wait to see how she matures over time.


I almost want to set aside more than one bottle of this beer to age, but I only have so much space in the old apartment to utilize at the moment. The idea is tempting though In the meantime, the Third Coast Old Ale from Bells Brewing is a seasonal release, so make sure to grab a 6pack or two before the 2009 batch is retired and one has to wait until spring of 2010 for more.

Bottle.  This ale is dark brown with a ruby hue and a frothy coffee-like tan head, poured in a snifter.  The aroma is huge: oak, dark chocolate, molasses, brown sugar, prune, raisin, alcohol.  Mouthfeel is full and chewy.  Theres lots of wood in the flavour, oak with some chocolate, prune.  The finish is long and dry with plenty of dark fruit, raisin, prune, cherry.
Pours a brown color with a very thin white head. Aroma of malts and caramel. Flavor is of some fruits, nuts, and caramel. Pretty good beer.

Reddish-brown with a medium-sized cream-colored head.  Lots of malted barley in the nose, with lots of sweet raisins in the taste.  Alcohol is obvious, but pleasant and helps offset the sweetness.  Dry finish is unexpected from the aroma and initial taste of sugary molasses, but also balances the beer somewhat.

Tap at Ashleys. Poured a hazy dark amber with an off-white head. Lots of malt and barley in the aroma with undertones of smokiness and some nuttiness. Flavor was sweet with malt and barley notes. It was quite thick on the tongue.

A beautiful old ale.  Caramel, malty, nutty.  Just enough carbonation and dryness to keep it from getting too sweet to drink.  Could have a couple bottles easy.  Well, easy on the palate, not on the walking away.

Cloudy amber color.  Some head with little lacing.  Smell is nutty, malty, with a little alcohol.  Taste is crazy-legithoppier than expected, with fruity, malty undertones.  Pleasant alcohol presence is also detectable.  Really, really good.
Aroma is of sweet malty notes with little fruits.  Flavor similar.  Not a bad beer.

Bottle. Appearance: Pours a dark brown with just a ring of bubbly off-white head that lingers. Aroma: Sweet and malty with some fruit on the nose. Flavor: Molasses and brown sugar with dark fruit notes. Alcohol is definitely present in this one. Palate: Medium-full body. Slick, syrupy mouthfeel. The alcohol lingered as it warmed up. Overall: A respectable barley wine for sure. This is the first beer Ive had from Bells, I guess you could say I dove right in. I dont regret it for a minute.

Bottle, thanks to tytoanderso. Aroma big and malty with tons of toffee and brown sugar, orange fruits cutting through just a bit, not sure if its from hops or not. Flavor follows just as expected. Wasnt bad at all, enjoyable even, but also for me exactly the same as many another such beast.
Bottle pours dark brown with a thin beige head. Lots of malty goodness in the nose. Flavor is lots of malt, dark ripe fruit, and a little booze.

bottle, pours brown with a medium off white head.  Aroma is light with brown sugar, some vanilla and yeast.  Flavors start mildly sweet with some biscuit malt and a tart apricot feel that yeilds to a hop and spiced peppercorn finish.  Lingers, but is dry at the same time.  A nice barley wine that grows in character as it warms with some alcohol in the finish as well.  Carbonation is moderate with a medium to heavy mouthfeel.  I could sip this for a while.

12 oz bottle at brickskeller in DC. Pours a nice dark almost opaque brown color. Aroma is sweet and malty with some spice. Taste is pretty spicy and sweet, very little bitterness, and the high alcohol content is very evident. Palate is very full and really fills the mouth with flavor. Very full body- not really meant to be consumed in large quantities. Definitely suited for a cold winter night but enjoyable any time of the year.

Bottle.  Pours a super cloudy brown with a small ring of white head.  Aroma of super sweet malt, raisin, apple skins.  Typical barleywine aroma.  Flavor is quite malty with light fruits and raisins.  Certainly very sweet but not bad actually (considering that barleywines are not my favorite style).  Heavy though.
7/4/7/4/15 (3.7/5)

Original review date 3/26/2008...

Rustic, bountiful frothy head with deep, dark mahogany body - looks like very nice stuff.
