A little skunky aroma, sort of like raw dough or sourdough - interesting

Deep hoppiness and heavy caramel malt with alcohol presence - balance is not an issue

Bitter mouthfeel but it coats nicely

Good stuff - of course its rather heavy

12 oz bottle in a snifter. Pours a cloudy dark tea color, lots of sediment, with a decent off-white head which dissipates.  Aroma is burnt candied sugar, toffee, brown sugar, lots of sweet malts.  Flavor is sweet malt, caramel, brown sugar, maple, and nice hopped bitter finish.  Nice alcohol warmth which is true to the style.  This could age very well.

Amazingly, if I have had this one, I dont remember.  A very impressive looking beer, a dark, deep amber color with a nice fruity sweet aroma.  This beer is sweet, malty and full of fruit, but has a nice hop presence and a nice warm ending.  This is a great beer, one that could only improve with time.  I would like to try this one on draft or maybe try it in a vertical tasting.

12 oz bottle from Greenwood in Bowling Green. Off-white moderate head fades quickly and leaves some lacing on sides of glass. Rusty brown body, slightly hazy and thick. Aroma of walnut, malt, alcohol. A relatively light barleywine on the palate with flavors of molasses, brown sugar, banana, caramel, & oak. The alcohol is pretty forward on this one.

I have been cellaring this since 2003: Pours a murky brick red with almost no head. Brown sugar, plums, maple syrup, damp basement and alcohol on the nose. Flavor of caramel and prunes up front with a slight alcohol finish. Very little carbonation. No hops apparent at all. Very easy to drink. This ages better than most of the other barleywines I have cellared, but I prefer it fresh.

Aroma: Very standard barley wine style aroma. Nothing distinctive, but nice and nothing offensive.  Apperance.  Intersting 3-pour.  First third (top third of botte) amber, transparent with a little settlement.  Second third: more brown but significant move to translucent bordering on opaque.  Bottom third: Opaque, brown.  Taste:  Combined all three pours.  Typical barleywine, although I would say the heat of the alcohol wasnt as well hidden as I would like.  Palate: again, typical barleywine style - it was fine, but nothing outstanding.  Overall: solid, safe Barley Wine style ale, but not truly exceptional.
Pours a dark amber color with a slight frothy head. Has a mild caramel smell. A bit smokey with hints of caramel very different for a barley wine. I will age this one and I cant wait to re rate.
Dark brown in color.  Almost no head.  Aroma of malt and yeast.  Flavors of malt, hops, toffee and raisins.  A smooth taste, warming and tingling.  For being 10.5% this beer is real easy to drink.

Aroma is strong but soft, malty and yeasty with an earthy undertone. It pours a dark clear amber brown with not much of a head. Flavor is malty, earthy, slightly hoppy, with smoky undertones and just a hint of cloves. Texture is fairly tingly and edgy, but also smooth and soft as a kitten.
The bottle looks good, the beer in the glass also. Starts old-malty, firy, a bit earthy, modest alcoholic. Finish a bit moldy. Well balanced finish, really good beer!

12 oz bottle.  Pours a dark ruby with virtually no head.  Aroma is of caramel, figs, dark fruit, and cherries.  Flavor is very similar to the aroma on this one, but with a bit of hops thrown in.  Not bad, but a bit overrated.  I like my barley wines to be prominent and strong and nothing in particular stood out on this one.

Tasting at Bells Fest in OH.  Poured a very interesting cloudy plum color with no head, reminded me of a bloody mary actually.  Sweetness in the aroma and same in the flavor with a great hoppy bitterness to play off the sweet sappy/woody characteristics.

Murky amber-brown, medium beige head, only temporary lace. Aroma of caramel, with a bit of smoke and toffee.  Flavor of caramel, powerfully resinous, woody, pine resin, tea, a bit of orange juice. Nothing is off here, and its certainly not bland, but it comes together as far less than the sum of its parts, and I dont like it. Full bodied, drinks smoothly.

Moderately strong aroma of caramel, figs, walnuts, blackberries, with a buttery edge. Cloudy brown, full of floaties. Medium yellow head. Resinously bitter and syrupy sweet. Tastes of pine sap and cherry cough medicne. Intensely rich. Smoky dried leaves afterwards. Alcohol is there but sidelined by the richnessn of flavor. I found it overbearing, but  enjoyable when sipping. Not for chugging!

A dark and foreboding concoction from Bells, great for a winter day or even, as it was for me, a weekend afternoon in June.  This is a peculiar one, it seemed to me that the beer was in a bad mood.  Dark, surly, and angry all come to mind.  Beer noir might be a better name for this one, and not as a reference to the color.  Hurts so good.

12 oz bottle courtesy of Adrian. Pours a dark cloudy amber colour with a reddish tint. Had a frothy off-white head which quickly dissipated. Aroma of oak, raisins, figs, plums, cherries, hops, malts, and brown sugar. Particles of hops floated throughout the beer and settled on the bottom. Tastes of dark fruit and hops. Great flavour.

12 oz. bottle (2008-09) in a snifter; pours a deep, deep ruby w/ a solid yellowish-white head that gradually sinks into some luscious lacing, rocky on the edges; aroma is sweet malty, heavy bread, hops and toffee; flavor is sweet and hoppy w/ nuts, leading into a long, bitter finish; extremely chewy. The bread in the aroma is truly the beers highlight- lovely. The only barley wine, along w/ North Coasts Old Stock Ale, that I have truly enjoyed.
Dark copper pour. Virtually no head. Aroma is sweet with a hint of hops. Maybe the smoothest BW Ive had. Scarily easy to drink. Great balance of huge malt and hope.

hazy dark amber under large creamy cream colored head.  heavy bouquet aroma of caramel, dark fruit, cherry, molasses.  flavors of sweet plums, cinnamon, cherry, molasses, cookies, caramel, christmas spices, floral.  an easy drinker for 10.5%.  smooth velvety palate.  more english than american.

12 oz. bottle from Grape & Gourmet (Batch 8211, bottled November 18, 2007).  Dark orange pour with a thick and creamy off-white head.  Aroma of citrus, cherry, soy sauce (theres a surprise but its hard to miss), and some sweetness.  Flavors of plum, raisin, orange, brown sugar, and chocolate.  Very smooth, but very complex.  Alcohol is not noticeable at first but more detectable as this one warms up.  An excellent barley wine that exceeded my expectations.
bottle, #7124, thanks to lumpy, dark amber color with no head, lots of raisin, plum and soy in the nose, flavors are butterscotchy, plum, chocolate, caramels, nice warm finish
An incredibly tasty strong ale.  Very rich flavor.  Sweet and somewhat dark fruity.  A very impressive balance.

Bottle after the 6000 not a good idea. It was a let down. But still pretty tasty. Pours out a brown topped with a small head.  Aroma of sweet brown sugar and some hops. Tast was of more brown sugar and a nice bitter end.

Pours deep mahogany with thick tan head.  Aroma is bursting with dark fruit- cherries, plum, figs, and some vinous notes, along with cola, biscuit, brown sugar, and oak.  Very slight citrus notes come through after some warming.  Flavor begins with sweet cherry and grape and finishes with bready malts, cola, chocolate, caramel, and some malty bitterness.  Really well balanced.  Palate is full and rich without being sticky.  Great example of a traditional ale.
Deep reddish-brown pour with a bit of haziness and a foamy head.  Malt, ripe fruit, and a touch of hop aroma.  Flavor is about the same.  Good, but I wish there was more hoppiness.

Batch 8211 which was packaged on 11/9/07 so this is about four months old. The color is a dark red and the smell is strong fruits like grapes and then fumes from the alcohol. The flavor is definitely more malty than hoppy and the alcohol is slightly present to the tongue. Overall, decent barleywine.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 03-23-2008 03:56:05  id: 646242

Draft.  Pours a murky brown with a thin head.  Aromas of sweet malt and cherry. Flavor is a strong bitter all the way through, along with some malt and chocolate. It got better as it got warmer, Id love to try this after it has been aged a few years.

12 oz. bottle.  This is definitely not what I  expected.  A murky brown pour full of sediment and an off-white head.  Heavy aromas of fruit and molasses, too sugary.  Given the tag of ale, I anticipated hops and bitterness.  Medium-bodied.  Its a bit overwhelming.

UPDATED: JUN 16, 2010 Bottle, The Den, Kalamazoo. Ruby red colour, tiny off-white head. Wouldn´t guess this is a barley wine. Thin bodied. Aroma of caramel malts, raisins and plums. Flavour has caramel malts, sour fruits, hops. Sweet finish. Not sure what to think of this.



Bottle from Bells Beer shop. This is good stuff. Oily texture, raisins, molasses. +.4

UPDATED: MAY 25, 2011 what an improvement over the third coast ale.  This one pours a rich red colour with average white heand.  This one has  a fruity aroma with a slight hoppiness.  Flvour is well balance with neither a bitterness nor sweetness  predominant yet both present.  A smooth sipper.  Qutie nice

bottle poured a red amber color with a nice frothy tan head. aroma has sweet sticky malt, dark fermented fruit, bitter hops, faint oak, and some alcohol. mouth feel is a heavy medium with some light carbonation. flavor is heavy to the malted side, caramel sweetness, hop bitterness, and some alcohol. warms you as it goes down. smooth and mellow.

Aroma: Deep, rich malt notes, restrained hops, hints of coffee and oak.
Appearance: Dark, clear, redish amber, with a dense toffee-colored, lingering head, almost like the crema on my espresso. Moderate lacing.
Flavor: Sweet, hevay palate with medium-bitter notes.  Great length. Powerful.   Warmth, chocolate, Umami!  
Palate: Full bold body with silky lingering and very long finish with low note-bitter tones.  
Overall: Excellent ale!  Heady.  Best suited for colder months and rainy days.  Can certainly be celllared to watch it develop. Multilayered, complex beverage.  Wonderful match for rich foods witn seet notes, such as BBQ

UPDATED: SEP 30, 2009 Pours a cloudy, medium-dark brown, slightly fizzy carbonation makes for a tight short beige head. Aroma is not what I expected, but good. Lots of sweet dark fruit, malt, and caramel/toffee. Flavor is sweet candied fruit and toasted caramel malt, that leads into an abrupt slightly bitter finish. Mouthfeel is pretty creamy, but the carbonation makes it a little less than smooth. Alcohol well hidden IMO.

Pours an ugly murky mild brown. Smells amazing of candied sugar and booze, a huge flavor of dark fruits and caramel. Flavor is very dark fruit intense with caramel and candied sugar, maple syrup flavor is also notable.
12oz - Toffee brown pour, carbonated but not fizzy, no real head.  Spice and tobacco on nose.  Creamy then nutty then sour.  This is not what I wanted right now.

2009 bottle. Pours very cloudy medium brown with a thinnish head that dissipates quickly. A fruity molasses sent carries halfway across the room. Up close, aroma is caramel-molasses-sweet malt with dried fruity notes. Vinous. Taste has a lot going on - sweet caramel, definite alcohol, sticky breadiness, dried fruit. Finish is hoppy and astringent at first, though this becomes less noticeable after a few sips. A sweet, sticky, spicy sort of aftertaste lingers for a long time.

2009 Bottle - Thanks BrewCzar! - Pours dk amber with a small off white head...aroma is caramel malt, maple syrup and dried fruit...flavour is nicely similar, sticky burnt sugar with a chewy, doughy mouthfeel, maybe thats because there was a a yeast/grain graveyard at the bottom of the bottle...very enjoyable!

The aroma is good with sweet malt, caramel, and toffee. The appearance is amber with a foamy head. The flavor is like the aroma but is also astringent. The palate is smooth. Overall its a quality beer but it has a bad finish.
this beer has some decent flavor but the end is not good at all. its got nice caramel flavor but with a real harsh astringent flavor.  falls short of perfection

I should know better by now than to try too hard to hunt down barleywines and drink them fresh (unless theyre of a hop-forward American variety).  I love Bells stouts, but this one was just too malt-forward for me.

Bottle 8863. Murky, sediment filled orange brown with a beige head. Sweet and bready malt aroma with a hint of hops. The flavor is very well balanced, with sweet caramel, toasted bread, and floral hops. Very good.

Pours a murky amber-brown with no head, but a touch of foam on the top. Super, super sweet aroma. Sweet malt with lots of astringency, plenty of alcohol and a messy, strong hop finish. Same bottle from 2004 shared with CapnCascade. Flat, moderately chewy body. Tasty - love the spicy, lingering finish.

Bottle shared with mgermani on 11-Apr-2009, Bells website has this one as begin from a 2004 batch. Cloudy copper-red pour with lots of suspended matter, moderate off-white head with little retention or lacing. Aroma of berries, caramelized sugar, wood, smoke, and wet earth. Flavour is quite vinous with prominent alcohol, toasted malts, dark sweet fruit, herbs, and bittering hops with a dry, slightly nutty finish. Very creamy body with prominent carbonation, perhaps a bit aggressive carbo for my taste but not overdone.

Pours golden but settles into a very dark brown with a hint of red and appearing almost purple-tinted in the glass. Has a rich, lathery head. Up front it smells like cherries and has a definite vinous quality. The alcohol is smooth but perceptible and paired with brown sugar and cinnamon. The nose is, however, dominated by a dark fruit character and heavily roasted malts, which have an almost nutty quality. There is a smoky character to the beer too. Wonderful to sniff. Flavor is huge, sweet, and bitter, tasting of raisins, molasses, ginger, dark cherries, cereal, wood, smoke, liquor, and I dont know what else; its complex, to say the least. Finishes with a touch of sweetness while the alcohol warms you up. A feast of a beer. Splendid and one of a kind.

Courtesy of After4ever, thanks Tom. It is a very beautiful, red mahogany color and the head is creamy. The aroma is vinous, malty with notes of raisin and other dark, dried fruits. The flavour has sweetness and notes of malt, alcohol, plum, light wood, caramel, cane sugar and citrus in the finish. The alcohol is warming, but also a little too dominating IMO.

Medium brown color with tan head and nice lacing. 

The scent is molases, alcohol, and oak.

Solid ale taste, the molases and alcohol seem to dominate.

Feels like chaos in my mouth, sweet then bitter then sweet then dry.

Pour me one, please. Just one.

Im going to age the other bottles of this to see how time improves them.

Im not a huge barleywine guy, but I really enjoyed this one.  Thanks to Brian for sending this one up to me.  Heavy malt aromas with dried fruit and earthy aromas.  Strong candied fruit on the palate with excellent hop finish.  Usually barleywines are a bit overdone on the finish for my palate, but this one is perfectly balanced.  Not surprising, given that the brewers at Bells seem to get everything right!

very nicely done barley wine.  heavy malt sweetness and very sweet dark candied fruits. very nice and bold finishing a little less sweet then it started, with a little savory taste on the end. cant wait to age this one!

Bottle. Heavy malt aromas of cereal, roasted and caramel, moderate perfume and cooked orange for the hops, light leather and earth for the yeast, with date, toffee and alcohol in the background. Head is large , creamy, off-white with good lacing and is mostly diminishing. Color is hazy brown. Flavor starts moderately sweet and lightly acidic, then finishes lightly sweet and moderately acidic and bitter. Palate is medium to full, oily and has a soft carbonation. It finishes lightly alcoholic, astringent and dry. The amount of sweetness is just perfect in this Barley Wine. Bells just doesnt disappoint.

Dark amber pour with a light beige head. Aroma is slight sweetness. What a great tasting beer. Slightly fruity, malty, other flavors I dont know how to explain them. Well-balanced. Alcohol is not noticeable. Aftertaste is sweetness, with the many tasty flavors that the beer provides. I hope I will be able to cellar at least one of the six for a year.

Thanks to HogTownHarry. At least a two year vintage.  Pours a beautiful brown orange with good visible carbonation and a large off white/yellow head. Aroma: Caramel malt with quite a sweet hop element, some alcohol, wood, pine, whiskey and mild peat. Lovely. Flavour: Bitter, huge alcohol hit but not in a negative way, malt, hops, bitterness shines through right to the end, whiskey finish. Lovely. I can just imagine drinking this on a nice cold winters evening.
a good barley wine.  amber color.  thanks to beth for the bottle.  had at beer meeting number 3.

has an aire of stiff upper lip .. . big ole head, with great lacing .. . faint aged hints of molasses and sherry .. . abv pretty mellowed .. . light medium vinious mouth .. . some light smokey sweetness .. cigar b callin ..

A Belles product designed for putting down.  Similar to many of the British-style barley wines, this beer has a rich warming malt character.  The hop flavor blended very well.  I would have like a little more hop aroma.  I liked the carbonation on the light side.  Another beer for saving.

Carmel color including head which also has darker carmel swills.  Sweet and smooth carmel and malt with a surprising twist of butternut squash.  Some nice bitter which lingers a fairly long time.  Worth another try sometime.
12oz bottle. Pours golden brown with light off white head. Smells sweet and malty. Seems to be full of flavor, bitter aftertaste. The alcohol def stands out in this one. ($3.29) Batch: 8723

Pours a hazy amber brown with a half finger head. Scent came off like prunes and grapes. Good body and flavorful beer, sweet/syrupy, plum/prunes, with a pleasant and slightly biitter finish. A very fine barley wine.
Bottle.  pours a dark red/brown color.  I love barley wines.  This one is no exception.  lots of sweet goodness balanced out with a mild to strong alcohol presence.

12 oz. bottle - batch #7695; pours reddish brown with foamy off-white head; caramel, sugar, belgain rock candy, malt and slight spice; flat and smooth; thin texture and slightly hot; has a very nice sweet dryness to it; killer stuff
Sweet caremel nose taste is sweet with slight alchohol taste. Very good malty flavor and aftertaste isnice

Thanks kiefdog for the share.  Pours cola brown with an off-white head.  Nose is boozy, malty maple and candy sugar.  Flavor is lots of sweetness, malt, maple, vanilla, and whiskey.  Boozy from start to finish.  Very enjoyable Old Ale.

12 oz bottle. Another Bells since they came to town. Pours a brown with hints of red and a finger high off-white head. Smells of caramel, dried fruit, a little citrus, and hints of alcohol. Tastes of caramel (quite potent actually), some sweetness, malt, and a bit of alcohol. Full-bodied feel with a strong taste and bite of alcohol. Overall a good barley wine, not as good as FFF Behemoth, but still quite good.

Pours a very murky old bronze with a 3 finger fluffy almond head that has o.k. retention and leaves specks of lacing. Aroma is caramel, earth, fruitcake, plum, alcohol and a little citrus. Flavor is licorice, caramel, some berry tartness, buttery pie crust, musty earth and wood notes, grapefruit, lots of spicy hops and some bitter hops and mellow earth to finish, I think I would like thes better if the hops were mellowed a bit as they seems to clash, some aging may help. Palate is medium, sticky, kind of syrupy and a bit overcarbonated.

12oz bottle. Pours amber with the most minimal white head. Aroma is of malt, spice, alcohol, caramel, and dark fruit. Taste is of caramel, spice, malt, alcohol, bread, and citrus. Big alcohol presence, and a nice lingering alcohol effect. Body is very carbonated and light. Mouthfeel is light, yet very sticky. Kind of a dissapointment.

12oz bottle, batch 8863.   Deep red-amber color with light sediment and a light beige head.   Cherry, vanilla, toffee, and caramel aroma.   Caramel, toffee, and vanilla flavors with a strong lingering hop bitterness and hot alcoholic finish.   Full bodied and smooth.   The hops seem to accentuate the alcohol and make it so you really need to sip this one.   I can see a year or two making this really nice but right now Im wondering how hopslam at almost the same strength is so much more drinkable than this is.

Pours looking like iced tea with a thin tan head.  Aroma i strong.  Dark fruit is prominent in the aroma (strong raisin smell).  Taste is sweet molasses, slight bitterness up front, and alcohol in this finish.  Creamy and thick beer that is not as hot as the 10.4% ABV would suggest.

Picked up this beer at Bruisin Ales in North Carolina. Glad they had Bells brewery beer there. Wow, this beer has a huge MALT aroma. Very nice. Almost chocolate like. Just a nice malt aroma that is pouring out of this beer. Not much of a head, but a thin head around the edge of the beer. Deep dark translucent brown with some crap floating around that eventually settles to the bottom of your glass. Wow, very creamy beer that has a heavy malt taste. The malt/chocolate malt aroma matches the flavor almost perfectly. Slight bitter hop at the end, not very bitter though. A nice barley wine, that if aged for a few years would be most amazing. Alcohol is WELL hidden. Overall, just a nice malty barley wine with great flavors. Sweet malts and a damn good barley wine with a nice subtle bitter finish.

Amber color with a decent head.  Very good nose.  Taste is of figs, chocolate, and malt.  Maybe a touch of nutmeg.  Creamy feel in the mouth.  Brown with a medium head.  No big alcohol aftertaste.  A very good barley wine.

huge nose of cereal malts, wet and sloppy. appearance is very light, nearly blonde. flavor is of sticky malt and alcohol. one of very few disappointments from bells, this is a sloppy beer that is far too strong for its own good, wasteful.

(bottle) A deep, murky red body with a fine head. Aroma of yeast, fruit (grape/raisins, strawberries, some orange), and bread crust. Flavor is sweet and malty up front, but hops slowly arise on the way back along with alcohol and bitterness lingers and is most apparent in the after taste. Alcohol peaks just as it goes down, but doesnt linger afterward - overall it is well balanced and even hidden for a beer of this strength. Full bodied and creamy-smooth. Lots of good things going on here.

Bottle...WOW  Redish brown and hazy.  Big roasty smell and flavor.  Lots of bittersweet fruits and dark malts in the smell.  Molasses is what I mostly get from it.   Alcohol is present and warming.  Another badass beer from Bells Brewery....alliteration.

Bottle @ Cock & Bull. Nice red color with thick three-fingers of foamy frothy lasting head. Burly warming aroma gets chewier and hotter as it warms. Aromas of rum cake, dates, figs, loads of malt. Low carbonation, smooth mouthfeel, and not chewy at all. Very sweet malty body but finishes on a spicy, dry note from the alcohol and has a nutmeg-like astringency. Cakey, whiskey-like. Interesting and a real winter warmer but heavy and hard to get through a whole one.

Bottle batch 8727. Pours a dark brown color with some reddish tint a good sized, foamy tan head that slowly settles to a thin layer of foam. Sheets of lacing are elft behind in the glass. The aroma is really nice showing good depth with notes of caramel, dark fruits, chocolate, oaky vanilla, cherries, all seeped in alcohol. The flavors follow suit with the caramel, bourbon, oaky vanilla, and alcohol soaked dark fruits. Some earthy hops are noticeable in the backend and add balance. Full bodied and a smooth mouthfeel which is perfect for a slow sipper. A long, sweet finish with some warming from the alcohol. A really great tasting barleywine from a great brewery.

12 oz bottle, batch 8863 i think. Pours a dark brown with a thick biege head. Aroma is of spice, hops, caramel, and wood. Nice full mouthfeel. Earth, caramel, hops, and justa bit of alcohol on the tongue. A really nice barley wine.
Dark copper and hazy with a large beige head. Aroma is of toffee, caramel, molasses and alcohol. Taste is heavy in toffee and caramel with a decent alcoholic warmth.

12oz bottle, batch 8723. Chestnut pour, with a a big khaki head. Rich aroma, with toffee, with highlights of nuts and citrus. Flavor begins with caramel, and is soon overcome by hefty pine and grapefruit hops. Chocolate and nutty flavors add complexity. Medium bodied with silky smooth texture; very drinkable. Beautiful beer.

12 oz. Pours a deep amber with a small off-white head. Rich caramel malts, dark fruit, some spicy earthy hops on the nose. Same caramel maltiness and dark fruits evident in the flavor, semi-dry with a little alcohol kick in the end, a late bitter finish. Dry, med mouthfeel, not syrupy at all, low carb. Very drinkable for its (metaphorical) size.
This barely wine is the hoppyist Ive ever tried.  The power of a titan, and speed of a viper, not my favorite, but I wont kick this titan out of bed.  Label is uninspiring.

Pours a clear brown with small tan head.  Nose is mostly bready, cookie-like malts, oak.  In the flavor I detect sweet malt, dates, peppery and allspice yeasts, and some alcohol.  Very warming.  Thick, heavy, rather oily mouthfeel.  Quite good
Taste is roasty malts. It was sweet, but not in a fruity way. It a heavy malted sweetness to it. Very full bodied. Rich and warm. Smooth and sweet. Its a nice one to sip and enjoy.

12oz bottle from Countryside Liquors (Tampa, FL). Pours a dark brown to black with a one finger white-tan head that settles slowly and heavily laces the glass. Aroma is sweet and floral with notes of citrus, grapefruit, maple syrup, some slight hints of ripe fresh fruit, plum, wood, and spice. Flavor is sweet and malty with notes of dark ripe fruit, citrus, grapefruit, some honey, caramel, and grassy yeast. Generally medium to full body with a sweet and malty finish.

Cloudy, golden orange appearance. Scent of window cleaner. Even in its youth, great balance of syrupy sugar and hoppy bitterness. Milk chocolate, pear, hazelnut, and molasses. Ill plan on storing the next bottle for a bit.
12oz. Pour was deep brown with frothy beige head. Aromas of malt, dark fruits, and a slight hop presence. Flavor is overwhelmingly smooth. Hops, malt, and nice plum flavor were all there. Nice brew.
user_location: back in NJ!, New Jersey, USA

text: On tap at South Park Tavern.  Cloudy Medium brown in color.  Sugary and malty sweet aroma with a touch of hop.  Sweet and boozy flavor like a typical barley wine with a crisp and dry hoppy finish.  Good stuff.

UPDATED: JAN 22, 2010 Re-Rate on 1/22/2010: 12oz bottle. Batch 8723 bottled on Sept 5, 2008. Pours a deep, murky, amber-red colored body with a finger-width, creamy, slowly dissipating, tannish brown head that leaves a nice lacing. Aroma is like I remembered, but Im going to bump it point. Sweet and malty with some plum and strawberry caramels, nutty toffees, raisin bread, and a light earthy cocoa. Not a whole lot of hoppiness to this malty aroma. Flavor is better than I remember, but still a little too sweet. The booze has settled down a lot since my last rating. Big and rich, very sweet malts up front with a strawberry fruitiness. More sweet toffees with a lighter nut than the aroma, plenty of raisin bread and other sweet fruits, caramels, honey, and a syrupy sweetness. Finishes with a light woody and earthy citrus that dries with just a touch of booze and a chewy maltiness that lingers for a moderate duration. Full body. Overall, a year later the booze has clearly settled, but it remains too sweet and chewy for my liking. The aroma has diminished somewhat and the malts dominate the hops. I dont know...maybe I wasnt meant to love Bells barley wine. (7,4,6,3,12=3.2).
Original Rating on 1/23/2009. 12oz bottle. Pours a murky, amber-red body with some particulate floating around. Very thin, beige head that dissipates immediately and remains delicately laced. The aroma is mainly sweet and malty. Lots of strawberry candy sugar malts with a bunch of toffee and a light boozy and doughy yeast backing. Flavor is initially very rich and sweetly malted before finishing boozy and moderately citrus hopped. Palate is pretty full and chewy with a dry and very woody finish. Overall, this is pretty boozy right now. The big maltiness is balanced decently well right now with the bitterness, but the big booze flavor is really bothering me. Im going to age the rest of this six pack and hope that this matures in time. I look forward to re-rating this in the future, but until then, this is off. (8,4,6,2,12=3.2).

UPDATED: FEB 5, 2014 Re-rate 1/5/14: Bottle sample at a tasting at Orens place. Thanks troubles. Clear deep red. Aroma of malt, caramel, cookies and a bit of hazelnuts. Sweet flavor, alcoholic and malty, with caramel, a bit of cookie notes and a bitter finish. Medium-bodied. OK, but a bit too simple and alcoholic. 7/4/6/3/12=3.2

(11/3/08) Bottle sample at a tasting in Pizza Port in Carlsbad (thanks whoever). Cloudy reddish-brown color with a beige head. Aroma of malt, caramel, a bit of earth and wood and chocolate hints. Very sweet and malty flavor with caramel, some chocolate hints, some fruitiness and alcohol notes. Full-bodied. 7/4/7/4/14=3.6

Look is amber colored, slightly cloudy, with a light tan colored head.  Smell is alcohol, caramel, molasses, fruits, and some sweetness.  Taste is the same as the smell but with more of the malts coming through.

batch #8723 bottled on September 5th 2008.Pour was a clean shsde of copper with orangish hue and small 1/2 inch head off white,aromas of caramelized malts,sweet friuts and bread taste of the same with a sweet  smooth finish not as bitter the old stock ale I drank a half hour before this one i will be cellaring this one for future tasting

Batch #8863. Amber brown pour with off white head. First nose full of malt, sweet tropical fruit, floral hops, light caramel, peaches, and cotton candy. Beautiful. Mouth is bold. Caramel, brown sugar, fruit, and more piney hops. Fairly oily. Nice carbonation. REALLY bitter. Up there. 10.5 ABV a shock. Points!

bottle from total wine in norfolk poured into a pint glass. pours a very nice cherry wood color with a very thin, quickly fading, light tan head. aroma is very pleasant with scents of fig, raisins, maybe some red berries, sweet breads, brown sugar, and maple. flavor is quite good. slightly sweet with flavors of dark fruits, caramel malts, brown sugar, and a very nice hoppy bitterness with a slight bit of citrus. mouthfeel is thick and rich with solid alcohol warmth no burn whatsoever. definitely a big beer but very well balanced. look forward to having one after a year of agine. another very solid effort from bells.

Pours dark caramel color with light tan head. Aromas of molasses and dark fruits. Sweet flavors of caramel and dark fruits. Slight boozy taste with some hoppy bitterness. Full body with mild carbonation and a syrupy mouthfeel.

pours amber - ruby with beige head.
Aroma is fruity - cherry and almost strawberry like with decent malty nose.
Taste is thick and fruity with some spices. Caramel malts with light chocolate - tofee - undertones.
 Mlalts remain dominant with barley.  Brown sugar mouthfeel with some dry prunes-plums with a light bitter hoppy finish.

Bottle thanks to Shane at Downtown Wine + Spirits.  Batch 8727.  Nice brown orange pour with a thin off white cover.  Very mellow sweet aroma of malt, brown sugar, molasses and raisins.  Tastes of light alcohol, maple syrup, brown sugar, and caramel.
Bottle.  A murky, amber brown pour with a thin head.  Light aroma of malt, plum and alcohol.  Much fuller flavor; starts sweet and fruity but finishes with a lot of piney hop flavor.

Sampled at the Second Cellar Reduction.  Pours a near opaque reddish brown with wispy khaki head.  Nose of raisin and plum, vanilla, and oak, and the slightest twinge of alcohol.  Flavor is nice and dark fruity, slightly bitter hoppiness, tannins, white grapes, caramel, some warming, but no real alcohol flavor.  Nice and smooth and semi-syrupy. bitter lingering finish.
Bottle at Second Cellar Reduction.  Light brown head and amber with a little haze.  Sweet fruit nose.  Butter and vanilla flavors.

Tulip glass from bottle.
Boozy aroma, hints of red fruit.  Thin white head with mild lacing.  Brown/red color.  Taste explodes on the tongue, thick boozy malt with syrupy goodness.  Oaky and tangy.  Huge beer, with a sweet bitey foamy mouth feel.

UPDATED: MAR 16, 2013 Dark red-amber with big, foamy, tan head / Sweet, toasty, malty nose of candied sugar, dark fruit, violet  / Medium to full body, moderately sweet but very malty, with strong hop balance to point of astringency, and slightly hot, bitter finish / Flavors of nut, toffee, brown sugar, raisin, and grape / Bitterness slightly overwhelming, but a fine brew.
Bottle, #432. Ruby pour with decent head. Sweet malty fruity aroma. Rich, somewhat complex flavor. More of an Old ale than barley wine, but still good.
Bottle pours ruby red with a thick creamy head.  Aroma is alcohol and sweet fruits.  Has a heavy mouthfeel.  Flavor is caramel, fruit, brown sugar, and slightly hoppy.  Overall a really nice brew.

Dark hazy amber brown with a small tan head.  Also chunks from the bottom of the 12oz bottle floating around, not real pleasant looking.  Starts out with a sweet mixture of dried dark fruits, brown sugar, and caramel.  Then comes the hops in a decent balance.  Some citrusy flavors in there as well.  Light carbonation and a heavy body.  Gets a little sticky at some points.  Finish leaves you with a little dryer hop flavor and hints of old citrus.

Hazy deep amber with mediu beige head. Sweet aroma with toasted malt, caramel and ripe fruits. Sweet flavour with ripe fruits, toasted malt, hops and alcohol notes. Bitter finish with warming alcohol.
Very dark brown, 8 bubble head.  Aroma of maple syrup.  Taste of caramel, malt and brown sugar.  Nice hop finish.

Pours a cloudy brown with a white head.  Smell is sweet and sugary like maple syrup with an alcohol kick and just a bit of citrus hops.  Taste is surprisingly hoppy, but still mellow and sweet with caramel and dark fruits.  Great balance between the myriad of flavors in this one, like most Bells beers.  Very good.
Bottle. Orange brown color with thin white head. Tastes of dark fruit, caramel, vanilla and brown sugar. Nice!

Pours an orange brown color with plenty of small particulate.  Medium off-white head that fades thinly.  Aroma is raspberry, tart, sugary sweetness, some toffee, caramel, and a bit of dark fruit.  Taste is malty, some dark fruit, brown sugar, caramel.  Overall a bit flat for a barley wine.  Warms the belly!

Bottle, just short of a year old. Pours dark brown, just on the edge of opaque, cloudy, with a very thin light tan head that thins to a ring quickly. Nose is toffee and molasses, rich dark fruits with a bit of alcohol, brown sugar - big and complex. Taste starts out with a big note of rich, over-ripe dark fruit and molasses, with the hops and alcohol  working to keep the sweetness from getting out of control early on. Towards the middle of the tongue the alcohol comes through just a bit clearer, as well as the rich sweetness - lots of toffee and brown sugar as well as the molasses,Hops never actually get out from underneath the huge malt not, but you still get a good, clear presence from them for balance, as well as a bit of a lingering lightly bitter, dry finish. Bitterness seems to come from the hops and the alcohol as well, and pick up  just a bit of the bitter-sweet dark fruit note. Warming. Mouthfeel is smooth, lightly carbonated, but still just a bit of scrubbing going on. Nice beer overall.

I had this beer at our holiday party this year. I was a couple of craft beers deep when this one hit my palate hard. Very heavy and alcoholic which was not what i had been expecting. I will try this again in a more appropriate setting for rating.

Bottle.  Pours semi clear brown with a small head.  Aroma of malt, caramel, dark fruit.  Taste is very malty, some hop, plenty of fruit, light booze, brown sugar, caramel.  Finish is bitter and body is smooth.  Overall, a very solid barleywine.

UPDATED: DEC 19, 2014 12/4/2008: Pours a fabulous caramel brown with a bright yellow, small head. Insanely good lacing. Aromas of caramel, toffee, sweet malt, and brown sugar. Taste is fairly bitter with the 10.5% by volume perfectly hidden by the hops and heavy malt character. Very dry, tart aftertaste with some spicy alcohol. Awesome!  Vertical tasting 8/27/2009: After some aging this is showing tons more burnt caramel, rich toffee, creme brulee, caramel syrup. Aroma is spicy, boozy. Very good. [ Bottle ][ 12oz ][ ? ][ ? ][ Southampton RIS Snifter ][ 12.18.14 ]
>> Last bottle of this from my cellar, batch9525 from Jan 2010. Pours clear burnt umber with minimal foam. Nose is deep red twizzlers, baked cherry, clafoutis, plum. Taste is toasted macadamia, white chocolate, bitter cocoa powder, quite bitter. No hot alcohol or booze, but holy shit does this get you buzzed quick after a few sips. Palate is extremely oily, like salmon oil, slick and dense. One of my favorite barleywine experiences. What a monster after this long in the cellar at room temp. 4.2

12oz bottle. Pours deep mohogany with tan head. Aroma is sweet malt, brown sugar, caramel, dark fruit, hops and booze. Flavor is sweet but bitter. Good amount of hops and sweet malt. Flavor is also dominated by brown sugar, dark fruit, and caramel. Nice hoppy barley wine that finishes bitter. Could use some more balance.
Thanks AgentSteve.  Mahogany, smooth, sweet, caramel, dark fruits, malty, molasses.
Pours rich deep copper red. Medium beige head. Very focused sprucy hop aroma. Tastes just like it smells. Very hoppy. Oily texture. Quite similar to Stone’s Double Bastard actually.

(11.25.08) 12 oz. bottle: Pours a clear mahogany with a decent head that falls away quickly. Not much lacing. Aroma is caramel malt with dried fruits and hops, along with some alcohol. Body is creamy. Flavor keeps the malt, adding some vanilla, dark fruits, and some piney hops. Solid barleywine / old ale.
Pours a flat ruddy brown with no head. The nose is caramel and dried fruits. The flavor is the same with some earthiness. Sweet and clean in the finish. Very easy drinking.

It is while drinking a beer like this that you think about a bud light and say, "really? how are these two things both called beer?"  Fantastic.  I can’t wait to put my other bottle away for a year or so.

Like many really top beers, one cant expect to spend all night drinking the. This beer is no exception. It is a wonderful full bodied delicious beer, which by the way is 10.5%ABV which in itself would preclude most mortals from drinking too much.

Medium hops with a sweet,  carmel flavor. Other barley wines I have had are generally sweeter and not quite as big a mouthful. This is really good.

YEA BELLS
Again!!

CD

Bottle.Batch # 8269 packaged Jan 11-2008.
A cloudy deep amber/peach pour with a head that disappeared quickly. Lots of sediment floating around, mmm. Aroma is hops, caramel malt sweetness, and dried fruits. Citrus, pine, molasses,pepper,and other spice come through as well.Thick and heavy bodied with good carbonation and a creamy sticky mouthfeel. Flavors of honey,caramel,biscuts,rasins,some very mute citrus tones,oak ,, very complex,the flavors change as it warms,no real strong alcohol hints at all, very very good,a little on the sweet side to drink several at one sitting,but a top notch offering for sure... Thank you Mr.Bell

Reviewed on: 11-11-2008 01:22:17

Pours deep murky and muddy into the glass, with a diminished ring of foam that leaves trace lace.  The nose is very much of caramel, currant, dates and figs.  Flavors are of dark esters, some dark caramel malt and earthen tones, with a nice bitterness that emboldens the finish, mixing with smoked peat.  Complex yet easily drinkable for the ABV, the mouthfeel is smooth and oily.  Nice slick brew.

Batch 7800...pours a deep brown with a thin tan head.    Aroma is somewhat subdued, but is full of caramel malts with a splash of hops and some dark fruit accents.  Flavor is robust and heavy...lots of roasted caramel malts, heavy levels of sweetness, alcohol, peanut brittle, maple syrup, dark fruits and an underlying woodiness.  Seems to be some slight oxidization going on here, but I think it actually works well at this point.  Palate is slightly oily and nicely done.  Good beer, though I think this would have continued to improve with some more age...

mcbackus gave me this at his house...thanks matt!  Man what a great friggin beer!! Pours a cloudy brown with a very small light tan head.  Aroma is full of caramel, dark fruit(raisins) and some hints of smoke...very light smoke that is.  Flavor is sweet and fruity, caramel, syrup and rounded out with a perfect hop bite.  A world class beer.  Thanks again matt!!!!!

12 fl oz bottle, courtesy of KimJohansen. Pours hazy amber to brown with a diminished light tan head. Smooth roasted caramel malty aroma with a light hoppy note. Dry and wooden flavoured with a dry caramel and breadish malty base. Ends roasted malty and chocolate smooth.

bottle thanks to gregis.  poured brown with a tan head and a set of legs that would turn any head.  aroma of malt and dark fruit.  flavor is sweet with dark fruits, alcohol, and a little bitter.  the alcohol is hidden very well with this.  what a way to start out the evening.
Pours dark amber/brown, very little head.  Dark, sweet fruit in the nose.  Malty sweet, dark fruit across the palate, a little bit of hops at the end, perfect balance.  Pretty awesome beer.

Bottle thanks to ericandersnavy.
Pours a dark brown, ruby hues, tan head. Aroma of dark fruit. Flavor is rich, dark fruit, licorice, sweet. Has a heavy body with med. carbonation. Very good barley wine!

Dark amber pour, some dark creamish head.  Quite a bit of malt, barrel like tones and booze in the nose.  Malty but not too sweet, some brown sugar, peat, raisin.  Nice and sticky, just a hint of some red fruit, very nice hop character toward the finish.  Rather clean finish considering the stickiness.  This was nice to me with respect to other barley wines in that it was not overpowering with the fruit flavors.  No sourness.  Definetely closer to an old ale, which it was an excellent one and believe it will be even more excellent with some aging.
user_location: from Michigan now in Charlotte, North Carolina, USA

text: Some barleywines are like licorice, some slam you with odd twists of hard-edged flavor, but this one is gentle, woodsy, creamy, amber/rust beautiful in the glass and - - something rare - - mild and complex for a barleywine - -  like autumn leaves and walking down creaky deck upon subdeck of three-masted frigates from the 1800’s.

UPDATED: FEB 19, 2009 Vintage #8269. Pours a dark, mahogany brown with tannish head. The bitter hop profile is mostly back-of the tongue bitterness, with a small grassy element remaining from the florals of this one. The malts are smoky and peat-like. Finishes on a smoky note. 
Vintage #8211. Same as above, but this one has some smoky leathery malty notes that just make this an incredibly delicious beer.
UPDATED: MAR 28, 2009 has a wonderful hop/alcohol aroma.very warming the more you drink.perfect for winter nights next to a woodstove. hands down one of the finest barley wines made.
dark amber with a hint of head. Malty, biscuity, toasty, caramel nose. Flavors of stone fruit, cocoa, with a forward hoppy, dry bitterness.

UPDATED: JUN 5, 2009 What a nice beer, though it tastes like an Old Ale or Malt Liquor.  Tastes like a 3 year old Jubilation, except manages that right out of the bottle.  Very pronounced chocolate, raisin, malt, brown sugar and maple in the aroma and flavor.  Smooth.  Very like a Samichlaus, The Beast or the DFH Raison Ds... but this is the beer they all aspire to be.

My favorite barley wine next to bigfoot.  This stuff is amazing.  Nose is hops, raisins, toffee, bread, and caramel.  Flavors of Chocolate, hops, roasted malts.  Very complex.  Thick inviting palate.  As it got warmer it got better.  By favorite brew from bells.

Bottle.  Very little head with a dark amber color for the body.  Aromas of wine, fruit, berries, and hints of port.  Smooth texture with an oily feel on the mouth.  Very little carbonation as would be expected.  Very strong representation of a barley wine.

a very rich, dark ale. My first one from bell’s, recommended by a friend. It begins sweet and rich, with a very smooth, smoky middle finishes a bit harsh out of the bottle, but opened up makes a wonderful ale

From bottle.  Poured deep brown/amber with virtually no head. Complex nose of caramel and malt.  Flavors include toffee, roasted malt and hops.  Long finish.  Alcohol is noticeable - may need some time to mature.

12oz.  By far the best barleywine I have had to date.  Pours a deep, deep amber with red highlights.  Nose is loads of caramel apples and sweet breads.  Flavors are exquisite butterscotch, toffee, apple cider, overall a fairly sweet experience.  The hops are undeniable in this one, bringing some bitter citrus fruit to the profile.  Overall, very well balanced sweetness to bitterness.  Decent carbonation makes this lively and very interesting.  One criticism is that it could be a bit more complex.  I am going to put a few of these away.

Beautiful deep copper color with a large tan head. Heavy malty aroma with delicious caramel notes inviting. Malty sweet forenotes followed by solid deep bitterness. Alcohol is apparent but not overwelming. Excellent!

Batch 7236 ~ 2006 Vintage
9/25/2008:  Third Coast Old Ale has a deep ruby amber color with a thin beige crown.  The nose is greeted by a hearty citrusy hop aroma accompanied by rich caramel, hints of vanilla, and some sweet alcohol.  The flavor is very strong and contains a smooth, caramel maltiness, aged alcohol, and a moderate citrus and herbal hoppiness.  There is some residual sweetness as well along with notes of prune, dried apricot, and and vanilla.  The bitterness lingers on the back of the tongue after each sip.  This beer is still quite smooth and easy to drink despite its high alcohol.  It is medium-bodied and mildly carbonated.  Overall this was a very good barleywine and is well-balanced.  However, I would have preferred a bit more sweetness.  Im sure this beer gets even better with another 1 or 2 years on it...
12 fl. oz. bottle (OG 1.098, Alc. by Vol. 10.2%, 335 cal. per 12 oz.).  Rating #835 for this beer...  Rating:  8  3  7  3  16 = 3.7.
______________________________
No Batch # ~ 2002 or Older Vintage (1-piece label and plain gold cap)
9/25/2008:  Third Coast Old Ale has a sweet aroma made up of caramel, dates, raisin, complex fruity malt (e.g. Marris Otter) and a hint of vanilla.  This beer really smells great.  It also looks really nice too.  It has a clear, deep honey color with ruby highlights and tight, shimmering carbonation.  There is a thin frothy beige veil floating on the surface.  The flavor is sweet and still has a decent level of sweet, aged citrus/apricot hop flavor and bitterness.  The slightly roasty caramel maltiness is also accompanied by a really smooth whiskey/brandy alcohol tone, prune and other aged fruits.  Again, this beer is very smooth and very easy to drink for its high alcohol content.  It is medium-bodied and has a mildly syrupy mouthfeel and a sticky quality on the lips.  The additional age on this particular bodied has helped the sweetness come through the normally high bitterness level.  It has developed a wonderful aroma and the flavor is quite good and balanced, but some complexity may be starting to fade away at this point...
12 fl. oz. bottle from West Side Wine and Liquor Store in West Harrison, Ohio.  Rating:  8  4  8  4  17 = 4.1.
Nice smooth barley wine with smooth sweetness and a medium body.  It holds it’s own with any well made barley wine.  A must try for strong beer fans.

UPDATED: JUN 24, 2009 Thanks 17thfloor! Pours a very dark red almost brown color with a light off-white head. Aroma is very sweet malty and has a lot of fruitiness to it but not in a crappy sort of way. I get some nice pineapple and plum notes along with a spicy backbone. Flavor starts out with a bang with the spicy notes filling my mouth immediately. There is a very pleasant rich caramel and molasses sweetness in the middle and a great hop bitterness that appears in the finishes and lingers for quite some time.  Really nice full body and low carbonation. Excellent example balance and a near perfect barley wine!

Tap Capital Ale House Innsbrook 08/31/2008. Roast malts, dark fruit, caramel and molasses. Cloudy amber brown with rocky tan head that persists.
Dark fruit and roast malts with assertive hop bitterness. Citrus, floral, and earthy hop flavors all present. Medium body with full creamy mouthfeel. Quite tasty.

12 oz bottle. no batch number. pours deep reddish brown. a small tan head but almost no carbonation. very deep rich aromas. dark fruits, caramel/toffee, some leather, maybe some wood. the flavours are equally deep and complex. the mouthfeel is soft and comforting but the flavour lasts forever. there is a noticeable english quality to this beer and i think that has won me over. best barley ive had to date.

Bottle: (Thanks kosko20!) Pours a hazy/rusty amber with a tight tan head. The aroma is rich with notes of vanilla, some buttery character, odd oxidized suggestions of vegetal/metallic notes, alcohol and dark fruits (dates) Has a substantial palate with mild carbonation. The flavor seems odd. I think this bottle is somewhat oxidized or was exposed to heat. Has apparent big malt character giving off some vanilla, leather, dust, metal, caramel, very subtle old raspberry puree (not tart, but sweet/candied raspberry) with some long and dry peppery hop notes that give off an almost mint-like hint. I want to try another bottle to see if its condition effected its potential quality.
Bottle, no batch on the label. Pours cloudy brown/amber, with a very small head. Aroma is fruit, malt, and caramel. Flavor is fruit, caramel, hops, malt, and alcohol. A nice one to sip.

Bottle, Batch 8269.  Pours a really nice deep amber color with almost no head.  Aroma is malt, dark fruit, alcohol, a little bready.

Flavor is very nice and complex, but has a wicked little bitter kick.  Not like hop bitterness at all.  Lot’s of caramel, plum, anise?  Could spend forever trying to find all the flavors.  I didn’t realize this one was a beer you could cellar.  I’ll have to hunt down another bottle and put it away for awhile.  Very nice beer.

On tap at Bocktown.  Pours a dark brown with hints of red.  A thick creamy off-white head that leaves more of a curtain of sticky foam than lacing.  Sweet malty aroma with raspberry, a little hops, and even somewhat of a perfume.  The flavor starts kind of chocolatey, but has some brown sugar, black raspberries, and a sort of creamy bitter.  The hop character is a very noticeable pine in the finish.  The body of this beer is extremely thick and rich.  A slight alcohol flavor, but not really that bad, considering the high ABV.  Another great offering from Bell’s.

This is one for wine drinkers (like me).  Dry, bitter aftertaste.  Beautiful citrus, blackberry, raisins, and maple syrup on the nose. little licorice.  This is balance and complexity.  California can learn alot from this beer.  This is not loud, its restrained and deliciuos and suprisingly lager-like if you know what I mean.

I loved this beer.  Poured a hazy amber color into a brandy snifter.  Aroma was of dark ripe fruits, malt and raisins/plums.  Lacing was minimal.  Flavor reflected the nose very well, with a little brown sugar flavor and a little alcohol warming at the end.  Medium-full bodied with minimal carbonation.  Great beer.  Must be presented at the correct temperature and in the correct glassware to be appreciated fully.

Bottle, batch 8135 pours a very ruddy cloudy color with no head at all. Smells like a carmel chew, toffee, and coffee tons of malts nice sweetness. Nice a nice barley wine alcohol is well hidden, very delicious. Once again Bells proves to be one of the best breweries out there.

batch 8211 bottle from ucusty... pours a hazy dark amber with a medium sized khaki colored head and some light lacing. foamy film and ring last until the end. smells good but not a whole lot going on... malty, caramel and some fruitiness, maybe raisins. the palate is terribly sweet all over and lacking anything to balance it out. very light bitter-ish dry-ish finish before a wafting of alcohol. medium to full body. smooth slick mouth feel with a sugary residue left on the lips. i suppose i should lay a few down...

Bottle.  Reddish amber without much head.  Only a small film remains after a minute or so.  Aroma is subtle with caramel, alcohol, and some fruit.  Flavor is sweet with some bittering hops that weren’t in the aroma and some peppery alcohol at the finish.  Low carbonation with a biting alcoholic aftertaste that isn’t overpowering.  Quite warming.  A good beer.  I can see the similarities to a barley wine but something about it sets it apart from that category.

Aroma is fruity, mostly red grapes.  Like a wine but not as powerful as wine.  Notes of malts and hops are there too.  Appearance is beautiful, deep amber like the description says with a thick reddish white head and streaming carb bubbles.  Flavor is pretty complex.  Nothing sticks out to dominant.  I say it tastes most like grapes, cherries, fruit flavored malts, and a bit of alcohol.  Palate is pretty smooth, the alcohol comes through in the end and the aftertaste isn’t much.  Overall its a good beer, my first barely wine and a good one.

5/6 pack given to me by a friend.  I didn’t realize I was getting the "Old" version, just the Third Coast.  What a surprise.  Not sure this is categorized correctly.  Old ales are their own style, not necessarily barley wines, just barley wine strengths.  I’ve only had the Three Floyd’s Behemoth barley wine, and that one was a lot more balanced and sweeter than this one.  Pours as dark as a porter, no head, really, or just a short one.  Smells of alcohol, fruit.  Bitter taste and finishes with an alcoholic slash.  I didn’t really enjoy it all that much.

UPDATED: MAY 14, 2009 Bottle thanks to mibirder. Labeled 8211. Pours with a small, off-white head covering an hazy amber body. Aroma of dark pitted fruits, plums, cherry and a lot of alcohol (a bit on the hot side). Taste is not very complex, toffee and a light bitter after taste. Syrupy with light bubbles.  Have since tried 7124 (2005). Still seemed hot with some brandy and still a bit of bitterness.

12 oz bottle from Secret Santa (sprinkle) thanks man. Pours a murky brown color with a medium cream head. Aroma of dark ripe fruits and roasted malts. The flavor featured caramel, raisins, dates, sweet roasted malts and a bit of tobacco. The mouthfeel was smooth and creamy with overactive prickly carbonation. The finish was long and dry with lingering biter-sweet almonds. Overall: A very tasty and well done ale from a brewer that never misses.  Thanks for this mike.

12oz bottle extra in a trade with Mattf311.  Thanks for this one big guy.  Pours a cloudy chocolate brown with a small beige ring, great lacing.  Sweet caramel and toasted malts.  I think I’m also confusing the smell of tomatoes with minerality.  Flavor was very sweet and fruity with a tinge of alcohol.  A very full bodied beer.

Pours ruby brown in color.  A nice half inch of head on the pour.  Looks delish.  First sip is very nice.  Just the way I like’em.  A smooth, port-like, english barleywine.  Not hopped to hell and back.  After just the initial taste, I’m imagining how incredible this would be to have aged at several years.  Full and creamy on the mouthfeel.  I guess I’ll have to start aging these next to my Expedtion Stout!

Bottle.  Dark amber in color with a thick beige head that leaves good lacing.  Aroma is malty with caramel.  Flavor is smooth, sweet malts, caramel, raisins, more malt and some hops.  An excellent combination and balance. Very flavorful and  impressively drinkable at 10%.

Batch 8135.  Been sitting on this for awhile, can’t wait anymore. A little malty aroma with hints of caramel and raisin. The head is creamy off white, good lacing and mostly diminishing. The body is cloudy and copper brown in color. The initial flavor is smooooth, a little sweet, a little bitter and creamy. The malt leaves a little caramel/vanilla taste and is average to long. The body is medium, the texture creamy. I’ll get another six to age.

UPDATED: JAN 21, 2010 Bottle of 7/28/08. Batch 8135. Much better than the bottle from the same batch that I had 7 months ago, which was far too hot. Sweet and "candied" taste mixed with some earthy wood. Still fairly hoppy giving a drier finish which was quite necessary to counteract the rich sweetness. It wasnt really cloying though and had rather soft mouth feel. Alcohol was noticeable but not detracting.  8/4/8/4/15-3.9

Bottle on 1/21/10. Batch 8135. Developed quite nicely. Nice plum. Nicely candied. Much like previous rating just older. Less alcohol. Nice hop bitterness actually. Some chocolate in the finish. 8/4/8/4/15-3.9

Thanks to alexsdad06 for this!  Pours dark brown with rusty highlights and a long lasting, fairly large off-white head. Aroma is of tobacco, leaves, grapefruit, dirt, wood, and maybe just a bit of mint or lime.  Tastes surprisingly hoppy, which I didn’t expect!  Bitter grapefruit hop flavor, but it’s an either grapfruit, along with caramel, dirt, burnt toast, tobacco, slight vanilla.  Malt flavors seem slightly light.  Finishes with an "Arrogant Bastard" style aftertaste of grapefruit and dark malt roast flavors.  Lingering tobacco flavor in the aftertaste along with grapefruit and a sort of unpleasant salty cloying sensation.  Very creamy bodied but the flavors seemed so soft to the point where it made the beer seem thinner than it actually is.  I’m not sure how that works.  Interesting beer, but I wish it were sweeter and that the aftertast was different.  Could be really good.
reddish brownn with mild head.  flavor is powerful with crystal, chocolate malt present with a huge hop bitterness and even some flavor.  a very strong example

Small light brown diminishing head.  Muddy brown/amber color with chunky particulates floating.  Strong grapefruit hoppiness with notes of carmel mixed with cherry/wine hints.  A little too bitter for my taste.  Full bodied oily texture with long lasting duration.  Heavy bitterness from start to finish.

(Sampled 7-6-08 from 12 oz. bottle poured into shaker)  Poured semi transparent very dark amber, huge frothy beige head formed and stayed around for the entire tasting with heavy lacing, aroma of malt and whiskey.  Hits the mouth with a high-medium body, very sticky on the mouth throughout swallow, sweetness from molasses and brown sugar comes in the middle and slides away on the finish.  Finish has moderate warming effect which I compare to scotch.  Another good brew!

12 oz. bottle into sniffer.  Nice rich amber reddish/brown with a big off-white, slightly tan head that fades pretty quickly.  Aroma is mostly dominated by citrus hops with a bit of sweet malt hiding around in there.  weird flavor; very subtle but very good once you figure out what is going on.  Bitter, woody, citrus hoppy, not a lot of alcohol (just warming on finish), hints of red fruit (cherries).  Thinner on the palate than abv. and style would suggest, but still smooth and pleasant.    Overall: great tasty brew.  A unique approach to barley wine, which is an extremely diverse, probably the most diverse, style IMO.

Dark red, brown color.  Smell of hops, alcohol, malt, nuts, barley, dark fruit, raisins, brown sugar and caramel.  Taste of hops, alcohol, malt, nuts, barley, dark fruit, raisins, brown sugar and caramel.  Very warm and enjoyable.

UPDATED: SEP 19, 2009 Re-rate 9/19/09.  Brown sugar, plums and figs in the aroma.  Dark brown color and pours with a nice tan head.  Some patches and a thin ring around the glass stick around.  Flavor shows sweet caramel mixing with dark fruit, toffee, candi sugar, and just the right amount of bitter grapefruit hops finishing this off and complimenting the sweet malt nicely.  A real nice English Barleywine that I need to revisit more often.  Original rating:  One of the better barleywines Ive had. Deep amber color, nice clarity, with a thin head. Thin patches and a foam ring sticks around to provide some spotty lacing. Sweet caramel malt flavor with generous doses of molasses and brown sugar. Faint traces of dark fruit and oak and the beer finishes a bit peppery but smooth. Hints of most of that is in the aroma which isnt over-powering but is quite complex. The alcohol is hidden remarkably well. A great drink.
Hazy brown pour. Malt heavy on the nose, very sweet smelling. Tastes like fruit cake. Very nice beer.
user_location: Redlands, by way of Wisconsin,, California, USA

text:
pours a dark copper-almost mahogany colour. Heavy sediment. Aroma is very sweet and malty, fruity raisin and fig tones, brandy like alc. & light vanilla.
Flavour is initially quite sweet. Fruitcake dried dates and cherries with a cakey malt transitions into a cherry brandy like alc, and finishes with a slightly mettalic bitterness.

Pours a light ruby color with a minimal filmy head. Aroma is sweet malt, raisin, cherry, toffee and nuts.. Flavor is rich, sweet and fruity yet surprisingly bitter. Long full bodied finish, sticky texture.

Pours a medium amber. Thin head. Aroma like a Christmas fruitcake - very sweet - also somewhat malty, nutty. Taste is good, sweet at first, with maybe some fig/date to it, very nice. Then a half-second later the alcohol kicks in with a nice burn. Then the finish is a bit tinny and bitter. Overall a good barleywine, maybe even a great one, but not quite a spectacular one.

Malty, almost sweet smelling nose.  Crisp up front but then very malty.  Notes of burnt sugar, caramel and a slight dark fruitness with hints of nuts.  Nice hop to the finish to balance.  Alcohol is apparent and gives a nice warming affect.

Copper with a thin tan head.  Aroma of sweet malts, alcohol, nuts, fruit and caramel.  Taste is fruity with nuts, caramel, alcohol and sweet malts and mild hops mixed in.  Malted body is a little too sweet and alcoholic.  Decent barley wine.

12oz bottle, new vintage. Retains a nice fine bubbled head with some adhesive spots. Rich aroma of toffee, caramel, darker fruits,  earthy hops. Taste is  well balanced for an ale that is this strong and so young. Creamy, silky mouthfeel gives way to a firm but unaggressive hop bitterness that endures to a dry exit. Very happy that this one is not over hopped or citrusy, some BWs are difficult to drink until they are 5 years old.

Bottle. Pours a lovely clear amber-red with a thick white head that lingers a while. Aroma of dark fruits - plums, dates, figs - and malt. Taste is big and bitter with a hint of sweetness, of malt and fruit. The alcohol comes through with just a hint. Great lingering malty bitterness. Very nice barley wine.

12oz Bottle - Trade - Masonjer 
Aroma  Big Barley wine aroma with lots of malt and fruit aromas.  
Appearance  Dark Amber in color, thin head and clear. 
Flavor  Big barley wine flavor.  Nice alcohol flavor with a good malt backing.     
Palate  Nice Mouthfeel, great texture with a good dry finish. 
Overall  This was a very nice Barley wine easy to drink this was one of the better barley wines.

I bought this not quite knowing what it was. I just knew it was from bells and it had a higher than average ABV. So I decided to get a sixer, and I am so happy I did! This stuff is fanatastic! It’s subtle plum and raisin notes make it taste like candy in a glass. I actually think I prefer this to Hopslam, because of it’s sweetness. Another big winner from Michigan’s best:-)

Pours a thick mahogany with very little head. Tons of boozy molasses malts, a little bit of dark fruit. Nice thick mouthfeel. Alcohol burn in the finish. Good beer,not my favorite barely wine, however.

bottle. pours hazy dark brown. tastes of burnt molasses, dark fruits, oak. boozy. malty. moderate hop. some vanilla and sweet spice that i didnt find too pleasant. similar to anderson valleys winter seasonal.  a well made beer but not my style.

Thanks to Al at the Blue NIle.  This was a great treat.  A ruby pour with no head.  Dark fruit and candied fruit aromas.  Alcohol is well hidden with a noticable brandy touch.  The dark sugary fruits shine through.  Great beer!

Pours a brownish amber color with a really small off white head. Caramel and really malty flavor with a smell hint of alcohol.  Taste is very sweet general barleywine flavor with a nice hop balance in the finish.

bottle. Maybe the best barleywine Ive had. Pours a deep brownish amber. Big caramel malt boozy aroma. Big full mouthfeel with nice alcohol burn in the finsh. Taste is malty sweet with some piney hop bitterness. Very good barleywine

A moderately opaque red-brown beer with beige head. Nose has cookies, sweet dark fruit, a decent citrus caramel hop contribution, and slight alcohol. Flavor is syrupy with caramel and some bitterness. Full bodied. Overall, a little sweet and syrupy for my taste, but with a harsh bitter component. The beer is not well balanced.

Bottle courtesy polomagnifico. Pours a dark amber brown with a thick tan head. Aroma is thick caramel malt like raw liquid extract. Taste is very thick dark malt balanced by some spicy hop bitterness. Finishes thick and malty with some residual hop bitterness. Maybe I should try this when the weather is cooler, but it seemed unbalanced for something so highly rated and I must have gotten a bad bottle.

(Bottle (stamped "7800") via trade with <A HREF=http://www.ratebeer.com/ViewUser.asp?UserID=3 target=blank>shigadeyo, thanks Craig!, cellared for 1 year after trade) Big and malty...Pours murky dark rusty amber with some solid chunkies. Thin biege head. Aroma is big candy-sugar and brown sugar. Mouthfeel is smooth, quite full and not really too sticky, if at all. Thin fine rings of lacing melt away quickly. Taste is big sugar candy and brown sugar maltiness with a nice low-key piney bitter bite overlaying and providing a nice pinch in the finish. Nicely waming alcohol presence that emerges through finish, making it a touch hot, but a "mellow" hotness. A little bit of doppel-like smokiness. A nicely balanced, easy drinking, yummy big beer.
Dark, thick and Malty. This is a great Winter beer. Im glad I was sitting in front of a cool fan when I drank this one.

Pours murky red brown with a thin off-white head. Nose is dried fruit, butterscotch, and caramel malt. Flavor is very malty with some caramel and hops in there. Also a bit of fruit and alcohol. Feels a little bit unbalanced to me. I think this will be better in a year.

12 oz bottle.  Pours dark brown red with some sediment and a medium tan head.  Aroma is sweet caramel, toffee, maybe a little hops and alcohol.  Flavor is caramel, toffee, honey, with malt and hops in a very good balance.  Hop bitterness and some warm alcohol in the finish.  A very nice barleywine.

UPDATED: NOV 5, 2010 In short: A Barley Wine with a Scotch Ale twist.  Meh.
How: Bottle 12oz, about 1 year old
The look: Cloudy redish brown body with a lot of yeast chunks and paticles.  Small beige head
In long: Toffee and caramel.  Some dried fruits, some raisins, some cranberries, some cherries dipped in chocolate.  Some whiskey hints.  Finish has some dryness but overall the fruity Hops is not assertive enough.  Although commercial description says this is one to age I suspect this beer is at best when fresh, with some hops presence.   I dont care for this beer.  Big distribution, very cheap, liked by everyone, very reliable are you sure this is not made in Japan?

bottle: batch 8135 - deep copper pour with decent size head that had a lot of stick.  mild aroma of hops and toffee.  taste is butterscotch, almond, molasses. chocolate and pine hops.  well balanced with a great texture.  barley wines arent necessarily my thing, but this is obviously well done.  K-6.5

Thanks to Secret Santa & Photekut, I have two bottles to enjoy!  Pours a murky deep reddish brown with a moderate tan head that quickly disappeared and left very little lace.  Very pleasant aroma of sweet malt, brown sugar and dates.  The flavor is very similar, but not as sweet as the aroma, with some alcohol and hops bitterness at the finish.  The bitterness lingers at the roof of my mouth well after the swallow.  This one is a sipper that I will enjoy on this last cool evening before the heat wave hits tomorrow!

Pours a beautiful cherry amber with a small off-white head that leaves a ring around the glass. Wonderful malty caramel, wood, cherry aroma, very pleasant. Flavor is very sweet caramel at first with a little fruit and an alcoholic, old hoppy finish. A lot of depth to the flavor palate of this beer. Very little sign of the 10% ABV.
Dark mahogany color. Very rich, sweet, strong flavor. The aroma resembles butterscotch or syrup. Very strong and flavorful.

12 oz bottle thanks from ucusty, thanks Dave. Pours a hazy funky brown that seems to have the slightest hint of pinkish red highlights and an average to slightly small creamy beige head. Aroma has lots of malts, caramel, toffee, alcohol, maple syrup blending nicely. The body on this one doesnt hide the 10.2% to well but it still goes down rather easy. Flavor of grain, caramel, some rotting fruit, and finishes up with some shery type flavors. Although this is listed as a BW and a very nice beer it is slightly dry to style but still a great drink.

gotten from a trade....If the person who traded this remembers...please let me know and I will credit you!
this was bottled in 05 and the aging did it well...some sherry notes and english barleywineish type flavors....fairly thick mouthfeel and low carbonation.  A darn good barleywine.

Bottle this is a solid bw and i could see someone saying it is their favorite.  Pours a ruby brown and thin head.  Flavor is vinous, with a strong hop presence that is loaded with hop flower aromas flavors and resins.  I should age a bottle to allow the hop character to mellow.
Just another great beer offered by Bell"s.  Quite possibly their best, right up there with Hopslam and Expo stout. IMHO.

Creamy, light brown head.  Heavymalt, dark bread, burnt, dark chocolate, and stron gcoffee.  No hoppiness.  Light dough and some licorice.  Initial flavor was lightly sweet, acidic, and bitter.  Texture was oily and with a full body.  Carbonation was flat.  Excellent old ale, no alcohol feel.  Great long aftertaste and loads of malt and coffee.

UPDATED: MAR 30, 2010 [Fresh 2008 bottle for later comparison] Pours a deep ruby red/orange with a thin fine white froth.  Aroma of sweet cherries, malted rye, citrus, toffee and plums.  Sweet and very rich  caramel malt flavor with light citrus.   Finishes very bitter, somewhat tannic,  Im sure this will mellow with time.  A little bit of cherry cough medicine flavor.  Smooth syrupy body.  Needs age... which is why I have more bottles =) 8.4.8.4.15 . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 

[Dec 01 bottle sampled Jun 08 - thanks Dukefan!!! - rating to come]   . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . [8727 3.30.10] 2nd time with this vintage, seems to be in-between, a dog-food like stale biscuit quality that is not very welcoming... needs more time... or less...
Rich.  Right up front attention grabber.  Boom.  Customer service to the Nth degree.  I can have no more than one of these and be responsible for the outcome.

12 oz bottle, poured amber/brown with small white head.  Aroma of heavy malt, dark fruit, and alcohol.  Taste is sweet, somewhat tart, malty and a bit bitter.  Standard barley wine flavor, very well done.

12 oz bottle:  Pours a true brown with many bubbles that slowly fade away and a very thin bubbly off-white head.   Aroma of apple and brown sugar and maybe some raisin.  Very full flavor, sweet and chalky, with the alcohol only slightly hidden with the sweetness.  Very bitter finish on the tongue.  This is a sipper for sure.
user_location: I F&ckin hate those guys from, Ohio, USA

text: This was a good beer! Shared by robert at stateline. Nice amber color. Good aroma of sweet fruits. Classic barleywine taste, thick, sweet and sugary and fruits. Thanks again robert for sharing!

Pours a lovely dark amber with thick head. Aroma is sweet: apples, brandy, candy sugar. Taste is sweet as well:fruits, brown sugar, maple syrup. Nice syrupy mouthfeel, and the alcohol is very well-hidden. A great barley wine indeed.

Pours muddy, dark amber, with a tan, somewhat dense head of medium duration. A few streaks of lacework remained as well as a film of bubbles on the surface. Quite a bit of particulates floating about and looking very murky. 
Aromatics are malt-laden, with caramel undertones and tinged brown sugar. A faint citrus profile along with raisin pulp adds some complexity. 
The mouthfeel is sticky, slick, and somewhat grainy. 
Pallet is pretty staightfoward, with carmelized malt and sugars. Barely a hint of any vineousity leans in the "old ale" direction, with the profile being more along the lines of an american strong ale. 
Bitterness is slightly heavy-handed, and helps combat the residuals nicely. 
Finishes with a husky coarseness, scortched sugars, and a lingering warmth.

Pours dark amber color with some floaties in there.  Hardly any head.  Sweet up front, molasses with maybe some brandy in there, with a bit of a bitter finish.  Decent but I dont know if Id get it again.

UPDATED: JUN 4, 2008 Bottle, courtesy Ughsmash. Pours a murky brown, with hazy yellow highlights. Thin fizzy white head, with decent wet lacing. Tons of caramel and molasses in the nose. Rich. Brown sugar and floral hop notes, too. Big caramel up front on the tongue. Candy corn notes intrigues me. Sweet overall. Overall, not that crazy; more focus on yumminess with less attention paid towards complexity. So velvety smooth and balanced, the epitome of a rich, sipping barley wine. It probably wont be the best barley wine you drink, but itll be one of the easiest to enjoy.

Old Ale on a monday night? Why the hell not.

A- Pours a nice reddish orange color, fairly clear with a very small head that goes away as quickly as it came.

S- Ahhh heres the old ale smell I love. I still feel tricked by adam. Oh well. This one is big and caramely with small alcohol notes.

T- Starts off deep caramel as in the nose and moves to a huge alcohol flavor that is so prevalent its hard to detect much else under it. Definitely a small hop bite at the end. Even though this one is a little hot I still like it.

M- Thick, low on the carbonation, excellent for the style.

D- I love old ales more and more the more I try, this one is no exception. Not the best ive had but its definitely worth a try if you like old ales.

12 oz bottle I picked up in Pittsburgh. Poured brownish copper in color with a very small beige head. Aroma of dark fruits and a touch of alcohol. Taste is has a bit of dark fruits, brown sugar, caramel with a little alcohol warming in the finish.  I was expecting better based on ratings, but it was still very solid.

12 oz bottle courtesy of IPADAN (BA site).  Pours a dark copper color with minimal off-white head which dissipated immediately.  Smells of vinous fruit mainly and some alcohol.  Taste is complex with vinous fruit - raisins - and also some hops.  Mouthfeel is creamy with some hop bitterness and hint of alcohol, but not near the alcohol feel of some other barleywines Ive had recently.b  Very nice.

hmmm...so this is the first by Bells that really didnt do a ton for me.  Murky burnt orange/muddy brown color with an off-white swirl of a head.  Aroma and flavor are sweet and doughy.  Brown sugar, toffee, and caramel are pronounced.  This beers most redeeming quality is, without doubt, its invisible alcohol content.  You wouldnt know youre above 10%.  Live dangerously!!!

This just does not hit home. Maybe its only for the past but this asva barleywine just is not appealing. Im surprised by the high rating, maybe I got a sour batch or immature, it just did not sit well.

I had no idea what to expect from this one.  The bottle doesnt really indicate this is a barley wine, which I have liked in the past, but have had very little experience with.  Pours a murky reddish brown, with some floaty bits in it.  Not the best look, but I went with it.  Aroma of a cinnamon roll, but without the cinnamon (if that makes sense?).  Flavor was of concentrated malts, with a smoky bitter finish.  I can see how this would age very well.  A lot of yeast sediment in the bottom (more than usual with Bells- which tends to have more than usual that most).  This amount of yeast keeps a yeasty funk in this one that works nicely with the malt and the hops.  Outstanding flavor profile that somehow manages to be malty, yeasty, and hoppy all at once.  I imagine that this one would be difficult to balance.  I would also love to try the barrel aged version of this one.  Another winner from Bells.
UPDATED: APR 19, 2012 Bottle.  This was a fantastic beer!  Great hops and some fruits (not sure what).  Just grabbed this off the shelf and it turned out to be a gem!
Delicious barley wine.  I am very surprised that this is over 10% abv, because it sure didnt seem like that when I was drinking it.  Im going to get some more of this.

BOTTLE: Dark pour with nice beige head.  Malty aroma reminds me of Expedition stout actually, but different of course.  Sense strong alcohol presence in the bouquet.  Fantastic balance hints at hops, caramel, maybe vanilla, but lacking the strong alcohol taste I thought it would have.  Palate is just perfect, nice mouthfeel and long finish.  Fabulous!

Bottle. Vinous, mild dark fruit aroma. Mahogany color with an off-white head that didnt amount to much. Bready aroma as the glass approaches the lips. Medium body with creamy/fizzy carbonation. It seems bottle conditioned in terms of mouthfeel - like Fullers 1845. Something grape, raisin/fig and roasted malts for flavor. Finish is mildly sweet with a decent amount of bitter. Excellent ale. It gets better with each passing sip.

Bottled. Dark brown color. Vinous aroma with raisin and grape juice. Vinous, woody flavor with bready notes, a firm earthy and flowery hopbitterness. Medium bodied, a bit rough and alcoholic, but not without complexity.

Deep red-brown hazy pour with a white head.  Very hoppy aroma with some maple and citrus.  Very bitter taste.  Too much for me.  Real bitter finish as well.  Some citrus and fruit and lots of alcohol.  Not a fan.

Bottled, from drmatt who generously sent 4 bottles in trade. Inviting, very dark and hazy burgundy appearance. Some initial beige head with spotty lacing.
