Wonderful aroma of fresh cinnamon raisin bread, chocolate-soaked cherries, rum fruitcake and lots of caramel. This stuff almost smells like it was barrel-aged. Similar fruity aroma with tons of toffee and caramel malts. The finish is a touch smoky with slight tobacco and leather influences. Warming palate and full bodied. Very good.

12oz bottle. Numbered 7800. Pours a dark reddish brown color with a very thin tan head that fades quick and leaves only a few specks of lace. Smells sweet and caramelly malty. Tastes caramelly sweet and malty, a little oxidation and a little booze on the finish. Thick, semi-syrupy body with active carbonation.

This beer pours an orangey amber color with a frothy tan head.  It smells sweet, like candied fruit.  The hop character comes out immediately.  Then it finishes with a sweet caramel, toffee taste and a touch of warmth.  The mouthfeel is very full without feeling heavy.  Its almost as if there might be melted streams of candy in this.  This barley wine would be spectacular served with chocolate fondue.  I might even experiment with mixing a little into the chocolate mixture.

Bottle. [thank you, Drmatt]
Pours a deep redish brown with a fine, creamy beige head on top. Aroma is really stunning! lots of malts, caramel, sugars, lightly roasted, some slight chocolate and a good raisin-based fruitiness. Low carbonation - very oily mouthfeel. Flavour is brilliantly balanced. Very sweet with a surprising chocolate edge to it. Lots of fruits, caramel, toffee, chocolate and a warming viniousness. Really stunning - damn, Ive had some good BW lately!
A fantastic strong from Bells. A very good balance of flavor components. Perhaps Thomas Hardy meets Hopslam?

A fantastic barleywine.  Pours a deep amber color with nearly no head.  Aroma is very malty and has a sticky fruity sweetness to it.  Flavor is sweet amd malty with a commplex fruitiness to it.  Alcohol was well hidden.  Finsh was smooth and sweet.  What a great beer

Winter 05-06 bottle tasted March 08.

I brought this bottle back from an Ann Arbor trip a couple of years ago, back before the TSA ban on carry-on beer. It pours an elegant dark caramel with plentiful lacing but not much by way of head. Nose of toffee, oxidized hops, maybe a touch of cinnamon. Rich toffee flavors, moving into the burnt-creme-brulee zone, rich sweet cream with a roasted edge, still an ample bit of hops coming in on the close to drive a fairly bitter finish even at 30+ months of age. Carbonation is very limited; the beer is close to flat but theres enough body to the liquid that its not an enormous problem. 

While its nice, Im just not seeing this as a 95th percentile barleywine. Its not quite doing it for me; there could be more sweetness here, the flavors are coming through a bit chemical. I guess Id better try it fresh and at say 5+ years of age as well; its good enough to merit that bit of exploration.

12 oz bottle:  Pours a clear copper amber color with a thick tan head that lingers.  Aroma has got a buttery malt characteristic,  some sharp hop notes as well, and light on the dark fruit.  Taste is got a really nice up front caramel malt, toffee, lightly rounding into a buttery and hoppy texture.  Alcohol is very well hidden for how young this Barley Wine is.  Palate is mildly hoppy with some of the alcohol slipping through.  Overall, I think that this is a decent Barley Wine.  Nice and smooth, but kind of bold at the same time.  Interesting to say the least.  Maybe this one will need some time to mature.

Thanks to Amish_Caravan for this one.  Pour is dark golden amber with medium white head.  Aroma is very strong with malt, caramel, and toffee.  Taste is again strong with malt, alcohol, and toffee.  Has a little bit of a bitter bite of hops both at the beginning and end.  Pretty complex brew.  There is a nice aftertaste of toffee and light alcohol.  Very well balanced and smooth.  Worth my future purchase.

06-07 12 ounce bottle.  Pours deep reddish amber, with tons of floaters and a nice yellow brown head.  Pretty good lacing.  Aroma is fruity and boozy...maybe a little apricot brandy or amaretto.  Some woody whiskey notes also.  Taste is similar, almost like weak whiskey.  I found it to be pretty dry from beginning to end.  Palate is medium full, with moderate carbonation and a pretty clean, smooth feel.  Certainly a nice barleywine, but I find it a bit bitter and alcoholic for my tastes.  Good one for cellaring.

What a fantastic brew! Excellent balance of barley, malt, and hops with just the added flavors of cream makes this one to serve to your "prized" guests at your party. It even resembles a crown of excellence by displaying a golden head when poured. Get this now while its available. Its worth the taste.

Bells Third Coast Old Ale is a reddish/amber ale with a small beige head. The aroma if light a sweet with notes of fruit. The flavor is also sweet with notes of caramlel and malt. I enjoyed this ale but could not drink more than one in a sittting.

Pours dark amber brown almost no head. Aroma of brandy, maple syrup, molasses, sweet malt, dark fruit: amazing aroma. Flavors include bourbon, caramel dark malts, good hop kick and long warm alcoholic finish  leaving wanting more. Very complex great beer.

UPDATED: FEB 26, 2016 Thanks to Eric for sharing this beer. A 2004 edition probably. Pours a dark amber with a thin off-white head. The aroma was just amazing; dark fruit and sweet candies. The taste was also full of a more subdued fruit, with light spices and perhaps some wood and caramel. There is simply no alcohol aspect. Perfectly aged, and so damn smooth and creamy. Just great. Re-rate: 12 ounce bottle from Beermongers. Really fruity, toffee. My original rating 8 years ago was dead on.

pours mahagony, beige head. smell is citrus, slightly more restrained then the bear republic stuff i have been drinking.  sweet toffee, and caramel are also prevolent as well as alcohol. almost brandy. some spices as well. thick sticky syrupy mouthfeel with loads of hops, citrus, but not overpoweringly acidic. extraordinary stuff. well balanced. probably the best since ive been home.
A superb brew- one of the very best Barley Wine-style ales I have had.  The alcohol is high but not out of balance. This one would be good to age, too.

A very nice winter warmer from Bells. This beer looks fantastic to me, pours a deep amber color with lots of chewy floaties (which I love). Smells nice and fruity with flavors like over-ripened apple. A very easy drinking BW style ale with just the right amount of hops and malt. Another winner from Bells!

Bottle  batch 7800. Pours an opaque brown like caramel ice cream topping. Minimal head and zero lacing with some floaters.  Nose is sweet malts and alcohol.  Palate is a bit too sweet for my tastes with candied fruit, malt and a minor bitter alcohol aftertaste - not much hops in this one.    At 10%, the ABV is nicely hidden.

bottle. pours dark squash with little head. very sweet aroma, and i get strawberry and even some pineapple as soon as it hits the tongue. finishes extremely well, with a candy-sweetness, butterscotch, hanging around for a while.

A delicate, somewhat pear-like aroma with spicy overtones. A light, creamy head with perky bubbles over a tea-like brew.

Overall flavor has so many notes ranging from cinnamon to honey, tobacco, and allspice giving way to a mellow, minerality that stays on the palate for a long time.

Old Ale would be a fine pair with an applewood smoked cheese and garlicy summer sausage.

12oz bottle.  Pours a hazy amber with good carbonation and a wispy thin head.  Aroma is sweet and thick, with strong notes of caramel, molasses, and dark fruit.  Taste is creamy and medium-bodied, with an initial flavor of dark fruit and malt giving way to a long, mellow finish of molasses, syrupy hops, and spices.  A balanced and approachable barleywine.

Pours hazy red-brown with a one-finger off-white head. Brandy-soaked raisin aroma with thick toffee and loads of anise. Hints of nuttiness. Beautifully rich and elegant in the mouth: raisin, plum, caramel, and light tobacco are all there. Noticeable, but not intrusive, hoppiness rounds out the flavor. Excellent sipper.

12oz. Bottle.  This one has been in my cellar since last spring.  Pours a deep ruby color with a minuscule tan head.  Aroma of caramel and brown sugar.  Body is viscous with lots of toffee, caramel and dark cherry flavor.  Finish is long and dry with a bit of wood character.  Alcohol is slightly more pronounced in the finish and as the beer warms up.  Outstanding sipping beer.  Has aged well over the past year.
Beautiful dark ruby color. Aroma is strong and sweet with some hops.  Sticky, and Malty sweet with lots of licorice and cherry, with some very pleasant spicy hop flavor.
Bottle thanks to cgarvieuk. Aroma is rich peppery malts, spice and toffee quite a bit of grassy/citrus hops. Taste is similar, pine character is key.

bottle.  small fizzy tan head that quickly dissapated leaving a ring of head on the glass.  burnt orange (almost brown) body.  minimal lacing.  aromas of strong toffee, ripe fruits and light hops.  flavors are moderately bitter with a light sweet just under the radar.  dry texture, average carbonation, finish is moderate to long in legnth.  alcohol is well hidden (but definately present as noticed from the difference in the state  I started the barley to the state I finished it).  surprisingly drinkable and damn fine barley!

Bottle at home with TOm and Royce ... Copper ... sweet barly wine nose ... toffee and sweet malts ... bit over strong alcohol wise but im a bit over tipsy. (i just cant keep up wit tom even if it is my tasting)  Like a lot of bartleys could do with another year or two.
Bottle at cgarvieuks sunday sojourn. Clear golden copper with no head. Lots of wood and fruit tones, some vanilla tones. Mouth is some chocolate and spirit burn. OK.
Dark, yet smooth with a bit of a bitter aftertaste on the way down.  Good when in the mood for a dark beer.

UPDATED: FEB 19, 2011 The black licoriche tint in a rich cloying malty beer which I feel is more true to the Old Ale style than a barley wine, especially with the raisin, cherry and mahogany fruit tones. There is a creaminess here which feels smooth to the tongue. It just could be a bit better balanced but is delicious nonetheless.

12oz brown bottle served in a brandy snifter. Batch 7695. Bottle conditioned with plenty of sediment. Pours a deep mahogany with a quickly dissipating off white head. Rich caramel malt aroma with butterscotch and molasses. Massive chewy body. This thing is a malt bomb. Some fruity flavors. There are a pretty good amount of hops that keep it from being cloying. I dont know why it took me so long to try this beer, but Im kicking myself, because its fantastic.

I have poured this into a tulip. Where the batch number should be listed, there is only a blank space. Not like it matters anyway, since every time I enter a batch number on the Bells website, it gives me the wrong beer. 

There is a slight head which quickly dissipates to a light swirl. The body is a deep amber color. Pour this carefully, as I was unable to keep some of the chunky yeast out of my glass. The nose is vinous, with the hops and the alcohol making their presence known. I detect some cherries, too. 

The taste is of cherries and raisins, with a nice citric hop character. Caramel malt appears, and I taste every bit of that 9%ABV. I dont ever mind tasting the alcohol. After all, that is a small part of why we drink beer. The mouthfeel is is like thick silk. The low carbonation is in keeping with the style. This is one of my favorite beers, as it is readily available to me pretty much year round. The drinkability rocks. This batch tastes quite fresh to me, but I cannot be certain, because of the problems I listed in the first paragraph. Assuming that this is a fresh sample, it is great now. I will, however, age the four samples remaining from this six-pack until the winter. 

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 08-26-2005 06:50:58
Flavourful ale with a thick head, Smells and tastes of caramel, malt, coffee.  Touch of alcohol for the greater than average beer kick.
UPDATED: APR 3, 2008 very tasty, very different from most barleywines these days.  not as hop forward as most, quite matly, carmely.  very smooth and drinkable for as strong as it is...

12oz bottle thanks to kramer17801: pours hazy dark brown with almost no head, aroma has a good amount of hops followed by spices and malt, flavor is much stronger than the aroma was telling me, spices come through the strongest along with a good amont of malt but just enough hops to back it all up. great beer its only the 4 lesser sences that are holding this one back.

pours a murky brownish red with a tannish head.  aroma is molasses, brown sugar, bourbon, dried fruits (dates) and malty sweetness.  taste is molasses, malt, roasty notes, complex malt.  really smooth.  wow.  this has to be one of the best BWs i had in a while.  this one was aged about a year.  beautiful sweetish finish with a very light bitter coating.  this one is complex!  nice and rich, but not over-the-top rich; very drinkable.  oily, slightly sticky mouthfeel with light carbonation.  definitely one of the best BWs ive had in a while.  will purchase again for sure!
dark amber pour almost a brown color with a nice bit of froth up top.  more hops than malts on the nose and a bit of fruit to top it off.  damn good example of a barley wine.

november 07 bottle.  Pours a dark ruby with a thick off white head.  Huge malt aroma,  lots of sweet everything going on here.  Flavor is just massive malt,  brandy.  brown sugar,  toffee,  maybe a bit of hops.  Finishes amazingly smooth,  perfect mouth and carbonation.  This is really,  really good.  Probably the most drinkable barley wine Ive ever sampled.

This ale/barley wine gets high marks for everything.  Frothy head, rich malty and hoppy aroma, nice alcohol warming, malt complexity, and very nice citrusy hopped finish.  It lacks a little bit of overall cohesion, but is certainly a special beer nonetheless.  Worth a try for sure, and I would love to have an aged example.

2-3-08 bottle shared at tasting. 

Looks great - thick brown with nice yellow-cream colored head.  Smells great as well - caramel and malt and some roasted toffee in there too.  Taste is interesting - it is toothache sweet.  It almost reminds me of dissolved pure sugar cane. Thick and dense texture and finish.  Bourbon wasnt very present in my opinion (or at least not where I wanted it to be).  Overall, pretty darn good and drinkable.

Bottles courtesy of for9719 and gregis.  Thanks!  
Pours a rich dark caramel color with a yellowish beige head.  Taste is rich dark caramel and almost orange creamy citrus as well.  More than ample finishing hops to balance and a lingering very mild sweetness and alcohol flavor at the end.  This was a pretty good beer and a nice example of the style.

June 2006 - Im almost ready to pack the family up and move to Michigan.  Another winner from Bells.  Beer poured cider brown, little head, but decent lacing.  First sip yielded disappointment as the beer just tasted candy sugar sweet.  The flavor mellowed a lot as it warmed, however, as the caramel, fruits and hop bite finish came out nicely.  Rich leathery mouthfeel.  The base flavor wasnt as good as Olde Suffolk, but the hop finish made up for it.
Amazingly complex and strong. The hops slow you down and alcohol makes sure you know youre in for a kick. Definitely a sipping beer.

Very pleasantly surprised by this old ale. Brown in color with light head. Very barleywine-like, rich, with an aftertaste which was tart and fruit-rind like yet bitter, making this quite complex. Flavor goes nicely with the alcohol.

Dark brown red beer with a nice thick cream color head. Light aroma of sweet malt, slight hoppiness. Nice carbonation on the tongue at first taste. Syrup, chocolate, brandy, heavy alcohol finish. Light hoppy finish.. bitter. Thick mouthfeel. Not my favorite barleywine.

Dark brown pour, didnt get much head.  Aroma of huge caramel malt, molasses, brown sugar, apples, alcohol.  Taste had burnt chocolate, sugar, caramel, brandy alcohol.  Light carbonation, thick oily mouthfeel.  Cold night in SF and a great way to warm up.

Dark brown body with a creamy head.  The aroma has a strong malty overpowering sugar character along with a light spicy hoppiness.  Flavor has lots of sweetness as well showing maple syrup candy.  The finish has a dry bitterness coming through along with a warm alcohol mouthfeel.  This gets better and better the longer I drink it.

UPDATED: FEB 22, 2008 Purchased 6-pack from Discount Liquor in Winona, MN.  this beer has a pleasant aroma of carmel and bourbon.  pours much thicker than expected with little head.  flavor is very strong with bourbon and fruit flavors.  goes down very smooth with a long lasting aftertaste.  An excellent barley wine.  Glad I have 5 more of these.  I would definitely purchase this one again.

Batch 7695, consumed January 2008.  Pours a very dark chocolate brown to mahogany body.  A large, frothy tan head settles slowly to a murky, bubbly, blanket of foam.  Huge, random flares of lacing are displayed prominently on the glass.  The aroma is rich and decadent, with gobs of boozy malts seeping from deep within.  Massive notes of caramel intertwine with nougat, chocolate, bourbon, oak and vanilla.  The layering effect is remarkable, as the scents seem to hit in waves, ending with a bit of alcohol soaked figs and cherries.  The flavor is similar, though not quite as well defined.  Caramel, nougat, and bourbon are all present.  They are accompanied by brown sugar, old leather, earthy hops, and dark fruits.  The taste is slightly muddled, and not as crisp as the nose.  Still, this is an excellent slow sipper.  The nearly full mouthfeel finishes long, smooth and warm.  I spent almost an hour with this bottle, and I savored every last drop.  Excellent brew from an excellent brewery.

To preface: My rating is based on what this beer is now and not how it is a few years down the road. I know what it should become and thats what makes this fun. A light brown colored barley wine with a small head that fades rather quickly. Scents of dry, tart apple, toffee and a very earthy essence. Taste is incohesive. I get some earthy/leathery/brown sugar qualities, but nothing really definitive. The warmth of the alcohol really shines through. This baby is young and needs time to mellow. It has great character now; enough to realize what lay ahead. Full bodied, for good measure. The dryness will fade and the sharpness will too. An outstanding beverage.

Nice and earthy barleywine. This one would really be something fantastic with aging, as now it is all flavors that need budding. There are some fruity essences of cherries, red delicious apple, and plum, but they arent sweet yet and instead the main tastes are these earthy smoke, dirt, leather, and leaf tastes that are very different. Its a nice change, and a great beer, but if youre expecting the sweet explosion of a well aged barley wine you should cellar this or look elsewhere. Still a great beer, just very different if you go into it thinking this is a barley wine.

Poured from a 12oz bottle (batch 7800) and served in a snifter.  This barley wine poured a muddy brown with a short lived head of beige foam.  A fair amount of oily, slippery lacing was left around the glass.  The aroma of the beer was made up of rich caramel, brown sugar, light molasses, very sweet toffee, and caramel covered red apples.  Very nice!  The flavor consisted of dark fruits, brown sugar, chewy caramel and toffee, nuts, light maple syrup, and a touch of warming alcohol.  The mouthfeel was full-bodied and oily with very light carbonation.  Very tasty and a great drink for cold winter weather.  An excellent barley wine from Bells.

Appearance: Pours a dark amber body with a small, creamy off-white head.

Smell: Dark fruits and crème caramel with notes of cinnamon and molasses backed by a hefty whiff of booze.

Taste: Brown sugar and dark fruits, particularly grapes, smothered in a sweet caramel sauce. Hint of molasses and cinnamon spice. Slight earthy bitterness. Long, hot finish.

Mouthfeel: Medium-full body. Medium carbonation. Coating mouthfeel. Warming alcohol presence.

Drinkability: A pretty good barleywine and another fine beer from Bells.

serious nose of fruits, raisons, and booze. Could smell it a mile away. Taste is less overwhelming, with dark fruits, cherries, bitterness from hops and alcohol dominating. A very warming and enjoyable barley wine, but not one that blew me away.

Bottle, batch 7800. Dark amber body, small off-white head, sweet nose with fruity, brown sugary, and vinous notes. Brown sugar dominates the flavor with finishing bitterness. Some peppery alcohol in finish.

Bottle.  Pours a deep, rich ruby with a small head. Mm, nice sweet, vinous nose on thiswith plenty of meaty, roasty scents to boot. Mouthfeel is par for the course and alcohol is well concealed. A malty complex flavor is presented here with suggestions of leather, meat, toffee, smoke, tobacco, brown sugar, ripe fruits, and a lingering non-descript bitterness that balances everything out. This reminds me a bit of HoD Adam, though leaning more towards the caramelly sweetness which can be found in a barleywine. Quite delicious.

12oz bottle.  Aroma has notes of yeast, toffee, molasses, caramel, and sweet dried dark fruit.  Above average sized tan cascading head that mostly diminished but left great lace.  Murky caramel hue with a good amount of particles in varying sizes.  Flavor is sweet and rich with a nice bitterness at the finish.  Palate is full bodied and oily flat.  A little alcohol on the nose, palate, and finish.  This is a very good barely wine, very well crafted with complex notes and rich flavors.

Draft at Ashleys in Ann Arbor.  This is the first Bells beer I  didnt like (goes for my girlfriend too).  Pours a brown color, with a strong taste of alcohol that overpowers everything.  Sweet and a bit sour.

Cloudy, chestnut pour with lace all along the glass. Rich caramel, toffee, cherries, and alcohol spiciness in the nose. Full flavors of sticky caramel, toffee, ripe fruits, and molasses. A truly great barley wine thats hearty and wonderful!

This is really well-done...deceptively sweet with lots of burnt, nutty caramel malts and a heady aroma. Good carbonation for a barley wine and rich golden-brown colour topped up with a thin beige head. Highly drinkable. Not hugely complex -- has very little aftertaste. Still, solid as a rock, classical yet distinct. Very clean.

The beer is a thick mixture of dark brown and black with no head.  It definitely smells like a barleywine with a lot of chocolate and caramel.  The flavor is very boozy with flavors of raisins and lots of yeast and spice.

bottle, batch 7124, consumed dec. 2007.  so nice to find 7000s still on the shelves when you travel off the beaten path!  pours a clear copper color with a thin off-white head that soon fades to a film, but laces nicely.  great smell of caramel, burnt brown sugar and molasses, bubble gum, and a bit of bread.  caramel candy flavor, with more of that burnt brown sugar taste, and maybe a bit of hops picking up the rear.  finishes like an old ale:  quite sweet for my tastes.  theres a bit of bitter on the back end that makes you try to think it wants balance, but this is a sweet beer.  relatively full-bodied, with a thick, sticky mouthfeel, and not a lot in the way of carbonation.  but carbonation wouldnt work in this beer.  this is an exceptional beer for the style, but this is a style that gets so cloying i can barely finish a bottle.

12oz bottle shared with ealdent. Pours a deep amber with touches of brown and red. A large, off-white head floats atop, relatively long-lived. The aroma is complex and strong. Caramel, malts, and alcohol hit first. Then there are other notes that add complexity to the nose - mostly fruity and estery. The flavor follows the nose. It starts with a noticeable tinge of alcohol accompanying strong but complex sweetness - a spicy malt profile with loads of caramel. There are also some fruit and earthy hops hiding in there, which grow towards mid-palate. The finish is somewhat dry with a balancing level of bitterness - but it still maintains an overall orientation towards malts, even in the finish. The mouthfeel seemed a little too spritzy at first, but as the beer warmed slightly, either I got used to it or it lost its fizz enough for me to notice - it finished with a nice texture, medium-to-full in body. Overall, a complex and interesting barleywine.

Bottle.  Apple cider brown coloring.  No head, cloudy and hazy.  Candied marshmellow scent like Lucky Charms. apple, caramel, sugary in flavor.  Toffee exhale is intriguing.  Solid but was hoping for more.

Bottle - batch #8211.  Dark copper color.  Long lasting big white frothy head with good lacing.  Thick carmal flavor with an enduring mouthfeel.  You gotta like when a beer sticks with you for a while so you can savor it.  Lots of earthiness.  First time Ive rated a barley wine, but this is very nice.  A little pricey for everyday drinking, and at 10.2% definitely not for beginners.  Excellent beer, worthy of it Bells heritage.

The aroma was deeply malty with of all things a coconut character when first poured into the glass. As the head fell and the beer warmed a nice nutty and toasty character coupled to a strong caramel presence began to emerge. The beer poured into the glass hazy amber with a beige low tight bubbled head which laced the glass. The flavor was malty with a substantial level of bittering which kept the malt in check. The hop flavor was earthy and a bit muddy. The malt back bone was well done, but the flavor was not well defined, perhaps a batch issue, this one has always been stellar in the past. The finish was dry with lasting bittering long into the aftertaste. The body was full with a moderate level of carbonation. Something seemed a bit off in this one, another bottle waits in the wings and the review might get a revision, but this one is average at best. 12 ounce bottle. Batch 8211.
user_location: North of Raleigh, North Carolina, USA

text: It has a very sweet malty aroma with an absence of hops.  It poured a nice copper red with a thin, bubbly off-white head.  The flavor hits with a very sweet caramel that is accompanied by a slight bitter and presence of alcohol.  My favorite part was the very thick mouthfeel.  I just dont think its a style I prefer though.

Served at the brewpub. This slightly dark amber beer has a surprisingly thick one finger dark off white head. Im not used to old ales having that. The aroma is sweet and malty with almost no hop aroma at all. The flavor equally malty but with a surprising amount of hop bitterness. It is medium to heavy bodied, which is right in line with an old ale. It was a bit tought to drink in the summer, but I think this would make a great winter beer.
Pours a glowing orange color with a white head . Hints of caramel, spice, dark fruits, lots of barley. Finishes sweet of caramel, and a warming alcohol feeling in the tummy.
This beer is fuckin fantastic. I wasnt goijng to rate but decided i will because of this beer. its awesome-new to 3rd coast but its great

UPDATED: FEB 9, 2008 bottle.  wondeful barley wine from an outstanding brewery.... pours a deep red with a thick white head... lots of yeast sediement in the glass.  brilliant aroma full of alcohol and caramel.  overly smooth for a barley wine... not the hoppiest of barley wines, which is not a bad thing, but I tend to like the hoppier ones more so....  thick and gooey palate...  simply a smooth and very warming barley wine.

Dark amber beer with a very small white head. Pretty red color when held close to the light. Plum and caramel aroma along with a decent bit of hop bitterness. Sweet upfront with an underlying hoppy note that refuses to mask the wonderful dark fruit flavors in this beer. Notable alcohol presence in the finish. Very enjoyable.

alcohol, raisin, caramel dominate the nose.  Very turbid, dark ruby/mahogany color with slight yeast suspended.  Caramel sweetness followed by slight yeast bite (shouldve decanted better) and appropriate alcohol presence.  A well attenuated beer that still retains the  the big body of a barley wine.  Quite a solid product from a very capable brewery.Earlier Rating: 9/24/2002 Total Score: 3.7Very smooth, sticky, caramel like feel.  Wonderful winter warmer with a slight taste of alc.  A good barleywine that will improve with age.

Pours a dark copper with medium tan head, and nice lacing.  The nose is cherry, caramel and dark fruit.  The flavorhas subtle hint of the nose, but is more citrus and hopped than one would expect.  Would like to cellar a couple years and try again.  A very good barley wine.

12 oz, batch 8211. Clear, dark copper-brown with a reddish tint. Four finger, lasting head with sticky webs of lace. Spicy raisin, cherry, cake and caramel aromas. Sherry and mixed fruit on the front with a citrus-herb hop flavor and dryness on the finish. Syrupy, medium-heavy body is smooth and tongue-tingly.

dark hazy amber with white head and honeycomb esque lacing.  Alcohol is extremely well masked. Malts and yeast on the nose. Flavor is nice. hints of sweet malts and a bread like finish.  I thought this would be hot in its young age... nope
Glowy orange body with a delicate circular off-white head. Hoppy, malty with loads of dark fruit and caramel complexities. Warm finish.  Stellar dessert brew.

Dark brown/black with lacing white head.  Smells of roasted malts with notes of yeast.  Really smooth on the tongue.  Tastes malty and sweet, smooth all the way down. Slight bitter finish but really really nice.

Bottle. Thanks to kramer17801 for this one. Pours a dark amber color with a small off-white head. Malty caramel aroma with hints of dark fruit. Sweet malty hoppy bitter caramel flavor with some hints of dark fruit. Sweet malty warming finish with some hints of dark fruit.

UPDATED: JUN 25, 2008 Original Rating 12/3/2007. Bottle. Not my favorite barley-wine. Flavors dont seem to meld quite right until the beer was quite warm. Pours brown and cloudy with sediment. Taste of molasses and hops. Thick mouthfeel, as expected.  5/3/7/4/14/3.3Rerate 6/25/2008. Batch 8269, bottled 1/11/08, from Market Street Wine Shop Downtown Location. Cloudy reddish brown pour with a tiny but persistent head. Aroma is very sweet and reminiscent of baked goods. Taste is dark fruits, brown sugar and a strong hoppiness. Thick mouthfeel. 7/4/7/4/15/3.7

Pour: hazy dark amber/brown with floating sediment. Head: thin, medium tan, creamy. Aroma: candy like, dark fruit, alcohol, sweet malts, caramel. Flavor: alcohol, candy, dark fruit, molasses, sweet mlats, caramel, English BW. Palate: smooth. Finish: warm.

Bottle, I like the barleywines that are a bit sweeter, but have a hint of bitterness.  This definitely fits that mold.  Pours with no head, clear in the way industrial gelatin or liquid fat is clear (with an amber hue).  If I knew anything about cars I gues I could compare the color to some type of engine fluid, but I dont, so I wont.  Very very good, words cant do it justice.

Thanks to someone in a trade. Pours a deep brown, rich brew, reddish in the light. The head is thin and tan, coaxed a one fingger orange head. The aroma is very rich, sweet, English for sure, toffee, caramel, butterscotch, alcohol, very rich malt aromas. The flavor was rich, mild hop waxy noticeable at first, toffee, caramel, malty, vinous, dry alcohol, English. The palate was rich and thick, warm and dry, and a bit of a waxy character. Has a long, warm, and waxy finish. Very nice.

Bouteille 12 oz (batch 7800), courtoisie de Hogtownharry. De couleur brune et voilée. Nez malté de caramel toffee légèrement boisé et aux notes terreuses, moyen de pain et de noix, léger de houblon herbeux, de sucre brun et dalcool doux avec des notes de levures fruitées (figues, notes de cerises et de prunes). Ronde en bouche avec un pétillement moyen et une texture riche, moyennement crémeuse et aux notes liquoreuses. Moyen goût de levures fruitées (figues, léger de prunes, traces de raisins et de cerises) avec un goût boisé (fumée de bois et fput de chêne) lors de lentrée en bouche auquel se rajoute rapidement un goût de malt du genre caramel toffee sucré aux notes fumées, rôties et terreuses (quelques traces de sucre brun) ainsi quun goût de pain et des notes de biscuits, parallèlement à un goût moyennement amer de houblon herbeux aux notes terreuses (progressant jusquen finale) puis en finale lon retrouve un moyen goût dalcool aux petites notes liquoreuses (un peu réchauffant) ainsi quun goût de noix asséchantes et des traces dépices (poivre). Post-goût long et sec, moyennement amer de houblon herbeux, dalcool, léger de rôti avec un goût fruité (moût de raisins, pelures de prunes) et un léger goût boisé.

Apparently I have much yet to learn about beer, looking over the other reviews. I have to admit I dont care for scotch ales and was disappointed to realize that this was one. Tastes too much like medicine for me. I hope someday Ill be able to re-rate more favorably

Had on tap at Brews. Sweet smell of bread. Taste was of caramel, bread, brown sugar and a few hops. Blended very nicely. I like a sweeter barley wine, myself, but this was certainly enjoyable! I never quite like Bells as much as I think I am supposed too though...Not sure why!

Batch 7800, bottled on 1-31-07.  Tasted 11-22-07

  Poured into a snifter.  Pours mahogony with a small fizzy off-white head that diminishes quickly leaving fair lacing.  The aroma is of bread and caramel malts with some nuttyness and brown sugar little to no hop aroma.  Taking a drink, the first thing I taste is the caramel and nutty malts with a little alcohol burn.  Very bitter, the finish is all bitterness that sticks with you for a while.  No hop flavor.  The body is full with a creamy texture and soft to lively carbonation.  Overall I am very impressed, next up is a 2006 bottle to see how it held up.

Batch 7236, bottled 2-8-06, tasted on 11-22-07.

12 oz bottle poured into a snifter.  Pours mahogony with a small off-white fizzy head that fades away rather quickly leaving fair lacing.  The aroma is of moderate caramel malts, no hop aroma.  Rather one dementional.  Taking  a drink, at first you get a very sweet caramel malt along with a little brown sugar, no hop flavor.  In the finish there is a slight bitterness, along with a very faint metallic finish.  The body is full with a creamy texture and soft carbonation.  Overall, it changed quite a bit with a year in the celler.  No alcohol taste, the bitterness mellowed out alot along with the malt complexety.  It was still good, but not as complex. 
Aroma-7
Appearance-3
Flavor-8
Palate-5
Overa score-3.9
Batch 8135. Pours a cloudy brown body with a tan short head. Caramel, dark fruit, sharp bite of hops and alcohol.  So good now and will be great to check back in on after a few years of mellowing.

UPDATED: JAN 26, 2012 Batch 7800. Ive had aged bottles of this that were slightly mellower, but its hard to deny the intensity and richness of this brew. A rich dark pour with moderate carbonation, this one is all about the complexity and the long finish. The initial flavors are fig and molasses, but the finish is dry smoke and a hint of licorice. Malts are certainly there (and the mouthfeel is thicker with older vintages of the beer), but I must admit, I kinda dig the hot, young-ish version. Awesome, whether fresh or aged.

UPDATED: MAR 23, 2009 Bottle thanks to drewbeerme.  Poured a thick auburn brown color with a thin beige head.  Aroma of caramel with some hoppiness peaking through.  Very interesting flavor profile.  Caramel malt up front with a but of a fruity undertone leads into a hop hit in the middle that pulls out even more spice and fruit flavors.  Quite thick, but nice.  Luckily Drew was nice enough to send me 2 so I can stick one away and see how it turns out in a year or so.  Thanks Drew.

12 oz bottle.  Just looked up the batch and two years old today.  Cool.  Deep amber brown with patches of froth and a ring.  Lace spots.  Buttery caramel and peppery pine.  Wonderfully mellow, almost medium body, a whisper of carb.  Rich but not sticky or syrupy.  Subtly spiced caramel and red fruits that melt away leaving candied grapefruit peel.  Very clean; none of the off-notes I sometimes find in barleywines.

[Bottle] Aroma is alcohol, caramel, some fruitiness.  Taste is somewhat sweet and bitter up front, then a long malt finish.  Medium-thick mouthfeel.  Very smooth.  A very nice barley wine, one of the better ones I have had.

(bottle) Pours dark amber with no head.  The aroma is quite complex with an initial scent of oatmel raisin cookies, dried fruit, caramel. tart apple with some hops.  Taste is largely caramel with some fruit and a slight lingering hoppy bitterness on the finish.  Medium mouthfeel and softly carbonated, this is a great beer.

Batch 7236 bottle.  Copper/amber pour with off-white head that diminishes into a halo of lace.  Sweet malt and dark fruits on the nose with a slight hint of alcohol.  Big malt presence in the taste.  Caramel, vanilla, chocolate, and alcohol flavors.  Full mouthfeel.  Sweet malt and bitterness in the finish, along with some warming heat. Great beer.

Thanks to theisti for this beer. Pours a very dirty brown with no head. Caramel and sweet malts on the nose. with some oak. Flavor is sweet breads, caramel, coffee, vanilla and toasty biscuits. Nice finish. Thanks T.

12 oz. Bottle. Pours a murky dark with a thin head. Small sweet malt armoa. Very nice flavor with very small hops upfront folloed by the sweet malty finish that covers the alcohol nicely. This is a very good Barley Wine.

12 oz bottle thanks to drewbeerme.  Pours a red brown with a soapy beige head.  Complex aroma of caramelized malts, burnt sugars, toffee, and vanilla.  Malty flavors where the sweetness and bitterness is balanced well.    Toffee, caramel, red fruit, alcohol, earthy, with a light piney bitterness.  Very tasty.

Bottle (Batch 7800): Pours a murky brown with little chunks of yeast floating around (wasnt expecting that - this is less than a yr old according to the batch ID), aroma of caramel, taste is malty, toffee, dry, with a slight bitter aftertaste, thick mouthfeel.  Probably one of the better barely wines Ive had.

Clear brown-red tint with no apparent head. Aroma is of strong caramel malts, alcohol, and vanilla. Flavor is a very strong rich maltiness. Very warm at first. Also present are caramel, butterscotch, brown sugar, alcohol and some others I cant determine. Buttery, silky texture with a nice aftertaste. I will store some of these  for aging.

Another reason why I love Bells so much. Beyond just being a beautiful glass of beer it smells and tastes wonderful. Very powerful aroma of fruits and wood and caramel. Nice dessert beer. Nice thick body but is not too heavy on the mouthfeel. Not syrup, just smoothness.

Pours a gorgeous murkified dark-clustered brown-ish opaque brown-on-brown color with no head and a 1cm. tan rim. Nose is oak barrel and caramel. The lacing is spotted and numerous. Flavors are enormous here: robust caramel, BIG caramel, strong oak, a bit overpowering, but redeemable after a few sips. Soft carbonation, huge body. Rich and warming. This beer is quite a mouthful and alcohol is hidden well despite the mouthiness of the body. A roaring fire and snowy night would seem appropriate. Its too bad that 60 degrees is the lowest temperature it gets here every year.
Bottle: Pours amber with very little head.  Strong flavor.  Very thick.  Nice beer, but not something that I would drink often.

Has a very subtle aroma.  The smell definitely doesnt overwhelm.  Love the appearance.  Great murky dark color, light on the bottom, dark on top.  A bit of caramel flavor in there.  Starts smooth with a bitter middle and finish.  The palate starts very smooth with a decent bite to finish.  Overall a decent seasonal.

12-oz. Thanks, MrFacto! Pours murky deep brown with a slim rim of dirty white foam for a head. Very little lace. Huge sweet toffee and caramel nose. Thick but very drinkable body on the attack, very little carb. Toffee, caramel, some vanilla, lots of grainy sugars all over the attack and mid-palate--they last through the finish and cling to the tongue for a while. This is a lovely little BW but it could probably use some time for these sugars to mellow out; its a bit of a candy bar right now (not sure the vintage). No detectable twang though--very well-made.

Bottled sample shared with oakbluff. Amber in colour with medium carbonation. Aromas of rich caramel malts, earthy and spicy hops, crusty bread, mild citrus, and vanilla. In the mouth, the malts are both rich and well focused. There are hints of toast and a whole lot of caramel that is balanced out nicely by a large dose of earthy hops. The palate strikes a perfect balance between fullness and drinkability. Well done indeed. Huge thanks to oakbluff for introducing me to this beer.

Bottle 7695 from _____.Small to no head, but consistent small bubble ring around the edge of the glass.  Deep amber color approaching black.  Low hop, malty aroma with some carmelization.  Possibly a bit of cloves.  
Taste is a bit hot initially, but becomes more mellow as it sits.  Sweet, brown sugar, molasses, and hop bitterness hiding under it all.  Pretty good, better with cheese.  I probably wont try it again.

Clear very red brown body with a huge beige head; Very caramel malt sugary sweet nose; Big soft body, soft texture and soft carbonation, slightly bitter and slightly sweet, balanced; Long finish with an initial alcohol burn, sweet without being sticky, slightly bitter, more malt sugar aromas then caramel. Good but not all that interesting.

Draft.  Pours dark ruby red with a fluffy off-white head.  Quintessential malt-forward barley wine smell.  Caramel, toffee, strong maple syrup, dark fruits, candy, raisin, brown sugar, with a lot of hops still noticeable underneath all that and after all this time.  Tastes the same as it smells.  Full, smooth, thick creamy body.  Some vanilla taste too.  This is sweet, no doubt, but is not cloying, which is great and something Im very picky about in high ABV barley wines.  The hops come through in the taste as well, providing mostly bitterness but some other hop flavors as well.  This is certainly one of the better barleywines Ive ever had.  A nice surprise and a great beer.

Pours a murky brownish with a sizeable light tan head that has some very good staying power. Nose is nice and malty with a woody sweetness and a level of complexity that speaks volumes that you hope the flavor can back up. Flavor is beautiful. Nice deep complexities. Touch of alcohol is there for sure. One thing that comes to be after contemplating it for a while is a hint of almonds. Mostly though there is the wood and the "old" malty character. Feel has a good level of carbonation and the liquid is just right. In a far stretch of a way, this is like drinking a sherry or medeira that has yet to be ages to perfection, but is almost there. I like it.
Bottle. Hazy, brown colour with a little head. Light aroma of caramel, malt, and alcohol. Flavour of burned caramel, hops, malt, and alcohol. Ends up very hoppy and with a bitter finish.

UPDATED: FEB 12, 2008 Date: 08/06/1998
Source: Brewfest, Real Ale Festival

dark amber, tan head, 
rich sweet carmel malt aroma, 
strong malt flavor, 
-------- />
Date: 02/09/2008
Mode: bottle
Words: brawleys

hazy dark amber, fine beige head, bits of lace, 
dark caramel malt aroma with a fruity candy sweetness balanced by an earthy quality, 
body is lighter than expected, 
sweet dark caramel flavor, touch of fruity character, well balanced with earthy hops, light bitter finish, 

Aroma: 8/10; Appearance: 5/10; Flavor: 7/10; Palate: 5/10; Overall: 16/20
Rating: 3.7/5.0Score: **4
-------- />
The score was calculated based upon the notes and an old scoring system.
A king of the barley wines. Rich, malty flavors. A slow drinking beer. Not for the weak hearted.

UPDATED: AUG 2, 2008 Third Coast Old Ale smells like a double Amber Ale with nice raisin accents.  The pour is cloudy amber and lacks hop lace compared to, say, Bigfoot.  The malts have nowhere to hide in this style, and Bells do not disappoint.  This features a massive caramel and pale malt flavor with much residual sweetness, perhaps too much so, without enough citric PNW hop flavor to offset the sweetness.  A decent barleywine but not in the top tier.  A recent sample was less sweet yet retained all the other Third Coast virtues.

An oak molasses nose resonates throughout this massive beer.  The mfirst taste is sweet, but not over the top like many barleywines, Almost like a mild prune or raisiny sweetness, and the hops are perfect, especially toward the end with a massive punch of bitternessthat linger until the next sip..

12oz bottle from Drewbeermes wedding reception.  Dark brown wtih red tint and beige head.  Aroma of cookie, some pine, dough, big malt. Big pine and grapefruit lasting hop flavor, big malt, red fruit, some alc.  Full creamy body.  Very well done barley wine.

Another bottle thanks to footbalm.  Pours a deep reddish orange with an orange/tan head.  Aroma is very sweet and caramely, with fruit and molasses.  Nice flavor of sugary malt, molasses, caramel, brown sugar, and a bit of vanilla and dark fruit.
amber/brown with suspended solids...thin tan head...aroma of sweet malt and molasses...thick sweet mouthfeel with a definate alcohol burn finish...alcohol taste is a bit too much for me in a beer

12 oz bottle: It pours a hazy brown with a reddish tint.  A small fizzy white head and some random floaters that remain compleatly motionless.  The aroma is molassas, brown sugar, etc and the flavor has a little bourbon. Has a signifant bite for a barleywine, but it is certainly enjoyable.
350 mL bottle.  Hazy brown with fizzy white head.  Molasses, caramel, and sugar aroma.  Thick sticky palate.  Tastes of brown sugar, alcohol, caramel, and a burnt taste to the finish.

dark amber pour wih lasting beige head that leaves nice lacing, this beer has a truly pleasent look and aroma but I just dont see the same greatness in the taste.  
I understand the style and setting in which Im supposed to drink this but Im left with the sensation of overripe fruit and schnapps mixed with a dark ale.  I cant even finish it.

Pours a murky, copperish brown color.  Aroma is malty sweetness, with a plum like component, though it is a bit muted.  Flavor is malty sweetness on steroids.  Some dark fruit flavors, more plums perhaps a touch of dried figs.  Very nice.

Received this bottle in trade from drmatt, thanks matt.  This was such a surprise.  Pours dark, though not opaque with a medium tan head.  Aroma of molasses, dark fruit.  Taste is so well balanced that I cant pick out anything dominant.  sweet malt, dark fruit, vanilla.  Loved it.
Taste is roasty malts.  It was sweet, but not in a fruity way.  It a heavy malted sweetness to it.  Very full bodied.  Rich and warm.  Smooth and sweet.  Its a nice one to sip and enjoy.

UPDATED: NOV 2, 2007 didnt know quite what i was getting into with this one, guess ill do my homework from now on.  but bells cant dissapoint.    its got a great taste to it however.  i think itll be better as its in the cellar longer.

UPDATED: DEC 31, 2007 Opaque brown in color with and nearly headless.  Fruity aroma has an oxidized hombrewy quality to it that I cant place, along with a certain figgy richness. Taste is deeply alcoholic and very roasty and finish is stabbingly bitter with chocolatey notes .  This is the type of beer that could take an hour to drink without the taste ever leaving your mouth. This product has a rather English quality to it. $4/12oz

06 bottle:  Muddy brown swamp-water color with a thin cream head. The fruitiness of the aroma is huge.  Some notes of cherries, blueberries, bananas and raisins are apparent with a cloying maltiness to it.  Fair amount of lacing.  The alcohol is apparent but doesnt diminish the rest of the body.  Smooth as butta.  Sweet, malt flavor with vague hints of the fruit complexities.  Some bitter, caramelly facets are present that finish this beer off nicely.  The alcohol is barely noticeable.  Sick-ass brew.
Pours dark red with nice head.  Very fruity nose along with a notice of alcohol.  Slightly roasty and smokey with some bitterness and a warming alcohol finish.

Bottle. Pours deep reddish black with glints of light coming through and thin particles suspended in it. Very small khaki head. Aroma is pungent port-wine alcohol scent along with tobacco and dried fruit. Also some woody, earthy notes in the aroma. Flavor has a lightly smokey character, heavy grains, thick rye bread, figs, cherries, fine brandy and nutty almond notes. Light bitterness neatly balances fruity sweetness. Sticky, full palate. Aftertaste is light alcohol sting and lingering fruit flavors. Enchanting.

Bottle.  [Thanks for sharing Papsoe, once again buddy you deliver the goodies every time]  Small frothy beige head that mostly diminished. Spare lacework. Hazy amber color. Aroma of lovely bread, caramel, grain, nutty, grassy and grapefruit notes as well. Underlying notes of raisin and mix of fruit. Full bodied with a complex texture of oily, sticky and alcohol. Soft carbonation. Moderated to heavy sweet flavor with well balanced light to moderated bitter hoppy notes. Bread like and sweet lingering finish. Very nice Barley Wine.
Pours dark brown with a small head. Some earthy aromas, some fruit, caramel. Nice sweetness, some bitterness at the end.
bottle. Semi clear brown coloured with almost no head. Malty and a bit sweet with notes of caramel, spices, hops and citrus. Smoothe.

Pours a dark, cloudy mahogany brown with chestnut highlights and a thin tan head.  Maderized aromas, some alcohol, fruit syrup--essence of prune--wood, and earth.  Dark flavors of bitter fruits surrounded by a caramelized roundness and distinct, though well-integrated alcohol characteristic.  The Body is fairly light and nimble despite the dense, dark flavor profile that leads into a complex finish that ends clean.

(Bottle 35,5 cl) Courtesy of JCapriotti. Pours a hazy, dark, orangey golden with a yellowish head. Fat aroma of caramel and aroma hops. Quite full-bodied with notes of burned caramel. all-sorts and nuts. Very bitter finish. Solid. 080707

Batch 7695. 12 oz. bottle. Pours out a nice brown with a small tan head that fades quickly. Aroma is of sweet carmel and dark candi sugars, touch of hops noted as well. Taste is very sweet of carmel, molassas and spice. Sticky as can be and absolutely wonderful flavor. The sweetness is then balanced out by a slight hop bittering for a clean finish. Mouthfeel is silky and notable as this brew is very pleasing to drink. I will say that this has been a pleasure of a drinking experience and I cant wait to hide my other bottle for a year or so and see how she does.

Botle from a trade with The_Epeeist. Thanks Chris! Pours a murky reddish amber color with a small off white head. Aroma of malt, toffee, and fermented fruit. Has a bit of a sweet flavor intially amd then gives way to a smooth hop taste. The alcohol was nicely balanced with the hoppy, every so slight bitter  finish making it a very enjoyable beer to drink.

Brown in color with off-brown head.  Caramel nose with a hint of spice.  Big and sweet up front with just a hint of hoppy love.  Medium body with a nice mouthfeel.  Finish is clean with just a bit of burn from the alcohol.

12 oz bottle.  Im fairly convinced that Bells could make a chipotle infused pale lager and it would be good.   This is a fine barley wine.  The aroma is so malty, with lots of caramel and brown sugar in the nose.  Flavor is delicious, although its a tad hot right now.  This will age to be a tremendous beer.

12oz. Bottle:  Medium sweet aroma.  Smells very malty, with notes of caramel, yeast, bread dough, cinnamon-raisin bread, and more malts.  Poured brown with hints of red and amber.  Medium-sized tan head lasted throughout.  Good lacing.  Very cloudy.  Tons of floating particles.  Opaque.  Flavor is medium sweet and medium bitter.  Starts off very malty, with flavors of wheat bread, and caramel.  Then it becomes hoppy and bitter.  Medium body.  Slick texture.  Soft carbonation.  Bitter, salty finish.  A nice Barley Wine.

Bottle (Sune) at The Club !! (Vintage 05) Clear red/brown - white edges. Aroma: Ryebread, berries, flowery, citrus, hoppy. Taste: High hoppy, berries, dark bread, ryebread, dried dark fruits, bitterness, citrus, sweetness, light-pleasant-alcho-burn. Very nice.
bottle. brown color with no head. there is barly in the aroma. there is also barly in the taste. bit alcohollic. but nice.

UPDATED: JUN 29, 2007 Thanks to Mibromeo for this one. (Secret Santa July 2006) Vintage 05, methinks. Pours brown with a tanned head. Sweet and very dry. Vary malty with strong alcohol flavors. Low carbonation. Very full bodied. Harsh on the throat. Quite bitter finish.

Pours dark mahogany with red hue to it, small white head. Aroma is caramel malts and dark fruits. Flavor is dark berries with lots of caramel sweetness. Big cloying sugary sweetness stays throughout with grassy noble hops also in the finish. Some honey in there as well with apples and pears. Some lingering bitterness but it is a barley wine. This beer is very well made and all over the place, I think itd be a great beer to age and do a vertical with. What a well made barley wine.

Ive had this several times in the past, but what a treat to have it on tap at the source! Mahogany based with a ruby/amber glow and noticable viscosity. A sandy/cream-colored head stays late as wisps and halo. Aroma of big, malty caramels. Citrus starts with subtlety but finally arrives with the juiciness of a ripe tangerine. Thick yet dry. Flavor finds alot of honey before a citrusy-maltbomb of flavor. A repressed dank character quantifies the "old ale" moniker. That along with a touch of grit in the finish. A little spiciness comes out late as well.
<font size=-4>Draught pint (after pint, after pint...) at <a href=http://www.ratebeer.com/Place/michigan/kalama Eccentric Cafe, Kalamazoo, MI 49007</font>

After years of not being able to find this one, I happened upon a 6er in MO on vacation.  My great memories of this beer have been upheld with great malt, and great balance in a beer that although good now, perhaps may benefit with a few months of age on it.  Definitely one of my favorites.

Bottle.  First couple sips took me by surprise, didnt hit me right.  More malty and syrupy than anticipated.  Lots of raisin and cherry.  However, it just kept getting better and better.  Alcohol is hidden and it is very smooth.  Really enjoyed it after the initial surprise; not like a lot of barleywines.

not what i was expecting from a baley wine. Aroma was slightly malty, but i seemed to be getting big notes of cherry, and cognac. Flavour as very smooth, and the alcohol was very well hidden. Finish was nice and bitter with more cognac notes. Nice barley wine, but not my fav

UPDATED: JUN 28, 2007 Dark murky amber pour with a light tan head.  This beer smells amazing.  Dark fruit, raisins,  pineapple, spice, light hops, just very rich.  Syrupy sweet and smooth mouthfeel with caramel, a lot of raisin and more dark fruit flavors, then a little hoppiness hinting at a barely burnt/smoke flavor before a nice alcohol finish.  Fantastic beer from the brewery down the road.  As Bells goes, this one puts up a fight with Expedition.  Awesome.
Pours murky amber with a moderate head.  Aroma of molasses, spices, and caramel.  Very smooth flavor with nice alcohol finish.

UPDATED: JUL 31, 2008 Fantastic beer.  
A very matured flavor even fresh.  A musty hoppiness and deep toffee/caramel maltiness.  Not overly complex, but with age the slight vinuous nature of the beer will emerge and the hops will settle very similarly to Behemoth from FFF.
848417
-----
Batch 7695 Date consumed 7/27/08
Aroma is huge caramel maltiness, port, caramel.  Bright red fruit.  
Looks beautiful: bright amber/orange, legs that go on forever.  
Taste is sweet red fruit, some club soda flavor, faded hops, caramel, oxidation.  
Finish is harsh bitter hoppiness with a lot of pine and citrus.  
9/5/8/4/17
------ 
Batch 7124 Consumed 7/31/08
Aroma is bright red fruit, some sherried oxidation, and alcohol.
After three years this beer has become subdued in carbonation, bright, ripe red fruit, still hoppy, plum.
Very, very nice.  
Finishes smooth.
9/4/9/5/17
Pours dark red/brown with a moderate head. Strong alcoholic warmth upfront with a berry, caramel, wine-like quality. Aroma of raisins and molasses of sorts. Quite a crazy beer!

UPDATED: JUL 18, 2007 Review of rating: Sampled a 2 year old bottle (Batch 6522; June 2005), courtesy of csbosox. Overall rating is unchanged, but with age, I dropped the aroma by one point and bumped up the flavor by one. The older bottle lost a bit of its complexity on the nose but gained a smoothness to the flavor that made it very well balanced. After a couple years of cellaring the nose and flavor seem more in sync. Young or aged its an amazing beer. Thanks for sharing this one, Chris.//Batch 7695; October 2006. Pours an opaque molasses with a pitted, frothy, tan head which laces nicely. The aroma is amazing, one of the best Ive ever sampled. Candied apple, pineapple, raisin, plum, and spicy hops with just a hint of alcohol in the background. The mouthfeel is full, creamy, sticky-sweet and soft on the tongue. The flavor is sweet dark fruits (plums/raisins/dates) with a smoky alcohol finish. This one is a bit "hot" on the finish, but still an excellent beer. I may need to cellar a few bottles for a year or two to see how it mellows.

Bottle from Capones sampled with Mad_Indian. Deep amber with a decent size off-white head. Aroma of caramel, molasses, spices, and alcohol. The flavor is amazingly smooth, caramel, molasses, spices, nice hoppy presence, and a good alcohol punch in the finish.

Bottle from Capones, Sampled with Stegosaurus. Red amber pour with aroma of sweet malt and a hint of alcohol. Mild fruit, and hop taste. Blended well and a good kick in the end. Good brew but than again it is BELLS!!!

Drewbeerme hooked this up. Hazy dark reddish brown with a moderate head, good lacing and retention. Aroma is big in almost all ways. PNW hops with some chewy caramel, toffee type malts. Fairly heavy beer, sweet syrupy finish with light alcohol. Its good, but didnt come off like a 4+/5 barley wine.
had at Beer bistro last night, good surprise. nice warming beer lotsa raisin and malt on th nose, well hopped like most american barley wines, somewhat sweet with good alcohol feel,

(Bottle) Pours a murky dark brown color, with a small tan head. Quite a bit of yeast that settled to the bottom as well. Aroma is of sugar and caramel. Taste is much more complex, with lots of malt, and a rather hoppy finish. Dark fruity notes in here as well. Moderate alcohol burn, with a rich syrupy mouthfeel. An interesting beer!

My first barleywine.  Great brew (really?  do you you expect anything less from bells?).  Amber in the glass with a non-existant head.  Smells sweet, a bit of caramel.  Not much hops.  The taste complex with hints of raisens, caramel, molasses and sugar with a mild bitterness and alcohol.  Heavy in the mouth, which I love and hence the nice rating.

12oz bottle courtesy of mreusch-A dark brown body with a small head that dissipates into a medium ring.  Aroma of malt, alcohol, and molasses. Taste of alcohol, malt, raisins, and brown sugar. A good barley wine since I dont really care for this style.

Gelatinous dark brown pour with a edium tan head that rapidly vanishes I know the use of the word gelatinous doesnt sound very flattering, but it actually looked very appealing. Strong sweet malty aroma with notes of brown sugar, candy, molasses, raisins, nuts and mild hops. Rich malty taste with a sweet opening followed by a delicious blend of hops. The body is syrup like in consistancy with a powerful alcohol burn.

Bottle.  Batch 7236 (from February 2006, sampled June 2007) via JCB - thanks, Jason!.  Aroma is sweet and malty with light brown sugar and nuttiness, raisins and light aroma hops.  Fruity (red berry, grape) with molasses and figs.  Beautiful clear garnet body with a short tanned head.  Taste is richly malty (And very fully malty), sticky but not syrupy, sweet and bitter in nice balance.  Lots of caramel with some toffee and dark figs.  Molasses and raisins dominate the extremely full body, chewy/earthy mf is layered and interesting.  Aftertaste is very dry and bitter with a little kick from hops and alcohol (which is otherwise well-integrated).  Touch of salt.  Grape is there, too, with light cherry and even a little grapefruit.  Hint of citrus on the doughy back end.  After sixteen months, seems to have aged very well.  Overly malty, full, artfully blended flavor, complex, ages well - this has the potential to be one of my favorite beers.

Rated 12/28/06:  What a beauty this old style ale turned out to be. Sparkling dark amber pour with a thin white film and very little lacing. Slow carbonation and a considerable amount of sediment, but no worries man. Sweet malty aroma, sugary with a punch of alcohol. Its almost good enough just to sniff away on this, but alas it must be tasted. Intense flavor explosion of sweet caramel, candied sugar, floral hops, and even a touch of citrus goodness. Oh my there are more than a few layers to this and it all melds wonderfully. Full bodied, the alcohol makes its presence once again in the finish. Exceptional.

Murky brown color.  Aromas of caramel and slight burning alcohol notes as well.  Taste is full bodied. Leaves a long sugary sweet mouth feel.  Some fruit, wheat, and yeast in the flavor as well.  Very complex flavors and aromas, very nice.  The fruit in the flavor reminds me of red fruit like strawberries.  Only negative would be the alcohol presence.

Dark brown with ruby highlights, light brown head that lasts. Malty nose of toffee, caramel, dark fruits. Slightly sweet caramel flavor melts into a nicely hoppy bitterness, enfolded in dark malts, where the dry finish rests and lasts a while. Alcohol is noticeable but not obtrusive or distracting. Creamy mouthfeel. Ive got an extra one, and I might have to lay it down for a few years. Outstanding.

Bottle. Poured a very hazy reddish brown color. Aroma is alot of malt and some hops smells very nice. Taste is smooth and full body, the malt start with a smooth hop finish is very nice and well balanced.

Bottled. Batch 7695. Poured dark brown, with a tan, rocky head. Nose was raisins, hops, and resin. The flavor is very rich, malty, and sweet with some raisin or currant notes. The finish was surpirsingly dry, with an undertone of alcohol. Very tasty!

bottle (again, didnt write down the batch number, damn it but its from early 07)....appearance:  muddled caramel brown.  not as opaque as the Doggie Claw i had beforehand.  minimal head....aroma: sense a lot of dark fruit with a nice malt profile....taste: much of the same.  starts of pretty sweet and remains that way for quite some time. overall not as gratifying as the Doggie Claw and def less complex.  that being said, i would never turn one of these down....one of the better barleywines that i have had.

Bottle courtesy of ibrew2or3 -Thanks! Pours a dark brown with a minimal light tan head that diminishes quickly. Aroma has hints of caramel and dried fruits. Flavor is rich with hints of caramel and some nuts. Has a thin creamy mouthfeel finishing with a dry, mild bitterness. Well balanced and tasty. It would have been more appealing if there was more head to it.

Bottle:  Nice amber pour with a medium, creamy beige head.  Nice lacing.  Nose is rich with malty sweetness, citrus, and wine.  A little caramel too.  Taste is sweet, malty, caramel, raison, and brown sugar.  A little citrus hops presence.  Thanks dirty_martini for sending this in trade.
Dark reddish brown body with a tight tan head.  Nice malty aroma - slightly spicy, alcoholic, and caramel.  Tastes malty, caramel, sugary, and slightly acoholic. Dry, warming finish.

Batch 7124.  Pours a dense caramel brown, almost no head.  Looks old, oh yeah, its an old ale.  Smells of dark malts, sausage, a hint of some funk and a touch of caramel, but not much.  Taste is quite sharp, slightly bitter, dark malts and caramel flavors are quite profound.  Really rich mouthfeel, aftertaste is a little bitter, but coats the the sides of the cheeks.  Defiinitely tastes like its got some age to it.  Still, nice carbonation and the flavors were still lively.  Nice.

Im not the biggest barley wine fan out there, but i can see why people like this one. Not as sweet as some, which i like. Pretty smooth...wouldnt mind trying this after it sat in a closet for a couple years

UPDATED: FEB 16, 2009 5/5/07, 12oz bottle, batch 6722, bottled on January 13, 2005, cellar aged 2 years and 3 months. pours dense dark red with no head. nose is clearly english style bw, subtle, but real nice toasted biscuits and molasses. no oxidation notes at this point. flavor is lightly sweet, charred-like caramel, nuts, and brown sugar. sweet but not cloying. alcohol is well hidden. 4.0. 

9/17/07, another sample from a fresh bottle and wow i dont recall enjoying this beer fresh as much as a do now. big nose of chocolate and toffee, flavor is very creamy, malty, toffee, all with a subtle aged quality. i like how the hops play a floral and piney quality to it all and adds a nice bitter finish. the alcohol is very well hidden and its not too sweet. wow i could really drink several of these but then id probably be passed out on the front lawn.4.0 

sample from batch 7800, pretty fresh. this batch seems to have a dominating charred wood character to it that i cant get past. not horrible but it takes over the complex malt profile from other batches. perhaps an off bottle.3.3. 

2/5/08, batch 7124 bottled on 11/14/05, aged 27 months. lots of raisins and dark fruits in the nose and flavor melded perfectly with a slight charness in there. at first it seems a bit cloyingly sweet but it balances out as a i drink it. no alcohol noticed. not oxidized at all. really solid barleywine with a few years age on it.8/4/8/4/16=4.0.

3/28/08, 12oz bottle, batch 6722, bottled on January 13, 2005, cellar aged 3 years and 2 months. pours dense dark red with no head. lots of brown sugar, toffee, raisins, and some alcohol in the nose, hint of smoke. flavors are sweet toffee, hints of tobacco, and plums. still not much oxidation after 3 years of age. Im thinking this may never get too oxidized but the protein just falls out leaving a watery muted and bland profile. well see! 4.0 

2/13/09, batch 6722 bottled 1/13/05, so 4 years o

This old ale is good and warming.  I feel North Coasts Old Ale to be less drinkable and less complex in flavor but somehow possessing a more appealing bourbon flavor.  To each his own, and this beer is still quite good..

This beer pours a hazy ruby red with a little bit of head which quickly fades to a soapy residue.  Aroma is a rich malty sweetness with abundant sweet bourbon smells (delicious).  Flavor is somewhat sour upfront with some bitterness in the middle, and bourbon-ness at the finish.  Mouthfeel is dry and warming.
Dark amber body with an oily resiny head.  Aroma is caramel, molasses, spice and a touch of boubon.  Sweet up front with lots of caramel malts.  Finishes with a gently smoothness.

Poured a dark reddish-amber, with a great deal of cloudiness, as well as visible particles floating in the beer.  A quickly fading tan head sticks to the glass, leaving some lacing as it goes down.  Sweet smell, with a hint of alcohol and spice hiding in the background.  Thick mouthfeel, very strong sweet malt flavors leaving behind a coffee like finish.  This is something I need to hunt down some more of for my cellar.

My bottle from batch#7695 pours a rich copper brown with a small head, and a strong rich spicy aroma with the presence of alcohol.  Full flavor that seems to hit every part of the tongue.  Sweet, malty, bitter tasting all at the same time.  The finish is bitter and strong , a fine barleywine!

From Batch #7236.  Poured a very dark brown color with ruby hues.  Loose, thin, light tan head.  Aroma of spice, caramel, alcohol, malt tones way below.  Medium palate, well-carbonated.  Thick malt start, spicy in the middle, quite a bit of heat and hops in the finish.  Seems like maybe I should have waited a bit longer, but it was still enjoyable.

UPDATED: NOV 26, 2007 12 oz. bottle split with my dad, from batch #7695. Aroma of rum-flavored chocolate and plums. The plum scent combines with the obvious alcohol smell for a slivovitz-like aroma. Tart, malty smell. Citrus hops evident in aroma after multiple sips. Subtle, appetizing aroma. Pours an amber-tinted, almost maroon, brown color. Cloudy. Large amount of suspended particulate. Small to moderate amount of yellowish tan head that reminds me of frappéd egg yolk. Produces strong lacing. Quite the site to see in the glass. The flavors, like the aroma, are enticingly subtle. The alcohol is noticeable in the taste. Begins bitterly hoppy but finishes with a fruit sweetness. Remarkably and impressively distinct flavors between the start and end of this beer. Pitted fruit tastes: plums and especially apricots. Very interesting and hard to describe flavors. Full-bodied, oily, and syrupy in the palate. Relatively low in carbonation but not unlively. Overall, reminiscent of a carbonated apricot nectar with a splash of equal parts dry vermouth (hops) and rum or brandy (malts). (Not that Ive ever tried that exact mix). I definitely notice the kinship with Two Hearted and Hopslam, yet Third Coast Old Ales greatness is unique. I regret sharing the bottle with my dad. Hes a fellow beer connoisseur, so he both appreciated and enjoyed this offering. I just wish I had more of it to drink myself! Im not generally the biggest barley wine fan in the world, as I find many examples cloyingly sweet. This beer, however, is fantastic!

Sweet vinuous aromas are present as the beer is poured. A very inviting caramel raisiny smell faintly like a tawny port. The beer is a dark copper to brown and burnt orange around the edges in the light. A medium to heavy body is full of more sweet caramel malt flavors with the same prune-like vinouous qualities. The alcohol is quite prominent in the taste, but not in an unpleasant way. In fact, for as strong as I can sense the alcohol in the taste, I am enjoying it quite a bit. An outstanding old ale that always calls me back for more.
Hmmmm...  A Dark barley-wine.  This one is definitely a sipper!  Thick and sweet with strong black n bitter licorice flavor which sticks to the back of the tongue.

Bottle aged 6 months. Pours deep amber into a snifter.  Offwhite head recedes slowly to skim surface leaving tearing.  Citrus and pine aromas.  Sweet full caramel with a syrupy lasting bitter citrus burn.

Pours a deep red/brown.  Small head that quickly fades.  Smells of caramel and hops.  Taste is much the same.  Hops, caramel, dark fruits.  A very nicely balanced beer.  Drinkable, but extremely tasty.

Bottle shared by Lubiere (merci!!) served in a goblet, cold. AP06/07
App.:  Deep brown-copper, large flakes of light-coloured yeast, tan head with some violent yellow-green hues (nuclear).
  
Aroma:  Tangy molasses and dried fruits, some earthy funk, slightly metallic, some grapefruit (C-hops)
  
Palate:  Fairly full body, soft, effervescent carbonation and a touch powdery.
  
Flav.:  Earthy, dirty molasses, lots of burnt sugar, green herbaceous hops, a touch of fruit, solid bitter finish, lingering caramel and a touch of alcohol.

Picked up bottle from Cellars LexLarp in St Paul, MN. Pours a dark reddish brown with a heavy tan head. Aroma of fruity bread, molasses, pine and caramel. Taste of very hoppy sweat barley malt, molasses, and citrus. Finish is grainy and sweet.

UPDATED: NOV 28, 2016 Bottle at the venerable Brickskeller, Washington.  Dark crimson with a light tan head.  Dark chocolate-cherry aroma.  Chewy raisin, dates, molasses, flowery bitterness.  Big chewy caramel malt.  Warming brew.  good warmer for a cold weekend in Washington.  (#2774, 4/6/2007)

12 oz. bottle.  Arc from lip to glass is about 5 shades darker than 

Pennzoil.  Once its in the glass, when held up to a lightbulb, this ale 

has a hue that is burgundy to brown, with some species of particulate 

matter held in suspension.  Looks like the crab nebula.  After trying 

only two beers from Bells, this one and Bells Best Brown Ale, I have come 

to expect nothing but excellence from this brewer, and Third Coast Old 

Ale delivers it in spades.  First impressions: be prepared for an intense 

beer experience.  When I first tasted this recipe, I felt disappointment 

wash over me because I thought the hops were overdone.  But I hadnt 

finished the first glass before becoming a convert.  Indeed, it has a hop 

presence that kicks like a mule, so, if you dont like hops, youd better 

keep pacing the beer aisle for another selection.  If, on the other hand, 

you love hops, youll be in heaven when savoring this brew.  Ill run 

this up the flagpole just to see if anyone will salute:  the better beers 

are not very verbose on their labels.  They dont need to blather on 

endlessly, boring you with regard to why this is the best beer on the 

planet.  The label on Bells Third Coast Old Ale says simply, "Perfect for 

your cellar, TCOA is strong and rich.  Its caramel malt and long, slow 

finish create an experience as warm and inviting as your favorite 

blanket."  The wordsmith in charge of that description drove that nail 

all the way home with only one lick from his Estwing.  He could have 

said, "Delicious, original, unique, " but didnt.  He let the contents of 

the bottle speak for themselves, and speak they did.  They said, 

"delicious, original, unique."  Hats off to the guys at Kalamazoo Brewing 

Co. for creating such a wonderful beer.  Dont know what CCR has to do 

with it but, "Poorboy twangs the rhythm out on his Kalamazoo, and Willie 

goes into a dance and doubles on kazoo."  Ive been a CCR fan since I was 

12 years old, and have never known what variety of musical instrument a 

Kalamazoo was.  Now I know.  Cheers, and happy quaffing.
12oz bottle -pours a thick tan head and dark red color.  Aroma is dark fruit, vanilla, dark malt.  Taste is dark fruit, vanilla, dark malt, oaky, secondary hops.

This is another wonderful product from Bells.    I have a two year old case of this stuff in my cellar, opening a bottle now and then to see how it ages.  The answer is it ages REAL GOOD!  Big sweet malt bomb with complex dark fruits like raisins and dates, vanilla, oak, caramel, brown sugar, alcohol (but not overbearing), toffee, molasses, and a charred note in the finish.   Very nice on a cold spring day and just as appreciated on my back porch on a hot summer night.

bottle: pours a chocolate clorour with amber hints small white lively head with some lacing. aroma is of nice dark fruits raisins i believe and sweet malts a wonderful balance of both. thef lavour is full and well balanced like most bells i have had.  strong chocolate and dark fruit up front. finishes bitter chocolate with just the right amount of alcohol feel. overall excellent.

12 oz bottle via trade with Brewso, thank Aaron, Ive been wanting this beer for a really long time and I just couldnt wait to crack it open. 7695 on back.  Pours deep brown little reddish near the bottom with a nice 3 finger foamy tan head.  Aroma is faint with a bit of noticeable character id assume from this style.  The taste is strong sweet, robust and full of dried fruit and malty goodness.  This is a serious BW, and shit it tastes damn good.  yummy
A nice dark red pour.  Sweet nose full of fruits and smoke.  Much the same in the body.  Went very well with chocolate covered raisins at the tasting.

Bottle.  Pours dark dark reddish brown with a foamy tan head.  Aroma of rich roasted malt, cheesy yeast, and slight hops bite.  Strong malty flavor, dried fruit, dark chocolate.  Hops presence is less noticable than most barleywines.  More similiar to a Belgian Strong Ale.  Thick and creamy, smooth, very good.

Tap.   Pours a reddish-brown color with a thin tan colored head.   Aroma is caramel, toffee, peat, alcohol.   Flavor is caramel, raisin, dried fruits, molasses, alcohol, floral hops.   Palate is full bodied, medium carbonation, sweet, hoppy finish.   Good.

Pours a nice dark reddish brown.  Very sweet nose of dark and ripe fruits, toffee, smoke, and plenty of heat.  The flavor is outstanding and is a great balance even when young.  Nice sweet port like flavors of caramel, toffee, raisens, and ripe fruit.  the finish is a light floral hoppiness that carries on forever.  Try pairing this up with some chocoalte covered raisens and you will be suprised how well they mellow the alcohol.
user_location: Farewell Minny; Hello Puyallup, Washington, USA

text: Batch #7695.  Pours a deep brown with hints of ruby when held to the light.  Smaller size creamy deep tan head that left spotty lacing and sustained as a small ring.  Aroma had lots of dark fruits, brandy, caramel, woody, vanilla, molasses, very sweet and malty. Flavor of deep toasty/roasted malts, dark fruits, hop bitterness and some pine from the hops. Flavor was bready along with a bunch of caramel and molasses along with hints of alcohol.

Bottle. Pours dark brown with some nice amber highlights. Lots of malt and caramel on the nose. Very full bodied and oily on the palate. Oaky, sweet and malty on the palate, but balanced nicely with some hop bitterness. Cant wait to see what this will be like in a few years.
Pours a hazy ruby color with an off white head.  Aroma is malty, caramel wth bitter hops.  Flavor is malty with caramel and biscuit.  Lots of bittering hops.  Good balanced barleywine.

12 oz bottle. Poured a clear reddish brown fall foliage color. Head was thick and off white with good retention and lacing. Malty and boozy aroma with a whiff of molasses and soy. Full bodied with a dry bitterness on the tongue. Nice fruity flavor with plum and raisin balanced against a toffee and caramel malt backbone. Pleasant mellow bitter finish tempered by a warm splash of alcohol. Good, not outstanding.

Poured from a 12 ounce bottle, very deep ruby red when held up to the light with almost no head. The aroma was of sweet dark fruit. The flavor was filled with plum, prune and other dark fruits, caramel, malts and some hops. There is an alcohol bite and the finish is ever so slightly bitter. Overall one of the better barley wines Ive tasted.

Oak, some alcohol, light chocolate malt and some hops make up the complex aroma.  Murky mohogany in color.  The palate is full and lies under a nice hoppy taste up front that leads slowly into a creamy malt finish.  Very good flavor.
