A very solid beer.  First things I noticed were the great aroma and beautiful color.  Started out great, but as the beer warmed it brought out the alcohol flavor, which became overpowering for me.  Otherwise, a terrific brew.

Batch 7236 packaged on February 8, 2006.  Pours a slightly hazy reddish orange with a one finger beige head.  Aroma of port, raisins, brown sugar, a litle cardboard, stale nuts, piney hops, caramel and toffee.  Flavor has much more toffee and boozey cherries, alcohol is almost harsh.  There is also sugar cookies, port, some spices (maybe nutmeg?).  Dry bitter (5 on a 1-10 scale) finish with hints of vanilla.  Lost a point due to the alcohol being so strong--its a year old and doesnt seem the slightest bit mellow.  Soft carbonation with a full body.  Even at a 3.7, I was expecting a little more from this.
user_location: Ocean Beach, San Diego, California, USA

text:
Batch 7124, bottled on November 14, 2005.

Pours a dark mahogany, with a thin layer of foam that fades quickly to a thin ring. The lacing is very minimal, but it is very sticky.

Smell; lost of dark rich malts. Toffee and and molasses mix with with plums, dates and raisins. Floral and citric hops are present as well, along with a bit of spiciness in the background.

Taste; this is a bit more fruity in the flavor than I was expecting. The plums and dates are present, but theres also hints of cherries and figs. A rich malty toffee and molasses, with a bit of vanilla, fill out the middle, and the finish is bitter, floral and citric hops.

Mouthfeel/Drinkability; the mouthfeel on this is very full bodied, and silky smooth from a relatively low carbonation. As far as the drinkability goes, the only thing holding it back, for me, is the high abv. If it werent for that I could drink this all night long.

Ive had many different batches of this beer, and it never disappoints. I jst wish that I could have this available to me all of the time, instead of just on my winter trips to Michigan.
user_location: Where the hell am I?, Nebraska, USA

text: 12 oz. bottle.  Pours a dark, cloudy, reddish amber with a large, tan head.  Aroma of caramel, prunes, and raisins.  Roasted malt flavor with some grapefruit and orange peel.  Well bittered with a long, bitter finish.  The body is pretty think and creamy.  Overall, an okay barly wine but Id be interested to see what its like after a little aging.

Bottle, batch #7695.  Pours a dark mahogany color with ruby highlights and a nice dense off-white head.  Deep malts, dark fuit, pine and citrus aroma and even a hint of chocolate.  Rich caramel malt flavor with a significant pine and citrus hop presence.  A touch of brandy in the finish too.  Not quite as sharp as fresh Bigfoot but definately lending more towards the American style barleywine.  Velvety smooth full body with just the right touch of soft carbonation and alcohol warming.

Just about the last bottle from shigadeyo. Thanks, Craig! Pours a hazy dark copper with a lacy white ring of foam. Caramel and toast nose. Full body and moderate carbonation. Taste of caramel, grapefruit. Lingering bitter finish that seems to fight a bit with the taste. Im all for hops in IPAs and APAs but the level seems a bit out of place here. Would probably taste great, given three or four years for the hops to chill out.
12 oz bottle.  Batch #7695. Pours caramel with a slight tan head.  Aroma is of caramel, citrus, hops and pine.  Taste is sweet with a carbonated bitter pine citrus finish.  Nice.

UPDATED: JUN 4, 2008 This beer scared me.  Didnt look or smell like a barelywine.  Opaque dark brown color that settled like a stout with a thin creamy tan head.  Smells like an IPA, heavy pine hops, but also a strong malt and caramel aroma.  Mouthfeel is unmistakable though, thick and syrupy and definitely a barleywine.  Flavor is like a brandy with touches of plums, grapes, toffee, caramel and citrus.  Heavy alcohol feel that warms the mouth and face and stomach long after the sip.  Very well crafted.  ***Quick re-rate from 6/3/2008, after aging for more than a year this beer was even more delicious than when first opened.  The hop aroma and flavor has mellowed a bit and the malt is thicker, sweeter and better than ever.  I will definitely be picking up a case for aging.

Bottle thanks to Secret Santa. It seems to have been aged, Batch # 6722. Pours a fairly dark cloudy amber with a small off-white head on top. Aroma is full of caramel malt, dark fruits, alcohol, and brandy notes. Flavor is caramel, dark fruits, toned down hop notes, brown sugar, alcohol. Wow this beer is quite flavorful. It still is quite complex even with some age on it. It is actually quite comparable to aged Bigfoot in flavor and appearance. This is quite an enjoyable beer. I would love to obtain a few fresh bottles and watch this age.
Bottle.  Aroma of sweet caramel malt and some alcohol.  Smooth on the palate, with flavor of berries, malt, and a little alcohol.  Nice beer.

12oz bottle from Artusory. This amber ale poured with a modest off-white head  that cliings to the snifter, and a strong malty aroma. The flavor is dominated by caramel malt, but there are some interesting fruit and candy flavors and a long bitter finish.

2004 bottle from Crosling. The last of my birthday stash. Pours a cloudy brown with almost no head--just a ring of tan bubbles around the edge of the glass. Intense aged maltiness in the nose and in the mouth. Also get notes of dark fruits, sugar, and alcohol. Delicious.

Dark fruits and caramel malts in the aroma.Pours a murky dark brown with a thin tan head.Very sweet caramel malt flavor with a hint of some hops in there as well.Medium to full mouthfeel with a sweet finish.

Bottle from 1FastST1. Batch 7236.Drank this side by side with a 2001 bottle. Dark brown with fast vanishing tan head. Rich and malty with some chalk. Full bodied beer with good roasted flavors.Alittle ruff with medicine like taste. Some sweetness but the finish was too bitter for me.






















 Bottle from drebeerme. Age has done this beer well, Darkbrown with no head. Malty brownsugar/caramel aroma. Smooth with some brown sugar in the taste. Roasted malts and some alcohol in the finish. Not as bitter as a fresh bottle which is good to me. Mellow and smooth aftertaste.
wow bells did it again with this.  nice dark beer with great flavor to it.  its good stuff

Nice dark brown/amber color with tight, diminishing light brown head that creates a nice lacing. A lot of huge floating sediment, some floaties remained suspended, some pieces sank to cover the bottom. Looked good other than that. Aroma was rich and malty with some berry notes. First sip was extremely powerful. Huge flavor malty and fruity. Burned the tongue for a second and ended bitter with the hops coming out. Both fruit and alcohol appeared more as it warmed. A lot going on here. batch 7695 (10/06)

Pours a deep reddish brown with little head. very mild aromas. well balanced big ale. hide the big abv well and goes down very very smooth. with so little aroma, hard to belive the flavor is sooooo nice and balanced.

Winelike, red grape, lemon, brandy and oak aromas.  Deep brown in the glass with a sticky, lacy head.  Caramel and brandy flavors.  Candy sugar that would subside with time.  A little cloying on the finish.  Slick on the palate with fine, but persistent, carbonation.  A little too sticky and sweet for now, but throw one in the cellar for later.

Bells Third Coast Old Ale 
12 oz bottle
Medium pour in an English pint.
Packaged 11/05, unwrapped 02/07

Poured a hazy ruddy brown with an average beige yellow frothy somewhat diminishing head with fair lacing.

Smelt of sweet sweet caramel with moderate lemon citrus undertones.

Taste was upfront strong roasted grain and moderate spruce bitterness with light caramel and orange sweetness followed by a strong bitter toasted whole grain bread taste and cedar with with a light sweet caramel on a long finish.  Palate was medium bodied, oily, lively carbonated, strongly astringent and slightly alcoholic.

Overall, an old ale that showcases the grain perfectly after over a year in a bottle, with hops still present and supporting the whole beer.
Pours brown.  Sweet malt, toffee, slightly roasted aroma.  Very sweet dark fruit taste.  You pick up on the alcohol, but that could also be brown sugar.  There is a lingering toasty aftertaste.
Bland grainy, chalky, malt-centric flavor with harsh alcohol burn. A oily yet sticky piney cloying mouthfeel. Perhaps the worst barely wine Ive tried.

Murky brown color - slightly hazy with a few floaties.  Nose is rich with malt, roasted malt mostly, maple syrup & chocolate. Flavor is earthy, malty and sweet, with some astringent bitterness.   Alcoholic finish. Pretty good - but there are better barleywines around.

UPDATED: JAN 31, 2007 On tap at the brewery. The pour reveals a clear amber pour with a thin offwhite head, Excellent aroma of caramel, earthy hops. wild flowers and honey. Superb flavor of caramel, earthy hops, wild flowers and honey with a bitter finish. The body is light with an oily texture while the carbonation is gentle. A very old ale.

UPDATED: AUG 30, 2007 Batch 7695. Aged about 6 months. Pours a nearly opaque deep brown with a large head. Good lacing. Aroma of toffee, molasses, dark fruits and earthy hops. Sweet brown sugar and raisin taste. Full Bodied. Syrupy texture. Has kind of a heavy bitter and alcohol aftertaste which follows every sip.

Bottles, pours a dark brown with very little head.  Aroma of malt, brown sugar, alcohol, overall sweet. Pretty oily mouthfeel.  Flavor was complex.  Sweet malt, vanilla, molasses, some hops.  Very enjoyable barleywine.

Pours a murky dark copper color with no head and no lace. Sweet malt, brown sugar, and molasses in the aroma.

The flavor is quite dense, with sweet dark bready malt, followed by (and nicely balanced by) bitter hops - full of citrus, herbal, and pine flavor. The malt and hops carry full into the finish, where I also taste some bitter almond. Mild rum and additinal hop bitterness round out the aftertaste.

This was a full-bodied sipper, with very light carbonation.

Okay, Im trying to find something wrong with this... maybe a little burn, other than that, pretty damn good. Nice oily pour covering your tongue with a delightful display of complex malting. Fruitcake comes to mind and then citrus peel as the hops asserts itself (themselves?). Dryish finish with just a touch of brown ale lingering until the next sip. Nice. thanks Jon.
12 oz bottle. Pours dark brown color with minimal brown head. Aroma of malt and slight hoppy aroma. Taste  of malt and coffee with bitter after taste.

UPDATED: MAR 14, 2008 A good barley wine by Bells. This was a delicious and tasty dark brown beer with fruity and hoppy overtones. The bitter hoppy aftertaste was a great suprise and made me want more. Bells is a force to be reckoned with.
user_location: Moon Twp, suburb of Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, USA

text:
I was tired, it was late.  I wanted to wind down with something special. I shuffled the bottles around and pulled this from the back of the fridge, I let it warm up.  I sat in a big chair and clicked to something mindless.  I sniffed, I drank, I remembered why I love beer. I relaxed, I went to sleep.
Thanks Jonno, great gift.
UPDATED: JAN 22, 2007 Dark brown coloring. Alcoholic taste that is slightly malty. Christmas present from my wife.

UPDATED: JUN 11, 2007 Batch 7236. Pours a deep copper with a small off white head. The aroma is pretty mild. Almost smells like Sweet Tarts. Light malts and hops. But the flavor is a different story. Pretty big hops. Has got a sweet citrus flavor also along with some decent malts.

UPDATED: FEB 17, 2007 Bottle from Whaleman, thanks Dave! Good hoppy aroma and great dark ruby color with a good size head that stayed. Nice flavor that has a good balance to it. Hoppy with a slight citrus hint to it. Alcohol noted during tasting. Would like to have this again after a couple years of aging. Cheers!

Wow!  Another winner from Bells.  Almond to copper brown color with a low, thick head.  The aroma was mellow but I could definitely smell some hops, toffee, and fruit.  The flavor, well, it was delicious.  Sweet malt and hops with hints of roasted almonds and very mild chocolates.  The finish is dry and slightly bitter.  One of the most well balanced barley wines I have had.
copper brown with beige head, the aroma is hops blended with toffee.  thick and creamy with a lot of body, it ends with a somewhat off balanced bitterness.

Poured a brown color with an almost non existant head.  Aroma is subtle but pleasant with caramelized malt with drak cherries and figs.  Flavor is a little more noticable with a roasted bittersweet chocolate note and a strong herbal pine hop flavor.  A fair amount of bitterness that gives the beer a dryish character.

12/02/06 Walk the Line Barleywine Festival, Dunedin, FL. 2003 vintage. This beer was brown with an off white head. The aroma was on the light side with hints of sweet dark fruit and caramel. There was a nice strong pine flavor that married well to a classic Barleywine dark fruitiness.

12/02/06 Walk the Line Barleywine Festival, Dunedin, FL. 1999 vintage. This one poured black with no head. It seemed thick and oily. The flavor was similar to the 03 except the pine hops were softer and the sweet maltiness was a bit more complex. Some caramel and toffee notes surfaced above the dark fruitiness.
Dark brown pour, small head taht leaves quick. Dark fruits and molases aroma. Coffee taste along with molases. Very dark brew. Warm alcohol finish.
a fine beer big fan super big taste at the finish i love this stuff another great offering from bells although come to think of it i aint had a bad one from them yet delicious i say GET SURLY ROUTES

UPDATED: JUL 8, 2008 Bottle, pours dark brown with an orange/red tint.  Slight head that dissipates quickly, no lacing.  Interesting aroma with dark fruits, caramel and sweet malts.  Nice sweet bite with warm alcohol and slight bitter finish.    
7/3/7/3/17 > 3.7

Rerate, also Batch 7695, 07/08/2008, two finger orange tinted tan head that slowly dissipates, good lacing.  Aroma has rounded out and matured nicely, with more sweet malts, bread/biscuit, vanilla, dark fruits and toffee.  Flavor is also a big improvement, following the new notes in the aroma nicely.  A bit sweet and warming, but both in a positive way.  Wow, this is a rewarding check-in on this batch, and can’t wait to try again in a year or so.  Wish I had a few more stored away...
8/4/8/4/17 > 4.1

A good representative of the barleywine style.  Deep color, not much head.  Nice aroma.  The taste is predominately sweet caramel, with some alcohol.  The finish is long and sweet.  I prefer a slightly more hoppy barleywine, but this is quite good.

Batch 7124.  Pours bronze / mahogany with a smallish tan head.  The aroma has a big caramel and toffee presence along with ABV warmth.  Thick body with sharp carbonation.  Taste has thick rich alcholic caramel that glides throughout the mouth - lots of dark malts as well.  The alcohol present is similar to red wine.  The finish gets a rough woody taste and feel.  This has a very full and dominating flavor that is quite enjoyable.

Bottle, thanks sersdf.  Pours a hazelnut brown color with an amazing off-white head.  Toffee, caramel, and sweet malty aroma with just right hops.  Notes of nuts (almond), vanilla, and raisins, hint of alcohol.  Really good bitterness in the finish.  Aroma matches up with the flavor really well.  Decent on the palate, a tad oily for me.  I really dig this beer.

UPDATED: DEC 11, 2006 (Bottle) Pours beautiful dark, dark red with a small nougat coloured head. Caramely malt and fruits in aroma with hints of alcohol, mint, raisin and figgs. Some allmond/nuts. Warming, peppery, alcohol-ish flavour with hints of coffee. Caramel sweet and bitter. Raisiny notes. Medium body.

UPDATED: JUN 14, 2007 Batch 7236 (with aging a little over a year): Pours a dark hazy honey brown, off-white bubbles, aromas of caramel, chocolate, brown sugar, lots of sweet on the nose, toasted malt fragrances, some fruit fragrance, some fruit with a Tootsie Roll aroma reminds me of the Great Divide Hibernation Ale, a sip has caramel, sweet and thick chewy malt flavors, there is a hop citrus bite but it seems to have calmed down a little with the aging, some warming alcohol on the tongue that appears to be hidden better, thick mouth feel, I appreciate this more, now that, my palate has adjusted over time, this was easier to drink. -------- Bottle, poured a muddy brown, little bubbles, looked dirty, murky, smelled sweet of prunes, sweet molasses, dark bread, tasted of thick chewy malts, chocolate, hop bite, the malts and hop are coliding, alcohol in the background, alcohol in the nose after each drink,
I did not enjoy this, I will store some to see how this changes with aging, old rating 8-3-7-5-12

February 2005 bottle.  Deep ruby/brown color with light head.  Rich dark fruit and hop aroma that is very inviting.  Taste is smooth, sweet, sugary.  Hoppiness is very pleasant.  Mouthfeel and finish very nice.  This definately lives up to its reputation, but it seems like it would be alot better after another year or so.  I have six from November 2005 that I plan to tuck away for safe keeping!

UPDATED: NOV 18, 2006 bottle - Pours murky amber with a small head.  Theres a sweet, lightly fruity aroma.  The flavor is quite sweet with some mild hops and a light hint of dark fruits.  The finish is moderately bitter and in this case, somewhat unpleasantly so.  The finish was off and Im wondering if this was a bad or very old bottle.  I will have to try it again if I can find it at a different bar.  For now Im going to have to go a little against the grain though.  It was a very disappointing finish.
Rerate: The finish was better in this bottle... still a little off tasting, but better.  Ill bump the rating up a bit more.

12 oz bottle via csbosox(thanks!). Pours a perfectly hazy amber with a tiny head. Aroma is of anise, bourbon and butterscotch. Flavor is...wow...lol...and expsosion of piney hops, oak aged ale, molasses and then a burning hit of alcoholic woody something...actually pretty tastey. Imagine an oak aged IIPA with lots of malts i suppose?

UPDATED: MAR 21, 2008 For the finest of winter occasions.  Vintage 2005. Pours to a thick, luminous consistency and color like maple syrup.  Aromas are indulgent.  Caramel, bourbon, honey, wood, molasses, etc.  The most warming tones of anticipation a beer can conjure up.  Nothing short of heavenly in flavors along similar lines, with more toffee and some milk chocolate, peat, and gentle tones of tart cherry and peach.  Wonderful layering and richness. 9/5/10/4/18 4.6

Vintage 2006, freshly cracked, is harsh, astringent, and metallic atop all the nicer nuances.  This is a beast that indisputably requires the grooming of age. 7/4/7/3/14 3.5  

Vintage 2002; pre-batch numbers.  Pours volcanic red and fairly clear with a sticky, thick layering of web-like foam.  Tannic tawny port aroma with brown spice, pineapple, caramel, brown sugar, and raisins.  Wet barrel, cherries, strawberries, iron, sticky toffee, brandy alexander; richly complex with beautiful, restrained sweetness and subtle colors.  Flavor is more oxidized with dominant tones of soil and wet bark, a bit like a dirty brandy; quite vinous and lightly tropical underneath with raisins, peaches, berries and orange cream candies.  Mid palate is burly with cardboard oxidation, singed with red pepper and giving a rich spirited heat.  Mouthfeel is soft and earthy, still quite generous and rich, and never even slightly soured; finishes graciously with quiet caramel sweetness and a firm, tannic bitterness.  Gentle.  Sophisticated.  Probably only a year or so past prime, and still very interesting and satisfying to drink. 8/4/8/4/17 4.1

UPDATED: APR 17, 2009 Bottle.  Pours out the color of an old leather basketball, brownish orange.  Earthy, hoppy, malty, citrus, this barley wine had all of it in very nice balance, both in nose and taste.  I really enjoyed this beer.

Finally drank one of these. I was sitting on a bottle for nearly a year, but my friend brought me 4, and I got another old vintage in a trade, so I figured it was time to give this a go. Batch 7236, from Feb. 06. Nine months old, sitting on a shelf in a beer store. Aroma is rich and complex, yet still mellow, with smooth milk chocolate, japanese white rice, fresh gutted pumpkin, lime juice and tequila, some grain alcohol. Gentle noble hops squeeze in there too. Pours a very dark brown ruby with a small, fizzy head. Flavor is a little harsh and bitter, slightly covering up rich caramel malt, liquid candy, anise. Im surprised at the intrusiveness the hops still play. An extremely enjoyable beer, to be sure, Im glad I have 5 more bottles of this to sit on for years. Would likely be sublime in 2 or 3.

Pours a hazy medium brown red color with a nice medium thin layer of light brown head.  Aroma is earthy piney hops, sweet toasted malts, caramel and citrus.  Flavor is slightly citric, earthy, bitter and warming, burbony, and just overall wonderful.  Loved this beer.

Pours a deep ruby red. Aroma is loaded with fruit, nuts, malts and booze. Flavor is rich with toffee, caramel, cherries, raisins, with earthy hops in the finish. A touch of alcohol that blends with thins beer flawlessly. Medium bodied and damn drinkable. My second favorite brew from Bells.

12 oz. bottle, Batch 6722 courtesy of Hellomynameis. Hazy coppery amber and a stable yellowish tan medium head that shows nice lace. Complex aroam characterized by citrus, grape, caramel, bread, and earthy spice. Medium/full body that is smooth with some chewiness. Rich malty sweetness balanced by citrus and spicy hop bitterness. Alcohol is well hidden. Surprisingly balnced dry finsih, considering the immense malt presence.

12oz., Batch #7124.  Pours a clear, medium-to-dark brown with a cherry tinge throughout; small headed, but maintains a perimeter of larger bubbles.  Huge aroma showing candy sugars, cotton candy, hints of red fruits and citrus; alcohol is well-hidden.  Generous, sweet mouthfeel: maple syrup, candy sugar, a slight piney hop bitterness, cherries, and a pronounced yeasty quality running throughout.  Finish shows layered belgian sugars and a balanced piney hop bitterness.

Bottle; Aroma hits you as you open the cap; nose of caramel, cherries, and nuts, like an ice cream sundae; Cherry-brown with a tiny beige head; flavor is sweet, caramel, and fruitiness, like a bing cherry; Finish has mild hop bitterness and alcohol.

bottle:  Aroma:  Big caramel aroma, rye bread, slight dark chocolate, raisins, and a touch of nuttiness.  Appearance:  Deep red in color and slightly hazed.  Head was light beige, small, and short lived.  Some lacing.  Flavor:  Sweet maltiness with strong caramel overtone.  Roasted nuts, Dark fruits, solid breadiness, and some floral hop flavors.  Bitterness was a little higher than I was expecting, but not bad.  Getting a touch of earthiness/basement in the finish.  Palate:  Full bodied and velvety on the tongue.  Low but appropriate carbonation.  Overall:  A good end of the night drink, but bitterness just doesnt gel with the rest of the flavors.

Bonus Brew from a recent trade with Kmweaver. Thanks Ken!  12 oz. Aroma is huge--caramel malts, a little grapefruit hops, yeast, and mild alcohol. Flavor is full--sweet at first sip and then with a bitter hop tinge on the palate. Very nice balance. Another great brew from Bells They know how to make big beers work well.

The aroma on this beer is a very nice fruity boquet of sweet cherries, grapes, and maybe a hint of apples, with alittle bit of bready or yeasty smell coming through as well.  Very smooth on the palate, with a lot of malt sweetness and fruty characteristics backed by a nice bitterness.  No really noticeable hops but they shine in the nice subtle bitter follow through of this beer.  A very good beer that is prolly borderline old ale...maybe a little bit of roast presence and it would be there.  A good barleywine, but I would expect nothing less of Bells.

Bottle: Dark, clear amber with a tan head.  Strong aromas of sweet grapefruit, tires, tangy yeast and a little licorice.  It has a robust bitter astringent quality to the taste that leaves a blunt bitter taste in the tongue.  Flavors or sorghum and some prune juice as well.  The body is thick and syrupy like drinking thin molasses - a little too thick for me.  Thanks Secret Santa!
Nice fruity barleywine.  Aromas of plums, grapes, cherries, apples.  Flavor matches aroma with an added hop bitterness.  Ruby-colored with a small off-white head.

An amber/red pour. An aroma of fruit and a slight alcohol presence. A nice complex fruit flavor to this bw. It was a very nice experience trying to figure out exactly what those flavors were. I really like this beer.
2005 bottle.  Pours ruby red with a thin pinkish head.  Smells of caramel, toffee, some fruit and earthy hops.  Taste is fruity with some buttery sweet caramel hints.

Aroma of black cherry, apple butter, and toffee.  Appears a hazy mahogany color, with no head and no effervescence.  Flavor of black cherry, currant, molasses, toffee, and hop bitterness.  Palate is medium-thick and appropriate.  Overall, a good old ale.

A dark reddish appearance. The aroma is complex with some molasses, orange, oak, and cherries. The flavor is primarly cherries with some raisins, grapes, oranges, and alcohol showing through. This one is more in the English mold. Excellent beer.

UPDATED: JAN 16, 2009 On tap at Capital Ale House - Innsbrook on 08/30/2008. Dark cloudy brown body with light ruby highlights and a large creamy tan head. Big caramel, rum soaked fruit and molassas aroma with a big hoppy kick. Big citrus, earthy floral hop flavor, caramel, rum soaked fruit and molassas. Full body with moderate carbonation. 8/4/8/3/17 - 4.0

08/27/2006: Very cloudy dark caramel body with a small creamy off-white head. Sweet caramel, a hint of vanilla and light hop aroma. Sweet caramel flavor, some light fruit, a touch of vanilla and a gentle floral hop ending. 8/4/8/4/17 - 4.1

Big thanks to the anon. RBer who sent this Barley Wine to me.  A very dark reddish-brown body with a thin ivory head, light syrupy pour.  Very light aroma, slightly sweet with some light malts.  Awesome taste, nice hoppy initial taste, malty backbone with some sweet fruit accents.  Sweet ending, overall very nice.

Bottle.  Poured a dark ruby amber with a minimal off-white head, a bit of chunk sediment floating throughout.  Aroma was only slightly sweet, but hinted at the potent malt body.  Hoppy upfront followed by an intense sweetness that was very rich but ended tart.  Silky and smooth on the palate.
Bottle.  Batch # 7236.  Strong caramel aroma.  Lots of hops and lots of sweet flavor.  Well balanced.

Moejuck is the man for sending me this my way. Thanks man! This is one friggin excellent beer. A delight for all the sense, I just wish it was the dead of winter so I could sip this one all night! Aroma is rum raisin bread, honey, chocolate, vanilla, brown sugar and hops. Appearance is a murky orange/brown color with minimal head. Mouthfeel is full and round. Flavors are nearly identical to the nose, but with a little more hoppyness found and nicely balanced all around. A truly excellent beer that I hope finds some noteriety.

Murky deep copper

smells a bit of pear and alcohol

hoppy bitterness fights for time with a pretty decent alcohol bite

apple maybe cranberryesque slight note of caramel.

fairly heavy mouthfeel with just the right amount of carbonation for an old ale.

would probably fair well with a year in the cellar.

I did enjoy it

A deep dark red beer with a sweet aroma. Lots of malt and very sweet,  a fruity taste, a little too sweet. Has a bitter hop finish which improves the overall taste. This is an appropiate beer for a cold winters day it wiill warm you up.

Pours deep red amber.  Thin head.  Aroma very malty; nut, caramel, toffee, hint molasses.  Smooth full mouthfeel.  Flavor is sweet caramel, tofee, dried fruith, and spice.  Finishes sweet and sticky and warm.  A very complex and interesting barleywine.  Definetely not an american style barleywine.

Poured from the bottle to a hazy rust color with suspended yeast particles. Thin off-white head lingers through mid glass and leaves good lacing. Strong malty-fruit aroma with hint of spice. Taste is mostly dark fruit and spice, but alcohol becomes more evident at mid-glass as beer warms. Finish a sweet, warming and smooth. A good barley wine.
Bottle. Pours ruby with thin off white head. Aroma is nutty, caramel, toffee, sour dough---quite complex. Taste is fruity, sour dough, caramel, vanilla. Complex.

UPDATED: JAN 23, 2010 12 oz. bottle (7124) via trade with hippie4beer - Pours a dark amber color with a light off white head that faded quickly.  Has a nice roasted caramel malt aroma with a touch of herbal hops and soap..  Flavor is sweet caramel malt with a tad bit of floral hops detected in the background.  Smooth and full bodied.  Very little alcohol warming.  A very good beer.  Thanks Seth.

Re-rate batch 9458 (about 2 months old).  Think this one needs to mellow.  Leave the numbers as is.

Picked this up on vacation through Michigan. Aroma was very nice, i like being able to smell the alcohol. Had a very nice hoppy flavor that was not citrusy at all which was good for a change. The body was a little light and the flavor seemed a little harsh at the beginning but this is really a pretty good beer.

Batch #71##: Dark murky ruby red pour with thin head. Aroma is sweet molasses with a bit of pine. Flavor is sweet in the front with a sort of pine tree sap character. Maybe a little vanilla is popping up. Cinnamon? A bit of orange rind. They could call this a Christmas Ale and I would buy in completely. Finish is well balanced with hops and is wonderfuly void of alcohol burn (at only 9%, I guess this is towards the weaker side of the Barley Wine spectrum). However, this also translates in to a somewhat thin mouthful. Id like to try an older vintage of this someday to see if the malts create more complexity.

From 12oz Bottle, Batch #6722.  Pours the color of a rubied, fiery orange sunset, topped with a thin layer of orange peel tinted cream head.  Nice lacing on the sides of my snifter glass.  Beautiful honey citrus bouquet, dripping with tangerine zest, strawberries, a light chili spice, and a touch of sprucy hops.  Im also noticing some juicy layers of peach and succulent spiced fig that leaves my mouth watering for my first sip.  Rich, lightly syrupy body and mouthfeel that opens up a flavor barrage flooding across my tongue.  What a sensual experience this is!  Rich, sticky flavors of sherried apricots, brown sugar, and orange peel quickly greets my tongue.  This wave of sweet nectar is soon followed by a second wave of blancing hop bitterness containing suggestions of white grapefruit peel, blue spruce resin, and some sticky melon rind.  The flavor residues take hold and blossom on my tongue, creating a memorable, lasting finish for this unforgettable brew.  Thanks, Tom!
Excellent smooth and captivating brew.  Oaky caramel malt overtones and soft hops with subtle spiciness even out the alcohol.  Goes down very warm and soothing.

Much thanks to Jaime at From the Vine in the Columbus, OH area for spending time on the phone with me to help prepare a list of brews for my family to pick up while on vacation. This was one of them. Very dark ruby. Small layer of off white foam doesnt hang around too long. Nose of sweet caramel/toffee malt, resinous piney hops, dark dried fruits - figs stand out, herbal anise like spice, melons, subtle smoked wood, alcohol. Beautifully complex. Flavors are the same, adding cocoa powder, a blade of grass, and hints of winter spices - like cinnamon or nutmeg, but not exactly. Full, smooth, rich body. Im very glad I got a 6 pack, 4 are going straight to the cellar.

Pours a solid maroonish brown to burgundy with the thinest of heads, looks an awful lot like a barleywine.  The nose is big sweet round malt with alcohol and relatively forward lightly floral hops.  Culminates in a sort of bubblegum/leather aroma.  The mouthfeel is smooth and bit slippery.syrupy, though not really as viscous as a barleywine really should be.  Big sweet cloying malt up front in the flavor.  Balanced by oaky and leathery flavors, alcohol, and the gentle, though assertive floral hops.  The finish is sweet yet a bit bitter with some alcohol warming.  I like this beer, I really do, but its hard for me to rate a decent barleywine as low as this!

Clear, deep red/maroon color lacking a substantial head.  Low carbonation and a smooth consistency.  It smells sweet, like creamy caramel, with good malt.  Similar flavour but with grapes, maybe some peppery spice and more bitterness (especially at the end of the sip).  Some detectable alcohol.  Its good, but its hard for me to dislike a barleywine, and I dont think it necessarily stands out in the style.
tap@ bells.  Clouded amber orange body.  nose was a light citrus sand apples.  flavours were roast and harshly bitter following a creamy feel.

Oh man. A customer brought me a 7 year old 12oz bottle of this. Opened it at a tasting the other night. Very very heavy alcohol smell...very woody and dry. Almost a mohogony color with tons of sedement floatly around. Had a very similar taste to a fine scotch. Very very dry and woody taste. Almost like a roasted cedar. Lots of caramel with a tad of sweetness. Wish i had more..and wish i didnt save this one for last. By far one of the best beers ive ever had. Glad i didnt have to save this one for 7yrs though It would have never made it.

UPDATED: MAY 10, 2007 Tasted at bewery pub---and bought a case. Loved this brew during the first 6 bottles, then I cut the rest 50% with "lawn mower" beer. The malt sweetness and alcohol were overpowering! Little hops. This is a quality barley wine designed for slooow sipping, but its not refreshing or suitable with food. Its a dessert, rather than a beverage. I wont buy this again. However, I continue to love Bells two Hearted Ale and dont fault Bells for this brew.

Pours a cloudy golden brown color with a small head and lots of sticky lacing.  ARoma is a little roasty/warm with definite nut hints.  Certainly a mouthful, coats the tongue and slightly over-powers the flavor.  Still a very enjoyable beer though.  Have another bottle and will re-rate!
From bottle.  Pours a cloudy deep brown with frothy tan head.  Huge caramel malt nose with brown sugar.  Flavor is a bitter version of nose.
UPDATED: SEP 8, 2006 Pours brown/orange, no head. Extremely aromatic. Full of sweet, spicy, dark fruits, a bit of plum and notes of hops. A bit of bitter caramel. Excellent beer!

Poured a dark brown-orangish color with a very thin head that didnt lace great. Lots of sedimentation. The aroma was hoppy and malty (hard to discern). The flavor was mostly hops with an underlying maltiness of caramel. Finishes hoppy (resinous and pine-like). Mouthfeel is heavy.

12 oz bottle via trade with Pailhead.Cloudy dark brown with a brown head. Plenty of floaties. Rich, malty nose, toffee, caramel. Much more bitter than expected, spicy dark fruit flavors. Wow! Thanks Kevin!

UPDATED: AUG 4, 2010 Bottle thanks to jimbowood.  Poured into a Corsendonk tulip glass.  Pours dark copper with almost no carbonation.  Aroma is plum/raisin barleywine sweetness with a malt background.  Very present but not over the top.  Taste is barleywine sweet with a good bit of bitterness.  Has a great mouthfeel.  Just the perfect combination of syrupy yet delicateness.  Leaves a hoppy aftertaste.  I got another bottle which Ill age for a few years and then compare the ratings. 7/4/8/4/1612 oz bottle, batch 7124, bottled on November 14, 2005, which makes this about 5.5 years old, need to clear out the cellar.  This beer has been through a lot of moves, some good storage and some not so good.  Bottle poured into a Melbourne Bros glass, poured straight down to create a medium sized head.  Aroma is raisin and tap water, not watery but literally smells like raisin mixed with NYC tap water.  Its alcoholic raisin of course.  Flavor is surprisingly light, not thick malts, not syruppy, just light alcohol raisin with a light palate.  easy to drink for a barleywine and absolutely no oxidation yet.  This is surprising and the beer gets a bit of a lift for being so age-able.
user_location: HdG (past: NYC, KS, Rain City), Maryland, USA

text: 12 oz bottle, back label with no batch number.  Pours a deer copper, almost ruby colored body with a thin whispy off-white head.  Moderate sediment in bottle.  Very rich aroma with heavy toffee and caramel maltiness, moderate alcohol, and rather vinous with candied dark fruits and figs.  Flavor is pretty intense with some sherry-like oxidation creeping in backed by caramel maltiness and moderate alcohol.  Finish is very warming.  Mouthfeel is full bodied, but alot of the stickyness is gone versus the fresher batches leaving a rather dry finish.  Very soft fine carbonation.  Overall, one of my favorite beers to age.  This held up very well provided you like a little bit of oxidation.  The carbonation in particular was especially well preserved.
Had this one on one of my pilgramages to the brewery. Very good Barley Wine style ale. Extremely fruity flavor, plum I think, theres alot goin on in this beer, you must drink it to believe it.
Just an explosion of fruit.  Banana, bubblegum, spices.  A HUGE beer with alot of power.  Tremendously complex.  Bravo Bells.

Bottle, from CharlesDarwin.  Holy crap, theres a lot of  stuff  suspended in this.  I wasnt really ready for that.  Well, at least theyre particles and not globules.  Smells like most other barley wines, very astringent nose, some hops, oakiness, lots of malt.  Very well balanced in the mouth.  Its a strong one, and it lets you know it.  Lots of everything in there  hops, bourbon, malt, vanilla, oak.  I even sensed a little bit of the kitchen sink.  Finishes sharp and bitter with a touch of malt and vanilla.  Very good.  Thanks, Tom!

Blind rating.  Pours copper with virtually no head.  Aroma is floral, perfumey hops, caramel malt (cookie) and maple notes.  Heavily hopped, bitter and acidic drying flavor, maple and caremel malt , burning alcohol (isopropyl) finish.  Medium bodied and smooth palate.

Beer pours a hazy medium amber with a small, off-white, mostly and almost-immedately diminishing head. Right up front Ill  say Ill have to revisit this one again if I have the chance. The aroma is malty with moderate sweet notes of toasted grain, cookie and caramel; hoppy with moderate notes of herbs. light notes of resin/pine; yeasty with light notes of dough; miscellaneous notes heavy sherry/cardboard, moderate notes of raisin, tea and warm alcohol. The flavor is heavily sweet, lightly dry/bitter with a long, moderately bitter and warm finish. The body is medium, the texture is watery-to-velvety and the carbonation is average.

Bottled, thanks heemer77. Dark reddish brown colour (muddy red), mediumsized brown foamy head. Pleasant aroma of plum with redwineish attributes, also a sting of alcohol. Flavour is Plummy, roasted malts, some fruits and berries and dark sugar are atleast present in the flavour. Creamy and smooth palate. Aftertaste of dark bread (malax limpa, which is a quite locally produced thing). Totally mindblowing barley wine! Hides ABV very well, though it is a bit noteable. Lovely!

Bottled 
Murky brown, good firm expresso head. Aroma of whisky barrel and licorice. Full-bodied. Salty, loads of licorice, hints of vanilla and toffee caramel. Loads of dark coffee and roasted malts. Hoppy bitterness in the aftertaste. Delicious barley wine, propably ages quite nicely.

Poured a murky red, with little head, mild alcohol taste, nothing overwhelming, I think the alcohol is perfect in this one! Fruity, dark fruits, hopped well enough too. A slight dark sugar taste, very nice flavor! Thanks to Duane for this wonderful brew!
12oz bottle.  Hazy, dark red "velvet" hue.  Bone white head.  Anise and raisiny, plum nose.  Creamy caramel and lingering cloying sticky malt flavor.
much better than the third coast ale, dark brown, great caramel malt balance with enough hops for a great taste

Bottle (thanks to Hogtownharry for this one): Poured a murky brown color ale with a medium foamy brown head with great retention. Aroma of sweet caramel malt and light bitter hops is very well balance. Taste is a mixture between dry figs, sweet caramel malt with a nice hops finish that is more subtle then what I was expecting based on some previous rating. Body is full and it seems like the beer had not been filtered, which is always a big plus. Alcohol was well hidden. Overall, this is probably one of the finest American barleywine that I have had the chance to try.

Acquired in a trade from jimbowood batch 7124.  Holy cow this stuff is awsome.  Has a sweet bit hoppy aroma, kinda caramelish.  Very silky body.  Has a bit of a roast taste to it, dry aftertaste, sweet taste.  This brew is all you would need as a reason to move to kalamazoo michigan.

(03.21.06) 12 oz brown bottle from DiCarlos, Mundelein, IL. Batch no. 7124. Pours clear amber with small white head. Soft carbonation. Caramel in the nose. Full bodied barleywine that starts with moderate malt sweetness and caramel/toffee flavors. Finishes with lingering hop bitterness and malt fade. More bittering hops than flavoring hops. Smooth and rich-tasting.   Well-balanced with a strong malt foundation to support the bittering hop.  Definite alcoholic warmth.  This is an excellent malty ale that is best served after a meal or as a night cap.

Thanks Sliffy.  Nice cross between a malty English and a hoppy American barley wine.  Has a nice brown sugar and dried fruit maltiness, balanced by a juicy hoppiness.  Strawberry and pine.  Thick and buttery up front, but a bit watery in the back.  The bitterness does hold the back end up well enough, though.  Nice interpretation of a barley wine.

bottle. mahogany coloured body with a small bubbly white head. beautiful aroma of chocolate malt, caramel, sweet yeasty hops, and some fruit. sweet caramel flavours along notes of dark chocolate. full body. alcohol is present throughout but is well balanced by the big sticky malts and English-style hops. Thanks for sharing yet another very good BW, Len.

Poured a bright red amber with a small, but lingering antique lace colored head.  Aroma is malt with a faint dry wine note.  Taste is vinous with notes of maple syrup, butter, and cherries.  An excellent brew for the barleywine category, though a little pricey.

Bottle courtesy of Styles. Thanks man! Dark mahogony pour dusted with a thin layer of tiny mocha bubbles. Candied and sugared malts in the nose, with brown sugar, milk chocolate, and mild hops. Very sweet toffee and candied fruits. Brown sugars, cherries, and woody apples. Nice! Warming finish with good lingering hops bite. I liked it! Thanks Chris!
Bottle.  2006 version is pure caramel malt.  No discernable hop flavor.  Excellent beer.  Really roasty and warming.

UPDATED: SEP 18, 2006 weak pour, little head but nice color.  aroma is strong, but not as appetizing as other barleywines ive had.  wonderful taste, though the sip is a little loaded early on, dynamically.  by which i meant the taste comes on strong and fast (a bit too strong perhaps initially) but then mellows out to a perfect barleywine flavor.  carmelly, nutty, and warm (alcoholish).  perfect for a fall evening.  smooth and terrific mouthfeel.  2nd best barleywine ive had... and probably my favorite Bells beer from the bottle (theyre often metallic) (and i havent had expedition in ages).

Bottled.  pours a murky brown color with a buttery yellowish colored head.  Aroma of dark fruits and brown sugar.   Extremely thick mouth feel. Caramel and dark fruit flavors with some honey and tobacco notes.  Bitter finish.

This beer offer the nostrils the smell of cooked dates that is similar to the smell of homemade fruit cake.  This beer fills the glass with a sediment filled copper solution that produces a small off-white head.  This heavy beer spreads smoothly through the mouth depositing a rich flavor of caramel, barley, and dates on the palate.  This beer fades from the mouth with a taste that mildly resembles cashews.  The aftertaste lingers well after beer has been swallowed.
Syrupy in looks...apples and raisins in flavor. Light head, but bursting with all sorts of caramel and raisins dangit!

The pink label on the bottle made me think this might have a cherry flavor.  Opened the bottle, poured, and...guess what...cherry fruit is what I detected.  Small ring of head, typical for the style.  Very good flavor, I love the way the fruit, malt, and hops combine together to give this a very well balanced flavor.  Excellent beer!

Pours a hazy copper/brown color with an off-white head. A sweet, caramel and dark fruit aroma fills the nose, though not as strong as I wouldve expected. Caramel malt,  dark fruits, and alcohol come out in the flavor and all of them seem fairly well-balanced between one another. Definetly full bodied and super malty and sweet, a bit chewy at times with a juicy, sugary yet subtle alcohol burn on the finish. A very drinkable, rich, warming winter offering.

Aged 1 year old bottle - Deep turbid coppery brown, creamy light tan head.  Rich and complex nose of pineapple, musty caramel, mango, molasses, brown sugar, and faint hints of coconut.  Flavor is practically mirrored with lots of caramel and tropical fruit leading the charge.  Light boozy notes and faded hop tones keep the loads of sweet malt well in check.  Full bodied, soft carbonation, bittersweet finish.  A great winter time sipper...

Pours clear, dark copper with lots of tiny bits floating throughout. Thin copper/beige head diminishes quickly with little lacing. Aroma is dried fruits, carmel, honey, cookie, alcohol. Flavor initially follows aroma, then finishes with a nice hoppy bitterness, a little warmth from the alcohol and just enough carbonation to cleanse the pallette. Mouthfeel is thick and syrupy but the subtle carbonation cuts through just fine.
I dont have a lot of experience with barleywine but, I do like this one...a lot. Delicious.
"Poured a dark brown with a thin head that didnt leave much lacing. Tons of sedimentation. Aroma was of hops. The flavor dominated by hops with some sweet malts. Good beer. "
Batch 6722 Pours a transperent dark  reddish brown. Aromas fulll of carmel fig brown surgar. Flavor was lighly sweet with carmel malt a dough bread and brown surgar flavor with some alc warming.

2003 edition. Fairly transparent brownish-red pour with average foam head offfers a rich nose of sugars, licorice and citric hop finish. Palate is silk but not overwhelming. Flavor is caramel, some plum, and then an oaky resinous hop-infused smile-inducing finish. Deep and luxurious, this is dangerously drinkable and, as a good barleywine, matures well.

Mostly clear, dark red colour with barely any head. Despite being pretty sweet and malty, this is dominated by resiny hops. There is a lot of character, with what I beleive is fig, and caramel or brown sugar. Ive got five more to age, and will look forward to rating them with age. As a young beer, Ill pass despite the complexity.

Bottle 2003 vintage.  Pours a clear mahogany brown, with a light tan thick and creamy head.   Thick and blocky lacing.  Wonderfull aromas of brown sugar, over-ripe apples, figs, dark pitted fruits and caramel.   Dont detect much hops here yet.  possibly due to a couple years of aging.   Flavor is similar.  Imediate aftertaste is  a bit fumey, the ABV hits you a bit but dissipates quickly.   very soft carbonation and a smooth soft and fairly heavy feel.  Very littel bittering on the trailer.  One of my favorite BWs.  Thanks to Styles This great one!

Pours a dark amber color with a thin off-white head.  Aroma is of malts and a hint of fruit.  A slight fruit and malty flavor with a finish of alcohol.  This was my first barley wine and a very good one at that.

UPDATED: SEP 20, 2006 2003 batch on draft at Dilly Deli in Cincinnati. Aroma of malt, dried fruit, and alcohol. Flavor is bitter,  balanced by sweet malt and brown sugar. Nice bitter and warming finish, slightly boozy. Overall, a very strong but easy to drink barleywine. I real treat. I have a bottle that I need rate next. 6-19-06. Batch 6722. Bottle pours a murky or muddy brown, almost no head. Very light carbonation, much less than the draft sample.  I think I prefer the draft sample, because it had more hops to balance the sweetness and more carbonation...basically the draft was more balanced.
Wondderfully smelling beer.  Its been a while since Ive had a good barley wine, but this one qualifies.  Sweet with no bitter aftertaste.  Yummy.
Bottle.  Amber/light brown in color.  Floral aroma.  Pretty good flavor.  Lots of floaties in the brew.

UPDATED: FEB 19, 2006 Think there could have been something wrong with this bottle I picked up...not lightstruck but maybe a slight infection....or maybe this is what it is.  It smelled like copper and sweet sweaty raisins.  It looks like apple cider and had a mid sized head when poured vigorously.  Probably has the most yeast funk Ive scene...maybe more than HoD Fred.  The taste was pretty good....  Lots of malt , sweetness, and no alcohol....With a bit of a dry bitter aftertaste.  Mouthfeel is grainy and warm.  Not quite sure if Im about to get sick from this beer.  Ill try another bottle later, but for now Im going to low ball it. 
***RERATE
That bottle was very old (pre batch# and neck label) and may not have been handled well.  I had this bad ass on tap at a barley wine fest the other day...it was incredible...

Had on tap at the Dilly Deli, aged two years at Bells.  Dark orange in color with a small amount of head. Aroma of malts, fruit and alcohol. Tastes of fruity sweetness, carmel, malt, alcohol and the taste lingers for quite some time.  A complex taste that is amazing as well as a great texture. Get a bottle and forget about it for a year or two, you wont regret it.

I love the state of Michigan for many reasons. From its beautiful lakes, its fertile farm lands, to the Motor City. Those are all good reasons to want to visit MI, but as a beer lover, there are about 70 more. Michigan is teeming with brewpubs and breweries, the beer hunting grounds are happy. One brewery in particular, makes this beer lover extremely happy, and that is the Kalamazoo Brewing Company, of Kalamazoo, MI. The owner is a man named Larry Bell, and to us beer lovers, he and his Bells beers, need no introduction. The Kalamazoo Brewing Company has a reputation of being one of the finest micro breweries in the US, and it is personally one of my, if not, my all time favorite brewery. I have visited the Eccentric Cafe, the brewpub attached to the brewery, and toured the brewery on several occasions. One of my favorites(they all are, they dont brew a beer I do not love) is Third Coast Old Ale.

Third Coast Old Ale is a barley wine by style, and it is an outstanding, authentic example. This style of beer is a rich, strong, warming ale, that was called barley wine because its alcoholic strength approached the threshold of wine. This beer is rich and malty, with a big, warming, high octane finish, Third Coast weighs in at over 10% abv. This beer pours to a beautiful, opaque caramel color with a slight tan head, and virtually no carbonation. The nose on this beer is incredible. Waves of malt aromas flood the nose. Sweet malt, caramel, butter scotch, toffee, and "fresh bread" malt aromas marry with peppery hints of alcohol. The palate is HUGE, rich and complex. Layers of malt flavors coat the tongue. Sweet malt, toffee, vanilla, fresh bread, and more butter scotch malt flavors. This is a big, hefty brew, the mouth feel is very viscous, syrup like. This beer finishes with more big malt flavor, and a long, warming, high octane burn. Hops are in this beer just to balance, but young, this beer is a bit cloying. 

I suggest that you let this beer age a year or two if you find the sweetness a bit too much. Barley wine is one of the few beer styles that will improve with age. This is a sipping brew, it should be enjoyed as a night cap, or as a beer to sip and savor by a snug fire. This beer is perfect on a cold fall eve, and great in the winter months as a winter warmer as well. I really wouldnt pair this with food, but if you had to, it would be desert. I would match this with creme brulee, or fruit cake.

UPDATED: AUG 15, 2006 Bottle shared with HogTownHarry, GregClow, tupalev, Dave B. and R. -- courtesy of Dave B. Pours a very hazy dark orange with a small off-white head. Very nice sweet aroma of hops, caramel malt, brown sugar, lots of fruit and alcohol. Flavour, also quite sweet, starts with caramel malt, brown sugar, fruit and alcohol and finishes with a nice hoppy bitterness. Medium bodied. Complex and well balanced, this is a very good Barley Wine.

12 oz bottle.  Hazy burgundy-garnet with a thick white head.  Sweet malty aroma, figs and plummy fruit, some toffee.  Nice spicy/earthy hop aroma.  Aroma is very fresh.  Flavour shows great complexity, sweet chewy malts, plum/prune/cherry, a hint of tartness and an unusual resiny texture.  Long, lingering bitter finish.  As it warms some more fruit and woodiness come out.  Cherry and a bit of white grape flavour as well.  Flavour shows terrific balance, great texture and an absolutely delicious brew.

Bottle (12oz).  Shared with blankboy, GregClow, tupalev, Dave B and R - courtesy of Dave B.  Poured hazy deep orange with a small off-white head.  Aroma of funky yeast, almost like wet wool, acidic hardwood malt, alcohol, and a hint of sour milk.  Lovely taste - pretty well balanced (could use a couple of years aging, but still ...) with orange juice and orange rind, alcohol bitterness, woody malt - pretty complex, better as it warms up, quite complex if a bit alcohol-burn-y.  Hard to believe its only 9% - not quite up to the North Coast Old Stock Ale, but in the ballpark.

2004 bottle - Deep amber with a small off white head.  Aroma of sweet malt and tons of fruit...cherry, raisins.  Flavor is same as aroma.  Decent bit of hotness. Very very good.  Soft mouthfeel.  Coffee and maybe some chocolate as well.

UPDATED: JAN 19, 2006 pours dark amber with an off white head. aroma of deep roasted malt plum dried fruit and nuts. extreamly well balanced sweet malt and bitter hops on the front with a nice hoppy finish. pleasant alcohol presence throughout. great beer.

Cloudy burnt orange/brown in color.... nice head, nice lace.... taste was very defined.
Extream hop, Extream Malt, Extream Taste... definately not a bland barley wine...
Hazy brown with an off white head.  Very floral aroma.  Coats the tongue with a nice mix of hops and malts.  Very smooth.  Another good beer from the Bell family.

Hazy brown ale with floaties. Honey and sweet malt aroma with light hoppyness. Sweet earthy malt with sharp hops, molasses,  and alcohol warmth. Rich and thick and oily. May 2005, Capflus BW tasting.

A pleasant aroma of caramel malt, molasses, and some alcohol.  The color is deep rich brownish oarnge with a long lasting tan head and lacing.  A full flavor of caramel malt, dark fruit, and a full bodied finish on the palate.

Bottle.  Pours a deep dark orange color, almost brown with a thin tan head that lingers.  Aroma is mildly sweet with notes of burnt caramel, molassess, and slight alcohol.  Flavor is tart at first with dark fruits; possibly cherries with toasty malts and an alcohol consistancy throughout.  Chewy palate that finishes smoothly.

Pours dark brown with a fully receding white head.  Aroma of molasses, smokey caramel, and dusty yeast.  Taste is dark toasted malts, toffee, and sweet caramel. Mouthfeel is heavy with medium carbonation.  Didnt care for this too much, perhaps the bottle needed more time.

12 oz bottle, batch 6722.  Miy first barely wine.  Poured a light brown with a very small off white head, very hazy with medium particles floating about.  This has a very complex aroma with Caramel, some citrus, prunes, a deep dry red wine and alcohol.  Taste was just as complex with a slight alcohol beginning, prunes, dark ruby port, some toffee. spices and the english yeast flavor, for some reason I thought of a younger congac.  Finish had a slight hop bittness and some alocohol.  Overall very pleased with this and will have to explore more barley Wines.

sweet fruit and alcohol on the nose. You can tell youre about to have some barley wine. Very little head, dark copper tint. Hard for me to describe the flavor, tart, alcohol, roasty-goodness. Lingers on the palate. Well balanced. I like other bells better, but this is a damn nice barley-wine. Better than doggie claws in my opinion.

This has a sweet aroma, and pours an opaque oragney-amber-brown color, with a small head that disappears quickly.  Flavor is complex, tastes malty, sweet, syrupy.  Has an average mouth feel for its style, low carbonation.  Overall this is a nice barley wine style ale, and one of my favorite Bells.  I buy these as single bottles from Whole Foods for about $3 and I think its a great deal.

Fresh batch, 7124. Pours a deep dark brick red, little head initially, after a minute or so, there is nothing. Great color. Aroma is alcohol, herbal hops, and plums, maybe some woodiness. Hard to get any more descriptive than that since the alcohol is pretty dominant. Taste is a huge thick blast or caramel malts, rather sweet, blended with dark fruits of cherries and raisins, some vanilla here and there, and finishes somewhat bitter with the herbal hops sucking the tongue of all its moisture. This is a good beer, but when I look back at it, all I rememeber is the initial sweetness, the ending bitterness, and the constant nature of alcohol burn. So, I guess what I am asking for is a bit more complexity to be better satisfied.

UPDATED: JUN 20, 2007 Thanks to secret santa.  Pours a somewhat hazy deep amber red.  Very thin lasting head and some lace.  Somewhat sweet aroma with lots of toasted and caramel malts.  Also noticed some caramel/nutty munich malt.  Flavor is malty, almost wine-like with a light acidity and some alcohol has it warms.  More caramel and fruity flavors develop as it warms.  Moderately bitter in the end.  Nice smooth mouthfeel and long finish.

Im a big barley wine fan, and had been looking foward to getting my hands on this one. This was probably just different than what Im used to. It had a big malty character at first, followed by a somewhat subtle bitter finish from the hops. I probably need to have a couple more of these to get a better appreciation for it.

Tart aroma with a heavy caramel compliment. Some herbal, earthy hops. Earthy brown in color, hazy with suspended, still chunks. Moderate, firm head. Sweet, tart, dark caramel flavor with some multi vitamin. Lingering bitter finish. The last time I had this I enjoyed it more. Perhaps this bottle was mishandled.

12oz bottle. Dirty brown in color with some "floaties" seen in the glass. Aromas of malts, cherries, sweet chocolate. Taste is cherry, plum, but to much alcohol coming through leaving it unbalanced. But it is nicely hopped. Full bodied, with a sour bite in the finish, and smooth textured. A decent barley wine.

12 oz bottle thanks to kramer17801.   Murky brown pour with a great head that left great lacing.  Wonderful aromas of dark cherry and currant.  Malty flavors with a very nice hop bite on the finish.   Pretty tasty stuff.

Bottle courtesy of CharlesDarwin.  No Batch ID #.  Label is slightly different than that in the picture.  A muddy brown pour with some floaties and a thin British khaki head.  Lots of rich caramel in the aroma along with some plums, raisins, soy sauce and malts.  Full-bodied and smooth.  Chocolate, caramel and cocoa flavors dominate.  Some oakiness and vanilla are present too.  A fairly dry, hoppy finish.

12oz bottle - Batch #6722 - Pours cloudy amber with a short tan head that stays very well and laces the snifter very well all the way down. Aroma is caramel, plum, alcohol, and some candied sugar.  Flavor is caramel, candied sugar, some vanilla, a bit of oak. Palate is quite smooth and amazingly drinkable for a beer of this size.  The alcohol while found in the aroma was not found in the flavor at all.  This is a great winter warmer and another fantastic brew by Kalamazoo!

12oz bottle -  pours a very murky,  cloudy, dark  brown color with a short but long lasting tan head. The lacing was impressive for such a small head. The aroma is strong with lots of alcohol and malt up front. There are nuances of caramel, chocolate, sugar and roasted nuts. The flavor is full bodied, rich, alcoholic and bitter. There are nuances of caramel, oak and coffee. Mouthfeel is full, rich and alcoholic. For me this is far too bitter and far to alcoholic. I had to struggle to finish this one. Not doubt a well crafted beer for the style.

Aroma of light sweet fermented caramel malt. Dark amber body with little head that disaplated quickly. Flavor has an alcohol presence though out the beer. As beer warms the sweet caramel notes come in to play. The palate thought this was a higher alcohol content without looking first. Beer warms the body

Pours an amber brown color with almost no head at all.  Unfiltered, looks like grain alcohol almost.  Lots of hops floating around.  Aroma has caramel,brown sugar, molasses,figs, cherries and raisons in it.  Taste is very sweet, almost syrupy, yet not too sweet.  Dark fruit, caramel, molasses and cherries are prominant in flavor.  Excellent beer.

Pours a murky reddish-brown with a small layer of brown foam.   Heavy aroma of caramel and molasses mixed with raisins and dark cherries.  Huge body - thick and silky mouth feel.  Sweet and complex, with caramel and orange amongst a myriad of dark fruit flavors.  The mild hops from the nose shows up in the finish, drying out the sweetness slightly.  A beautiful barley wine.

Strong aroma of malts and molasses and alcohol with hints of raisins and caramel. Heavy body with an almost syrupy mouthfeel. Flavor is filled with sweet fruits, molasses, figs,  alcohol with a slightly bitter hop aftertaste. The pour was dark copper. cloudy with sediment afloat. No head, but off-white rim.

UPDATED: OCT 16, 2007 Deep reddish-brown pour with very little head and lots of chunky sediment suspended in there.  There was a whole lot going on in the aroma.. dark berry sweetness, figs, tobacco, alcohol, soy...  Carbonation was low, but just right.  This was just heaven on the palate... full and smooth, with the wonderful, complex flavors just rolling across the tastebuds... flavors that followed the aroma quite well.  Somewhat bitter toward the finish, with some alcohol flavor and warmth on the finish.  I gotta pick up some of these for consumption on those cold winter days coming up.. by the fireplace...  2000 bottle thanks to Blake!  The aroma picked up deep caramel, some chocolate, and darker fruity notes.. dry yeasty notes as well.  The flavor began with deep, aged caramel, and carried it through the finish.. dry, dusty yeast and oxidation notes pick up about halfway and also carry through the finish.  Felt great upfront, but lost a bit on the latter half.. bit too grainy at the end.  Thanks Blake!

Cloudy amber brown liquid with a bit of suspended sediment. Faint head. Rich sweet malt aroma with bits of vinous alcohol and soy. Assertive hop flavor that was not present in aroma is accompanied by sweet malt, fruit notes and some dry roast. Slightly oily palate. Good complex barleywine, if a bit on the dry side.
heeavy and rich.  Beautiful color with practically no head.  Flavor was a nice rich  malt and alchol.  Probably a little to heavy but nice none the less
bottle.  Pours golden amber color.  rich fruity, malty aroma.  complex flavors of malt and hops.  slight alcohol aftertaste.
Bottle. Red brown colour with a small baige head. Fruity, caramel malty aroma and a light sweet caramel malty, hoppy taste. Medium body and a light sweet light alcoholic finish.

Hazy red-amberish colored beer with small yellowish head leaving a nice lacing. This beer has rich aromas with an elegant refreshing caracter. It has complex touches of caramel, Orangettes, ripe stone fruits, tuttie fruttie, Picon au vin blanc, dry figgs, dates, forest honey, pine needles, hops, sunflower pits, fresh corn on the BBQ and fresh dried céréals. The taste is round and smooth. It is sweet, fruity, mellow, has some earthy tones (chesnuts) and a nice bitterish unthertone that is well integrated in this brew. I notised some hints of caramelized edges of a fruit cake, Baba au Rhum, Bowmore Bordeaux cask Whisky, loads of nuts and ripe stone fruits. It has a fine and complex hoppy soft-bitterness to end with. Thanks a lot Philip for this most original beer.

Red-amber beer, hazy; cream-ochre, creamy head, some lace.  Pine branches, covered with hop vines and various fruit and nuts dangling from it. If nobody had invented X-mas ale before, THIS is it. Apricot, sweet cherry, confited oranges, etc. Do bitter cakes exist? If not, here they are, in liquid form. I get some caramel, I get cookie malts, but all of it is covered in a hoppy icing, and then softly caramelised in the oven. Rich, well-filled, slick, nearly chewy MF. I WANT this! Ill drink this this Christmas until oblivion.Thanks for bringing this along Lachesis - great.

UPDATED: APR 13, 2008 Pours deep dark amber with mostly diminishing head.  Aroma is of sweet malts, nuts, and slightly of alcohol.  Flavor is sweet and nutty, finish is long with citrusy bitterness. A lot going on, quite complex. Mouthfeel is soft and smooth.

UPDATED: SEP 2, 2007 Bottled.
Cloudy orange brown coloured with an off white head.
Sweet aroma of dried fruits, caramel and hops.
Flavour of fruits, caramel, dried fruits and hops.
Bottled. Pours a dark nut brown, with a small head. Aroma is sweet, prunes, alcohol, dark fruits. Taste is sweet, rasins/prunes. Some alcohol burning. A really nice barley wine

haha, my notes, start out saying "smells good. cherries and stuff.  sour and mean."   really this had some sour cherries and other dark fruits, like plums and blackberries.  it was sour on the finish, and left a dr. pepper like aftertaste.  very unique and appreciable.

UPDATED: JUL 29, 2007 #700 Hazy orange brown color.  Spiderweb of film for the head.  Deep rich aroma.  Plenty of sediment in the glass.  Massive malt with a kick of hops.  Enjoyable stuff. 8/3/8/4/16 

RERATE: 12oz bottle aged about a year.  Aroma is quite potent.  A good amount of alcohol but it cannot hide the massive malt and hop presence.  This is a very classic example of an American barley wine.  The malt is huge and well formed, caramel, candi sweetness.  Hops are still present and still biting in the finish. Quality... but Im not excited by it. 7/3/7/4/17

UPDATED: JAN 31, 2006 12oz - pre batch number - thanks pailhead - Aroma is carmel, plum, oak, and a touch of hops.  Pours a cloudy brown with a very small head and good lacing.  Flavor is sweet  chewy carmel, oak, bown sugar and plum.  Palate is creamy and smooth.  A different tasting barleywine, but one of my favorites.

Thin, white head.  Murky brown-red hue.  Brown sugar, plums, cranberries (can), caramel and treacle aromas.  Heavily sweet, lightly acidic flavor.  Heavily sweet, lightly bitter finish.  Medium-full body, oily texture, soft carbonation.

Large very dense head of fine bubbles.  Light beige in color. Thick and creamy on top.  Good carbonation for a barleywine.  Rich caramel and malt aroma.  Toffee, brown sugar and very rich.  Color is a murky dark brown with a bunch of floaters that I did not see and poured into my glass.  BOO HOO!  Thick, rich, malty, hoppy, alcoholic and delicious.  Exactly as a fine Barleywine should be.  More toffee, brown sugar and a big hops presence.  Thick and coating.  Nice alcohol warming but it is still a little hot.  Finish is slick and slightly dry and bitter.  A very good barleywine.  Hits all the marks and then some.  Thanks to Eyedrinkale for this one!

Bottle 2003 Vintage. Still needs some time to even out even after a few years. The caramel/toffee/brown sugar are there, the orange peel (which reminds me of Grand Marnier on the nose) is also present. But the hops bite still hasnt tempered enough so that the richness of the body and flavours come shining through. Unfortunately, this was from the oldest Third Coast Old Ale six-pack I had in the cellar, so Ill rerate in in about 1.5 years.

Pours a thick, dark, orange/brown color body with a tan head that disappears quickly.  Malty nose with a little sweet chocolate.  Flavors are huge carmel malts, chocolate covered cherries, and raisins, with a molasses finish and subtle alcohol taste.  Full bodied with a smooth finish.  I wasnt in a barleywine mood when I grabbed this but for some reason, I still did.  I definately glad I did!

Poured a chestnutty brown, a bit hazy, with a fair head that faded fast with little lacing.  Aromas were malt, bread, caramel, alcohol, some dark fruit and cherry, earth, wet meadow, chocolate and coffee.  Absolute spectacular, chewy malt taste -- chocolate, smoke, cherry, moist tobacco, bourbon, scotch, coffee, caramel, toffee, molasses, brown sugar, barley and tempered hops.  Moderately bitter finish.  Mouthfeel like velvet, thick and chewy, leaving lots of flavor behind.  This had a spectacular roasted malt flavor!  Bravo!  Kalamazoo has yet to let me down.

Did not relize that I was opening my first blarley wine ever.  If others or similar I might be a new fan.  The strong alchol blends well with a little sweetness and hops.  The 9% alcohol really gave me a kick.

Full, reddish brown color with a tan head that was gone very soon after the pour -- thankis to the alcohol, no doubt.  From the aroma, it seems like its underhopped, and upon tasting it, I find Im right.  A fair barleywine, but slightly unbalanced and unintersting.  Bells has much better to offer.

dark cloudy rusty brown color with a thin foamy tan head that goes away real quickly.  sweet malty aroma and quite like a Manhattan - sweet vermouth, blended Canadian whiskey, and faint marascino cherry aromas.  wow how unexpected was that!  flavor is deeep sweet malt but not syrupy like so many other barley wines.  hoppiness approaches in the middle.  lots of microfloaties in the body.  some alcohol flavors - a little bourbon, a little whiskey.  very smooth barley wine, nothing hurts!  aftertaste is pretty hoppy with a peaty scotch punch.  thanks Beeryum and Secret Santa 1FastSti for this one!!

Thanks to Pailhead for this. I opened it before I knew it was a Barley Wine or I would have saved it. Sweet malty caramel aroma. Very intense aroma. Cloudy reddish brown with a fairly thick head for a barley wine. Thick and full. Huge malt flavor. One of the maltier beers I have ever tasted. Mashed fruit and vegetable flavors as well. Noticeable alcohol. Creamy moutfeel.

Malty thickness with a sweet tinge that burned of alcohol, not a wimpy beer. 
Too much for me to drink alot of it- but it was a good thing to try.

Bottle, 05.  Dark brown pour.  Huge sweet caramel malt aroma.  Flavor was complex - lots of sweet caramel malts, candied dark fruits, raisins, peppery alcohol, lots of woodish hops.  Medium thick, good body and carbonation.
Pours a dark brown color with little head.  Smells of caramel malt.  Tastes of malt, bit of chocolate, caramel, mild hops.  Very sweet and syrupy.  Decent.

Wow, didnt realize you had cellared this one jerc, thanks for sharing.  Dark brown, big tan head.  Lots of sediment, looks like a snowglobe!  Big strong bready caramel sundae aroma - sweet (figuratively and as a randomly yelled adjective).  Chewy mouthfeel.  Strong hops in taste, combined with an alcohol and caramel mix - lovely.  Sweeter and hoppier than my recent sampling of North Coast Old Stock Ale but maybe not quite as balanced (taking nothing away from either fantastic beer, I just found them similar).  Very very good.

UPDATED: AUG 31, 2012 Bottle cellared for a year, courtesy of Obisbeer. Dark ruby amber with a gorgeous tan head. Sweet malty aroma wi a brown sugar undercurrent. Simplisticly luxurious. Flavour has a dryness throught but the sweet malty middle is the star of the show. Hops are pleasant accents. Medium to full bodied. Lingering warmth and malty aftertaste.  Am regretting not having cracked this one open earlier so I would have known to get more!!! 
2012-08-18. Very dark brown, fruity, oxidized. Sweet fruiy malt. Old. Bottle,Batch 7124 Campground Brewdown 2012 shared by puzzl

Bottle shared with jerc and tupalev - courtesy of jerc. Dark mahogany colour with a small tan head and lots of floaties. Aroma of whisky-soaked cherries dipped in caramel, with some chocolate and dates/figs in there as well. Rich, warming mouthfeel. Flavour starts quite sweet, with brown sugar and fruit, turns roasty in the middle, and finishes with dry citric hops. Damn good!

UPDATED: MAR 18, 2006 Pours cloudy amber with zero head.  I dont know what happened.  I just started getting really excited with Bells and then I tried this one.  Dont get me wrong, its not bad, but its a major disappointment.  I think I may have gotten a light exposed one.  Has an apple/pear aroma and flavor.  Nothing like any barleywine ive had and reminds a lot of the skunky Pride and Joy i had.  However, this one might supposed to taste like that.  Its not an overpowering grossness.  It as has a caramelly sweetness taste, too.  
Rerate.  A lot better.  I think the first one was light struck.  This reminds me a lot of Avery Hog Heaven.  Very malty but a fair balance of hops.   The aroma has some noticeable alcohol but not in the flavor.

UPDATED: JUL 16, 2005 Dark amber color with a light beige head. Aroma is rich and fruity. Flavor is very rich, fruity with some citrus, cherry and  touch of honey. Middle is lightly bitter balanced by the honey and the finish has dry citrus rind aftertaste. Rich smooth palate.

Blue Max Liquors, Burnsville, Mn - 12 oz bottle. Pours a dark auburn with specks of sediment floating about in lazy circles. Sweet, molasses aroma with hints of fresh grapes, raisins and dates. Some chocolate in there as well. Flavor is like a fruit salad with a menagarie of tastes, some citrus, dates and raisins and a bit of molasses. Faint trace of alcohol - but it is not distracting. Thick, creamy mouthfeel. Another excellent entry from Bells - which is usually the case .

12 oz. Bottle. Pours a orange red color with thin head and little lacing. Big malt, plum, raisin, and brown sugar in the nose. Big in body with a hot alcohol flavor and some malt in the background. Good with chocolate. This needs a lot more age to be enjoyed properly.
Opague dark orange brown.  Film of tan head.  Sour cherry and sweet malt aroma.  Maple, caramel, and currants in the flavor.  Alcoholic finish.  Mouthfeel this thick and hot.

UPDATED: APR 22, 2006 Pours to a thin beige head atop a brown body with tons of big chunks.  Not very appealing.  The aroma is strong and excellent smelling.  Caramel, raisins or maraschino cherries, light aromatic herbs, clover.  Very complex.  Hint of chocolate.  The flavor is very strongly doused in alcohol.  Chocolate, maple syrup, molasses, nuts, overall pretty good.  This warming isnt too appaling. 8, 2, 8, 4, 17 = 3.9

Re-rate: I had a bottle of this sitting in my fridge for awhile.  The beer pours to a nice clean body.  I must have gotten a "bad" bottle before.

Translucent caramel brown in color with one small isolated bubble for its head.  Nevermind, it just popped  now theres no head.  Aroma is heavy honey, lavender, maraschino cherries, whole wheat bread, and a small waft carrying hints of the high ABV and wet towels.  Flavor is sweet maple sugar, caramel sundae shavings, butterscotch, sherry, pine sap, rose petals and saffron.  Full-bodied and perhaps the best palate Ive had with a barleywine.  Love the malt sweetness and hop bitterness.  Finish is maple fudge and cedar sauna panels.  Well done.  Bravo.

UPDATED: MAY 31, 2005 Couleur cuivrée parsemée dune faible mousse brune pale et diminuante.  Arômes huileux, terreux, florale et levuré.  Une touche dherbe, de miel et de malt grillé vient agrémenter les intenses flaveurs de malt carameleux et biscuité.  Texture très résineuse en bouche, corps de densité moyenne.  Finale, douce tout en étant pleinement amérisante, rappelant ainsi lhuile de pin.  Jai limpression que cette brasserie soit incapable de me décevoir.

Creamy auburn, like the caramel spread my grandma used to make, complete with floaty chunks.  A milky way swirl of lace.

Smell:  Earthy, and had a clover or blueberry honey aroma.

Taste:  Rich and round maltyness at first, the alcohol takes a quick step up, only to get pushed back where it belongs by bitter hop finish.
Bottle.  Not a big fan of barley wines, but this was a treat.  Lots of barley malt  and full bodied but not overly sweet or sugary, a hint of ale twang, and easy on the hops.

12 oz bottle pured in a Duvel glass.
Toast, honey, nuts, toffee, and some light vanilla come through in the BIG malt nose.  Alcohol come through pretty good too.  The malt way overpowers any hops that would be present.  Copper orange, and opaque.  No real haed formed to speak of when poured.  If I give it swirl if froths up real good, and fades to a dusting.  Toffee, light chocolate, caramel, and alcohol dominate.  Plenty of bitterness. SWEET.
Very mouth filling and chewy.  Alcohol evident all  the way through.  Personally, I could drink this every night.  Outstanding beer.  Will re-review after it gets some more conditioning time.  I may need to go buy another sixer for that though.

UPDATED: MAR 27, 2007 12oz bottle from the cellar at 66.7° (cellar is getting a bit toasty!). Served in my NB worthy glass. Pours dark orange/red with a small off white head. The aroma is honey with a pretty floral aroma. The mouthfeel is pretty big, in fact that is noticed immeadiately. The taste is malty and sweet with some bitterness (and nice, subtle hops flavor) that comes at the end, making this non-cloying.

***** This beer is tons better aged, I am drinking a two year old version right now, but I am far too lazy to do a proper review (I already wrote a lengthy review of the 99 FS Old Backus) so I will just say I was not impressed by this beer when new, but put a little age on it and it is a sexy lady ready to party.
pours a dark red with a thin off white head leaves some nice lacing in the glass. aroma is hops and malt and barley. taste is the same. very good although i think anchor old foghorn is better.

Thanks to Sprinkle for sending this one!
This poured a ruddy orange/brown color with a typically reserved Barleywine/Old Ale head. 
This is well done and would rate well on its own, but it was sampled along with several others and just couldnt hold its own in strong company. Just lacked the intensity and deep lingering aromas and flavors of the others at the sampling.

UPDATED: FEB 4, 2006 Poured muddy orange with a tan head that faded fast. Tons of yeast sediment. This rating is based on a March 05 bottle.
